verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:3
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:4

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:5
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:6
verses.text: Written about the year 400.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:7
verses.text: [Faustus was undoubtedly the acutest, most determined and most unscrupulous opponent of orthodox Christianity in the age of Augustin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:8
verses.text: The occasion of Augustin's great writing against him was the publication of Faustus' attack on the Old Testament Scriptures, and on the New Testament so far as it was at variance with Manich aean error.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:9
verses.text: Faustus seems to have followed in the footsteps of Adimantus, against whom Augustin had written some years before, but to have gone considerably beyond Adimantus in the recklessness of his statements.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:10
verses.text: The incarnation of Christ, involving his birth from a woman, is one of the main points of attack.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:11
verses.text: He makes the variations in the genealogical records of the Gospels a ground for rejecting the whole as spurious.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:12
verses.text: He supposed the Gospels, in their present form, to be not the works of the Apostles, but rather of later Judaizing falsifiers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:13
verses.text: The entire Old Testament system he treats with the utmost contempt, blaspheming the Patriarchs, Moses, the Prophets, etc.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:14
verses.text: , on the ground of their private lives and their teachings.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:15
verses.text: Most of the objections to the morality of the Old Testament that are now current were already familiarly used in the time of Augustin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:16
verses.text: Augustin's answers are only partially satisfactory, owing to his imperfect view of the relation of the old dispensation to the new; but in the age in which they were written they were doubtless very effective.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:17
verses.text: The writing is interesting from the point of view of Biblical criticism, as well as from that of polemics against Manich aeism.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:18
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:19
verses.text: H.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:20
verses.text: N.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:21
verses.text: ]      Book I.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:22
verses.text: Who Faustus was.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:23
verses.text: Faustus's object in writing the polemical treatise that forms the basis of Augustin's reply.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:24
verses.text: Augustin's remarks thereon.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:25
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:26
verses.text: Faustus was an African by race, a citizen of Mileum; he was eloquent and clever, but had adopted the shocking tenets of the Manich aean heresy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:27
verses.text: He is mentioned in my Confessions,  where there is an account of my acquaintance with him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:28
verses.text: This man published a certain volume against the true Christian faith and the Catholic truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:29
verses.text: A copy reached us, and was read by the brethren, who called for an answer from me, as part of the service of love which I owe to them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:30
verses.text: Now, therefore, in the name and with the help of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, I undertake the task, that all my readers may know that acuteness of mind and elegance of style are of no use to a man unless the Lord directs his steps.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:31
verses.text: In the mysterious equity of divine mercy, God often bestows His help on the slow and the feeble; while from the want of this help, the most acute and eloquent run into error only with greater rapidity and willfulness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:32
verses.text: I will give the opinions of Faustus as if stated by himself, and mine as if in reply to him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:33
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:34
verses.text: Faustus said: As the learned Adimantus, the only teacher since the sainted Manich aeus deserving of our attention, has plentifully exposed and thoroughly refuted the errors of Judaism and of semi-Christianity, I think it not amiss that you should be supplied in writing with brief and pointed replies to the captious objections of our adversaries, that when, like children of the wily serpent, they try to bewilder you with their quibbles, you may be prepared to give intelligent answers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:35
verses.text: In this way they will be kept to the subject, instead of wandering from one thing to another.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:36
verses.text: And I have placed our opinions and those of our opponent over against one another, as plainly and briefly as possible, so as not to perplex the reader with a long and intricate discourse.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:37
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:38
verses.text: Augustin replies: You warn against semi-Christians, which you say we are; but we warn against pseudo-Christians, which we have shown you to be.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:39
verses.text: Semi-Christianity may be imperfect without being false.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:40
verses.text: So, then, if the faith of those whom you try to mislead is imperfect, would it not be better to supply what is lacking than to rob them of what they have? It was to imperfect Christians that the apostle wrote, "joying and beholding your conversation," and "the deficiency in your faith in Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:41
verses.text: The apostle had in view a spiritual structure, as he says elsewhere, "Ye are God's building;"  and in this structure he found both a reason for joy and a reason for exertion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:42
verses.text: He rejoiced to see part already finished; and the necessity of bringing the edifice to perfection called for exertion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:43
verses.text: Imperfect Christians as we are, you pursue us with the desire to pervert what you call our semi-Christianity by false doctrine; while even those who are so deficient in faith as to be unable to reply to all your sophisms, are wise enough at least to know that they must not have anything at all to do with you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:44
verses.text: You look for semi-Christians to deceive: we wish to prove you pseudo-Christians, that Christians may learn something from your refutation, and that the less advanced may learn to avoid you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:45
verses.text: Do you call us children of the serpent? You have surely forgotten how often you have found fault with the prohibition in Paradise, and have praised the serpent for opening Adam's eyes.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:46
verses.text: You have the better claim to the title which you give us.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:47
verses.text: The serpent owns you as well when you blame him as when you praise him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:48
verses.text: Book II.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:49
verses.text: Faustus claims to believe the Gospel, yet refuses to accept the genealogical tables on various grounds which Augustin seeks to set aside.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:50
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:51
verses.text: Faustus said: Do I believe the gospel? Certainly.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:52
verses.text: Do I therefore believe that Christ was born? Certainly not.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:53
verses.text: It does not follow that because I believe the gospel, as I do, I must therefore believe that Christ was born.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:54
verses.text: This I do not believe; because Christ does not say that He was born of men, and the gospel, both in name and in fact, begins with Christ's preaching.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:55
verses.text: As for the genealogy, the author himself does not venture to call it the gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:56
verses.text: For what did he write? "The book of the generation of Jesus Christ the Son of David".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:57
verses.text: The book of the generation is not the book of the gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:58
verses.text: It is more like a birth-register, the star confirming the event.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:59
verses.text: Mark, on the other hand, who recorded the preaching of the Son of God, without any genealogy, begins most suitably with the words, "The gospel of Jesus Christ the Son of God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:60
verses.text: It is plain that the genealogy is not the gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:61
verses.text: Matthew himself says, that after John was put in prison, Jesus began to preach the gospel of the kingdom; so that what is mentioned before this is the genealogy, and not the gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:62
verses.text: Why did not Matthew begin with, "The gospel of Jesus Christ the Son of God," but because he thought it sinful to call the genealogy the gospel? Understand, then, what you have hitherto overlooked —the distinction between the genealogy and the gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:63
verses.text: Do I then admit the truth of the gospel? Yes; understanding by the gospel the preaching of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:64
verses.text: I have plenty to say about the generations too, if you wish.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:65
verses.text: But you seem to me now to wish to know not whether I accept the gospel, but whether I accept the generations.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:66
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:67
verses.text: Augustin replied: Well, in answer to your own questions, you tell us first that you believe the gospel, and next, that you do not believe in the birth of Christ; and your reason is, that the birth of Christ is not in the gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:68
verses.text: What, then, will you answer the apostle when he says, "Remember that Christ Jesus rose from the dead, of the seed of David, according to my gospel?"  You surely are ignorant, or pretend to be ignorant, what the gospel is.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:69
verses.text: You use the word, not as the apostle teaches, but as suits your own errors.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:70
verses.text: What the apostles call the gospel you depart from; for you do not believe that Christ was of the seed of David.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:71
verses.text: This was Paul's gospel; and it was also the gospel of the other apostles, and of all faithful stewards of so great a mystery.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:72
verses.text: For Paul says elsewhere, "Whether, therefore, I or they, so we preach, and so ye believed".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:73
verses.text: They did not all write the gospel, but they all preached it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:74
verses.text: The name evangelist is properly given to the narrators of the birth, the actions, the words, the sufferings of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:75
verses.text: The word gospel means good news, and might be used of any good news, but is properly applied to the narrative of the Saviour.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:76
verses.text: If, then, you teach something different, you must have departed from the gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:77
verses.text: Assuredly those babes whom you despise as semi-Christians will oppose you, when they hear their mother Charity declaring by the mouth of the apostle, "If any one preach another gospel than that which we have preached to you, let him be accursed".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:78
verses.text: Since, then, Paul, according to his gospel, preached that Christ was of the seed of David, and you deny this and preach something else, may you be accursed! And what can you mean by saying that Christ never declares Himself to have been born of men, when on every occasion He calls Himself the Son of man?  3.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:79
verses.text: You learned men, forsooth, dress up for our benefit some wonderful First Man, who came down from the race of light to war with the race of darkness, armed with his waters against the waters of the enemy, and with his fire against their fire, and with his winds against their winds.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:80
verses.text: And why not with his smoke against their smoke, and with his darkness against their darkness? According to you, he was armed against smoke with air, and against darkness with light.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:81
verses.text: So it appears that smoke and darkness are bad, since they could not belong to his goodness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:82
verses.text: The other three, again—water, wind, and fire—are good.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:83
verses.text: How, then, could these belong to the evil of the enemy? You reply that the water of the race of darkness was evil, while that which the First Man brought was good; and so, too, his good wind and fire fought against the evil wind and fire of the adversary.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:84
verses.text: But why could he not bring good smoke against evil smoke? Your falsehoods seem to vanish in smoke.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:85
verses.text: Well, your First Man warred against an opposite nature.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:86
verses.text: And yet only one of the five things he brought was the opposite of what the hostile race had.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:87
verses.text: The light was opposed to the darkness, but the four others are not opposed to one another.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:88
verses.text: Air is not the opposite of smoke, and still less is water the opposite of water, or wind of wind, or fire of fire.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:89
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:90
verses.text: One is shocked at your wild fancies about this First Man changing the elements which he brought, that he might conquer his enemies by pleasing them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:91
verses.text: So you make what you call the kingdom of falsehood keep honestly to its own nature, while truth is changeable in order to deceive.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:92
verses.text: Jesus Christ, according to you, is the son of this First Man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:93
verses.text: Truth springs, forsooth, from your fiction.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:94
verses.text: You praise this First Man for using changeable and delusive forms in the contest.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:95
verses.text: If you, then, speak the truth, you do not imitate him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:96
verses.text: If you imitate him, you deceive as he did.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:97
verses.text: But our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, the true and truthful Son of God, the true and truthful Son of man, both of which He testifies of Himself, derived the eternity of His godhead from true God, and His incarnation from true man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:98
verses.text: Your First Man is not the first man of the apostle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:99
verses.text: "The first man," he says, "was of the earth, earthy; the second man is from heaven, heavenly.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:100
verses.text: As is the earthy, such are they also that are earthy; as is the heavenly, such are they also that are heavenly.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:101
verses.text: As we have borne the image of the earthy, let us also bear the image of the heavenly".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:102
verses.text: The first man of the earth, earthy, is Adam, who was made of dust.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:103
verses.text: The second man from heaven, heavenly, is the Lord Jesus Christ; for, being the Son of God, He became flesh that He might be a man outwardly, while He remained God within; that He might be both the true Son of God, by whom we were made, and the true Son of man, by whom we are made anew.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:104
verses.text: Why do you conjure up this fabulous First Man of yours, and refuse to acknowledge the first man of the apostle? Is this not a fulfillment of what the apostle says: "Turning away their ears from the truth, they will give heed to fables?"  According to Paul, the first man is of the earth, earthy; according to Manich aeus, he is not earthy, and is equipped with five elements of some unreal, unintelligible kind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:105
verses.text: Paul says: "If any one should have announced to you differently from what we have announced let him be accursed".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:106
verses.text: Therefore lest Paul be a liar, let Manich aeus be accursed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:107
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:108
verses.text: Again, you find fault with the star by which the Magi were led to worship the infant Christ, which you should be ashamed of doing, when you represent your fabulous Christ, the son of your fabulous First Man not as announced by a star, but as bound up in all the stars.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:109
verses.text: For you say that he mingled with the principles of darkness in his conflict with the race of darkness, that by capturing these principles the world might be made out of the mixture.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:110
verses.text: So that, by your profane fancies, Christ is not only mingled with heaven and all the stars, but conjoined and compounded with the earth and all its productions, —a Saviour no more, but needing to be saved by you, by your eating and disgorging Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:111
verses.text: This foolish custom of making your disciples bring you food, that your teeth and stomach may be the means of relieving Christ, who is bound up in it, is a consequence of your profane fancies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:112
verses.text: You declare that Christ is liberated in this way—not, however, entirely; for you hold that some tiny particles of no value still remain in the excrement, to be mixed up and compounded again and again in various material forms, and to be released and purified at any rate by the fire in which the world will be burned up, if not before.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:113
verses.text: Nay, even then, you say, Christ is not entirely liberated; but some extreme particles of His good and divine nature, which have been so defiled that they cannot be cleansed, are condemned to stay for ever in the horrid mass of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:114
verses.text: And these people pretend to be offended with our saying that a star announced the birth of the Son of God, as if this were placing His birth under the influence of a constellation; while they subject Him not to stars only, but to such polluting contact with all material things, with the juices of all vegetables, and with the decay of all flesh, and with the decomposition of all food, in which He is bound up, that the only way of releasing Him, at least one great means, is that men, that is the Elect of the Manich aeans, should succeed in digesting their dinner.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:115
verses.text: We, too, deny the influence of the stars upon the birth of any man; for we maintain that, by the just law of God, the free-will of man, which chooses good or evil, is under no constraint of necessity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:116
verses.text: How much less do we subject to any constellation the incarnation of the eternal Creator and Lord of all! When Christ was born after the flesh, the star which the Magi saw had no power as governing, but attended as a witness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:117
verses.text: Instead of assuming control over Him, it acknowledged Him by the homage it did.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:118
verses.text: Besides, this star was not one of those which from the beginning of the world continue in the course ordained by the Creator.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:119
verses.text: Along with the new birth from the Virgin appeared a new star, which served as a guide to the Magi who were themselves seeking for Christ; for it went before them till they reached the place where they found the Word of God in the form of a child.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:120
verses.text: But what astrologer ever thought of making a star leave its course, and come down to the child that is born, as they imagine, under it? They think that the stars affect the birth, not that the birth changes the course of the stars; so, if the star in the Gospel was one of those heavenly bodies, how could it determine Christ's action, when it was compelled to change its own action at Christ's birth? But if, as is more likely, a star which did not exist before appeared to point out Christ, it was the effect of Christ's birth, and not the cause of it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:121
verses.text: Christ was not born because the star was there; but the star was there because Christ was born.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:122
verses.text: If there was any fate, it was in the birth, and not in the star.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:123
verses.text: The word fate is derived from a word which means to speak; and since Christ is the Word of God by which all things were spoken before they were, the conjunction of stars is not the fate of Christ, but Christ is the fate of the stars.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:124
verses.text: The same will that made the heavens took our earthly nature.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:125
verses.text: The same power that ruled the stars laid down His life and took it again.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:126
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:127
verses.text: Why, then, should the narrative of the birth not be the gospel, since it conveys such good news as heals our malady? Is it because Matthew begins, not like Mark, with the words, "The beginning of the gospel of Jesus Christ," but, "The book of the generation of Jesus Christ?" In this way, John, too, might be said not to have written the gospel, for he has not the words, Beginning of the gospel, or Book of the gospel, but, "In the beginning was the Word".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:128
verses.text: Perhaps the clever word-maker Faustus will call the introduction in John a Verbidium, as he called that in Matthew a Genesidium.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:129
verses.text: The wonder is, that you are so impudent as to give the name of gospel to your silly stories.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:130
verses.text: What good news is there in telling us that, in the conflict against some strange hostile nation, God could protect His own kingdom only by sending part of His own nature into the greedy jaws of the former, and to be so defiled, that after all those toils and tortures it cannot all be purged? Is this bad news the gospel? Every one who has even a slender knowledge of Greek knows that gospel means good news.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:131
verses.text: But where is your good news, when your God himself is said to weep as under eclipse till the darkness and defilement are removed from his members? And when he ceases to weep, it seems he becomes cruel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:132
verses.text: For what has that part of him which is to be involved in the mass done to deserve this condemnation? This part must go on weeping for ever.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:133
verses.text: But no; whoever examines this news will not weep because it is bad, but will laugh because it is not true.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:134
verses.text: Book III.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:135
verses.text: Faustus objects to the incarnation of God on the ground that the evangelists are at variance with each other, and that incarnation is unsuitable to deity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:136
verses.text: Augustin attempts to remove the critical and theological difficulties.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:137
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:138
verses.text: Faustus said: Do I believe in the incarnation? For my part, this is the very thing I long tried to persuade myself of, that God was born; but the discrepancy in the genealogies of Luke and Matthew stumbled me, as I knew not which to follow.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:139
verses.text: For I thought it might happen that, from not being omniscient, I might take the true for false, and the false for true.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:140
verses.text: So, in despair of settling this dispute, I betook myself to Mark and John, two authorities still, and evangelists as much as the others.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:141
verses.text: I approved with good reason of the beginning of Mark and John, for they have nothing of David, or Mary, or Joseph.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:142
verses.text: John says, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God," meaning Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:143
verses.text: Mark says, "The gospel of Jesus Christ, the Son of God," as if correcting Matthew, who calls him the Son of David.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:144
verses.text: Perhaps, however, the Jesus of Matthew is a different person from the Jesus of Mark.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:145
verses.text: This is my reason for not believing in the birth of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:146
verses.text: Remove this difficulty, if you can, by harmonizing the accounts, and I am ready to yield.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:147
verses.text: In any case, however, it is hardly consistent to believe that God, the God of Christians, was born from the womb.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:148
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:149
verses.text: Augustin replied: Had you read the Gospel with care, and inquired into those places where you found opposition, instead of rashly condemning them, you would have seen that the recognition of the authority of the evangelists by so many learned men all over the world, in spite of this most obvious discrepancy, proves that there is more in it than appears at first sight.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:150
verses.text: Any one can see, as well as you, that the ancestors of Christ in Matthew and Luke are different; while Joseph appears in both, at the end in Matthew and at the beginning in Luke.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:151
verses.text: Joseph, it is plain, might be called the father of Christ, on account of his being in a certain sense the husband of the mother of Christ; and so his name, as the male representative, appears at the beginning or end of the genealogies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:152
verses.text: Any one can see as well as you that Joseph has one father in Matthew and another in Luke, and so with the grandfather and with all the rest up to David.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:153
verses.text: Did all the able and learned men, not many Latin writers certainly, but innumerable Greek, who have examined most attentively the sacred Scriptures, overlook this manifest difference? Of course they saw it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:154
verses.text: No one can help seeing it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:155
verses.text: But with a due regard to the high authority of Scripture, they believed that there was something here which would be given to those that ask, and denied to those that snarl; would be found by those that seek, and taken away from those that criticise; would be open to those that knock, and shut against those that contradict.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:156
verses.text: They asked, sought, and knocked; they received, found, and entered in.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:157
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:158
verses.text: The whole question is how Joseph had two fathers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:159
verses.text: Supposing this possible, both genealogies may be correct.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:160
verses.text: With two fathers, why not two grandfathers, and two great-grandfathers, and so on, up to David, who was the father both of Solomon, who is mentioned in Matthew's list, and of Nathan, who occurs in Luke? This is the difficulty with many people who think it impossible that two men should have one and the same son, forgetting the very obvious fact that a man may be called the son of the person who adopted him as well as of the person who begot him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:161
verses.text: Adoption, we know, was familiar to the ancients; for even women adopted the children of other women, as Sarah adopted Ishmael, and Leah her handmaid's son, and Pharaoh's daughter Moses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:162
verses.text: Jacob, too, adopted his grandsons, the children of Joseph.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:163
verses.text: Moreover, the word adoption is of great importance in the system of our faith, as is seen from the apostolic writings.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:164
verses.text: For the Apostle Paul, speaking of the advantages of the Jews, says: "Whose are the adoption, and the glory, and the covenants, and the giving of the law; whose are the fathers, and of whom, according to the flesh, Christ came, who is over all, God blessed for ever".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:165
verses.text: And again: "We ourselves also groan within ourselves, waiting for the adoption of the sons of God, even the redemption of the body".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:166
verses.text: Again, elsewhere: "But in the fullness of time, God sent His Son, made of a woman, made under the law, that we might receive the adoption of sons".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:167
verses.text: These passages show clearly that adoption is a significant symbol.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:168
verses.text: God has an only Son, whom He begot from His own substance, of whom it is said, "Being in the form of God, He thought it not robbery to be equal to God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:169
verses.text: Us He begot not of His own substance, for we belong to the creation which is not begotten, but made; but that He might make us the brothers of Christ, He adopted us.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:170
verses.text: That act, then, by which God, when we were not born of Him, but created and formed, begot us by His word and grace, is called adoption.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:171
verses.text: So John says, "He gave them power to become the sons of God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:172
verses.text: Since, therefore; the practice of adoption is common among our fathers, and in Scripture, is there not irrational profanity in the hasty condemnation of the evangelists as false because the genealogies are different, as if both could not be true, instead of considering calmly the simple fact that frequently in human life one man may have two fathers, one of whose flesh he is born, and another of whose will he is afterwards made a son by adoption? If the second is not rightly called father, neither are we right in saying, "Our Father which art in heaven," to Him of whose substance we were not born, but of whose grace and most merciful will we were adopted, according to apostolic doctrine, and truth most sure.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:173
verses.text: For one is to us God, and Lord, and Father: God, for by Him we are created, though of human parents; Lord, for we are His subjects; Father, for by His adoption we are born again.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:174
verses.text: Careful students of sacred Scripture easily saw, from a little consideration, how, in the different genealogies of the two evangelists, Joseph had two fathers, and consequently two lists of ancestors.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:175
verses.text: You might have seen this too, if you had not been blinded by the love of contradiction.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:176
verses.text: Other things far beyond your understanding have been discovered in the careful investigation of all parts of these narratives.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:177
verses.text: The familiar occurrence of one man begetting a son and another adopting him, so that one man has two fathers, you might, in spite of Manich aean error, have thought of as an explanation, if you had not been reading in a hostile spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:178
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:179
verses.text: But why Matthew begins with Abraham and descends to Joseph, while Luke begins with Joseph and ascends, not to Abraham, but to God, who made man, and, by giving a commandment, gave him power to become, by believing, a son of God; and why Matthew records the generations at the commencement of his book, Luke after the baptism of the Saviour by John; and what is the meaning of the number of the generations in Matthew, who divides them into three sections of fourteen each, though in the whole sum there appears to be one wanting; while in Luke the number of generations recorded after the baptism amount to seventy-seven, which number the Lord Himself enjoins in connection with the forgiveness of sins, saying, "Not only seven times, but seventy-seven times;"—these things you will never understand, unless either you are taught by some Catholic of superior stamp, who has studied the sacred Scriptures, and has made all the progress possible, or you yourselves turn from your error, and in a Christian spirit ask that you may receive, seek that you may find, and knock that it may be opened to you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:180
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:181
verses.text: Since, then, this double fatherhood of nature and adoption removes the difficulty arising from the discrepancy of the genealogies, there is no occasion for Faustus to leave the two evangelists and betake himself to the other two, which would be a greater affront to those he betook himself to than to those he left.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:182
verses.text: For the sacred writers do not desire to be favored at the expense of their brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:183
verses.text: For their joy is in union, and they are one in Christ; and if one says one thing, and another another, or one in one way and another in another, still they all speak truth, and in no way contradict one another; only let the reader be reverent and humble, not in an heretical spirit seeking occasion for strife, but with a believing heart desiring edification.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:184
verses.text: Now, in this opinion that the evangelists give the ancestors of different fathers, as it is quite possible for a man to have two fathers, there is nothing inconsistent with truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:185
verses.text: So the evangelists are harmonized, and you, by Faustus's promise are bound to yield at once.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:186
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:187
verses.text: You may perhaps be troubled by that additional remark which he makes: "In any case, however, it is hardly consistent to believe that God, the God of Christians, was born from the womb".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:188
verses.text: As if we believed that the divine nature came from the womb of a woman.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:189
verses.text: Have I not just quoted the testimony of the apostle, speaking of the Jews: "Whose are the fathers, and of whom, according to the flesh, Christ came, who is God over all, blessed for ever?" Christ, therefore, our Lord and Saviour, true Son of God in His divinity, and true son of man according to the flesh, not as He is God over all was born of a woman, but in that feeble nature which He took of us, that in it He might die for us, and heal it in us: not as in the form of God, in which He thought it not robbery to be equal to God, was He born of a woman, but in the form of a servant, in taking which He emptied Himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:190
verses.text: He is therefore said to have emptied Himself because He took the form of a servant, not because He lost the form of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:191
verses.text: For in the unchangeable possession of that nature by which in the form of God He is equal to the Father, He took our changeable nature, by which He might be born of a virgin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:192
verses.text: You, while you protest against putting the flesh of Christ in a virgin's womb, place the very divinity of God in the womb not only of human beings, but of dogs and swine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:193
verses.text: You refuse to believe that the flesh of Christ was conceived in the Virgin's womb, in which God was not found nor even changed; while you assert that in all men and beasts, in the seed of male and in the womb of female, in all conceptions on land or in water, an actual part of God and the divine nature is continually bound, and shut up, and contaminated, never to be wholly set free.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:194
verses.text: Book IV.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:195
verses.text: Faustus's reasons for rejecting the Old Testament, and Augustin's animadversions thereon.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:196
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:197
verses.text: Faustus said: Do I believe the Old Testament? If it bequeaths anything to me, I believe it; if not, I reject it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:198
verses.text: It would be an excess of forwardness to take the documents of others which pronounce me disinherited.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:199
verses.text: Remember that the promise of Canaan in the Old Testament is made to Jews, that is, to the circumcised, who offer sacrifice, and abstain from swine's flesh, and from the other animals which Moses pronounces unclean, and observe Sabbaths, and the feast of unleavened bread, and other things of the same kind which the author of the Testament enjoined.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:200
verses.text: Christians have not adopted these observances, and no one keeps them; so that if we will not take the inheritance, we should surrender the documents.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:201
verses.text: This is my first reason for rejecting the Old Testament, unless you teach me better.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:202
verses.text: My second reason is, that this inheritance is such a poor fleshly thing, without any spiritual blessings, that after the New Testament, and its glorious promise of the kingdom of heaven and eternal life, I think it not worth the taking.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:203
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:204
verses.text: Augustin replied: No one doubts that promises of temporal things are contained in the Old Testament, for which reason it is called the Old Testament; or that the kingdom of heaven and the promise of eternal life belong to the New Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:205
verses.text: But that in these temporal things were figures of future things which should be fulfilled in us upon whom the ends of the ages are come, is not my fancy, but the judgment of the apostle, when he says of such things, "These things were our examples;" and again, "These things happened to them for an example, and they are written for us on whom the ends of the ages are come".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:206
verses.text: We receive the Old Testament, therefore, not in order to obtain the fulfillment of these promises, but to see in them predictions of the New Testament; for the Old bears witness to the New.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:207
verses.text: Whence the Lord, after He rose from the dead, and allowed His disciples not only to see but to handle Him, still, lest they should doubt their mortal and fleshly senses, gave them further confirmation from the testimony of the ancient books, saying, "It was necessary that all things should be fulfilled which were written in the law of Moses, and in the Prophets and Psalms, concerning me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:208
verses.text: Our hope, therefore, rests not on the promise of temporal things.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:209
verses.text: Nor do we believe that the holy and spiritual men of these times—the patriarchs and prophets—were taken up with earthly things.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:210
verses.text: For they understood, by the revelation of the Spirit of God, what was suitable for that time, and how God appointed all these sayings and actions as types and predictions of the future.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:211
verses.text: Their great desire was for the New Testament; but they had a personal duty to perform in those predictions, by which the new things of the future were foretold.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:212
verses.text: So the life as well as the tongue of these men was prophetic.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:213
verses.text: The carnal people, indeed, thought only of present blessings, though even in connection with the people there were prophecies of the future.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:214
verses.text: These things you do not understand, because, as the prophet said, "Unless you believe, you shall not understand".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:215
verses.text: For you are not instructed in the kingdom of heaven,—that is, in the true Catholic Church of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:216
verses.text: If you were, you would bring forth from the treasure of the sacred Scriptures things old as well as new.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:217
verses.text: For the Lord Himself says, "Therefore every scribe instructed in the kingdom of heaven is like an householder who brings forth from his treasure things new and old".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:218
verses.text: And so, while you profess to receive only the new promises of God, you have retained the oldness of the flesh, adding only the novelty of error; of which novelty the apostle says, "Shun profane novelties of words, for they increase unto more ungodliness, and their speech eats like a cancer.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:219
verses.text: Of whom is Hymen aeus and Philetus, who concerning the faith have erred, saying that the resurrection is past already, and have overthrown the faith of some".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:220
verses.text: Here you see the source of your false doctrine, in teaching that the resurrection is only of souls by the preaching of the truth, and that there will be no resurrection of the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:221
verses.text: But how can you understand spiritual things of the inner man, who is renewed in the knowledge of God, when in the oldness of the flesh, if you do not possess temporal things, you concoct fanciful notions about them in those images of carnal things of which the whole of your false doctrine consists? You boast of despising as worthless the land of Canaan, which was an actual thing, and actually given to the Jews; and yet you tell of a land of light cut asunder on one side, as by a narrow wedge, by the land of the race of darkness,—a thing which does not exist, and which you believe from the delusion of your minds; so that your life is not supported by having it, and your mind is wasted in desiring it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:222
verses.text: Book V.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:223
verses.text: Faustus claims that the Manich aeans and not the Catholics are consistent believers in the Gospel, and seeks to establish this claim by comparing Manich aean and Catholic obedience to the precepts of the Gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:224
verses.text: Augustin exposes the hypocrisy of the Manich aeans and praises the asceticism of Catholics.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:225
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:226
verses.text: Faustus said: Do I believe the gospel? You ask me if I believe it, though my obedience to its commands shows that I do.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:227
verses.text: I should rather ask you if you believe it, since you give no proof of your belief.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:228
verses.text: I have left my father, mother, wife, and children, and all else that the gospel requires;  and do you ask if I believe the gospel? Perhaps you do not know what is called the gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:229
verses.text: The gospel is nothing else than the preaching and the precept of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:230
verses.text: I have parted with all gold and silver, and have left off carrying money in my purse; content with daily food; without anxiety for tomorrow; and without solicitude about how I shall be fed, or where-withal I shall be clothed: and do you ask if I believe the gospel? You see in me the blessings of the gospel;   and do you ask if I believe the gospel? You see me poor, meek, a peacemaker, pure in heart, mourning, hungering, thirsting, bearing persecutions and enmity for righteousness' sake; and do you doubt my belief in the gospel? One can understand now how John the Baptist, after seeing Jesus, and also hearing of His works, yet asked whether He was Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:231
verses.text: Jesus properly and justly did not deign to reply that He was; but reminded him of the works of which he had already heard: "The blind see, the deaf hear, the dead are raised".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:232
verses.text: In the same way, I might very well reply to your question whether I believe the gospel, by saying, I have left all, father, mother, wife, children, gold, silver, eating, drinking, luxuries, pleasures; take this as a sufficient answer to your questions, and believe that you will be blessed if you are not offended in me.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:233
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:234
verses.text: But, according to you, to believe the gospel is not only to obey its commands, but also to believe in all that is written in it; and, first of all, that God was born.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:235
verses.text: But neither is believing the gospel only to believe that Jesus was born, but also to do what He commands.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:236
verses.text: So, if you say that I do not believe the gospel because I disbelieve the incarnation, much more do you not believe because you disregard the commandments.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:237
verses.text: At any rate, we are on a par till these questions are settled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:238
verses.text: If your disregard of the precepts does not prevent you from professing faith in the gospel, why should my rejection of the genealogy prevent me? And if, as you say, to believe the gospel includes both faith in the genealogies and obedience to the precepts, why do you condemn me, since we both are imperfect? What one wants the other has.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:239
verses.text: But if, as there can be no doubt, belief in the gospel consists solely in obedience to the commands of God, your sin is twofold.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:240
verses.text: As the proverb says, the deserter accuses the soldier.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:241
verses.text: But suppose, since you will have it so, that there are these two parts of perfect faith, one consisting in word, or the confession that Christ was born, the other in deed or the observance of the precepts; it is plain that my part is hard and painful, yours light and easy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:242
verses.text: It is natural that the multitude should flock to you and away from me, for they know not that the kingdom of God is not in word, but in power.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:243
verses.text: Why, then, do you blame me for taking the harder part, and leaving to you, as to a weak brother, the easy part? You have the idea that your part of faith, or confessing that Christ was born, has more power to save the soul than the other parts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:244
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:245
verses.text: Let us then ask Christ Himself, and learn from His own mouth, what is the chief means of our salvation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:246
verses.text: Who shall enter, O Christ, into Thy kingdom? He that doeth the will of my Father in heaven,  is His reply; not, "He that confesses that I was born".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:247
verses.text: And again, He says to His disciples, "Go, teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost, teaching them to observe all things which I have commanded you".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:248
verses.text: It is not, "teaching them that I was born," but, "to observe my commandments".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:249
verses.text: Again, "Ye are my friends if ye do what I command you;"  not, "if you believe that I was born".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:250
verses.text: Again, "If ye keep my commandments, ye shall abide in my love,"  and in many other places.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:251
verses.text: Also in the sermon on the mount, when He taught, "Blessed are the poor, blessed are the meek, blessed are the peacemakers, blessed are the pure in heart, blessed are they that mourn, blessed are they that hunger, blessed are they that are persecuted for righteousness' sake,"  He nowhere says, "Blessed are they that confess that I was born".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:252
verses.text: And in the separation of the sheep from the goats in the judgment, He says that He will say to them on the right hand, "I was hungry, and ye gave me meat; I was thirsty, and ye gave me drink,"  and so on; therefore "inherit the kingdom".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:253
verses.text: Not, "Because ye believe that I was born, inherit the kingdom".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:254
verses.text: Again, to the rich man seeking for eternal life, He says, "Go, sell all that thou hast, and follow me;"  not, "Believe that I was born, that you may have eternal life".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:255
verses.text: You see, the kingdom, life, happiness, are everywhere promised to the part I have chosen of what you call the two parts of faith, and nowhere to your part.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:256
verses.text: Show, if you can, a place where it is written that whoso confesses that Christ was born of a woman is blessed, or shall inherit the kingdom, or have eternal life.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:257
verses.text: Even supposing, then, that there are two parts of faith, your part has no blessing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:258
verses.text: But what if we prove that your part is not a part of faith at all? It will follow that you are foolish, which indeed will be proved beyond a doubt.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:259
verses.text: At present, it is enough to have shown that our part is crowned with the beatitudes.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:260
verses.text: Besides, we have also a beatitude for a confession in words: for we confess that Jesus Christ is the Son of the living God; and Jesus declares with His own lips that this confession has a benediction, when He says to Peter, "Blessed art thou, Simon Barjona; for flesh and blood hath not revealed this unto thee, but my Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:261
verses.text: So that we have not one, but both these parts of faith, and in both alike are we pronounced blessed by Christ; for in one we reduce faith to practice, while in the other our confession is unmixed with blasphemy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:262
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:263
verses.text: Augustin replied: I have already said that the Lord Jesus Christ repeatedly calls Himself the Son of man, and that the Manich aeans have contrived a silly story about some fabulous First Man, who figures in their impious heresy, not earthly, but combined with spurious elements, in opposition to the apostle, who says, "The first man is of the earth, earthy;"  and that the apostle carefully warns us, "If any one preaches to you differently from what we have preached, let him be accursed".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:264
verses.text: So that we must believe Christ to be the Son of man according to apostolic truth, not according to Manich aean error.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:265
verses.text: And since the evangelists assert that Christ was born of a woman, of the seed of David, and Paul writing to Timothy says, "Remember that Jesus Christ, of the seed of David, was raised from the dead, according to my gospel,"  it is clear what sense we must believe Christ to be the Son of man; for being the Son of God by whom we were made, He also by His incarnation became the Son of man, that He might die for our sins, and rise again for our justification.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:266
verses.text: Accordingly He calls Himself both Son of God and Son of man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:267
verses.text: To take only one instance out of many, in the Gospel of John it is written, "Verily, verily, I say unto you, The hour cometh, and now is, when the dead shall hear the voice of the Son of God; and they that hear shall live.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:268
verses.text: For as the Father hath life in Himself, so He hath given to the Son to have life in Himself; and hath given Him power to execute judgment also, because He is the Son of man".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:269
verses.text: He says, "They shall hear the voice of the Son of God;" and He says, "because He is the Son of man".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:270
verses.text: As the Son of man, He has received power to execute judgment, because He will come to judgment in human form, that He may be seen by the good and the wicked.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:271
verses.text: In this form He ascended into heaven, and that voice was heard by His disciples, "He shall so come as ye have seen Him go into heaven".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:272
verses.text: As the Son of God, as God equal to and one with the Father, He will not be seen by the wicked; for "blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:273
verses.text: Since, then, He promises eternal life to those that believe in Him, and since to believe in Him is to believe in the true Christ, such as He declares Himself and His apostles declare Him to be, true Son of God and true Son of man; you, Manich aeans, who believe on a false and spurious son of a false and spurious man, and teach that God Himself, from fear of the assault of the hostile race, gave up His own members to be tortured, and after all not to be wholly liberated, are plainly far from that eternal life which Christ promises to those who believe in Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:274
verses.text: It is true, He said to Peter when he confessed Him to be the Son of God, "Blessed art thou, Simon.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:275
verses.text: Barjona".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:276
verses.text: But does He promise nothing to those who believe Him to be the Son of man, when the Son of God and the Son of man are the same? Besides, eternal life is expressly promised to those who believe in the Son of man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:277
verses.text: "As Moses," He says, "lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, so must the Son of man be lifted up, that whosoever believeth in Him should not perish, but have eternal life".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:278
verses.text: [19] What more do you wish? Believe then in the Son of man, that you may have eternal life; for He is also the Son of God, who can give eternal life: for He is "the true God and eternal life," as the same John says in his epistle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:279
verses.text: John also adds, that he is antichrist who denies that Christ has come in the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:280
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:281
verses.text: There is no need, then that you should extol so much the perfection of Christ's commands, because you obey the precepts of the gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:282
verses.text: For the precepts, supposing you really to fulfill them, would not profit you without true faith.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:283
verses.text: Do you not know that the apostle says, "If I distribute all my goods to the poor, and give my body to be burned, and have not charity, it profiteth me nothing?"  Why do you boast of having Christian poverty, when you are destitute of Christian charity? Robbers have a kind of charity to one another, arising from a mutual consciousness of guilt and crime; but this is not the charity commended by the apostle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:284
verses.text: In another passage he distinguishes true charity from all base and vicious affections, by saying, "Now the end of the commandment is charity out of a pure heart, and a good conscience, and faith unfeigned".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:285
verses.text: How then can you have true charity from a fictitious faith?  You persist in a faith corrupted by falsehood: for your First Man, according to you, used deceit in the conflict by changing his form, while his enemies remained in their own nature; and, besides, you maintain that Christ, who says, "I am the truth," feigned His incarnation, His death on the cross, the wounds of His passion, the marks shown after His resurrection.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:286
verses.text: If you speak the truth, and your Christ speaks falsehood, you must be better than he.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:287
verses.text: But if you really follow your own Christ, your truthfulness may be doubted, and your obedience to the precepts you speak of may be only a pretence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:288
verses.text: Is it true, as Faustus says, that you have no money in your purses? He means, probably, that your money is in boxes and bags; nor would we blame you for this, if you did not profess one thing and practise another.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:289
verses.text: Constantius, who is still alive, and is now our brother in Catholic Christianity, once gathered many of your sect into his house at Rome, to keep these precepts of Manich aeus, which you think so much of, though they are very silly and childish.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:290
verses.text: The precepts proved too much for your weakness, and the gathering was entirely broken up.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:291
verses.text: Those who persevered separated from your communion, and are called Mattarians, because they sleep on mats,—a very different bed from the feathers of Faustus and his goatskin coverlets, and all the grandeur that made him despise not only the Mattarians, but also the house of his poor father in Mileum.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:292
verses.text: Away, then, with this accursed hypocrisy from your writing, if not from your conduct; or else your language will conflict with your life by your deceitful words, as your First Man with the race of darkness by his deceitful elements.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:293
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:294
verses.text: I am, however, addressing not merely men who fail to do what they are commanded, but the members of a deluded sect.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:295
verses.text: For the precepts of Manich aeus are such that, if you do not keep them, you are deceivers; if you do keep them, you are deceived.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:296
verses.text: Christ never taught you that you should not pluck a vegetable for fear of committing homicide; for when His disciples were hungry when passing through a field of corn, He did not forbid them to pluck the ears on the Sabbath-day; which was a rebuke to the Jews of the time since the action was on Sabbath; and a rebuke in the action itself to the future Manich aeans.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:297
verses.text: The precept of Manich aeus, however, only requires you to do nothing while others commit homicide for you; though the real homicide is that of ruining miserable souls by such doctrines of devils.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:298
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:299
verses.text: The language of Faustus has the typhus of heresy in it, and is the language of overweening arrogance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:300
verses.text: "You see in me" he says, "the beatitudes of the gospel; and do you ask if I believe the gospel? You see me poor, meek, a peacemaker, pure in heart, mourning, hungering, thirsting, bearing persecution and enmity for righteousness' sake; and do you doubt my belief in the gospel?" If to justify oneself were to be just, Faustus would have flown to heaven while uttering these words.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:301
verses.text: I say nothing of the luxurious habits of Faustus, known to all the followers of the Manich aeans, and especially to those at Rome.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:302
verses.text: I shall suppose a Manich aean such as Constantius sought for, when he enforced the observance of these precepts with the sincere desire to see them observed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:303
verses.text: How can I see him to be poor in spirit, when he is so proud as to believe that his own soul is God, and is not ashamed to speak of God as in bondage? How can I see him meek, when he affronts all the authority of the evangelists rather than believe? How a peacemaker, when he holds that the divine nature itself by which God is whatever is, and is the only true existence, could not remain in lasting peace? How pure in heart, when his heart is filled with so many impious notions? How mourning, unless it is for his God captive and bound till he be freed and escape, with the loss, however, of a part which is to be united by the Father to the mass of darkness, and is not to be mourned for? How hungering and thirsting for righteousness, which Faustus omits in his writings lest, no doubt, he should be thought destitute of righteousness? But how can they hunger and thirst after righteousness, whose perfect righteousness will consist in exulting over their brethren condemned to darkness, not for any fault of their own, but for being irremediably contaminated by the pollution against which they were sent by the Father to contend?  8.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:304
verses.text: How do you suffer persecution and enmity for righteousness' sake, when, according to you, it is righteous to preach and teach these impieties? The wonder is, that the gentleness of Christian times allows such perverse iniquity to pass wholly or almost unpunished.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:305
verses.text: And yet, as if we were blind or silly, you tell us that your suffering reproach and persecution is a great proof of your righteousness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:306
verses.text: If people are just according to the amount of their suffering, atrocious criminals of all kinds suffer much more than you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:307
verses.text: But, at any rate, if we are to grant that suffering endured on account of any sort of profession of Christianity proves the sufferer to be in possession of true faith and righteousness, you must admit that any case of greater suffering that we can show proves the possession of truer faith and greater righteousness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:308
verses.text: Of such cases you know many among our martyrs, and chiefly Cyprian himself, whose writings also bear witness to his belief that Christ was born of the Virgin Mary.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:309
verses.text: For this faith, which you abhor, he suffered and died along with many Christian believers of that day, who suffered as much, or more.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:310
verses.text: Faustus, when shown to be a Manich aean by evidence, or by his own confession, on the intercession of the Christians themselves, who brought him before the proconsul, was, along with some others, only banished to an island, which can hardly be called a punishment at all, for it is what God's servants do of their own accord every day when they wish to retire from the tumult of the world.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:311
verses.text: Besides, earthly sovereigns often by a public decree give release from this banishment as an act of mercy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:312
verses.text: And in this way all were afterwards released at once.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:313
verses.text: Confess, then, that they were in possession of a truer faith and a more righteous life, who were accounted worthy to suffer for it much more than you ever suffered.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:314
verses.text: Or else, cease boasting of the abhorrence which many feel for you, and learn to distinguish between suffering for blasphemy and suffering for righteousness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:315
verses.text: What it is you suffer for, your own books will show in a way that deserves your most particular attention.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:316
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:317
verses.text: Those evangelical precepts of peculiar sublimity which you make people who know no better believe that you obey, are really obeyed by multitudes in our communion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:318
verses.text: Are there not among us many of both sexes who have entirely refrained from sexual intercourse, and many formerly married who practise continence? Are there not many others who give largely of their property, or give it up altogether, and many who keep the body in subjection by fasts, either frequent or daily, or protracted beyond belief? Then there are fraternities whose members have no property of their own, but all things common, including only things necessary for food and clothing, living with one soul and one heart towards God, inflamed with a common feeling of charity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:319
verses.text: In all such professions many turn out to be deceivers and reprobates, while many who are so are never discovered; many, too, who at first walk well, fall away rapidly from willfulness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:320
verses.text: Many are found in times of trial to have adopted this kind of life with another intention than they professed; and again, many in humility and steadfastness persevere in their course to the end, and are saved.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:321
verses.text: There are apparent diversities in these societies; but one charity unites all who, from some necessity, in obedience to the apostle's injunction, have their wives as if they had them not, and buy as if they bought not, and use this world as if they used it not.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:322
verses.text: With these are joined, in the abundant riches of God's mercy, the inferior class of those to whom it is said, "Defraud not one another, except it be with consent for a time, that ye may give yourselves to prayer; and come together again, that Satan tempt you not for your incontinency.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:323
verses.text: But I speak this by permission, and not of commandment".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:324
verses.text: To such the same apostle also says, "Now therefore there is utterly a fault among you, that ye go to law one with another;" while, in consideration of their infirmity, he adds, "If ye have judgments of things pertaining to this life, set them to judge who are least esteemed in the Church".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:325
verses.text: For in the kingdom of heaven there are not only those who, that they may be perfect, sell or leave all they have and follow the Lord; but others in the partnership of charity are joined like a mercenary force to the Christian army, to whom it will be said at last, "I was hungry, and ye gave me meat," and so on.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:326
verses.text: Otherwise, there would be no salvation for those to whom the apostle gives so many anxious and particular directions about their families, telling the wives to be obedient to their husbands, and husbands to love their wives; children to obey their parents, and parents to bring up their children in the instruction and admonition of the Lord; servants to obey with fear their masters according to the flesh, and masters to render to their servants what is just and equal.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:327
verses.text: The apostle is far from condemning such people as regardless of gospel precepts, or unworthy of eternal life.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:328
verses.text: For where the Lord exhorts the strong to attain perfection, saying, "If any man take not up his cross and follow me, he cannot be my disciple," He immediately adds, for the consolation of the weak, "Whoso receiveth a just man in the name of a just man shall receive a just man's reward; and whoso receiveth a prophet in the name of a prophet, shall receive a prophet's reward".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:329
verses.text: So that not only he who gives Timothy a little wine for his stomach's sake, and his frequent infirmities, but he who gives to a strong man a cup of cold water only in the name of a disciple, shall not lose his reward.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:330
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:331
verses.text: If it is true that a man cannot receive the gospel without giving up everything, why do you delude your followers, by allowing them to keep in your service their wives, and children, and households, and houses, and fields? Indeed, you may well allow them to disregard the precepts of the gospel: for all you promise them is not a resurrection, but a change to another mortal existence, in which they shall live the silly, childish, impious life of those you call the Elect, the life you live yourself, and are so much praised for; or if they possess greater merit, they shall enter into melons or cucumbers, or some eatables which you will masticate, that they may be quickly purified by your digestion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:332
verses.text: Least of all should you who teach such doctrines profess any regard for the gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:333
verses.text: For if the faith of the gospel had any connection with such nonsense, the Lord should have said, not, "I was hungry, and ye gave me meat;" but, "Ye were hungry, and ye ate me," or, "I was hungry, and I ate you".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:334
verses.text: For, by your absurdities, a man will not be received into the kingdom of God for the service of giving food to the saints, but, because he has eaten them and belched them out, or has himself been eaten and belched into heaven.
