verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:335
verses.text: Instead of saying, "Lord, when saw we Thee hungry, and fed Thee?" the righteous must say, "When saw we Thee hungry, and were eaten by Thee?" And He must answer, not, "When ye gave food to one of the least of these my brethren, you gave to me;" but, "When you were eaten by one of the least of these my brethren, you were eaten by me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:336
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:337
verses.text: Believing and teaching such monstrosities, and living accordingly, you yet have the boldness to say that you obey the precepts of the gospel, and to decry the Catholic Church, which includes many weak as well as strong, both of whom the Lord blesses, because both according to their measure obey the precepts of the gospel and hope in its promises.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:338
verses.text: The blindness of hostility makes you see only the tares in our harvest: for you might easily see wheat too, if you were willing that there should be any.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:339
verses.text: But among you, those who are pretended Manich aeans are wicked, and those who are really Manich aeans are silly.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:340
verses.text: For where the faith itself is false, he who hypocritically professes it acts deceitfully, while he who truly believes is deceived.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:341
verses.text: Such a faith cannot produce a good life, for every man's life is good or bad according as his heart is engaged.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:342
verses.text: If your affections were set upon spiritual and intellectual good, instead of material forms, you would not pay homage to the material sun as a divine substance, and as the light of wisdom, which every one knows you do, though I now only mention it in passing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:343
verses.text: Book VI.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:344
verses.text: Faustus avows his disbelief in the Old Testament and his disregard of its precepts, and accuses Catholics of inconsistency in neglecting its ordinances, while claiming to accept it as authoritative.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:345
verses.text: Augustin explains the Catholic view of the relation of the Old Testament to the New.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:346
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:347
verses.text: Faustus said: You ask if I believe the Old Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:348
verses.text: Of course not, for I do not keep its precepts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:349
verses.text: Neither, I imagine, do you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:350
verses.text: I reject circumcision as disgusting; and if I mistake not, so do you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:351
verses.text: I reject the observance of Sabbaths as superfluous: I suppose you do the same.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:352
verses.text: I reject sacrifice as idolatry, as doubtless you also do.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:353
verses.text: Swine's flesh is not the only flesh I abstain from; nor is it the only flesh you eat.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:354
verses.text: I think all flesh unclean: you think none unclean.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:355
verses.text: Both alike, in these opinions, throw over the Old Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:356
verses.text: We both look upon the weeks of unleavened bread and the feast of tabernacles as unnecessary and useless.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:357
verses.text: Not to patch linen garments with purple; to count it adultery to make a garment of linen and wool; to call it sacrilege to yoke together an ox and an ass when necessary; not to appoint as priest a bald man, or a man with red hair, or any similar peculiarity, as being unclean in the sight of God, are things which we both despise and laugh at, and rank as of neither first nor second importance; and yet they are all precepts and judgments of the Old Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:358
verses.text: You cannot blame me for rejecting the Old Testament; for whether it is right or wrong to do so, you do it as much as I.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:359
verses.text: As for the difference between your faith and mine, it is this, that while you choose to act deceitfully, and meanly to praise in words what in your heart you hate, I, not having learned the art of deception, frankly declare that I hate both these abominable precepts and their authors.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:360
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:361
verses.text: Augustin replied: How and for what purpose the Old Testament is received by the heirs of the New Testament has been already explained.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:362
verses.text: But as the remarks of Faustus were then about the promises of the Old Testament, and now he speaks of the precepts, I reply that he displays ignorance of the difference between moral and symbolical precepts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:363
verses.text: For example, "Thou shalt not covet" is a moral precept; "Thou shalt circumcise every male on the eighth day" is a symbolical precept.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:364
verses.text: From not making this distinction, the Manich aeans, and all who find fault with the writings of the Old Testament, not seeing that whatever observance God appointed for the former dispensation was a shadow of future things, because these observances are now discontinued, condemn them, though no doubt what is unsuitable now was perfectly suitable then as prefiguring the things now revealed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:365
verses.text: In this they contradict the apostle who says, "All these things happened to them for an example, and they were written for our learning, on whom the end of the world is come".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:366
verses.text: The apostle here explains why these writings are to be received, and why it is no longer necessary to continue the symbolical observances.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:367
verses.text: For when he says, "They were written for our learning," he clearly shows that we should be very diligent in reading and in discovering the meaning of the Old Testament Scriptures, and that we should have great veneration for them, since it was for us that they were written.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:368
verses.text: Again, when he says, "They are our examples," and "these things happened to them for an example," he shows that, now that the things themselves are clearly revealed, the observance of the actions by which these things were prefigured is no longer binding.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:369
verses.text: So he says elsewhere, "Let no man judge you in meat, or in drink, or in respect of an holy day, or of the new moon or of the sabbath-days, which are a shadow of things to come".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:370
verses.text: Here also, when he says, "Let no one judge you" in these things, he shows that we are no longer bound to observe them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:371
verses.text: And when he says, "which are a shadow of things to come," he explains how these observances were binding at the time when the things fully disclosed to us were symbolized by these shadows of future things.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:372
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:373
verses.text: Assuredly, if the Manich aeans were justified by the resurrection of the Lord,—the day of whose resurrection, the third after His passion, was the eighth day, coming after the Sabbath, that is, after the seventh day,—their carnal minds would be delivered from the darkness of earthly passions which rests on them; and rejoicing in the circumcision of the heart, they would not ridicule it as prefigured in the Old Testament by circumcision in the flesh, although they should not enforce this observance under the New Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:374
verses.text: But, as the apostle says, "To the pure all things are pure.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:375
verses.text: But to the impure and unbelieving nothing is pure, but both their mind and conscience are defiled".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:376
verses.text: So these people, who are so pure in their own eyes, that they regard, or pretend to regard, as impure these members of their bodies, are so defiled with unbelief and error, that, while they abhor the circumcision of the flesh,—which the apostle calls a seal of the righteousness of faith,—they believe that the divine members of their God are subjected to restraint and contamination in these very carnal members of theirs.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:377
verses.text: For they say that flesh is unclean; and it follows that God, in the part which is detained by the flesh, is made unclean: for they declare that He must be cleansed, and that till this is done, as far as it can be done, He undergoes all the passions to which flesh is subject, not only in suffering pain and distress, but also in sensual gratification.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:378
verses.text: For it is for His sake, they say, that they abstain from sexual intercourse, that He may not be bound more closely in the bondage of the flesh, nor suffer more defilement.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:379
verses.text: The apostle says, "To the pure all things are pure".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:380
verses.text: And if this is true of men, who may be led into evil by a perverse will, how much more must all things be pure to God, who remains for ever immutable and immaculate! In those books which you defile with your violent reproaches, it is said of the divine wisdom, that "no defiled thing falleth into it, and it goeth everywhere by reason of its pureness".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:381
verses.text: It is mere prurient absurdity to find fault with the sign of human regeneration appointed by that God, to whom all things are pure, to be put on the organ of human generation, while you hold that your God, to whom nothing is pure, is in a part of his nature subjected to taint and corruption by the vicious actions in which impure men employ the members of their body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:382
verses.text: For if you think there is pollution in conjugal intercourse, what must there be in all the practices of the licentious? If you ask, then, as you often do, whether God could not find some other way of sealing the righteousness of faith, the answer is, Why not this way, since all things are pure to the pure, much more to God? And we have the authority of the apostle for saying that circumcision was the seal of the righteousness of the faith of Abraham.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:383
verses.text: As for you, you must try not to blush when you are asked whether your God had nothing better to do than to entangle part of his nature with these members that you revile so much.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:384
verses.text: These are delicate subjects to speak of, on account of the penal corruption attending the propagation of man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:385
verses.text: They are things which call into exercise the modesty of the chaste, the passions of the impure, and the justice of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:386
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:387
verses.text: The rest of the Sabbath we consider no longer binding as an observance, now that the hope of our eternal rest has been revealed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:388
verses.text: But it is a very useful thing to read of, and to reflect on.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:389
verses.text: In prophetic times, when things now manifested were prefigured and predicted by actions as well as words, this sign of which we read was a presage of the reality which we possess.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:390
verses.text: But I wish to know why you observe a sort of partial rest.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:391
verses.text: The Jews, on their Sabbath, which they still keep in a carnal manner, neither gather any fruit in the field, nor dress and cook it at home.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:392
verses.text: But you, in your rest, wait till one of your followers takes his knife or hook to the garden, to get food for you by murdering the vegetables, and brings back, strange to say, living corpses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:393
verses.text: For if cutting plants is not murder, why are you afraid to do it? And yet, if the plants are murdered, what becomes of the life which is to obtain release and restoration from your mastication and digestion? Well, you take the living vegetables, and certainly you ought, if it could be done to swallow them whole; so that after the one wound your follower has been guilty of inflicting in pulling them, of which you will no doubt consent to absolve him, they may reach without loss or injury your private laboratory, where your God may be healed of his wound.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:394
verses.text: Instead of this, you not only tear them with your teeth, but, if it pleases your taste, mince them, inflicting a multitude of wounds in the most criminal manner.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:395
verses.text: Plainly it would be a most advantageous thing if you would rest at home too, and not only once a week, like the Jews, but every day of the week.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:396
verses.text: The cucumbers suffer while you are cooking them, without any benefit to the life that is in them: for a boiling pot cannot be compared to a saintly stomach.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:397
verses.text: And yet you ridicule as superfluous the rest of the Sabbath.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:398
verses.text: Would it not be better, not only to refrain from finding fault with the fathers for this observance, in whose case it was not superfluous, but, even now that it is superfluous, to observe this rest yourselves instead of your own, which has no symbolical use, and is condemned as grounded on falsehood? According to your own foolish opinions, you are guilty of a defective observance of your own rest, though the observance itself is foolish in the judgment of truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:399
verses.text: You maintain that the fruit suffers when it is pulled from the tree, when it is cut and scraped, and cooked, and eaten.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:400
verses.text: So you are wrong in eating anything that can not be swallowed raw and unhurt, so that the wound inflicted might not be from you, but from your follower in pulling them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:401
verses.text: You declare that you could not give release to so great a quantity of life, if you were to eat only things which could be swallowed without cooking or mastication.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:402
verses.text: But if this release compensates for all the pains you inflict, why is it unlawful for you to pull the fruit? Fruit may be eaten raw, as some of your sect make a point of eating raw vegetables of all kinds.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:403
verses.text: But before it can be eaten at all, it must be pulled or fall off, or be taken in some way from the ground or from the tree.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:404
verses.text: You might well be pardoned for pulling it, since nothing can be done without that, but not for torturing the members of your God to the extent you do in dressing your food.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:405
verses.text: One of your silly notions is that the tree weeps when the fruit is pulled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:406
verses.text: Doubtless the life in the tree knows all things, and perceives who it is that comes to it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:407
verses.text: If the elect were to come and pull the fruit, would not the tree rejoice to escape the misery of having its fruit plucked by others, and to gain felicity by enduring a little momentary pain? And yet, while you multiply the pains and troubles of the fruit after it is plucked, you will not pluck it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:408
verses.text: Explain that, if you can! Fasting itself is a mistake in your case.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:409
verses.text: There should be no intermission in the task of purging away the dross of the excrements from the spiritual gold, and of releasing the divine members from confinement.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:410
verses.text: The most merciful man among you is he who keeps himself always in good health, takes raw food, and eats a great deal.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:411
verses.text: But you are cruel when you eat, in making your food undergo so much suffering; and you are cruel when you fast, in desisting from the work of liberating the divine members.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:412
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:413
verses.text: With all this, you venture to denounce the sacrifices of the Old Testament, and to call them idolatry, and to attribute to us the same impious notion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:414
verses.text: To answer for ourselves in the first place, while we consider it no longer a duty to offer sacrifices, we recognize sacrifices as part of the mysteries of Revelation, by which the things prophesied were foreshadowed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:415
verses.text: For they were our examples, and in many and various ways they all pointed to the one sacrifice which we now commemorate.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:416
verses.text: Now that this sacrifice has been revealed, and has been offered in due time, sacrifice is no longer binding as an act of worship, while it retains its symbolical authority.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:417
verses.text: For these things "were written for our learning, upon whom the end of the world is come".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:418
verses.text: What you object to in sacrifice is the slaughter of animals, though the whole animal creation is intended conditionally in some way for the use of man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:419
verses.text: You are merciful to beasts, believing them to contain the souls of human beings, while you refuse a piece of bread to a hungry beggar.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:420
verses.text: The Lord Jesus, on the other hand, was cruel to the swine when He granted the request of the devils to be allowed to enter into them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:421
verses.text: The same Lord Jesus, before the sacrifice of His passion, said to a leper whom He had cured, "Go, show thyself to the priest, and give the offering, as Moses commanded, for a testimony unto them".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:422
verses.text: When God, by the prophets, repeatedly declares that He needs no offering, as indeed reason teaches us that offerings cannot be needed by Him who stands in need of nothing, the human mind is led to inquire what God wished to teach us by these sacrifices.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:423
verses.text: For, assuredly, He would not have required offerings of which He had no need, except to teach us something that it would profit us to know, and which was suitably set forth by means of these symbols.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:424
verses.text: How much better and more honorable it would be for you to be still bound by these sacrifices, which have an instructive meaning, though they are not now necessary, than to require your followers to offer to you as food what you believe to be living victims.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:425
verses.text: The Apostle Paul says most appropriately of some who preached the gospel to gratify their appetite, that their "god was their belly".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:426
verses.text: But the arrogance of your impiety goes much beyond this; for, instead of making your belly your god, you do what is far worse in making your belly the purifier of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:427
verses.text: Surely it is great madness to make a pretence of piety in not slaughtering animals, while you hold that the souls of animals inhabit all the food you eat, and yet make what you call living creatures suffer such torture from your hands and teeth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:428
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:429
verses.text: If you will not eat flesh why should you not slay animals in sacrifice to your God, in order that their souls, which you hold to be not only human, but so divine as to be members of God Himself, may be released from the confinement of flesh, and be saved from returning by the efficacy of your prayers? Perhaps, however, your stomach gives more effectual aid than your intellect, and that part of divinity which has had the advantage of passing through your bowels is more likely to be saved than that which has only the benefit of your prayers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:430
verses.text: Your objection to eating flesh will be that you cannot eat animals alive, and so the operation of your stomach will not avail for the liberation of their souls.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:431
verses.text: Happy vegetables, that, torn up with the hand, cut with knives, tortured in fire, ground by teeth, yet reach alive the altars of your intestines! Unhappy sheep and oxen, that are not so tenacious of life, and therefore are refused entrance into your bodies! Such is the absurdity of your notions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:432
verses.text: And you persist in making out an opposition in us to the Old Testament, because we consider no flesh unclean: according to the opinion of the apostle, "To the pure all things are pure;"  and according to the saying of our Lord Himself, "Not that which goeth into your mouth defileth you, but that which cometh out".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:433
verses.text: This was not said to the crowd only, as your Adimantus, whom Faustus, in his attack on the Old Testament, praises as second only to Manich aeus, wishes us to understand; but when retired from the crowd, the Lord repeated this still more plainly and pointedly to His disciples.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:434
verses.text: Adimantus quotes this saying of our Lord in opposition to the Old Testament, where the people are prohibited from eating some animals which are pronounced unclean; and doubtless he was afraid that he should be asked why, since he quotes a passage from the Gospel about man not being defiled by what enters into his mouth and passes into his belly, and out into the draft, he yet considers not some only, but all flesh unclean, and abstains from eating it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:435
verses.text: It is in order to escape from this strait, when the plain truth is too much for his error, that he makes the Lord say this to the crowd; as if the Lord were in the habit of speaking the truth only in small companies, while He blurted out falsehoods in public.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:436
verses.text: To speak of the Lord in this way is blasphemy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:437
verses.text: And all who read the passage can see that the Lord said the same thing more plainly to His disciples in private.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:438
verses.text: Since Faustus praises Adimantus so much at the beginning of this book of his, placing him next to Manich aeus, let him say in a word whether it is true or false that a man is not defiled by what enters into his mouth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:439
verses.text: If it is false, why does this great teacher Adimantus quote it against the Old Testament? If it is true, why, in spite of this, do you believe that eating any flesh will defile you? It is true, if you choose this explanation, that the apostle does not say that all things are pure to heretics, but, "to the pure all things are pure".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:440
verses.text: The apostle also goes on to explain why all things are not pure to heretics: "To the impure and unbelieving nothing is pure, but both their mind and conscience are defiled".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:441
verses.text: So to the Manich aeans there is absolutely nothing pure; for they hold that the very substance or nature of God not only may be, but has actually been defiled, and so defiled that it can never be wholly restored and purified.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:442
verses.text: What do they mean when they call animals unclean, and refrain from eating them, when it is impossible for them to think anything, whether food or whatever it may be, clean? According to them, vegetables too, fruits, all kinds of crops, the earth and sky, are defiled by mixture with the race of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:443
verses.text: Why do they not act up to their opinions about other things as well as about animals? Why do they not abstain altogether, and starve themselves to death, instead of persisting in their blasphemies? If they will not repent and reform, this is evidently the best thing that they could do.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:444
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:445
verses.text: The saying of the apostle, that "to the pure all things are pure," and that "every creature of God is good," is not opposed to the prohibitions of the Old Testament; and the explanation, if they can understand it, is this.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:446
verses.text: The apostle speaks of the natures of the things, while the Old Testament calls some animals unclean, not in their nature, but symbolically, on account of the prefigurative character of that dispensation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:447
verses.text: For instance, a pig and a lamb are both clean in their nature, for every creature of God is good; but symbolically, a lamb is clean, and a pig unclean.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:448
verses.text: So the words wise and fool are both clean in their nature, as words composed of letters but fool may be called symbolically unclean, because it means an unclean thing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:449
verses.text: Perhaps a pig is the same among symbols as a fool is among real things.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:450
verses.text: The animal, and the four letters which compose the word, may mean the same thing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:451
verses.text: No doubt the animal is pronounced unclean by the law, because it does not chew the cud; which is not a fault but its nature.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:452
verses.text: But the men of whom this animal is a symbol are unclean, not by nature, but from their own fault; because, though they gladly hear the words of wisdom, they never reflect on them afterwards.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:453
verses.text: For to recall, in quiet repose, some useful instruction from the stomach of memory to the mouth of reflection, is a kind of spiritual rumination.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:454
verses.text: The animals above mentioned are a symbol of those people who do not do this.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:455
verses.text: And the prohibition of the flesh of these animals is a warning against this fault.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:456
verses.text: Another passage of Scripture speaks of the precious treasure of wisdom, and describes ruminating as clean, and not ruminating as unclean: "A precious treasure resteth in the mouth of a wise man; but a foolish man swallows it up".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:457
verses.text: Symbols of this kind, either in words or in things, give useful and pleasant exercise to intelligent minds in the way of inquiry and comparison.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:458
verses.text: But formerly people were required not only to hear, but to practise many such things.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:459
verses.text: For at that time it was necessary that, by deeds as well as by words, those things should be foreshadowed which were in after times to be revealed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:460
verses.text: After the revelation by Christ and in Christ, the community of believers is not burdened with the practice of the observances, but is admonished to give heed to the prophecy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:461
verses.text: This is our reason for accounting no animals unclean, in accordance with the saying of the Lord and of the apostle, while we are not opposed to the Old Testament, where some animals are pronounced unclean.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:462
verses.text: Now let us hear why you consider all animal food unclean.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:463
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:464
verses.text: One of your false doctrines is, that flesh is unclean on account of mixture with the race of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:465
verses.text: But this would make not only flesh unclean, but your God himself, in that part which he sent to become subject to absorption and contamination, in order that the enemy might be conquered and taken captive.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:466
verses.text: Besides, on account of this mixture, all that you eat must be unclean.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:467
verses.text: But you say flesh is especially unclean.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:468
verses.text: It requires patience to listen to all their absurd reasons for this peculiar impurity of flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:469
verses.text: I will mention only what will suffice to show the inveterate folly of these critics of the Old Testament, who, while they denounce flesh, savor only fleshly things, and have no sort of spiritual perception.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:470
verses.text: And a lengthy discussion of this question may perhaps enable us to dispense with saying much on some other points.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:471
verses.text: The following, then, is an account of their vain delusions in this matter:—In that battle, when the First Man ensnared the race of darkness by deceitful elements, princes of both sexes belonging to this race were taken.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:472
verses.text: By means of these princes the world was constructed; and among those used in the formation of the heavenly bodies, were some pregnant females.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:473
verses.text: When the sky began to rotate, the rapid circular motion made these females give birth to abortions, which, being of both sexes, fell on the earth, and lived, and grew, and came together, and produced offspring.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:474
verses.text: Hence sprang all animal life in earth, air, and sea.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:475
verses.text: Now if the origin of flesh is from heaven, that is no reason for thinking it especially unclean.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:476
verses.text: Indeed, in this construction of the world, they hold that these principles of darkness were arranged higher or lower, according to the greater or less amount of good mixed with them in the construction of the various parts of the world.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:477
verses.text: So flesh ought to be cleaner than vegetables which come out of the earth, for it comes from heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:478
verses.text: And how irrational to suppose that the abortions, before becoming animate, were so lively, though in an abortive state, that after falling from the sky, they could live and multiply; whereas, after becoming animate, they die if brought forth prematurely, and a fall from a very moderate height is enough to kill them! The kingdom of life in contest with the kingdom of death ought to have improved them, by giving them life instead of making them more perishable than before.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:479
verses.text: If the perishableness is a consequence of a change of nature, it is wrong to say that there is a bad nature.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:480
verses.text: The change is the only cause of the perishableness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:481
verses.text: Both natures are good, though one is better than the other.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:482
verses.text: Whence then comes the peculiar impurity of flesh as it exists in this world, sprung, as they say, from heaven? They tell us, indeed, of the first bodies of these principles of darkness being generated like worms from trees of darkness; and the trees, they say, are produced from the five elements.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:483
verses.text: But supposing that the bodies of animals come in the first place from trees, and afterwards from heaven, why should they be more unclean than the fruit of trees? Perhaps it will be said that what remains after death is unclean, because the life is no longer there.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:484
verses.text: For the same reason fruits and vegetables must be unclean, for they die when they are pulled or cut.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:485
verses.text: As we saw before, the elect get others to bring their food to them, that they may not be guilty of murder.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:486
verses.text: Perhaps, since they say that every living being has two souls, one of the race of light, and the other of the race of darkness, the good soul leaves at death, and the bad soul remains.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:487
verses.text: But, in that case, the animal would be as much alive as it was in the kingdom of darkness, when it had only the soul of its own race, with which it had rebelled against the kingdom of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:488
verses.text: So, since both souls leave at death, why call the flesh unclean, as if only the good soul had left? Any life that remains must be of both kinds; for some remains of the members of God are found, we are told, even in filth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:489
verses.text: There is therefore no reason for making flesh more unclean than fruits.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:490
verses.text: The truth is, they pretend to great chastity in holding flesh unclean because it is generated.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:491
verses.text: But if the divine body is more grossly shut in by flesh, there is all the more reason that they should liberate it by eating.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:492
verses.text: And there are innumerable kinds of worms not produced from sexual intercourse; some in the neighborhood of Venice come from trees, which they should eat, since there is not the same reason for their being unclean.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:493
verses.text: Besides, there are the frogs produced by the earth after a shower of rain.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:494
verses.text: Let them liberate the members of their God from these.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:495
verses.text: Let them rebuke the mistake of mankind in preferring fowls and pigeons produced from males and females to the pure frogs, daughters of heaven and earth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:496
verses.text: By this theory, the first principles of darkness produced from trees must be purer than Manich aeus, who was produced by generation; and his followers, for the same reason, must be less pure than the lice which spring from the perspiration of their bodies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:497
verses.text: But if everything that comes from flesh is unclean, because the origin of flesh itself is unclean, fruits and vegetables must also be unclean, because they are manured with dung.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:498
verses.text: After this, what becomes of the notion that fruits are cleaner than flesh? Dung is the most unclean product of flesh, and also the most fertilizing manure.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:499
verses.text: Their doctrine is, that the life escapes in the mastication and digestion of the food, so that only a particle remains in the excrement.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:500
verses.text: How is it, then, that this particle of life has such an effect on the growth and the quality of your favorite food? Flesh is nourished by the productions of the earth, not by its excrements; while the earth is nourished by the excrements of flesh, not by its productions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:501
verses.text: Let them say which is the cleaner.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:502
verses.text: Or let them turn from being unbelieving and impure to whom nothing is clean, and join with us in embracing the doctrine of the apostle, that to the pure all things are pure; that the earth is the Lord's, and the fullness thereof; that every creature of God is good.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:503
verses.text: All things in nature are good in their own order; and no one sins in using them, unless, by disobedience to God, he transgresses his own order, and disturbs their order by using them amiss.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:504
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:505
verses.text: The elders who pleased God kept their own order by their obedience, in observing, according to God's arrangement, what was appointed as suitable to certain times.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:506
verses.text: So, although all animals intended for food are by nature clean, they abstained from some which had then a symbolical uncleanness, in preparation for the future revelation of the things signified.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:507
verses.text: And so with regard to unleavened bread and all such things, in which the apostle says there was a shadow of future things, neglect of their observance under the old dispensation, when this observance was enjoined, and was employed to prefigure what was afterwards to be revealed, would have been as criminal, as it would now be foolish in us, after the light of the New Testament has arisen, to think that these predictive observances could be of any use to us.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:508
verses.text: On the other hand, since the Old Testament teaches us that the things now revealed were so long ago prefigured, that we may be firm and faithful in our adherence to them, it would be blasphemy and impiety to discard these books, simply because the Lord requires of us now not a literal, but a spiritual and intelligent regard to their contents.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:509
verses.text: They were written, as the apostle says, for our admonition, on whom the end of the world is come.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:510
verses.text: "For whatsoever things were written aforetime were written for our learning".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:511
verses.text: Not to eat unleavened bread in the appointed seven days was a sin in the time of the Old Testament; in the time of the New Testament it is not a sin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:512
verses.text: But having the hope of a future world through Christ, who makes us altogether new by clothing our souls with righteousness and our bodies with immortality, to believe that the bondage and infirmity of our original corruption will prevail over us or over our actions, must continue to be a sin, till the seven days of the course of time are accomplished.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:513
verses.text: In the time of the Old Testament, this, under the disguise of a type, was perceived by some saints.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:514
verses.text: In the time of the New Testament it is fully declared and publicly preached.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:515
verses.text: [19]  What was then a precept of Scripture is now a testimony.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:516
verses.text: Formerly, not to keep the feast of tabernacles was a sin, which is not the case now.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:517
verses.text: But not to form part of the building of God's tabernacle, which is the Church, is always a sin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:518
verses.text: Formerly this was acted in a figure; now the record serves as testimony.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:519
verses.text: The ancient tabernacle, indeed, would not have been called the tabernacle of the testimony, unless as an appropriate symbol it had borne testimony to some truth which was to be revealed in its own time.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:520
verses.text: To patch linen garments with purple, or to wear a garment of woollen and linen together, is not a sin now.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:521
verses.text: But to live intemperately, and to wish to combine opposite modes of life,—as when a woman devoted to religion wears the ornaments of married women, or when one who has not abstained from marriage dresses like a virgin,—is always sin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:522
verses.text: So it is sin whenever inconsistent things are combined in any man's life.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:523
verses.text: This, which is now a moral truth, was then symbolized in dress.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:524
verses.text: What was then a type is now revealed truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:525
verses.text: So the same Scripture which then required symbolical actions, now testifies to the things signified.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:526
verses.text: The prefigurative observance is now a record for the confirmation of our faith.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:527
verses.text: Formerly it was unlawful to plough with an ox and an ass together; now it is lawful.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:528
verses.text: The apostle explains this when he quotes the text about not muzzling the ox that is treading out the corn.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:529
verses.text: He says, "Does God care for oxen?" What, then, have we to do with an obsolete prohibition? The apostle teaches us in the following words, "For our sakes it is written".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:530
verses.text: It must be impiety in us not to read what was written for our sakes; for it is more for our sakes, to whom the revelation belongs, than for theirs who had only the figure.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:531
verses.text: There is no harm in joining an ox with an ass where it is required.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:532
verses.text: But to put a wise man and a fool together, not that one should teach and the other obey, but that both with equal authority should declare the word of God, cannot be done without causing offence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:533
verses.text: So the same Scripture which was once a command enjoining the shadow in which future things were veiled, is now an authoritative witness to the unveiled truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:534
verses.text: In what he says of the uncleanness of a man that is bald or has red hair, Faustus is inaccurate, or the manuscript he has used is incorrect.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:535
verses.text: Would that Faustus were not ashamed to bear on his forehead the cross of Christ, the want of which is baldness, instead of maintaining that Christ, who says, "I am the truth," showed unreal marks, after His resurrection, of unreal wounds! Faustus says he has not learned the art of deceiving, and speaks what he thinks.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:536
verses.text: He cannot therefore be a disciple of his Christ, whom he madly declares to have shown false marks of wounds to his disciples when they doubted.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:537
verses.text: Are we to believe Faustus, not only in his other absurdities, but also when he tells us that he does not deceive us in calling Christ a deceiver? Is he better than Christ? Is he not a deceiver, while Christ is? Or does he prove himself to be a disciple not of the truthful Christ, but of the deceiver Manich aeus, by this very falsehood, when he boasts that he has not learned the art of deceiving?               Book VII.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:538
verses.text: The genealogical question is again taken up and argued on both sides.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:539
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:540
verses.text: Faustus said: You ask why I do not believe in the genealogy of Jesus.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:541
verses.text: There are many reasons; but the principal is, that He never declares with His own lips that He had an earthly father or descent, but on the contrary, that he is not of this world, that He came forth from God the Father, that He descended from heaven, that He has no mother or brethren except those who do the will of His Father in heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:542
verses.text: Besides, the framers of these genealogies do not seem to have known Jesus before His birth or soon after it, so as to have the credibility of eye-witnesses of what they narrate.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:543
verses.text: They became acquainted with Jesus as a young man of about thirty years of age, if it is not blasphemy to speak of the age of a divine being.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:544
verses.text: Now the question regarding a witness is always whether he has seen or heard what he testifies to.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:545
verses.text: But the writers of these genealogies never assert that they heard the account from Jesus Himself, nor even the fact of His birth; nor did they see Him till they came to know Him after his baptism, many years after the time of His birth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:546
verses.text: To me, therefore, and to every sensible man, it appears as foolish to believe this account, as it would be to call into court a blind and deaf witness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:547
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:548
verses.text: Augustin replied: As regards what Faustus calls his principal reason for not receiving the genealogy of Jesus Christ, a complete refutation is found in the passages formerly quoted, where Christ declares Himself to be the Son of man, and in what we have said of the identity of the Son of man with the Son of God: that in His Godhead He has no earthly descent, while after the flesh He is of the seed of David, as the apostle teaches.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:549
verses.text: We are to believe, therefore, that He came forth from the Father, that He descended from heaven, and also that the Word was made flesh and dwelt amongst men.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:550
verses.text: If the words, "Who is my mother, and who are my brethren?"  are quoted to show that Christ had no earthly mother or descent, it follows that we must believe that His disciples, whom He here teaches by His own example to set no value on earthly relationship, as compared with the kingdom of heaven, had no fathers, because Christ says to them, "Call no man father upon earth; for one is your Father, even God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:551
verses.text: What He taught them to do with reference to their fathers, He Himself first did in reference to His own mother and brethren; as in many other things He condescended to set us an example, and to go before that we might follow in His footsteps.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:552
verses.text: Faustus' principal objection to the genealogy fails completely; and after the defeat of this invincible force, the rest is easily routed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:553
verses.text: He says that the apostles who declared Christ to be the Son of man as well as the Son of God are not to be believed, because they were not present at the birth of Christ, whom they joined when He had reached manhood, nor heard of it from Christ Himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:554
verses.text: Why then do they believe John when he says, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:555
verses.text: The same was in the beginning with God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:556
verses.text: All things were made by Him, and without Him was not anything made,"  and such passages, which they agree to, without understanding them? Where did John see this, or did he ever hear it from the Lord Himself? In whatever way John learned this, those who narrate the nativity may have learned also.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:557
verses.text: Again, how do they know that the Lord said, "Who is my mother, and who are my brethren?" If on the authority of the evangelist, why do they not also believe that the mother and the brethren of Christ were seeking for Him? They believe that Christ said these words, which they misunderstand, while they deny a fact resting on the same authority.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:558
verses.text: Once more, if Matthew could not know that Christ was born, because he knew Him only in His manhood, how could Manich aeus, who lived so long after, know that He was not born? They will say that Manich aeus knew this from the Holy Spirit which was in him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:559
verses.text: Certainly the Holy Spirit would make him speak the truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:560
verses.text: But why not rather believe what Christ's own disciples tell us, who were personally acquainted with Him, and who not only had the gift of inspiration to supply defects in their knowledge, but in a purely natural way obtained information of the birth of Christ, and of His descent, when the event was fresh in memory? And yet he dares to call the apostles deaf and blind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:561
verses.text: Why were you not deaf and blind, to prevent you from learning such profane nonsense, and dumb too, to prevent you from uttering it?               Book VIII.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:562
verses.text: Faustus maintains that to hold to the Old Testament after the giving of the New is putting new cloth on an old garment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:563
verses.text: Augustin further explains the relation of the Old Testament to the New, and reproaches the Manich aeans with carnality.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:564
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:565
verses.text: Faustus said: Another reason for not receiving the Old Testament is, that I am provided with the New; and Scripture says that old and new do not agree.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:566
verses.text: For "no one putteth a piece of new cloth unto an old garment, otherwise the rent is made worse".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:567
verses.text: To avoid making a worse rent, as you have done, I do not mix Christian newness with Hebrew oldness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:568
verses.text: Every one accounts it mean, when a man has got a new dress, not to give the old one to his inferiors.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:569
verses.text: So, even if I were a Jew by birth, as the apostles were, it would be proper for me, on receiving the New Testament, to discard the Old, as the apostles did.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:570
verses.text: And having the advantage of being born free from the yoke of bondage, and being early introduced into the full liberty of Christ, what a foolish and ungrateful wretch I should be to put myself again under the yoke! This is what Paul blames the Galatians for; because, going back to circumcision, they turned again to the weak and beggarly elements, whereunto they desired again to be in bondage.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:571
verses.text: Why should I do what I see another blamed for doing? My going into bondage would be worse than their returning to it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:572
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:573
verses.text: Augustin replied: We have already shown sufficiently why and how we maintain the authority of the Old Testament, not for the imitation of Jewish bondage, but for the confirmation of Christian liberty.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:574
verses.text: It is not I, but the apostle, who says, "All these things happened to them as an example, and they were written for our admonition, on whom the ends of the world are come".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:575
verses.text: We do not therefore, as bondmen, observe what was enjoined as predictive of us; but as free, we read what was written to confirm us.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:576
verses.text: So any one may see that the apostle remonstrates with the Galatians not for devoutly reading what Scripture says of circumcision, but for superstitiously desiring to be circumcised.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:577
verses.text: We do not put a new cloth to an old garment, but we are instructed in the kingdom of heaven, like the householder, whom the Lord describes as bringing out of his treasure things new and old.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:578
verses.text: He who puts a new cloth to an old garment is the man who attempts spiritual self-denial before he has renounced fleshly hope.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:579
verses.text: Examine the passage, and you will see that, when the Lord was asked about fasting, He replied, "No man putteth a new cloth to an old garment".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:580
verses.text: The disciples had still a carnal affection for the Lord; for they were afraid that, if He died, they would lose Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:581
verses.text: So He calls Peter Satan for dissuading Him from suffering, because he understood not the things of God, but the things of men.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:582
verses.text: The fleshly character of your hope is evident from your fancies about the kingdom of God, and from your paying homage and devotion to the light of the sun, which the carnal eye perceives, as if it were an image of heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:583
verses.text: So your carnal mind is the old garment to which you join your fasts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:584
verses.text: Moreover, if a new cloth and an old garment do not agree, how do the members of your God come to be not only joined or fastened, but to be united far more intimately by mixture and coherence to the principles of darkness? Perhaps both are old, because both are false, and both of the carnal mind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:585
verses.text: Or perhaps you wish to prove that one was new and the other old, by the rent being made worse, in tearing away the unhappy piece of the kingdom of light, to be doomed to eternal imprisonment in the mass of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:586
verses.text: So this pretended artist in the fashions of the sacred Scriptures is found stitching together absurdities, and dressing himself in the rags of his own invention.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:587
verses.text: Book IX.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:588
verses.text: Faustus argues that if the apostles born under the old covenant could lawfully depart from it, much more can he having been born a Gentile.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:589
verses.text: Augustin explains the relation of Jews and Gentiles alike to the Gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:590
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:591
verses.text: Faustus said: Another reason for not receiving the Old Testament is, that if it was allowable for the apostles, who were born under it, to abandon it, much more may I, who was not born under it, be excused for not thrusting myself into it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:592
verses.text: We Gentiles are not born Jews, nor Christians either.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:593
verses.text: Out of the same Gentile world some are induced by the Old Testament to become Jews, and some by the New Testament to become Christians.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:594
verses.text: It is as if two trees, a sweet and a bitter, drew from one soil the sap which each assimilates to its own nature.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:595
verses.text: The apostle passed from the bitter to the sweet; it would be madness in me to change from the sweet to the bitter.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:596
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:597
verses.text: Augustin replied: You say that the apostle, in leaving Judaism, passed from the bitter to the sweet.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:598
verses.text: But the apostle himself says that the Jews, who would not believe in Christ, were branches broken off, and that the Gentiles, a wild olive tree, were grafted into the good olive, that is, the holy stock of the Hebrews, that they might partake of the fatness of the olive.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:599
verses.text: For, in warning the Gentiles not to be proud on account of the fall of the Jews, he says: "For I speak to you Gentiles, inasmuch as I am the apostle of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:600
verses.text: I magnify my office; if by any means I may provoke to emulation them which are my flesh, and might save some of them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:601
verses.text: For if the casting away of them be the reconciling of the world, what shall the receiving of them be, but life from the dead? For if the first fruit be holy, the lump is also holy; and if the root be holy, so are the branches.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:602
verses.text: And if some of the branches are broken off, and thou, being a wild olive tree, were grafted in among them, and with them partakest of the root and fatness of the olive tree; boast not against the branches: but if thou boast, thou bearest not the root, but the root thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:603
verses.text: Thou wilt say then, The branches were broken off, that I might be grafted in.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:604
verses.text: Well; because of unbelief they were broken off, and thou standest by faith.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:605
verses.text: Be not high-minded, but fear; for if God spared not the natural branches, take heed lest He also spare not thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:606
verses.text: Behold therefore the goodness and severity of God: on them which fell, severity; but toward thee, goodness, if thou continue in His goodness; otherwise thou also shalt be cut off.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:607
verses.text: And they also, if they abide not still in unbelief, shall be grafted in; for God is able to graft them in again.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:608
verses.text: For if thou wert cut out of the olive tree, which is wild by nature, and wert grafted contrary to nature into a good olive tree; how much more shall these, which be the natural branches, be grafted into their own olive tree? For I would not, brethren, that ye should be ignorant of this mystery (lest ye should be wise in your own conceits), that blindness in part is happened to Israel, until the fullness of the Gentiles be come in; and so all Israel shall be saved".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:609
verses.text: It appears from this, that you, who do not wish to be graffed into this root, though you are not broken off, like the carnal unbelieving Jews, remain still in the bitterness of the wild olive.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:610
verses.text: Your worship of the sun and moon has the true Gentile flavor.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:611
verses.text: You are none the less in the wild olive of the Gentiles, because you have added thorns of a new kind, and worship along with the sun and moon a false Christ, the fabrication not of your hands, but of your perverse heart.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:612
verses.text: Come, then, and be grafted into the root of the olive tree, in his return to which the apostle rejoices, after by unbelief he had been among the broken branches.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:613
verses.text: He speaks of himself as set free, when he made the happy transition from Judaism to Christianity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:614
verses.text: For Christ was always preached in the olive tree, and those who did not believe on Him when He came were broken off, while those who believed were grafted in.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:615
verses.text: These are thus warned against pride: "Be not high-minded, but fear; for if God spared not the natural branches, neither will He spare thee".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:616
verses.text: And to prevent despair of those broken off, he adds: "And they also, if they abide not still in unbelief, shall be grafted in; for God is able to graft them in again.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:617
verses.text: For if thou wert cut out of the olive tree, which is wild by nature, and wert grafted contrary to nature into a good olive tree, how much more shall these, which be the natural branches, be grafted into their own olive tree".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:618
verses.text: The apostle rejoices in being delivered from the condition of a broken branch, and in being restored to the fatness of the olive tree.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:619
verses.text: So you who have been broken off by error should return and be grafted in again.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:620
verses.text: Those who are still in the wild olive should separate themselves from its barrenness, and become partakers of fertility.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:621
verses.text: Book X.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:622
verses.text: Faustus insists that the Old Testament promises are radically different from those of the New.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:623
verses.text: Augustin admits a difference, but maintains that the moral precepts are the same in both.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:624
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:625
verses.text: Faustus said: Another reason for not receiving the Old Testament is, that both the Old and the New teach us not to covet what belongs to others.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:626
verses.text: Everything in the Old Testament is of this kind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:627
verses.text: It promises riches, and plenty, and children, and children's children, and long life, and withal the land of Canaan; but only to the circumcised, the Sabbath observers, those offering sacrifices, and abstaining from swine's flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:628
verses.text: Now I, like every other Christian, pay no attention to these things, as being trifling and useless for the salvation of the soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:629
verses.text: I conclude, therefore, that the promises do not belong to me.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:630
verses.text: And mindful of the commandment, Thou shall not covet, I gladly leave to the Jews their own property, and content myself with the gospel, and with the bright inheritance of the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:631
verses.text: If a Jew were to claim part in the gospel, I should justly reproach him with claiming what he had no right to, because he does not obey its precepts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:632
verses.text: And a Jew might say the same to me if I professed to receive the Old Testament while I disregard its requirements.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:633
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:634
verses.text: Augustin replied: Faustus is not ashamed to repeat the same nonsense again and again.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:635
verses.text: But it is tiresome to repeat the same answers, though it is to repeat truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:636
verses.text: What Faustus says here has already been answered.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:637
verses.text: But if a Jew asks me why I profess to believe the Old Testament while I do not observe its precepts, my reply is this: The moral precepts of the law are observed by Christians; the symbolical precepts were properly observed during the time that the things now revealed were prefigured.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:638
verses.text: Accordingly, those observances, which I regard as no longer binding, I still look upon as a testimony, as I do also the carnal promises from which the Old Testament derives its name.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:639
verses.text: For although the gospel teaches me to hope for eternal blessings, I also find a confirmation of the gospel in those things which "happened to them for an example, and were written for our admonition, on whom the ends of the world are come".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:640
verses.text: So much for our answer to the Jews.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:641
verses.text: And now we have something to say to the Manich aeans.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:642
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:643
verses.text: By showing the way in which we regard the authority of the Old Testament we have answered the Jews, by whose question about our not observing the precepts Faustus thought we would be puzzled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:644
verses.text: But what answer can you give to the question, why you deceive simple-minded people by professing to believe in the New Testament, while you not only do not believe it, but assail it with all your force? It will be more difficult for you to answer this than it was for us to answer the Jews.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:645
verses.text: We hold all that is written in the Old Testament to be true, and enjoined by God for suitable times.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:646
verses.text: But in your inability to find a reason for not receiving what is written in the New Testament, you are obliged, as a last resource, to pretend that the passages are not genuine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:647
verses.text: This is the last gasp of a heretic in the clutches of truth; or rather it is the breath of corruption itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:648
verses.text: Faustus, however, confesses that the Old Testament as well as the New teaches him not to covet.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:649
verses.text: His own God could never have taught him this.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:650
verses.text: For if this God did not covet what belonged to another, why did he construct new worlds in the region of darkness? Perhaps the race of darkness first coveted his kingdom.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:651
verses.text: But this would be to imitate their bad example.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:652
verses.text: Perhaps the kingdom of light was previously of small extent, and war was desirable in order to enlarge it by conquest.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:653
verses.text: In that case, no doubt, there was covetousness, though the hostile race was allowed to begin the wars to justify the conquest.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:654
verses.text: If there had been no such desire, there was no necessity to extend the kingdom beyond its old limits into the region of the conquered foe.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:655
verses.text: If the Manich aeans would only learn from these Scriptures the moral precepts, one of which is, Do not covet, instead of taking offence at the symbolical precept, they would acknowledge in meekness and candor that they suited the time then present.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:656
verses.text: We do not covet what belongs to another, when we read in the Old Testament what "happened to them for examples, and was written for our admonition, on whom the ends of the world are come".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:657
verses.text: It is surely not coveting when a man reads what is written for his benefit.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:658
verses.text: Book XI.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:659
verses.text: Faustus quotes passages to show that the Apostle Paul abandoned belief in the incarnation, to which he earlier held.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:660
verses.text: Augustin shows that the apostle was consistent with himself in the utterances quoted.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:661
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:662
verses.text: Faustus said: Assuredly I believe the apostle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:663
verses.text: And yet I do not believe that the Son of God was born of the seed of David according to the flesh,  because I do not believe that God's apostle could contradict himself, and have one opinion about our Lord at one time, and another at another.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:664
verses.text: But, granting that he wrote this,—since you will not hear of anything being spurious in his writings,—it is not against us.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:665
verses.text: For this seems to be Paul's old belief about Jesus, when he thought, like everybody else, that Jesus was the son of David.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:666
verses.text: Afterwards, when he learned that this was false, he corrects himself; and in his Epistle to the Corinthians he says: "We know no man after the flesh; yea, though we have known Christ after the flesh, yet now henceforth know we Him no more".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:667
verses.text: Observe the difference between these two verses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:668
verses.text: In one he asserts that Jesus was the son of David after the flesh; in the other he says that now he knows no man after the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:669
verses.text: If Paul wrote both, it can only have been in the way I have stated.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:670
verses.text: In the next verse he adds: "Therefore, if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature; old things are passed away; behold, all things are become new".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:671
verses.text: The belief that Jesus was born of the seed of David according to the flesh is of this old transitory kind; whereas the faith which knows no man after the flesh is new and permanent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:672
verses.text: So, he says elsewhere: "When I was a child, I spoke as a child, I understood as a child, I thought as a child; but when I became a man, I put away childish things".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:673
verses.text: We are thus warranted in preferring the new and amended confession of Paul to his old and faulty one.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:674
verses.text: And if you hold by what is said in the Epistle to the Romans, why should not we hold by what is said to the Corinthians? But it is only by your insisting on the correctness of the text that we are made to represent Paul as building again the things which he destroyed, in spite of his own repudiation of such prevarication.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:675
verses.text: If the verse is Paul's, he has corrected himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:676
verses.text: If Paul should not be supposed to have written anything requiring correction, the verse is not his.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:677
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:678
verses.text: Augustin replied: As I said a little ago, when these men are beset by clear testimonies of Scripture, and cannot escape from their grasp, they declare that the passage is spurious.
