verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:679
verses.text: The declaration only shows their aversion to the truth, and their obstinacy in error.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:680
verses.text: Unable to answer these statements of Scripture, they deny their genuineness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:681
verses.text: But if this answer is admitted, or allowed to have any weight, it will be useless to quote any book or any passage against your errors.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:682
verses.text: It is one thing to reject the books themselves, and to profess no regard for their authority, as the Pagans reject our Scriptures, and the Jews the New Testament, and as we reject any books peculiar to your sect, or any other heretical sect, and also the apocryphal books, which are so called, not because of any mysterious regard paid to them, but because they are mysterious in their origin, and in the absence of clear evidence, have only some obscure presumption to rest upon; and it is another thing to say, This holy man wrote only the truth, and this is his epistle, but some verses are his, and some are not.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:683
verses.text: And then, when you are asked for a proof, instead of referring to more correct or more ancient manuscripts, or to a greater number, or to the original text, your reply is, This verse is his, because it makes for me; and this is not his, because it is against me.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:684
verses.text: Are you, then, the rule of truth? Can nothing be true that is against you? But what answer could you give to an opponent as insane as yourself, if he confronts you by saying, The passage in your favor is spurious, and that against you is genuine? Perhaps you will produce a book, all of which can be explained so as to support you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:685
verses.text: Then, instead of rejecting a passage, he will reply by condemning the whole book as spurious.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:686
verses.text: You have no resource against such an opponent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:687
verses.text: For all the testimony you can bring in favor of your book from antiquity or tradition will avail nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:688
verses.text: In this respect the testimony of the Catholic Church is conspicuous, as supported by a succession of bishops from the original seats of the apostles up to the present time, and by the consent of so many nations.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:689
verses.text: Accordingly, should there be a question about the text of some passage, as there are a few passages with various readings well known to students of the sacred Scriptures, we should first consult the manuscripts of the country where the religion was first taught; and if these still varied, we should take the text of the greater number, or of the more ancient.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:690
verses.text: And if any uncertainty remained, we should consult the original text.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:691
verses.text: This is the method employed by those who, in any question about the Scriptures, do not lose sight of the regard due to their authority, and inquire with the view of gaining information, not of raising disputes.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:692
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:693
verses.text: As regards the passage from Paul's epistle which teaches, in opposition to your heresy, that the Son of God was born of the seed of David, it is found in all manuscripts both new and old of all Churches, and in all languages.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:694
verses.text: So the profession which Faustus makes of believing the apostle is hypocritical.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:695
verses.text: Instead of saying, "Assuredly I believe," he should have said, Assuredly I do not believe, as he would have said if he had not wished to deceive people.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:696
verses.text: What part of his belief does he get from the apostle? Not the first man, of whom the apostle says that he is of the earth, earthy; and again, "The first man Adam was made a living soul".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:697
verses.text: Faustus' First Man is neither of the earth, earthy, nor made a living soul, but of the substance of God, and the same in essence as God; and this being is said to have mixed up with the race of darkness his members, or vesture, or weapons, that is, the five elements, which also are part of the substance of God, so that they became subject to confinement and pollution.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:698
verses.text: Nor does Faustus get from Paul his Second Man, of whom Paul says that He is from heaven, and that He is the last Adam, and a quickening spirit; and also that He was born of the seed of David after the flesh, that He was made of a woman, made under the law, that He might redeem them that were under the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:699
verses.text: Of Him Paul says to Timothy: "Remember that Jesus Christ, of the seed of David, was raised from the dead, according to my gospel".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:700
verses.text: And this resurrection he quotes as an example of our resurrection: "I delivered unto you first of all that which I also received, how that Christ died for our sins, according to the Scriptures; and that He was buried, and that He rose again the third day, according to the Scriptures".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:701
verses.text: And a little further on he draws an inference from this doctrine: "Now, if Christ be preached that He rose from the dead, how say some among you that there is no resurrection of the dead?"   Our professed believer in Paul believes nothing of all this.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:702
verses.text: He denies that Jesus was born of the seed of David, that He was made of a woman (by the word woman is not meant a wife in the common sense of the word, but merely one of the female sex, as in the book of Genesis, where it is said that God made a woman before she was brought to Adam ); he denies His death, His burial, and His resurrection.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:703
verses.text: He holds that Christ had not a mortal body, and therefore could not really die; and that the marks of His wounds which He showed to His disciples when He appeared to them alive after His resurrection, which Paul also mentions,  were not real.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:704
verses.text: He denies, too, that our mortal body will be raised again, changed into a spiritual body; as Paul teaches: "It is sown a natural body, it is raised a spiritual body".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:705
verses.text: To illustrate this distinction between the natural and the spiritual body, the apostle adds what I have quoted already about the first and the last Adam.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:706
verses.text: Then he goes on: "But this I say, brethren, that flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:707
verses.text: And to explain what he means by flesh and blood, that it is not the bodily substance, but corruption, which will not enter into the resurrection of the just, he immediately says, "Neither shall corruption inherit incorruption".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:708
verses.text: And in case any one should still suppose that it is not what is buried that is to rise again, but that it is as if one garment were laid aside and a better taken instead, he proceeds to show distinctly that the same body will be changed for the better, as the garments of Christ on the mount were not displaced, but transfigured: "Behold, I show you a mystery; we shall not all be changed, but we shall all rise".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:709
verses.text: Then he shows who are to be changed: "In a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trumpet: for the trumpet shall sound, and the dead shall rise incorruptible, and we shall be changed".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:710
verses.text: And if it should be said that it is not as regards our mortal and corruptible body, but as regards our soul, that we are to be changed, it should be observed that the apostle is not speaking of the soul, but of the body, as is evident from the question he starts with: "But some one will say, How are the dead raised, and with what body do they come?" So also, in the conclusion of his argument, he leaves no doubt of what he is speaking: "This corruptible must put on incorruption, and this mortal must put on immortality".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:711
verses.text: Faustus denies this; and the God whom Paul declares to be "immortal, incorruptible, to whom alone is glory and honor,"  he makes corruptible.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:712
verses.text: For in this monstrous and horrible fiction of theirs, the substance and nature of God was in danger of being wholly corrupted by the race of darkness, and to save the rest part actually was corrupted.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:713
verses.text: And to crown all this, he tries to deceive the ignorant who are not learned in the sacred Scriptures, by making this profession: I assuredly believe the Apostle Paul; when he ought to have said, I assuredly do not believe.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:714
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:715
verses.text: But Faustus has a proof to show that Paul changed his mind, and, in writing to the Corinthians, corrected what he had written to the Romans; or else that he never wrote the passage which appears as his, about Jesus Christ being born of the seed of David according to the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:716
verses.text: And what is this proof? If the passage, he says, in the Epistle to the Romans is true, "the Son of God, who was made of the seed of David according to the flesh," what he says to the Corinthians cannot be true, "Henceforth know we no man after the flesh; yea, though we have known Christ after the flesh, yet now henceforth know we Him no more".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:717
verses.text: We must therefore show that both these passages are true, and not opposed to one another.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:718
verses.text: The agreement of the manuscripts proves both to be genuine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:719
verses.text: In some Latin versions the word "born"  is used instead of "made,"  which is not so literal a rendering, but gives the same meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:720
verses.text: For both these translations, as well as the original, teach that Christ was of the seed of David after the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:721
verses.text: We must not for a moment suppose that Paul corrected himself on account of a change of opinion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:722
verses.text: Faustus himself felt the impropriety and impiety of such an explanation, and preferred to say that the passage was spurious, instead of that Paul was mistaken.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:723
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:724
verses.text: As regards our writings, which are not a rule of faith or practice, but only a help to edification, we may suppose that they contain some things falling short of the truth in obscure and recondite matters, and that these mistakes may or may not be corrected in subsequent treatises.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:725
verses.text: For we are of those of whom the apostle says: "And if ye be otherwise minded, God shall reveal even this unto you".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:726
verses.text: Such writings are read with the right of judgment, and without any obligation to believe.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:727
verses.text: In order to leave room for such profitable discussions of difficult questions, there is a distinct boundary line separating all productions subsequent to apostolic times from the authoritative canonical books of the Old and New Testaments.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:728
verses.text: The authority of these books has come down to us from the apostles through the successions of bishops and the extension of the Church, and, from a position of lofty supremacy, claims the submission of every faithful and pious mind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:729
verses.text: If we are perplexed by an apparent contradiction in Scripture, it is not allowable to say, The author of this book is mistaken; but either the manuscript is faulty, or the translation is wrong, or you have not understood.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:730
verses.text: In the innumerable books that have been written latterly we may sometimes find the same truth as in Scripture, but there is not the same authority.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:731
verses.text: Scripture has a sacredness peculiar to itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:732
verses.text: In other books the reader may form his own opinion, and perhaps, from not understanding the writer, may differ from him, and may pronounce in favor of what pleases him, or against what he dislikes.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:733
verses.text: In such cases, a man is at liberty to withhold his belief, unless there is some clear demonstration or some canonical authority to show that the doctrine or statement either must or may be true.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:734
verses.text: But in consequence of the distinctive peculiarity of the sacred writings, we are bound to receive as true whatever the canon shows to have been said by even one prophet, or apostle, or evangelist.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:735
verses.text: Otherwise, not a single page will be left for the guidance of human fallibility, if contempt for the wholesome authority of the canonical books either puts an end to that authority altogether, or involves it in hopeless confusion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:736
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:737
verses.text: With regard, then, to this apparent contradiction between the passage which speaks of the Son of God being of the seed of David, to the words, "Though we have known Christ after the flesh, yet now henceforth know we Him no more," even though both quotations were not from the writings of one apostle,—though one were from Paul, and the other from Peter, or Isaiah, or any other apostle or prophet,—such is the equality of canonical authority, that it would not be allowable to doubt of either.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:738
verses.text: For the utterances of Scripture, harmonious as if from the mouth of one man, commend themselves to the belief of the most accurate and clear-sighted piety, and demand for their discovery and confirmation the calmest intelligence and the most ingenious research.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:739
verses.text: In the case before us both quotations are from the canonical, that is, the genuine epistles of Paul.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:740
verses.text: We cannot say that the manuscript is faulty, for the best Latin translations substantially agree; or that the translations are wrong, for the best texts have the same reading.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:741
verses.text: So that, if any one is perplexed by the apparent contradiction, the only conclusion is that he does not understand.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:742
verses.text: Accordingly it remains for me to explain how both passages, instead of being contradictory, may be harmonized by one rule of sound faith.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:743
verses.text: The pious inquirer will find all perplexity removed by a careful examination.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:744
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:745
verses.text: That the Son of God was made man of the seed of David, is not only said in other places by Paul, but is taught elsewhere in sacred Scripture.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:746
verses.text: As regards the words, "Though we have known Christ after the flesh, yet now henceforth know we Him no more," the context shows what is the apostle's meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:747
verses.text: Here, or elsewhere, he views with an assured hope, as if it were already present and in actual possession, our future life, which is now fulfilled in our risen Head and Mediator, the man Christ Jesus.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:748
verses.text: This life will certainly not be after the flesh, even as Christ's life is now not after the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:749
verses.text: For by flesh the apostle here means not the substance of our bodies, in which sense the Lord used the word when, after His resurrection, He said, "Handle me, and see, for a spirit hath not flesh and bones, as ye see me have,"  but the corruption and mortality of flesh, which will then not be in us, as now it is not in Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:750
verses.text: The apostle uses the word flesh in the sense of corruption in the passage about the resurrection quoted before: "Flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God, neither shall corruption inherit incorruption".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:751
verses.text: So, after the event described in the next verse, "Behold, I show you a mystery; we shall all rise, but we shall not all be changed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:752
verses.text: In a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trump (for the trumpet shall sound); and the dead shall be raised incorruptible, and we shall be changed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:753
verses.text: For this corruptible must put on incorruption, and this mortal must put on immortality," —then flesh, in the sense of the substance of the body, will, after this change, no longer have flesh, in the sense of the corruption of mortality; and yet, as regards its own nature, it will be the same flesh, the same which rises and which is changed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:754
verses.text: What the Lord said after His resurrection is true, "Handle me, and see; for a spirit hath not flesh and bones, as ye see me have;" and what the apostle says is true, "Flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:755
verses.text: The first is said of the bodily substance, which exists as the subject of the change: the second is said of the corruption of the flesh, which will cease to exist, for, after its change, flesh will not be corrupted.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:756
verses.text: So, "we have known Christ after the flesh," that is, after the mortality of flesh, before His resurrection; "now henceforth we know Him no more," because, as the same apostle says, "Christ being risen from the dead, dieth no more, and death hath no more dominion over Him".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:757
verses.text: [19] The words, "we have known Christ after the flesh," strictly speaking, imply that Christ was after the flesh, for what never was cannot be known.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:758
verses.text: And it is not "we have supposed," but "we have known".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:759
verses.text: But not to insist on a word, in case some one should say that known is used in the sense of supposed, it is astonishing, if one could be surprised at want of sight in a blind man, that these blind people do not perceive that if what the apostle says about not knowing Christ after the flesh proves that Christ had not flesh, then what he says in the same place of not knowing any one henceforth after the flesh proves that all those here referred to had not flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:760
verses.text: For when he speaks of not knowing any one, he cannot intend to speak only of Christ; but in his realization of the future life with those who are to be changed at the resurrection, he says, "Henceforth we know no man after the flesh;" that is, we have such an assured hope of our future incorruption and immortality, that the thought of it makes us rejoice even now.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:761
verses.text: So he says elsewhere: "If ye then be risen with Christ, seek those things that are above, where Christ sitteth at the right hand of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:762
verses.text: Set your affections upon things above, and not on things on the earth".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:763
verses.text: It is true we have not yet risen as Christ has, but we are said to have risen with Him on account of the hope which we have in Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:764
verses.text: So again he says: "According to His mercy He saved us, by the washing of regeneration".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:765
verses.text: Evidently what we obtain in the washing of regeneration is not the salvation itself, but the hope of it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:766
verses.text: And yet, because this hope is certain, we are said to be saved, as if the salvation were already bestowed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:767
verses.text: Elsewhere it is said explicitly: "We groan within ourselves, waiting for the adoption, even the redemption of our body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:768
verses.text: For we are saved by hope.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:769
verses.text: But hope which is seen is not hope; for what a man seeth, why doth he yet hope for? But if we hope for what we see not, then do we with patience wait for it".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:770
verses.text: The apostle says not, "we are to be saved," but, "We are now saved," that is, in hope, though not yet in reality.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:771
verses.text: And in the same way it is in hope, though not yet in reality, that we now know no man after the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:772
verses.text: This hope is in Christ, in whom what we hope for as promised to us has already been fulfilled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:773
verses.text: He is risen, and death has no more dominion over Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:774
verses.text: Though we have known Him after the flesh, before His death, when there was in His body that mortality which the apostle properly calls flesh, now henceforth know we Him no more; for that mortal of His has now put on immortality, and His flesh, in the sense of mortality, no longer exists.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:775
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:776
verses.text: The context of the passage containing this clause of which our adversaries make such a bad use, brings out its real meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:777
verses.text: "The love of Christ," we read, "constrains us, because we thus judge, that if one died for all, then all died; and He died for all, that they which live should not henceforth live unto themselves, but to Him who died for them, and rose again.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:778
verses.text: Therefore henceforth know we no man after the flesh; and though we have known Christ after the flesh, yet now henceforth know we Him no more".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:779
verses.text: The words, "that they which live should not henceforth live unto themselves, but unto Him who died for them, and rose again," show plainly that the resurrection of Christ is the ground of the apostle's statement.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:780
verses.text: To live not to themselves, but to Him, must mean to live not after the flesh, in the hope of earthly and perishable goods, but after the spirit, in the hope of resurrection,—a resurrection already accomplished in Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:781
verses.text: Of those, then, for whom Christ died and rose again, and who live henceforth not to themselves, but to Him, the Apostle says that he knows no one after the flesh, on account of the hope of future immortality to which they were looking forward,—a hope which in Christ was already a reality.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:782
verses.text: So, though he has known Christ after the flesh, before His death, now he knows Him no more; for he knows that He has risen, and that death has no more dominion over Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:783
verses.text: And because in Christ we all are even now in hope, though not in reality, what Christ is, he adds: "Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature: old things are passed away; behold, all things are become new.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:784
verses.text: And all things are of God, who has reconciled us to Himself by Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:785
verses.text: What the new creature—that is, the people renewed by faith—hopes for regarding itself, it has already in Christ; and the hope will also hereafter be actually realized.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:786
verses.text: And, as regards this hope, old things have passed away, because we are no longer in the times of the Old Testament, expecting a temporal and carnal kingdom of God; and all things are become new, making the promise of the kingdom of heaven, where there shall be no death or corruption, the ground of our confidence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:787
verses.text: But in the resurrection of the dead it will not be as a matter of hope, but in reality, that old things shall pass away, when the last enemy, death, shall be destroyed; and all things shall become new when this corruptible has put on incorruption, and this mortal has put on immortality.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:788
verses.text: This has already taken place in Christ, whom Paul accordingly, in reality, knew no longer after the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:789
verses.text: But not yet in reality, but only in hope, did he know no one after the flesh of those for whom Christ died and rose again.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:790
verses.text: For, as he says to the Ephesians, we are already saved by grace.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:791
verses.text: The whole passage is to the purpose: "But God, who is rich in mercy, for His great love wherewith He loved us, even when we were dead in sins, hath quickened us together with Christ, by whose grace we have been saved".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:792
verses.text: The words, "hath quickened us together with Christ," correspond to what he said to the Corinthians, "that they which live should no longer live to themselves, but to Him that died for them and rose again".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:793
verses.text: And in the words, "by whose grace we have been saved," he speaks of the thing hoped for as already accomplished.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:794
verses.text: So, in the passage quoted above, he says explicitly, "We have been saved by hope".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:795
verses.text: And here he proceeds to specify future events as if already accomplished.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:796
verses.text: "And has raised us up together," he says, "and has made us sit together in heavenly places in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:797
verses.text: Christ is certainly already seated in heavenly places, but we not yet.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:798
verses.text: But as in an assured hope we already possess the future, he says that we sit in heavenly places, not in ourselves, but in Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:799
verses.text: And to show that it is still future, in case it should be thought that what is spoken of as accomplished in hope has been accomplished in reality, he adds, "that He might show in the ages to come the exceeding riches of His grace in His kindness towards us in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:800
verses.text: So also we must understand the following passage: "For when we were in the flesh, the motions of sins, which were by the law, did work in our members to bring forth fruit unto death".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:801
verses.text: He says, "when we were in the flesh," as if they were no longer in the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:802
verses.text: He means to say, when we were in the hope of fleshly things, referring to the time when the law, which can be fulfilled only by spiritual love, was in force, in order that by transgression the offence might abound, that after the revelation of the New Testament, grace and the gift by grace might much more abound.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:803
verses.text: And to the same effect he says elsewhere, "They which are in the flesh cannot please God;" and then, to show that he does not mean those not yet dead, he adds, "But ye are not in the flesh, but in the Spirit".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:804
verses.text: The meaning is, those who are in the hope of fleshly good cannot please God; but you are not in the hope of fleshly things, but in the hope of spiritual things, that is, of the kingdom of heaven, where the body itself, which now is natural, will, by the change in the resurrection, be, according to the capacity of its nature, a spiritual body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:805
verses.text: For "it is sown a natural body, it will be raised a spiritual body".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:806
verses.text: If, then, the apostle knew no one after the flesh of those who were said to be not in the flesh, because they were not in the hope of fleshly things, although they still were burdened with corruptible and mortal flesh; how much more significantly could he say of Christ that he no longer knew Him after the flesh, seeing that in the body of Christ what they hoped for had already been accomplished! Surely it is better and more reverential to examine the passages of sacred Scripture so as to discover their agreement with one another, than to accept some as true, and condemn others as false, whenever any difficulty occurs beyond the power of our weak intellect to solve.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:807
verses.text: As to the apostle in his childhood understanding as a child, this is said merely as an illustration.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:808
verses.text: And when he was a child he was not a spiritual man, as he was when he produced for the edification of the churches those writings which are not, as other books, merely a profitable study, but which authoritatively claim our belief as part of the ecclesiastical canon.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:809
verses.text: Book XII.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:810
verses.text: Faustus denies that the prophets predicted Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:811
verses.text: Augustin proves such prediction from the New Testament, and expounds at length the principal types of Christ in the Old Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:812
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:813
verses.text: Faustus said: Why do I not believe the prophets? Rather why do you believe them? On account, you will reply, of their prophecies about Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:814
verses.text: For my part, I have read the prophets with the most eager attention, and have found no such prophecies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:815
verses.text: And surely it shows a weak faith not to believe in Christ without proofs and testimonies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:816
verses.text: Indeed, you yourselves are accustomed to teach that Christian faith is so simple and absolute as not to admit of laborious investigations.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:817
verses.text: Why, then, should you destroy the simplicity of faith by buttressing it with evidences, and Jewish evidences too? Or if you are changing your opinion about evidences, what more trustworthy witness could you have than God Himself testifying to His own Son when He sent Him on earth,—not by a prophet or an interpreter,—by a voice immediately from heaven: "This is my beloved Son, believe Him?"  And again He testifies of Himself: "I came forth from the Father, and am come into the world;"  and in many similar passages.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:818
verses.text: When the Jews quarrelled with this testimony, saying "Thou bearest witness of thyself, thy witness is not true," He replied: "Although I bear witness of myself, my witness is true.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:819
verses.text: It is written in your law, The witness of two men is true.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:820
verses.text: I am one that bear witness of myself, and the Father who sent me beareth witness of me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:821
verses.text: He does not mention the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:822
verses.text: Again He appeals to the testimony of His own works, saying, "If ye believe not me, believe the works;"  not, "If ye believe not me, believe the prophets".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:823
verses.text: Accordingly we require no testimonies concerning our Saviour.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:824
verses.text: All we look for in the prophets is prudence and virtue, and a good example, which, you are well aware, are not to be found in the Jewish prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:825
verses.text: This, no doubt, explains your referring me at once to their predictions as a reason for believing them, without a word about their actions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:826
verses.text: This may be good policy, but it is not in harmony with the declaration of Scripture, that it is impossible to gather grapes from thorns, or figs from thistles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:827
verses.text: This may serve meanwhile as a brief and sufficient reply to the question, why we do not believe the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:828
verses.text: The fact that they did not prophesy of Christ is abundantly proved in the writings of our fathers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:829
verses.text: I shall only add this, that if the Hebrew prophets knew and preached Christ, and yet lived such vicious lives, what Paul says of the wise men among the Gentiles might be applied to them: "Though they knew God, they glorified Him not as God, nor were thankful; but they became vain in their imaginations, and their foolish heart was darkened".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:830
verses.text: You see the knowledge of great things is worth little, unless the life corresponds.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:831
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:832
verses.text: Augustin replied: The meaning of all this is, that the Hebrew prophets foretold nothing of Christ, and that, if they did, their predictions are of no use to us, and they themselves did not live suitably to the dignity of such prophecies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:833
verses.text: We must therefore prove the fact of the prophecies; and their use for the truth and steadfastness of our faith; and that the lives of the prophets were in harmony with their words.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:834
verses.text: In this threefold discussion, it would take a long time under the first head to quote from all the books the passages in which Christ may be shown to have been predicted.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:835
verses.text: Faustus' frivolity may be met effectually by the weight of one great authority.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:836
verses.text: Although Faustus does not believe the prophets, he professes to believe the apostles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:837
verses.text: Above, as if to satisfy the doubts of some opponent, he declares that he assuredly believes the Apostle Paul.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:838
verses.text: Let us then hear what Paul says of the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:839
verses.text: His words are: "Paul, a servant of Jesus Christ, called to be an apostle, separated unto the gospel of God, which He had promised before by His prophets in the holy Scriptures, concerning His Son, who was made of the seed of David according to the flesh".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:840
verses.text: What more does Faustus wish? Will he maintain that the apostle is speaking of some other prophets, and not of the Hebrew prophets? In any case, the gospel spoken of as promised was concerning the Son of God, who was made for Him of the seed of David according to the flesh: and to this gospel the apostle says that he was separated.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:841
verses.text: So that the Manich aean heresy is opposed to faith in the gospel, which teaches that the Son of God was made of the seed of David according to the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:842
verses.text: Besides, there are many passages where the apostle plainly testifies in behalf of the Hebrew prophets, with an authority by which the necks of these proud Manich aeans are broken.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:843
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:844
verses.text: "I speak the truth in Christ," says the apostle, "I lie not, my conscience bearing me witness in the Holy Ghost, that I have great heaviness and continual sorrow of heart.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:845
verses.text: For I could wish that myself were accursed from Christ, for my brethren, my kinsmen according to the flesh: who are Israelites; to whom pertaineth the adoption, and the glory, and the covenants, and the giving of the law, and the service and the promises; whose are the fathers, and of whom, as concerning the flesh, Christ came, who is over all, God blessed for ever".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:846
verses.text: Here is the most abundant and express testimony and the most solemn commendation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:847
verses.text: The adoption here spoken of is evidently through the Son of God; as the apostle says to the Galatians: "In the fullness of time, God sent forth His Son, made of a woman, made under the law, that He might redeem them that were under the law, that we might receive the adoption of sons".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:848
verses.text: And the glory spoken of is chiefly that of which he says in the same Epistle to the Romans: "What advantage hath the Jew? or what profit is there in circumcision? Much every way: chiefly, because unto them were committed the oracles of God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:849
verses.text: Can the Manich aeans tell us of any oracles of God committed to the Jews besides those of the Hebrew prophets? And why are the covenants said to belong especially to the Israelites, but because not only was the Old Testament given to them, but also the New was prefigured in the Old? Our opponents often display much ignorant ferocity in attacking the dispensation of the law given to the Israelites, not understanding that God wishes us to be not under the law, but under grace.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:850
verses.text: They are here answered by the apostle himself, who, in speaking of the advantages of the Jews, mentions this as one, that they had the giving of the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:851
verses.text: If the law had been bad, the apostle would not have referred to it in praise of the Jews.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:852
verses.text: And if Christ had not been preached by the law, the Lord Himself would not have said, "If ye believe Moses, ye would have believed me, for he wrote of me;"  nor would He have borne the testimony He did after His resurrection, saying, "All things must needs be fulfilled that were written in the law of Moses, and in the Prophets, and in the Psalms, concerning me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:853
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:854
verses.text: But because the Manich aeans preach another Christ, and not Him whom the apostles preached, but a false Christ of their own false contrivance, in imitation of whose falsehood they themselves speak lies, though they may perhaps be believed when they are not ashamed to profess to be the followers of a deceiver, that has befallen them which the apostle asserts of the unbelieving Jews: "When Moses is read, a veil is upon their heart".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:855
verses.text: Neither will this veil which keeps them from understanding Moses be taken away from them till they turn to Christ; not a Christ of their own making, but the Christ of the Hebrew prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:856
verses.text: For, as the apostle says, "When thou shalt turn to the Lord, the veil shall be taken away".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:857
verses.text: We cannot wonder that they do not believe in the Christ who rose from the dead, and who said, "All things must needs be fulfilled which were written in the law of Moses, and in the prophets, and in the Psalms, concerning me;" for this Christ has Himself told us what Abraham said to a hard-hearted rich man when he was in torment in hell, and asked Abraham to send some one to his brothers to teach them, that they might not come too into that place of torment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:858
verses.text: Abraham's reply was: "They have Moses and the prophets, let them hear them".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:859
verses.text: And when the rich man said that they would not believe unless some one rose from the dead, he received this most truthful answer: "If they hear not Moses and the prophets, neither will they believe even though one rose from the dead".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:860
verses.text: Wherefore, the Manich aeans will not hear Moses and the prophets, and so they do not believe Christ, though He rose from the dead.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:861
verses.text: Indeed, they do not even believe that Christ rose from the dead.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:862
verses.text: For how can they believe that He rose, when they do not believe that He died? For, again, how can they believe that He died, when they deny that He had a mortal body?  5.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:863
verses.text: But we reject those false teachers whose Christ is false, or rather, whose Christ never existed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:864
verses.text: For we have a Christ true and truthful, foretold by the prophets, preached by the apostles, who in innumerable places refer to the testimonies of the law and the prophets in support of their preaching.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:865
verses.text: Paul, in one short sentence, gives the right view of this subject.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:866
verses.text: "Now," he says, "the righteousness of God without the law is manifested, being witnessed by the law and the prophets".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:867
verses.text: What prophets, if not of Israel, to whom, as he expressly says, pertain the covenants, and the giving of the law, and the promises? And what promises, but about Christ? Elsewhere, speaking of Christ, he says concisely: "All the promises of God are in Him yea".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:868
verses.text: Paul tells me that the giving of the law pertained to the Israelites.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:869
verses.text: He also tells me that Christ is the end of the law for righteousness to every one that believeth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:870
verses.text: He also tells me that all the promises of God are in Christ yea.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:871
verses.text: And you tell me that the prophets of Israel foretold nothing of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:872
verses.text: Shall I believe the absurdities of Manich aeus relating a vain and long fable in opposition to Paul? or shall I believe Paul when he forewarns us: "If any man preach to you another gospel than that which we have preached, let him be accursed?"  6.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:873
verses.text: Our opponents may perhaps ask us to point out passages where Christ is predicted by the prophets of Israel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:874
verses.text: One would think they might be satisfied with the authority of the apostles, who declare that what we read in the writings of the Hebrew prophets was fulfilled in Christ, or with that of Christ Himself, who says that these things were written of Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:875
verses.text: Whoever is unable to point out the passages should lay the blame on his own ignorance; for the apostles and Christ and the sacred Scriptures are not chargeable with falsehood.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:876
verses.text: However, one instance out of many may be adduced.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:877
verses.text: The apostle, in the verses following the passage quoted above, says: "The word of God cannot fail.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:878
verses.text: For they are not all Israel which are of Israel; neither, because they are the seed of Abraham, are they all children: but, In Isaac shall thy seed be called: that is, they which are the children of the flesh, these are not the children of God; but the children of promise are counted for the seed".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:879
verses.text: What can our opponent say against this, in view of the declaration made to Abraham: "In thy seed shall all the nations of the earth be blessed?" At the time when the apostle gave the following exposition of this promise, "To Abraham and to his seed were the promises made.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:880
verses.text: He saith not, To seed, as of many, but as of one, To thy seed, which is Christ,"  a doubt on this point might then have been less inexcusable, for at that time all nations had not yet believed on Christ, who is preached as of the seed of Abraham.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:881
verses.text: But now that we see the fulfillment of what we read in the ancient prophecy,—now that all nations are actually blessed in the seed of Abraham, to whom it was said thousands of years ago, "In thy seed shall all nations be blessed,"—it is mere obstinate folly to try to bring in another Christ, not of the seed of Abraham, or to hold that there are no predictions of Christ in the prophetical books of the children of Abraham.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:882
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:883
verses.text: To enumerate all the passages in the Hebrew prophets referring to our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, would exceed the limits of a volume, not to speak of the brief replies of which this treatise consists.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:884
verses.text: The whole contents of these Scriptures are either directly or indirectly about Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:885
verses.text: Often the reference is allegorical or enigmatical, perhaps in a verbal allusion, or in a historical narrative, requiring diligence in the student, and rewarding him with the pleasure of discovery.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:886
verses.text: Other passages, again, are plain; for, without the help of what is clear, we could not understand what is obscure.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:887
verses.text: And even the figurative passages, when brought together, will be found so harmonious in their testimony to Christ as to put to shame the obtuseness of the sceptic.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:888
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:889
verses.text: In the creation God finished His works in six days, and rested on the seventh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:890
verses.text: The history of the world contains six periods marked by the dealings of God with men.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:891
verses.text: The first period is from Adam to Noah; the second, from Noah to Abraham; the third, from Abraham to David; the fourth, from David to the captivity in Babylon; the fifth, from the captivity to the advent of lowliness of our Lord Jesus Christ; the sixth is now in progress, and will end in the coming of the exalted Saviour to judgment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:892
verses.text: What answers to the seventh day is the rest of the saints,—not in this life, but in another, where the rich man saw Lazarus at rest while he was tormented in hell; where there is no evening, because there is no decay.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:893
verses.text: On the sixth day, in Genesis, man is formed after the image of God; in the sixth period of the world there is the clear discovery of our transformation in the renewing of our mind, according to the image of Him who created us, as the apostle says.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:894
verses.text: [19] As a wife was made for Adam from his side while he slept, the Church becomes the property of her dying Saviour, by the sacrament of the blood which flowed from His side after His death.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:895
verses.text: The woman made out of her husband's side is called Eve, or Life, and the mother of living beings; and the Lord says in the Gospel: "Except a man eat my flesh and drink my blood, he has no life in him".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:896
verses.text: The whole narrative of Genesis, in the most minute details, is a prophecy of Christ and of the Church with reference either to the good Christians or to the bad.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:897
verses.text: There is a significance in the words of the apostle when he calls Adam "the figure of Him that was to come;"  and when he says, "A man shall leave his father and mother, and shall cleave to his wife, and they two shall be one flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:898
verses.text: This is a great mystery; but I speak concerning Christ and the Church".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:899
verses.text: This points most obviously to the way in which Christ left His Father; for "though He was in the form of God, and thought it not robbery to be equal with God, He emptied Himself, and took upon Him the form of a servant".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:900
verses.text: And so, too, He left His mother, the synagogue of the Jews which cleaved to the carnality of the Old Testament, and was united to the Church His holy bride, that in the peace of the New Testament they two might be one flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:901
verses.text: For though with the Father He was God, by whom we were made, He became in the flesh partaker of our nature, that we might become the body of which He is the head.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:902
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:903
verses.text: As Cain's sacrifice of the fruit of the ground is rejected, while Abel's sacrifice of his sheep and the fat thereof is accepted, so the faith of the New Testament praising God in the harmless service of grace is preferred to the earthly observances of the Old Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:904
verses.text: For though the Jews were right in practising these things, they were guilty of unbelief in not distinguishing the time of the New Testament when Christ came, from the time of the Old Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:905
verses.text: God said to Cain, "If thou offerest well, yet if thou dividest not well, thou hast sinned".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:906
verses.text: If Cain had obeyed God when He said, "Be content, for to thee shall be its reference, and thou shalt rule over it," he would have referred his sin to himself, by taking the blame of it, and confessing it to God; and so assisted by supplies of grace, he would have ruled over his sin, instead of acting as the servant of sin in killing his innocent brother.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:907
verses.text: So also the Jews, of whom all these things are a figure, if they had been content, instead of being turbulent, and had acknowledged the time of salvation through the pardon of sins by grace, and heard Christ saying, "They that are whole need not a physician, but they that are sick; I came not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance;"  and, "Every one that committeth sin is the servant of sin;" and, "If the Son make you free, ye shall be free indeed," —they would in confession have referred their sin to themselves, saying to the Physician, as it is written in the Psalm, "I said, Lord, be merciful to me; heal my soul, for I have sinned against Thee".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:908
verses.text: And being made free by the hope of grace, they would have ruled over sin as long as it continued in their mortal body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:909
verses.text: But now, being ignorant of God's righteousness, and wishing to establish a righteousness of their own, proud of the works of the law, instead of being humbled on account of their sins, they have not been content; and in subjection to sin reigning in their mortal body, so as to make them obey it in the lusts thereof, they have stumbled on the stone of stumbling, and have been inflamed with hatred against him whose works they grieved to see accepted by God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:910
verses.text: The man who was born blind, and had been made to see, said to them, "We know that God heareth not sinners; but if any man serve Him, and do His will, him He heareth;"  as if he had said, God regardeth not the sacrifice of Cain, but he regards the sacrifice of Abel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:911
verses.text: Abel, the younger brother, is killed by the elder brother; Christ, the head of the younger people, is killed by the elder people of the Jews.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:912
verses.text: Abel dies in the field; Christ dies on Calvary.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:913
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:914
verses.text: God asks Cain where his brother is, not as if He did not know, but as a judge asks a guilty criminal.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:915
verses.text: Cain replies that he knows not, and that he is not his brother's keeper.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:916
verses.text: And what answer can the Jews give at this day, when we ask them with the voice of God, that is, of the sacred Scriptures, about Christ, except that they do not know the Christ that we speak of? Cain's ignorance was pretended, and the Jews are deceived in their refusal of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:917
verses.text: Moreover, they would have been in a sense keepers of Christ, if they had been willing to receive and keep the Christian faith.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:918
verses.text: For the man who keeps Christ in his heart does not ask, like Cain, Am I my brother's keeper? Then God says to Cain, "What hast thou done? The voice of thy brother's blood crieth unto me from the ground".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:919
verses.text: So the voice of God in the Holy Scriptures accuses the Jews.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:920
verses.text: For the blood of Christ has a loud voice on the earth, when the responsive Amen of those who believe in Him comes from all nations.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:921
verses.text: This is the voice of Christ's blood, because the clear voice of the faithful redeemed by His blood is the voice of the blood itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:922
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:923
verses.text: Then God says to Cain: "Thou art cursed from the earth, which hath opened its mouth to receive thy brother's blood at thy hand.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:924
verses.text: For thou shalt till the earth, and it shall no longer yield unto thee its strength.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:925
verses.text: A mourner and an abject shalt thou be on the earth".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:926
verses.text: It is not, Cursed is the earth, but, Cursed art thou from the earth, which hath opened its mouth to receive thy brother's blood at thy hand.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:927
verses.text: So the unbelieving people of the Jews is cursed from the earth, that is, from the Church, which in the confession of sins has opened its mouth to receive the blood shed for the remission of sins by the hand of the people that would not be under grace, but under the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:928
verses.text: And this murderer is cursed by the Church; that is, the Church admits and avows the curse pronounced by the apostle: "Whoever are of the works of the law are under the curse of the law".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:929
verses.text: Then, after saying, Cursed art thou from the earth, which has opened its mouth to receive thy brother's blood at thy hand, what follows is not, For thou shalt till it, but, Thou shalt till the earth, and it shall not yield to thee its strength.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:930
verses.text: The earth he is to till is not necessarily the same as that which opened its mouth to receive his brother's blood at his hand.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:931
verses.text: From this earth he is cursed, and so he tills an earth which shall no longer yield to him its strength.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:932
verses.text: That is, the Church admits and avows the Jewish people to be cursed, because after killing Christ they continue to till the ground of an earthly circumcision, an earthly Sabbath, an earthly passover, while the hidden strength or virtue of making known Christ, which this tilling contains, is not yielded to the Jews while they continue in impiety and unbelief, for it is revealed in the New Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:933
verses.text: While they will not turn to God, the veil which is on their minds in reading the Old Testament is not taken away.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:934
verses.text: This veil is taken away only by Christ, who does not do away with the reading of the Old Testament, but with the covering which hides its virtue.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:935
verses.text: So, at the crucifixion of Christ, the veil was rent in twain, that by the passion of Christ hidden mysteries might be revealed to believers who turn to Him with a mouth opened in confession to drink His blood.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:936
verses.text: In this way the Jewish people, like Cain, continue tilling the ground, in the carnal observance of the law, which does not yield to them its strength, because they do not perceive in it the grace of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:937
verses.text: So too, the flesh of Christ was the ground from which by crucifying Him the Jews produced our salvation, for He died for our offences.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:938
verses.text: But this ground did not yield to them its strength, for they were not justified by the virtue of His resurrection, for He arose again for our justification.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:939
verses.text: As the apostle says: "He was crucified in weakness, but He liveth by the power of God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:940
verses.text: This is the power of that ground which is unknown to the ungodly and unbelieving.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:941
verses.text: When Christ rose, He did not appear to those who had crucified Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:942
verses.text: So Cain was not allowed to see the strength of the ground which he tilled to sow his seed in it; as God said, "Thou shalt till the ground, and it shall no longer yield unto thee its strength".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:943
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:944
verses.text: "Groaning and trembling shalt thou be on the earth".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:945
verses.text: Here no one can fail to see that in every land where the Jews are scattered they mourn for the loss of their kingdom, and are in terrified subjection to the immensely superior number of Christians.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:946
verses.text: So Cain answered, and said: "My case is worse, if Thou drivest me out this day from the face of the earth, and from Thy face shall I be hid, and I shall be a mourner and an outcast on the earth; and it shall be that every one that findeth me shall slay me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:947
verses.text: Here he groans indeed in terror, lest after losing his earthly possession he should suffer the death of the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:948
verses.text: This he calls a worse case than that of the ground not yielding to him its strength, or than that of spiritual death.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:949
verses.text: For his mind is carnal; for he thinks little of being hid from the face of God, that is, of being under the anger of God, were it not that he may be found and slain.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:950
verses.text: This is the carnal mind that tills the ground, but does not obtain its strength.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:951
verses.text: To be carnally minded is death; but he, in ignorance of this, mourns for the loss of his earthly possession, and is in terror of bodily death.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:952
verses.text: But what does God reply? "Not so," He says; "but whosoever shall kill Cain, vengeance shall be taken on him sevenfold".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:953
verses.text: That is, It is not as thou sayest; not by bodily death shall the ungodly race of carnal Jews perish.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:954
verses.text: For whoever destroys them in this way shall suffer sevenfold vengeance, that is, shall bring upon himself the sevenfold penalty under which the Jews lie for the crucifixion of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:955
verses.text: So to the end of the seven days of time, the continued preservation of the Jews will be a proof to believing Christians of the subjection merited by those who, in the pride of their kingdom, put the Lord to death.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:956
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:957
verses.text: "And the Lord God set a mark upon Cain, lest any one finding him should slay him".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:958
verses.text: It is a most notable fact, that all the nations subjugated by Rome adopted the heathenish ceremonies of the Roman worship; while the Jewish nation, whether under Pagan or Christian monarchs, has never lost the sign of their law, by which they are distinguished from all other nations and peoples.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:959
verses.text: No emperor or monarch who finds under his government the people with this mark kills them, that is, makes them cease to be Jews, and as Jews to be separate in their observances, and unlike the rest of the world.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:960
verses.text: Only when a Jew comes over to Christ, he is no longer Cain, nor goes out from the presence of God, nor dwells in the land of Nod, which is said to mean commotion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:961
verses.text: Against this evil of commotion the Psalmist prays, "Suffer not my feet to be moved;"  and again, "Let not the hands of the wicked remove me;"  and, "Those that trouble me will rejoice when I am moved:"  and, "The Lord is at my right hand, that I should not be moved;"  and so in innumerable places.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:962
verses.text: This evil comes upon those who leave the presence of God, that is, His loving-kindness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:963
verses.text: Thus the Psalmist says, "I said in my prosperity, I shall never be moved".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:964
verses.text: But observe what follows, "Lord, by Thy favor Thou hast given strength to my honor; Thou didst hide Thy face, and I was troubled;"  which teaches us that not in itself, but by participation in the light of God, can any soul possess beauty, or honor, or strength.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:965
verses.text: The Manich aeans should think of this, to keep them from the blasphemy of identifying themselves with the nature and substance of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:966
verses.text: But they cannot think, because they are not content.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:967
verses.text: The Sabbath of the heart they are strangers to.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:968
verses.text: If they were content, as Cain was told to be, they would refer their sin to themselves; that is, they would lay the blame on themselves, and not on a race of darkness that no one ever heard of, and so by the grace of God they would prevail over their sin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:969
verses.text: But now the Manich aeans, and all who oppose the truth by their various heresies, leave the presence of God, like Cain and the scattered Jews, and inhabit the land of commotion, that is, of carnal disquietude, instead of the enjoyment of God, that is instead of Eden, which is interpreted Feasting, where Paradise was planted.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:970
verses.text: But not to depart too much from the argument of this treatise I must limit myself to a few, short remarks under this head.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:971
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:972
verses.text: Omitting therefore many passages in these Books where Christ may be found, but which require longer explanation and proof, although the most hidden meanings are the sweetest, convincing testimony may be obtained from the enumeration of such things as the following:—That Enoch, the seventh from Adam, pleased God, and was translated, as there is to be a seventh day of rest into which all will be translated who, during the sixth day of the world's history, are created anew by the incarnate Word.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:973
verses.text: That Noah, with his family is saved by water and wood, as the family of Christ is saved by baptism, as representing the suffering of the cross.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:974
verses.text: That this ark is made of beams formed in a square, as the Church is constructed of saints prepared unto every good work: for a square stands firm on any side.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:975
verses.text: That the length is six times the breadth, and ten times the height, like a human body, to show that Christ appeared in a human body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:976
verses.text: That the breadth reaches to fifty cubits; as the apostle says, "Our heart is enlarged,"  that is, with spiritual love, of which he says again, "The love of God is shed abroad in our heart by the Holy Ghost, which is given unto us".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:977
verses.text: For in the fiftieth day after His resurrection, Christ sent His Holy Spirit to enlarge the hearts of His disciples.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:978
verses.text: That it is three hundred cubits long, to make up six times fifty; as there are six periods in the history of the world during which Christ has never ceased to be preached,—in five foretold by the prophets, and in the sixth proclaimed in the gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:979
verses.text: That it is thirty cubits high, a tenth part of the length; because Christ is our height, who in his thirtieth year gave His sanction to the doctrine of the gospel, by declaring that He came not to destroy the law, but to fulfil it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:980
verses.text: Now the ten commandments are to be the heart of the law; and so the length of the ark is ten times thirty.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:981
verses.text: Noah himself, too, was the tenth from Adam.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:982
verses.text: That the beams of the ark are fastened within and without with pitch, to signify by compact union the forbearance of love, which keeps the brotherly connection from being impaired, and the bond of peace from being broken by the offences which try the Church either from without or from within.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:983
verses.text: For pitch is a glutinous substance, of great energy and force, to represent the ardor of love which, with great power of endurance, beareth all things in the maintenance of spiritual communion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:984
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:985
verses.text: That all kinds of animals are inclosed in the ark; as the Church contains all nations, which was also set forth in the vessel shown to Peter.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:986
verses.text: That clean and unclean animals are in the ark; as good and bad take part in the sacraments of the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:987
verses.text: That the clean are in sevens, and the unclean in twos; not because the bad are fewer than the good, but because the good preserve the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace; and the Spirit is spoken of in Scripture as having a sevenfold operation, as being "the Holy Spirit of wisdom and understanding, of counsel and might, of knowledge and piety, and of the fear of God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:988
verses.text: So also the number fifty, which is connected with the advent of the Holy Spirit, is made up of seven times seven, and one over; whence it is said, "Endeavoring to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:989
verses.text: The bad, again, are in twos, as being easily divided, from their tendency to schism.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:990
verses.text: That Noah, counting his family, was the eighth; because the hope of our resurrection has appeared in Christ, who rose from the dead on the eighth day, that is, on the day after the seventh, or Sabbath day.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:991
verses.text: This day was the third from His passion; but in the ordinary reckoning of days, it is both the eighth and the first.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:992
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:993
verses.text: That the whole ark together is finished in a cubit above; as the Church, the body of Christ gathered into unity, is raised to perfection.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:994
verses.text: So Christ says in the Gospel: "He that gathereth not with me, scattereth".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:995
verses.text: That the entrance is on the side; as no man enters the Church except by the sacrament of the remission of sins which flowed from Christ's opened side.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:996
verses.text: That the lower spaces of the ark are divided into two and three chambers: as the multitude of all nations in the Church is divided into two, as circumcised and uncircumcised; or into three, as descended from the three sons of Noah.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:997
verses.text: And these parts of the ark are called lower, because in this earthly state there is a difference of races, and above we are completed in one.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:998
verses.text: Above there is no diversity; for Christ is all and in all, finishing us, as it were, in one cubit above with heavenly unity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:999
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1000
verses.text: That the flood came seven days after Noah entered the ark; as we are baptized in the hope of the future rest, which was denoted by the seventh day.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1001
verses.text: That all flesh on the face of the earth, outside the ark, was destroyed by the flood; as, beyond the communion of the Church, though the water of baptism is the same, it is efficacious only for destruction, and not for salvation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1002
verses.text: That it rained for forty days and forty nights; as the sacrament of heavenly baptism washes away all the guilt of the sins against the ten commandments throughout all the four quarters of the world (four times ten is forty), whether that guilt has been contracted in the day of prosperity or in the night of adversity.
