verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1003
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1004
verses.text: That Noah was five hundred years old when God told him to make the ark, and six hundred when he entered the ark; which shows that the ark was made during one hundred years, which seem to correspond to the years of an age of the world.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1005
verses.text: So the sixth age is occupied with the construction of the Church by the preaching of the gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1006
verses.text: The man who avails himself of the offer of salvation is made like a square beam, fitted for every good work, and forms part of the sacred fabric.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1007
verses.text: Again, it was the second month of the six hundredth year when Noah entered the ark, and in two months there are sixty days; so that here, as in every multiple of six, we have the number denoting the sixth age.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1008
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1009
verses.text: That mention is made of the twenty seventh day of the month; as we have already seen the significance of the square in the beams.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1010
verses.text: Here especially it is significant; for as twenty-seven is the cube of three, there is a trinity in the means by which we are, as it were, squared, or fitted for every good work.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1011
verses.text: By the memory we remember God; by the understanding we know Him; by the will we love Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1012
verses.text: That in the seventh month the ark rested; reminding us again of the seventh day of rest.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1013
verses.text: And here again, to denote the perfection of those at rest, the twenty-seventh day of the month is mentioned for the second time.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1014
verses.text: So what is promised in hope is realized in experience.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1015
verses.text: There is here a combination of seven and eight; for the water rose fifteen cubits above the mountains, pointing to a profound mystery in baptism,—the sacrament of our regeneration.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1016
verses.text: For the seventh day of rest is connected with the eighth of resurrection.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1017
verses.text: For when the saints receive again their bodies after the rest of the intermediate state, the rest will not cease; but rather the whole man, body and soul united, renewed in the immortal health, will attain to the realization of his hope in the enjoyment of eternal life.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1018
verses.text: Thus the sacrament of baptism, like the waters of Noah, rises above all the wisdom of the proud.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1019
verses.text: Seven and eight are also combined in the number of one hundred and fifty, made up of seventy and eighty, which was the number of days during which the water prevailed, pointing out the deep import of baptism in consecrating the new man to hold the faith of rest and resurrection.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1020
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1021
verses.text: That the raven sent out after forty days did not return, being either prevented by the water or attracted by some floating carcase; as men defiled by impure desire, and therefore eager for things outside in the world, are either baptized, or are led astray into the company of those to whom, as they are outside the ark, that is, outside the Church, baptism is destructive.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1022
verses.text: That the dove when sent forth found no rest, and returned; as in the New Testament rest is not promised to the saints in this world.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1023
verses.text: The dove was sent forth after forty days, a period denoting the length of human life.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1024
verses.text: When again sent forth after seven days, denoting the sevenfold operation of the Spirit, the dove brought back a fruitful olive branch; as some even who are baptized outside of the Church, if not destitute of the fatness of charity, may come after all, as it were in the evening, and be brought into the one communion by the mouth of the dove in the kiss of peace.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1025
verses.text: That, when again sent forth after seven days, the dove did not return; as, at the end of the world, the rest of the saints shall no longer be in the sacrament of hope, as now, while in the communion of the Church, they drink what flowed from the side of Christ, but in the perfection of eternal safety, when the kingdom shall be delivered up to God and the Father, and when, in that unclouded contemplation of unchangeable truth, we shall no longer need natural symbols.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1026
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1027
verses.text: There are many other points which we cannot take notice of even in this cursory manner.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1028
verses.text: Why in the six hundred and first year of Noah's life—that is, after six hundred years were completed—the covering of the ark is removed, and the hidden mystery, as it were, disclosed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1029
verses.text: Why the earth is said to have dried on the twenty-seventh day of the second month; as if the number fifty-seven denoted the completion of the rite of baptism.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1030
verses.text: For the twenty-seventh day of the second month is the fifty-seventh day of the year; and the number fifty-seven is seven times eight, which are the numbers of the spirit and the body, with one over, to denote the bond of unity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1031
verses.text: Why they leave the ark together, though they entered separately.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1032
verses.text: For it is said: "Noah went in, and his sons, and his wife, and his sons' wives with him, into the ark;" the men and the women being spoken of separately; which denotes the time when the flesh lusteth against the spirit, and the spirit against the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1033
verses.text: But they go forth, Noah and his wife, and his sons and their wives,—the men and women together.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1034
verses.text: For in the end of the world, and in the resurrection of the just, the body will be united to the spirit in perfect harmony, undisturbed by the wants and the passions of mortality.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1035
verses.text: Why, after leaving the ark, only clean animals are offered in sacrifice to God, though both clean and unclean were in the ark.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1036
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1037
verses.text: Then, again, it is significant that when God speaks to Noah, and begins anew, as it were, in order, by repetition in various forms, to draw attention to the figure of the Church, the sons of Noah are blessed, and told to replenish the earth, and all animals are given to them for food; as was said to Peter of the vessel, "Kill and eat".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1038
verses.text: That they are told to pour out the blood when they eat; that the former life may not be kept shut up in the conscience, but may be, as it were, poured out in confession.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1039
verses.text: That God makes the bow, which appears in the clouds only when the sun shines, the sign of His covenant with men, and with every living thing, that He will not destroy them with a flood; as those do not perish by the flood, in separation from the Church, who in the clouds of God—that is, in the prophets and in all the sacred Scriptures—discern the glory of Christ, instead of seeking their own glory.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1040
verses.text: The worshippers of the sun, however, need not pride themselves on this; for they must understand that the sun, as also a lion, a lamb, and a stone, are used as types of Christ because they have some resemblance, not because they are of the same substance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1041
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1042
verses.text: Again, the sufferings of Christ from His own nation are evidently denoted by Noah being drunk with the wine of the vineyard he planted, and his being uncovered in his tent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1043
verses.text: For the mortality of Christ's flesh was uncovered, to the Jews a stumbling-block, and to the Greeks foolishness; but to them that are called, both Jews and Greeks, both Shem and Japhet, the power of God and the wisdom of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1044
verses.text: Because the foolishness of God is wiser than men, and the weakness of God is stronger than men.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1045
verses.text: Moreover, the two sons, the eldest and the youngest, carrying the garment backwards, are a figure of the two peoples, and the sacrament of the past and completed passions of the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1046
verses.text: They do not see the nakedness of their father, because they do not consent to Christ's death; and yet they honor it with a covering, as knowing whence they were born.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1047
verses.text: The middle son is the Jewish people, for they neither held the first place with the apostles, nor believed subsequently with the Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1048
verses.text: They saw the nakedness of their father, because they consented to Christ's death; and they told it to their brethren outside, for what was hidden in the prophets was disclosed by the Jews.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1049
verses.text: And thus they are the servants of their brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1050
verses.text: For what else is this nation now but a desk for the Christians, bearing the law and the prophets, and testifying to the doctrine of the Church, so that we honor in the sacrament what they disclose in the letter?  24.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1051
verses.text: Again, every one must be impressed, and be either enlightened or confirmed in the faith, by the blessing of the two sons who honored the nakedness of their father, though they turned away their faces, as displeased with the evil done by the vine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1052
verses.text: "Blessed," he says, "be the Lord God of Shem".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1053
verses.text: For although God is the God of all nations, even the Gentiles acknowledge Him to be in a peculiar sense the God of Israel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1054
verses.text: And how is this to be explained but by the blessing of Japhet? The occupation of all the world by the Church among the Gentiles was exactly foretold in the words: "Let God enlarge Japhet, and let him dwell in the tents of Shem".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1055
verses.text: That is for the Manich aean to attend to.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1056
verses.text: You see what the state of the world actually is.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1057
verses.text: The very thing that you are astonished and grieved at in us is this, that God is enlarging Japhet.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1058
verses.text: Is He not dwelling in the tents of Shem?—that is, in the churches built by the apostles, the sons of the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1059
verses.text: Hear what Paul says to the believing Gentiles: "Ye were at that time without Christ, being aliens from the commonwealth of Israel, and strangers from the covenants; having no hope of the promise, and without God in the world".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1060
verses.text: In these words there is a description of the state of Japhet before he dwelt in the tents of Shem.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1061
verses.text: But observe what follows: "Now then;" he says, "ye are no more strangers and foreigners, but fellow-citizens with the saints, and of the household of God, being built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Jesus Christ Himself being the chief corner-stone".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1062
verses.text: Here we have Japhet enlarged, and dwelling in the tents of Shem.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1063
verses.text: These testimonies are taken from the epistles of the apostles, which you yourselves acknowledge, and read, and profess to follow.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1064
verses.text: You occupy an unhappy middle position in a building of which Christ is not the chief corner-stone.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1065
verses.text: For you do not belong to the wall of those who, like the apostles, being of the circumcision, believed in Christ; nor to the wall of those who, being of the uncircumcision, like all the Gentiles, are joined in the unity of faith, as in the fellowship of the corner-stone.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1066
verses.text: However, all who accept and read any books of our canon in which Christ is spoken of as having been born and having suffered in the flesh, and who do not unite with us in a common veiling with the sacrament of the mortality, uncovered by the passion, but without the knowledge of piety and charity make known that from which we all are born,—although they differ among themselves, whether as Jews and heretics, or as heretics of one kind or other,—are still all useful to the Church, as being all alike servants, either in bearing witness to or in proving some truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1067
verses.text: For of heretics it is said: "There must be heresies, that those who are approved among you may be manifested".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1068
verses.text: Go on, then, with your objections to the Old Testament Scriptures! Go on, ye servants of Ham! You have despised the flesh from which you were born when uncovered.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1069
verses.text: For you could not have called yourselves Christians unless Christ had come into the world, as foretold by the prophets, and had drunk of His own vine that cup which could not pass from Him, and had slept in His passion, as in the drunkenness of the folly which is wiser than men; and so, in the hidden counsel of God, the disclosure had been made of that infirmity of mortal flesh which is stronger than men.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1070
verses.text: For unless the Word of God had taken on Himself this infirmity, the name of Christian, in which you also glory, would not exist in the earth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1071
verses.text: Go on, then, as I have said.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1072
verses.text: Declare in mockery what we may honor with reverence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1073
verses.text: Let the Church use you as her servants to make manifest those members who are approved.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1074
verses.text: So particular are the predictions of the prophets regarding the state and the sufferings of the Church, that we can find a place even for you in what is said of the destructive error by which the reprobate are to perish, while the approved are to be manifested.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1075
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1076
verses.text: You say that Christ was not foretold by the prophets of Israel, when, in fact, their Scriptures teem with such predictions, if you would only examine them carefully, instead of treating them with levity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1077
verses.text: Who in Abraham leaves his country and kindred that he may become rich and prosperous among strangers, but He who, leaving the land and country of the Jews, of whom He was born in the flesh, is now extending His power, as we see, among the Gentiles? Who in Isaac carried the wood for His own sacrifice, but He who carried His own cross? Who is the ram for sacrifice, caught by the horns in a.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1078
verses.text: bush, but He who was fastened to the cross as an offering for us?  26.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1079
verses.text: Who in the angel striving with Jacob, on the one hand is constrained to give him a blessing, as the weaker to the stronger, the conquered to the conqueror, and on the other hand puts his thigh-bone out of joint, but He who, when He suffered the people of Israel to prevail against Him, blessed those among them who believed, while the multitude, like Jacob's thigh-bone, halted in their carnality? Who is the stone placed under Jacob's head, but Christ the head of man? And in its anointing the very name of Christ is expressed, for, as all know, Christ means anointed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1080
verses.text: Christ refers to this in the Gospel, and declares it to be a type of Himself, when He said of Nathanael that he was an Israelite indeed, in whom was no guile, and when Nathanael, resting his head, as it were, on this Stone, or on Christ, confessed Him as the Son of God and the King of Israel anointing the Stone by his confession, in which he acknowledged Jesus to be Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1081
verses.text: On this occasion the Lord made appropriate mention of what Jacob saw in his dream "Verily I say unto you, Ye shall see heaven opened, and the angels of God ascending and descending upon the Son of man".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1082
verses.text: This Jacob saw, who in the blessing was called Israel, when he had the stone for a pillow, and had the vision of the ladder reaching from earth to heaven, on which the angels of God were ascending and descending.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1083
verses.text: The angels denote the evangelists, or preachers of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1084
verses.text: They ascend when they rise above the created universe to describe the supreme majesty of the divine nature of Christ as being in the beginning God with God, by whom all things were made.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1085
verses.text: They descend to tell of His being made of a woman, made under the law, that He might redeem them that were under the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1086
verses.text: Christ is the ladder reaching from earth to heaven, or from the carnal to the spiritual: for by His assistance the carnal ascend to spirituality; and the spiritual may be said to descend to nourish the carnal with milk when they cannot speak to them as to spiritual, but as to carnal.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1087
verses.text: There is thus both an ascent and a descent upon the Son of man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1088
verses.text: For the Son of man is above as our head, being Himself the Saviour; and He is below in His body, the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1089
verses.text: He is the ladder, for He says, "I am the way".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1090
verses.text: We ascend to Him to see Him in heavenly places; we descend to Him for the nourishment of His weak members.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1091
verses.text: And the ascent and descent are by Him as well as to Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1092
verses.text: Following His example, those who preach Him not only rise to behold Him exalted, but let themselves down to give a plain announcement of the truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1093
verses.text: So the apostle ascends, "Whether we be beside ourselves, it is to God;" and descends, "Whether we be sober, it is for your sake".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1094
verses.text: And by whom did he ascend and descend? "For the love of Christ constraineth us: for we thus judge, that if one died for all, then all died; and that He died for all, that they which live should no longer live unto themselves, but unto Him that died for them, and rose again".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1095
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1096
verses.text: The man who does not find pleasure in these views of sacred Scripture is turned away to fables, because he cannot bear sound doctrine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1097
verses.text: The fables have an attraction for childish minds in people of all ages; but we who are of the body of Christ should say with the Psalmist; "O Lord, the wicked have spoken to me pleasing things, but they are not after Thy law".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1098
verses.text: In every page of these Scriptures, while I pursue my search as a son of Adam in the sweat of my brow, Christ either openly or covertly meets and refreshes me.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1099
verses.text: Where the discovery is laborious my ardor is increased, and the spoil obtained is eagerly devoured, and is hidden in my heart for my nourishment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1100
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1101
verses.text: Christ appears to me in Joseph, who was persecuted and sold by his brethren, and after his troubles obtained honor in Egypt.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1102
verses.text: We have seen the troubles of Christ in the world, of which Egypt was a figure, in the sufferings of the martyrs.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1103
verses.text: And now we see the honor of Christ in the same world which He subdues to Himself, in exchange for the food which He bestows.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1104
verses.text: Christ appears to me in the rod of Moses, which became a serpent when cast on the earth as a figure of His death, which came from the serpent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1105
verses.text: Again, when caught by the tail it became a rod, as a figure of His return after the accomplishment of His work in His resurrection to what He was before, destroying death by His new life, so as to leave no trace of the serpent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1106
verses.text: We, too, who are His body, glide along in the same mortality through the folds of time; but when at last the tail of this course of things is laid hold of by the hand of judgment that it shall go no further, we shall be renewed, and rising from the destruction of death, the last enemy, we shall be the sceptre of government in the right hand of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1107
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1108
verses.text: Of the departure of Israel from Egypt, let us hear what the apostle himself says: "I would not, brethren, that ye should be ignorant that all our fathers were under the cloud, and all passed through the sea, and were all baptized into Moses in the cloud and in the sea, and did all eat the same spiritual meat, and did all drink of the same spiritual drink.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1109
verses.text: For they drank of the spiritual rock which followed them, and that rock was Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1110
verses.text: The explanation of one thing is a key to the rest.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1111
verses.text: For if the rock is Christ from its stability, is not the manna Christ, the living bread which came down from heaven, which gives spiritual life to those who truly feed on it? The Israelites died because they received the figure only in its carnal sense.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1112
verses.text: The apostle, by calling it spiritual food, shows its reference to Christ, as the spiritual drink is explained by the words, "That rock was Christ," which explain the whole.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1113
verses.text: Then is not the cloud and the pillar Christ, who by His uprightness and strength supports our feebleness; who shines by night and not by day, that they who see not may see, and that they who see may be made blind? In the clouds and the Red Sea there is the baptism consecrated by the blood of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1114
verses.text: The enemies following behind perish, as past sins are put away.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1115
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1116
verses.text: The Israelites are led through the wilderness, as those who are baptized are in the wilderness while on the way to the promised land, hoping and patiently waiting for that which they see not.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1117
verses.text: In the wilderness are severe trials, lest they should in heart return to Egypt.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1118
verses.text: Still Christ does not leave them; the pillar does not go away.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1119
verses.text: The bitter waters are sweetened by wood, as hostile people become friendly by learning to honor the cross of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1120
verses.text: The twelve fountains watering the seventy palm trees are a figure of apostolic grace watering the nations.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1121
verses.text: As seven is multiplied by ten, so the decalogue is fulfilled in the sevenfold operation of the Spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1122
verses.text: The enemy attempting to stop them in their way is overcome by Moses stretching out his hands in the figure of the cross.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1123
verses.text: The deadly bites of serpents are healed by the brazen serpent, which was lifted up that they might look at it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1124
verses.text: The Lord Himself gives the explanation of this: "As Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, so must the Son of man be lifted up, that whosoever believeth in Him may not perish, but have everlasting life".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1125
verses.text: So in many other things we may find a protest against the obstinacy of unbelieving hearts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1126
verses.text: In the passover a lamb is killed, representing Christ, of whom it is said in the Gospel, "Behold the Lamb of God, who taketh away the sin of the world!"  In the passover the bones of the lamb were not to be broken; and on the cross the bones of the Lord were not broken.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1127
verses.text: The evangelist, in reference to this, quotes the words, "A bone of Him shall not be broken".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1128
verses.text: The posts were marked with blood to keep away destruction, as people are marked on their foreheads with the sign of the Lord's passion for their salvation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1129
verses.text: The law was given on the fiftieth day after the passover; so the Holy Spirit came on the fiftieth day after the passion of the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1130
verses.text: The law is said to have been written with the finger of God; and the Lord says of the Holy Spirit, "With the finger of God I cast out devils".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1131
verses.text: Such are the Scriptures in which Faustus, after shutting his eyes, declares that he can see no prediction of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1132
verses.text: But we need not wonder that he should have eyes to read and yet no heart to understand, since, instead of knocking in devout faith at the door of the heavenly secret, he dares to act in profane hostility.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1133
verses.text: So let it be, for so it ought to be.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1134
verses.text: Let the gate of salvation be shut to the proud.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1135
verses.text: The meek, to whom God teaches His ways, will find all these things in the Scriptures, and those things which he does not see he will believe from what he sees.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1136
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1137
verses.text: He will see Jesus leading the people into the land of promise; for this name was given to the leader of Israel, not at first, or by chance, but on account of the work to which he was called.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1138
verses.text: He will see the cluster from the land of promise hanging from a wooden pole.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1139
verses.text: He will see in Jericho, as in this perishing world, an harlot, one of those of whom the Lord says that they go before the proud into the kingdom of heaven, putting out of her window a scarlet line symbolical of blood, as confession is made with the mouth for the remission of sins.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1140
verses.text: He will see the walls of Jericho, like the frail defences of the world, fall when compassed seven times by the ark of the covenant; as now in the course of the seven days of time the covenant of God compasses the whole globe, that in the end, death, the last enemy, may be destroyed, and the Church, like one single house, be saved from the destruction of the ungodly, purified from the defilement of fornication by the window of confession in the blood of remission.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1141
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1142
verses.text: He will see the times of the judges precede those of the kings, as the judgment will precede the kingdom.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1143
verses.text: And under both the judges and the kings he will see Christ and the Church repeatedly prefigured in many and various ways.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1144
verses.text: Who was in Samson, when he killed the lion that met him as he went to get a wife among strangers, but He who, when going to call His Church from among the Gentiles, said, "Be of good cheer, I have overcome the world?"   What means the hive in the mouth of the slain lion, but that, as we see, the very laws of the earthly kingdom which once raged against Christ have now lost their fierceness, and have become a protection for the preaching of gospel sweetness? What is that woman boldly piercing the temples of the enemy with a wooden nail, but the faith of the Church casting down the kingdom of the devil by the cross of Christ? What is the fleece wet while the ground was dry, and again the fleece dry while the ground was wet, but the Hebrew nation at first possessing alone in its typical institution Christ the mystery of God, while the whole world was in ignorance? And now the whole world has this mystery revealed, while the Jews are destitute of it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1145
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1146
verses.text: To mention only a few things in the times of the kings, at the very outset does not the change in the priesthood when Eli was rejected and Samuel chosen, and in the kingdom when Saul was rejected and David chosen, clearly predict the new priesthood and kingdom to come in our Lord Jesus Christ, when the old, which was a shadow of the new, was rejected? Did not David, when he ate the shew-bread, which it was not lawful for any but the priests to eat, prefigure the union of the kingdom and priesthood in one person, Jesus Christ? In the separation of the ten tribes from the temple while two were left, is there not a figure of what the apostle asserts of the whole nation: "A remnant is saved by the election of grace".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1147
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1148
verses.text: In the time of famine, Elijah is fed by ravens bringing bread in the morning and flesh in the evening; but the Manich aeans cannot in this perceive Christ, who, as it were, hungers for our salvation, and to whom sinners come in confession, having now the first-fruits of the Spirit, while in the end, that is to say in the evening of the age, they will have the resurrection of their bodies also.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1149
verses.text: Elijah is sent to be fed by a widow woman of another nation, who was going to gather two sticks before she died, denoting the two wooden beams of the cross.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1150
verses.text: Her meal and oil are blessed, as the fruit and cheerfulness of charity do not diminish by expenditure, for God loveth a cheerful giver.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1151
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1152
verses.text: The children that mocked Elisha by calling out Baldhead, are devoured by wild beasts, as those who in childish folly scoff at Christ crucified on Calvary are destroyed by devils.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1153
verses.text: Elisha sends his servants to lay his staff on the dead body, but it does not revive; he comes himself, and lays himself exactly upon the dead body, and it revives: as the Word of God sent the law by His servant, without any profit to mankind dead in sins; and yet it was not sent without purpose by Him who knew the necessity of its being first sent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1154
verses.text: Then He Himself came, conformed Himself to us by participation in our death, and we were revived.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1155
verses.text: When they were cutting down wood with axes, the iron, flying off the wood, sank to the bottom of the river, and came up again when the wood was thrown in by Elisha.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1156
verses.text: So, when Christ's bodily presence was cutting down the unfruitful trees among the unbelieving Jews, according to the saying of John, "Behold, the axe is laid to the roots of the tree,"  by the death they inflicted, Christ was separated from His body, and descended to the depths of the infernal world; and then, when His body was laid in the tomb, like the wood on the water, His spirit returned, like the iron to the handle, and He rose.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1157
verses.text: The reader will observe how many things of this kind are omitted for the sake of brevity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1158
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1159
verses.text: As regards the departure to Babylon, where the Spirit of God by the prophet Jeremiah enjoins them to go, telling them to pray for the people in whose land they dwell as strangers, because in their peace they would find peace, and to build houses, and plant vineyards and gardens,—the figurative meaning is plain, when we consider that the true Israelites, in whom is no guile, passed over in the ministry of the apostles with the ordinances of the gospel into the kingdom of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1160
verses.text: So the apostle, like an echo of Jeremiah, says to us, "I will first of all that prayer, supplications, intercessions and giving of thanks be made for all men, and for those in authority, that we may live a quiet and peaceable life in all godliness and charity; for this is good and acceptable in the sight of God our Saviour, who will have all men to be saved, and to come to the knowledge of the truth".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1161
verses.text: Accordingly the basilicas of Christian congregations have been built by believers as abodes of peace, and vineyards of the faithful have been renewed, and gardens planted, where chief among the plants is the mustard tree, in whose wide-spreading branches the pride of the Gentiles, like the birds of heaven, in its soaring ambition, takes shelter.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1162
verses.text: Again, in the return from captivity after seventy years, according to Jeremiah's prophecy, and in the restoration of the temple, every believer in Christ must see a figure of our return as the Church of God from the exile of this world to the heavenly Jerusalem, after the seven days of time have fulfilled their course.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1163
verses.text: Joshua the high priest, after the captivity, who rebuilt the temple, was a figure of Jesus Christ, the true High Priest of our restoration.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1164
verses.text: The prophet Zechariah saw this Joshua in a filthy garment; and after the devil who stood by to accuse him was defeated, the filthy garment was taken from him, and a dress of honor and glory given him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1165
verses.text: So the body of Jesus Christ, which is the Church, when the adversary is conquered in the judgment at the end of the world, will pass from the pains of exile to the glory of everlasting safety.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1166
verses.text: This is the song of the Psalmist at the dedication of his house: "Thou hast turned for me my mourning into gladness; Thou hast removed my sackcloth, and girded me with gladness, that my glory may sing praise unto Thee, and not be silent".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1167
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1168
verses.text: It is impossible, in a digression like this, to refer, however briefly, to all the figurative predictions of Christ which are to be found in the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1169
verses.text: Will it be said that these things happened in the regular course of things, and that it is a mere ingenious fancy to make them typical of Christ? Such an objection might come from Jews and Pagans; but those who wish to be considered Christians must yield to the authority of the apostle when he says, "All these things happened to them for an example;" and again, "These things are our examples".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1170
verses.text: For if two men, Ishmael and Isaac, are types of the two covenants, can it be supposed that there is no significance in the vast number of particulars which have no historical or natural value? Suppose we were to see some Hebrew characters written on the wall of a noble building, should we be so foolish as to conclude that, because we cannot understand the characters, they are not intended to be read, and are mere painting, without any meaning? So, whoever with a candid mind reads all these things that are contained in the Old Testament Scriptures, must feel constrained to acknowledge that they have a meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1171
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1172
verses.text: As an example of those particulars which have no meaning at all if not a symbolical one: Granting that it was necessary that woman should be made as an help meet for man, what natural reason can be assigned for her being taken from his side while he slept? Granting that an ark was required in order to escape from the flood, why should it have precisely these dimensions, and why should they be recorded for the devout study of future generations? Granting that the animals were brought into the ark to preserve the various races, why should there be seven clean and two unclean? Granting that the ark must have a door, why should it be in the side, and why should this fact be committed to writing? Abraham is commanded to sacrifice his son: we may allow that this proof of his obedience was required in order to make it conspicuous in all ages; we may allow, too, that it was a proper thing for the son to carry the wood instead of the aged father, and that in the end the fatal stroke was forbidden, lest the father should be left childless.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1173
verses.text: But what had the shedding of the ram's blood to do with Abraham's trial? or if it was necessary to complete the sacrifice, was the ram any the better of being caught by the horns in a bush? The human mind, that is to say, a rational mind, is led by the consideration of the way in which these apparently superfluous things are blended with what is necessary, first to acknowledge their significance, and then to try to discover it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1174
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1175
verses.text: The Jews themselves, who scoff at the crucified Saviour in whom we believe, and who consequently will not allow that Christ is predicted in the sayings and actions recorded in the Old Testament, are compelled to come to us for an explanation of those things which, if not explained, must appear trifling and ridiculous.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1176
verses.text: This led Philo, a Jew of great learning, whom the Greeks speak of as rivalling Plato in eloquence, to attempt to explain some things without any reference to Christ, in whom he did not believe.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1177
verses.text: His attempt only shows the inferiority of all ingenious speculations, when made without keeping Christ in view, to whom all the predictions really point.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1178
verses.text: So true is that saying of the apostle: "When they shall turn to the Lord, the veil shall be taken away".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1179
verses.text: For instance, Noah's ark is, according to Philo, a type of the human body, member by member: with this view, he shows that the numerical proportions agree perfectly.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1180
verses.text: For there is no reason why a type of Christ should not be a type of the human body, too, since the Saviour of mankind appeared in a human body, though what is typical of a human body is not necessarily typical of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1181
verses.text: Philo's explanation fails, however, as regards the door in the side of the ark.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1182
verses.text: He actually, for the sake of saying something, makes this door represent the lower apertures of the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1183
verses.text: He has the hardihood to put this in words, and on paper.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1184
verses.text: Indeed, he knew not the door and could not understand the symbol.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1185
verses.text: Had he turned to Christ the veil would have been taken away, and he would have found the sacraments of the Church flowing from the side of Christ's human body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1186
verses.text: For, according to the announcement, "They two shall be one flesh," some things in the ark which is a type of Christ, refer to Christ, and some to the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1187
verses.text: This contrast between the explanations which keep Christ in view, and all other ingenious perversions, is the same in every particular of all the figures in Scripture.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1188
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1189
verses.text: The Pagans, too, cannot deny our right to give a figurative meaning to both words and things, especially as we can point to the fulfillment of the types and figures.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1190
verses.text: For the Pagans themselves try to find in their own fables figures of natural and religious truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1191
verses.text: Sometimes they give clear explanations, while at other times they disguise their meaning, and what is sacred in the temples becomes a jest in the theatres.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1192
verses.text: They unite a disgraceful licentiousness to a degrading superstition.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1193
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1194
verses.text: Besides this wonderful agreement between the types and the things typified, the adversary may be convinced by plain prophetic intimations, such as this: "In thy seed shall all nations be blessed".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1195
verses.text: This was said to Abraham,  and again to Isaac,  and again to Jacob.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1196
verses.text: Hence the significance of the words "I am the God of Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1197
verses.text: God fulfills His promise to their seed in blessing all nations.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1198
verses.text: With a like significance, Abraham himself, when he made his servant swear, told him to put his hand under his thigh;  for he knew that thence would come the flesh of Christ, in whom we have now, not the promise of blessing to all nations, but the promise fulfilled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1199
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1200
verses.text: I should like to know, or rather, it would be well not to know, with what blindness of mind Faustus reads the passage where Jacob calls his sons, and says, "Assemble, that I may tell you the things that are to happen in the last day.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1201
verses.text: Assemble and hear, ye sons of Jacob; give ear to Israel, your father".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1202
verses.text: Surely these are the words of a prophet.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1203
verses.text: What, then, does he say of his son Judah, of whose tribe Christ came of the seed of David according to the flesh, as the apostle teaches? "Judah," he says, "thy brethren shall praise thee: thy hand shall be upon the backs of thine enemies; the sons of thy father shall bow down to thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1204
verses.text: Judah is a lion's whelp; my son and offspring: bowing down, thou hast gone up: thou sleepest as a lion, and as a young lion, who will rouse him up? A prince shall not depart from Judah, nor a leader from his loins, till those things come which have been laid up for him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1205
verses.text: He also is the desire of nations: binding his foal unto the vine, and his ass's colt with sackcloth, he shall wash his garment in wine, and his clothes in the blood of grapes: his eyes are bright with wine, and his teeth whiter than milk".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1206
verses.text: There is no falsehood or obscurity in these words when we read them in the clear light of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1207
verses.text: We see His brethren the apostles and all His joint-heirs praising Him, seeking, not their own glory, but His.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1208
verses.text: We see His hands on the backs of His enemies, who are bent and bowed to the earth by the growth of the Christian communities in spite of their opposition.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1209
verses.text: We see Him worshipped by the sons of Jacob, the remnant saved according to the election of grace.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1210
verses.text: Christ, who was born as an infant, is the lion's whelp, as it is added, My son and offspring, to show why this whelp, in whose praise it is said, "The lion's whelp is stronger than the herd,"  is even in infancy stronger than its elders.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1211
verses.text: We see Christ ascending the cross, and bowing down when He gave up His spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1212
verses.text: We see Him sleeping as a lion, because in death itself He was not the conquered, but the conqueror, and as a lion's whelp; for the reason of His birth and of His death was the same.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1213
verses.text: And He is raised from the dead by Him whom no man hath seen or can see; for the words, "Who will raise Him up?" point to an unknown power.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1214
verses.text: A prince did not depart from Judah, nor a leader from his loins, till in due time those things came which had been laid up in the promise.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1215
verses.text: For we learn from the authentic history of the Jews themselves, that Herod, under whom Christ was born, was their first foreign king.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1216
verses.text: So the sceptre did not depart from the seed of Judah till the things laid up for him came.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1217
verses.text: Then, as the promise is not only to the believing Jews, it is added: "He is the desire of the nations".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1218
verses.text: Christ bound His foal—that is, His people—to the vine, when He preached in sackcloth, crying, "Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1219
verses.text: The Gentiles made subject to Him are represented by the ass's colt, on which He also sat, leading it into Jerusalem, that is, the vision of peace teaching the meek His ways.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1220
verses.text: We see Him washing His garments in wine; for He is one with the glorious Church, which He presents to Himself, not having spot or wrinkle; to whom also it is said by Isaiah: "Though your sins be as scarlet, I will make them white as snow".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1221
verses.text: How is this done but by the remission of sins? And the wine is none other than that of which it is said that it is "shed for many, for the remission of sins".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1222
verses.text: Christ is the cluster that hung on the pole.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1223
verses.text: So it is added, "and His clothes in the blood of the grape".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1224
verses.text: Again, what is said of His eyes being bright with wine, is understood by those members of His body who are enabled, in holy aberration of mind from the current of earthly things, to gaze on the eternal light of wisdom.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1225
verses.text: So Paul says in a passage quoted before: "If we be beside ourselves, it is to God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1226
verses.text: Those are the eyes bright with wine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1227
verses.text: But he adds: "If we be sober, it is for your sakes".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1228
verses.text: The babes needing to be fed with milk are not forgotten, as is denoted by the words, "His teeth are whiter than milk".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1229
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1230
verses.text: What can our deluded adversaries say to such plain examples, which leave no room for perverse denial, or even for sceptical uncertainty? I call on the Manich aeans to begin to inquire into these subjects, and to admit the force of these evidences, on which I have no time to dwell; nor do I wish to make a selection, in case the ignorant reader should think there are no others, while the Christian student might blame me for the omission of many points more striking than those which occur to me at the moment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1231
verses.text: You will find many passages which require no such explanation as has been given here of Jacob's prophecy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1232
verses.text: For instance, every reader can understand the words, "He was led as a lamb to the slaughter," and the whole of that plain prophecy, "With His stripes we are healed"—"He bore our sins".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1233
verses.text: We have a poetical gospel in the words: "They pierced my hands and feet.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1234
verses.text: They have told all my bones.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1235
verses.text: They look and stare upon me.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1236
verses.text: They divided my garments among them, and cast lots on my vesture".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1237
verses.text: The blind even may now see the fulfillment of the words: "All the ends of the earth shall remember and turn unto the Lord, and all kingdoms of the nations shall worship before Him".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1238
verses.text: The words in the Gospel, "My soul is sorrowful, even unto death," "My soul is troubled," are a repetition of the words in the Psalm, "I slept in trouble".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1239
verses.text: And who made Him sleep? Whose voices cried, Crucify him, crucify him? The Psalm tells us: "The sons of men, their teeth are spears and arrows, and their tongue a sharp sword".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1240
verses.text: But they could not prevent His resurrection, or His ascension above the heavens, or His filling the earth with the glory of His name; for the Psalm says: "Be Thou exalted, O God, above the heavens, and let Thy glory be above all the earth".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1241
verses.text: Every one must apply these words to Christ: "The Lord said unto me, Thou art my Son, this day have I begotten Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1242
verses.text: Ask of me, and I will give Thee the heathen for Thine inheritance, and the uttermost parts of the earth for Thy possession".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1243
verses.text: And what Jeremiah says of wisdom plainly applies to Christ: "Jacob delivered it to his son, and Israel to his chosen one.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1244
verses.text: Afterwards He appeared on earth, and conversed with men".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1245
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1246
verses.text: The same Saviour is spoken of in Daniel, where the Son of man appears before the Ancient of days, and receives a kingdom without end, that all nations may serve Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1247
verses.text: In the passage quoted from Daniel by the Lord Himself, "When ye shall see the abomination of desolation, spoken of by Daniel the prophet, standing in the holy place, let him that readeth understand,"  the number of weeks points not only to Christ, but to the very time of His advent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1248
verses.text: With the Jews, who look to Christ for salvation as we do, but deny that He has come and suffered, we can argue from actual events.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1249
verses.text: Besides the conversion of the heathen, now so universal, as prophesied of Christ in their own Scriptures, there are the events in the history of the Jews themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1250
verses.text: Their holy place is thrown down, the sacrifice has ceased, and the priest, and the ancient anointing; which was all clearly foretold by Daniel when he prophesied of the anointing of the Most Holy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1251
verses.text: Now, that all these things have taken place, we ask the Jews for the anointed Most Holy, and they have no answer to give.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1252
verses.text: But it is from the Old Testament that the Jews derive all the knowledge they have of Christ and His advent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1253
verses.text: Why do they ask John whether he is Christ? Why do they say to the Lord, "How long dost thou make us to doubt? If thou art the Christ, tell us plainly".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1254
verses.text: Why do Peter and Andrew and Philip say to Nathanael, "We have found Messias, which is interpreted Christ," but because this name was known to them from the prophecies of their Scriptures? In no other nation were the kings and priests anointed, and called Anointed or Christs.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1255
verses.text: Nor could this symbolical anointing be discontinued till the coming of Him who was thus prefigured.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1256
verses.text: For among all their anointed ones the Jews looked for one who was to save them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1257
verses.text: But in the mysterious justice of God they were blinded; and thinking only of the power of the Messiah, they did not understand His weakness, in which He died for us.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1258
verses.text: In the book of Wisdom it is prophesied of the Jews: "Let us condemn him to an ignominious death; for he will be proved in his words.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1259
verses.text: If he is truly the Son of God, He will aid him; and deliver him from the hand of his enemies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1260
verses.text: Thus they thought, and erred; for their wickedness blinded them".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1261
verses.text: These words apply also to those who, in spite of all these evidences, in spite of such a series of prophecies, and of their fulfillment, still deny that Christ is foretold in the Scriptures.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1262
verses.text: As often as they repeat this denial, we can produce fresh proofs, with the help of Him who has made such provision against human perversity, that proofs already given need not be repeated.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1263
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1264
verses.text: Faustus has an evasive objection, which he no doubt thinks a most ingenious way of eluding the force of the clearest evidence of prophecy, but of which one is unwilling to take any notice, because answering it may give it an appearance of importance which it does not really possess.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1265
verses.text: What could be more irrational than to say that it is weak faith which will not believe in Christ without evidence? Do our adversaries, then, believe in testimony about Christ? Faustus wishes us to believe the voice from heaven as distinguished from human testimony.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1266
verses.text: But did they hear this voice? Has not the knowledge of it come to us through human testimony? The apostle describes the transmission of this knowledge, when he says: "How shall they call on Him on whom they have not believed? and how shall they believe on Him of whom they have not heard? and how shall they hear without a preacher? and how shall they preach except they be sent? As it is written, "How beautiful are the feet of them who publish peace, who bring good tidings!"  Clearly, in the preaching of the apostles there was a reference to prophetic testimony.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1267
verses.text: The apostles quoted the predictions of the prophets, to prove the truth and importance of their doctrines.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1268
verses.text: For although their preaching was accompanied with the power of working miracles, the miracles would have been ascribed to magic, as some even now venture to insinuate, unless the apostles had shown that the authority of the prophets was in their favor.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1269
verses.text: The testimony of prophets who lived so long before could not be ascribed to magical arts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1270
verses.text: Perhaps the reason why Faustus will not have us believe the Hebrew prophets as witnesses of the true Christ, is because he believes Persian heresies about a false Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1271
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1272
verses.text: According to the teaching of the Catholic Church, the Christian mind must first be nourished in simple faith, in order that it may become capable of understanding things heavenly and eternal.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1273
verses.text: Thus it is said by the prophet: "Unless ye believe, ye shall not understand".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1274
verses.text: Simple faith is that by which, before we attain to the height of the knowledge of the love of Christ, that we may be filled with all the fullness of God, we believe that not without reason was the dispensation of Christ's humiliation, in which He was born and suffered as man, foretold so long before by the prophets through a prophetic race, a prophetic people, a prophetic kingdom.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1275
verses.text: This faith teaches us, that in the foolishness which is wiser than men, and in the weakness which is stronger than men, is contained the hidden means of our justification and glorification.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1276
verses.text: There are hid all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge, which are opened to no one who despises the nourishment transmitted through the breast of his mother that is, the milk of apostolic and prophetic instruction; or who, thinking himself too old for infantile nourishment, devours heretical poison instead of the food of wisdom, for which he rashly thought himself prepared.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1277
verses.text: To require simple faith is quite consistent with requiring faith in the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1278
verses.text: The very use of simple faith is to believe the prophets at the outset, while the understanding of the person who speaks in the prophets is attained after the mind has been purified and strengthened.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1279
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1280
verses.text: But, it is said, if the prophets foretold Christ, they did not live in a way becoming their office.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1281
verses.text: How can you tell whether they did or not? You are bad judges of what it is to live well or ill, whose justice consists in giving relief to an inanimate melon by eating it, instead of giving food to the starving beggar.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1282
verses.text: It is enough for the babes in the Catholic Church, who do not yet know the perfect justice of the human soul, and the difference between the justice aimed at and that actually attained, to think of those men according to the wholesome doctrine of the apostles, that the just lives by faith.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1283
verses.text: "Abraham believed God, and it was counted to him for righteousness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1284
verses.text: For the scripture, foreseeing that God would justify the Gentiles by faith, preached before the gospel unto Abraham, saying, In thy seed shall all nations be blessed".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1285
verses.text: These are the words of the apostle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1286
verses.text: If you would, at his clear well-known voice, wake up from your unprofitable dreams, you would follow in the footsteps of our father Abraham, and would be blessed, along with all nations, in his seed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1287
verses.text: For, as the apostle says, "He received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had, yet being uncircumcised, that he might be the father of all that believe in uncircumcision; that he might be the father of circumcision not only to those who are of the circumcision, but also to those who follow the footsteps of the faith of our father Abraham in uncircumcision".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1288
verses.text: Since the righteousness of Abraham's faith is thus set forth as an example to us, that we too, being justified by faith, may have peace with God, we ought to understand his manner of life, without finding fault with it; lest, by a premature separation from mother-Church, we prove abortions, instead of being brought forth in due time, when the conception has arrived at completeness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1289
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1290
verses.text: This is a brief reply to Faustus in behalf of the character of the patriarchs and prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1291
verses.text: It is the reply of the babes of our faith, among whom I would reckon myself, inasmuch as I would not find fault with the life of the ancient saints, even if I did not understand its mystical character.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1292
verses.text: Their life is proclaimed to us with approval by the apostles in their Gospel, as they themselves in their prophecy foretold the future apostles, that the two Testaments, like the seraphim, might cry to one another, "Holy, holy, holy is the Lord God of hosts".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1293
verses.text: When Faustus, instead of the vague general accusation which he makes here, condemns particular actions in the lives of the patriarchs and the prophets, the Lord their God, and ours also, will assist me to reply suitably and appropriately to the separate charges.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1294
verses.text: For the present, the reader must choose whether to believe the commendation of the Apostle Paul or the accusations of Faustus the Manich aean.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1295
verses.text: Book XIII.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1296
verses.text: Faustus asserts that even if the Old Testament could be shown to contain predictions, it would be of interest only to the Jews, pagan literature subserving the same purpose for Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1297
verses.text: Augustin shows the value of prophesy for Gentiles and Jews alike.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1298
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1299
verses.text: Faustus said: We are asked how we worship Christ when we reject the prophets, who declared the promise of His advent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1300
verses.text: It is doubtful whether, on examination, it can be shown that the Hebrew prophets foretold our Christ, that is, the Son of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1301
verses.text: But were it so, what does it matter to us? If these testimonies of the prophets that you speak of were the means of converting any one from Judaism to Christianity, and if he should afterwards neglect these prophets, he would certainly be in the wrong, and would be chargeable with ingratitude.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1302
verses.text: But we are by nature Gentiles, of the uncircumcision; as Paul says, born under another law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1303
verses.text: Those whom the Gentiles call poets were our first religious teachers, and from them we were afterwards converted to Christianity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1304
verses.text: We did not first become Jews, so as to reach Christianity through faith in their prophets; but were attracted solely by the fame, and the virtues, and the wisdom of our liberator Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1305
verses.text: If I were still in the religion of my fathers, and a preacher were to come using the prophets as evidence in favor of Christianity, I should think him mad for attempting to support what is doubtful by what is still more doubtful to a Gentile of another religion altogether.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1306
verses.text: He would require first to persuade me to believe the prophets, and then through the prophets to believe Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1307
verses.text: And to prove the truth of the prophets, other prophets would be necessary.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1308
verses.text: For if the prophets bear witness to Christ, who bears witness to the prophets? You will perhaps say that Christ and the prophets mutually support each other.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1309
verses.text: But a Pagan, who has nothing to do with either, would believe neither the evidence of Christ to the prophets, nor that of the prophets to Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1310
verses.text: If the Pagan becomes a Christian, he has to thank his own faith, and nothing else.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1311
verses.text: Let us, for the sake of illustration, suppose ourselves conversing with a Gentile inquirer.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1312
verses.text: We tell him to believe in Christ, because He is God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1313
verses.text: He asks for proof.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1314
verses.text: We refer him to the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1315
verses.text: He asks, What prophets? We reply, The Hebrew.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1316
verses.text: He smiles, and says that he does not believe them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1317
verses.text: We remind him that Christ testifies to them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1318
verses.text: He replies, laughing, that we must first make him believe in Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1319
verses.text: The result of such a conversation is that we are silenced, and the inquirer departs, thinking us more zealous than wise.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1320
verses.text: Again, I say, the Christian Church, which consists more of Gentiles than of Jews, can owe nothing to Hebrew witnesses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1321
verses.text: If, as is said, any prophecies of Christ are to be found in the Sibyl,  or in Hermes,  called Trismegistus, or Orpheus, or any heathen poet, they might aid the faith of those who, like us, are converts from heathenism to Christianity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1322
verses.text: But the testimony of the Hebrews is useless to us before conversion, for then we cannot believe them; and superfluous after, for we believe without them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1323
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1324
verses.text: Augustin replied: After the long reply of last book, a short answer may suffice here.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1325
verses.text: To one who has read that reply, it must seem insanity in Faustus to persist in denying that Christ was foretold by the Hebrew prophets, when the Hebrew nation was the only one in which the name Christ had a peculiar sacredness as applied to kings and priests; in which sense it continued to be applied till the coming of Him whom those kings and priests typified.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1326
verses.text: Where did the Manich aean learn the name of Christ? If from Manich aeus, it is very strange that Africans, not to speak of others, should believe the Persian Manich aeus, since Faustus finds fault with the Romans and Greeks, and other Gentiles, for believing the Hebrew prophets as belonging to another race.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1327
verses.text: According to Faustus, the predictions of the Sibyl, or Orpheus, or any heathen poet, are more suitable for leading Gentiles to believe in Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1328
verses.text: He forgets that none of these are read in the churches, whereas the voice of the Hebrew prophets, sounding everywhere, draws swarms of people to Christianity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1329
verses.text: When it is so evident that men are everywhere led to Christ by the Hebrew prophets, it is great absurdity to say that those prophets are not suitable for the Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1330
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1331
verses.text: Christ as foretold by the Hebrew prophets does not please you; but this is the Christ in whom the Gentile nations believe, with whom, according to you, Hebrew prophecy should have no weight.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1332
verses.text: They receive the gospel which, as Paul says, "God had promised before by His prophets in the Holy Scriptures of His Son, who was made of the seed of David according to the flesh".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1333
verses.text: So we read in Isaiah: "There shall be a Root of Jesse, which shall rise to reign in the nations; in Him shall the Gentiles trust".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1334
verses.text: And again: "Behold, a virgin shall conceive and bear a son, and they shall call His name Emmanuel,"  which is, being interpreted, God with us.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1335
verses.text: Nor let the Manich aean think that Christ is foretold only as a man by the Hebrew prophets; for this is what Faustus seems to insinuate when he says, "Our Christ is the Son of God," as if the Christ of the Hebrews was not the Son of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1336
verses.text: We can prove Christ the virgin's son of Hebrew prophecy to be God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1337
verses.text: For the Lord Himself teaches the carnal Jews not to think that, because He is foretold as the son of David, He is therefore no more than that.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1338
verses.text: He asks: "What think ye of Christ? Whose son is He?" They reply: "Of David".
