verses.text: In the words, "Cursed is every one that hangeth on a tree," there is no more blasphemy than in the words of the apostle, "He died," or, "Our old man was crucified along with Him,"  or, "By sin He condemned sin,"  or, "He made Him to be sin for us who knew no sin,"  and in many similar passages.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1674
verses.text: Confess, then, that when you exclaim against the curse of Christ, you exclaim against His death.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1675
verses.text: If this is not an old wife's railing on your part, it is devilish delusion, which makes you deny the death of Christ because your own souls are dead.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1676
verses.text: You teach people that Christ's death was feigned, making Christ your leader in the falsehood with which you use the name of Christian to mislead men.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1677
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1678
verses.text: If Faustus thinks Moses an enemy of continence or virginity because he says, "Cursed is everyone that raiseth not up seed in Israel," let them hear the words of Isaiah: "Thus saith the Lord to all eunuchs; To them who keep my precepts, and choose the things that please me, and regard my covenant, will I give in my house and within my walls a place and a name better than of sons and of daughters; I will give them an everlasting name, that shall not be cut off".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1679
verses.text: Though our adversaries disagree with Moses, if they agree with Isaiah it is something gained.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1680
verses.text: It is enough for us to know that the same God spoke by both Moses and Isaiah, and that every one is cursed who raiseth not up seed in Israel, both then when begetting children in marriage (for the continuation of the people was a civil duty), and now because no one spiritually born should rest content without seeking spiritual increase in the production of Christians by preaching Christ, each one according to his ability.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1681
verses.text: So that the times of both Testaments are briefly described in the words, "Cursed is every one that raiseth not up seed in Israel".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1682
verses.text: Book XV.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1683
verses.text: Faustus rejects the Old Testament because it leaves no room for Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1684
verses.text: Christ the one Bridegroom suffices for His Bride the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1685
verses.text: Augustin answers as well as he can, and reproves the Manich aeans with presumption in claiming to be the Bride of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1686
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1687
verses.text: Faustus said: Why do we not receive the Old Testament? Because when a vessel is full, what is poured on it is not received, but allowed to run over; and a full stomach rejects what it cannot hold.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1688
verses.text: So the Jews, satisfied with the Old Testament, reject the New; and we who have received the New Testament from Christ, reject the Old.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1689
verses.text: You receive both because you are only half filled with each, and the one is not completed, but corrupted by the other.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1690
verses.text: For vessels half filled should not be filled up with anything of a different nature from what they already contain.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1691
verses.text: If it contains wine, it should be filled up with wine, honey with honey, vinegar with vinegar.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1692
verses.text: For to pour gall on honey, or water on wine, or alkalies on vinegar, is not addition, but adulteration.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1693
verses.text: This is why we do not receive the Old Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1694
verses.text: Our Church, the bride of Christ, the poor bride of a rich bridegroom, is content with the possession of her husband, and scorns the wealth of inferior lovers, and despises the gifts of the Old Testament and of its author, and from regard to her own character, receives only the letters of her husband.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1695
verses.text: We leave the Old Testament to your Church, that, like a bride faithless to her spouse, delights in the letters and gifts of another.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1696
verses.text: This lover who corrupts your chastity, the God of the Hebrews in his stone tablets promises you gold and silver, and abundance of food, and the land of Canaan.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1697
verses.text: Such low rewards have tempted you to be unfaithful to Christ, after all the rich dowry bestowed by him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1698
verses.text: By such attractions the God of the Hebrews gains over the bride of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1699
verses.text: You must know that you are cheated, and that these promises are false.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1700
verses.text: This God is in poverty and beggary, and cannot do what he promises.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1701
verses.text: For if he cannot give these things to the synagogue, his proper wife, who obeys him in all things like a servant, how can he bestow them on you who are strangers, and who proudly throw off his yoke from your necks? Go on, then, as you have begun, join the new cloth to the old garment, put the new wine in old bottles, serve two masters without pleasing either, make Christianity a monster, half horse and half man; but allow us to serve only Christ, content with his immortal dower, and imitating the apostle who says, "Our sufficiency is of God, who has made us able ministers of the New Testament".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1702
verses.text: In the God of the Hebrews we have no interest whatever; for neither can he perform his promises, nor do we desire that he should.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1703
verses.text: The liberality of Christ has made us indifferent to the flatteries of this stranger.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1704
verses.text: This figure of the relation of the wife to her husband is sanctioned by Paul, who says: "The woman that has a husband is bound to her husband as long as he liveth; but if her husband die, she is freed from the law of her husband.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1705
verses.text: So, then, if while her husband liveth she be joined to another man, she shall be called an adulteress; but if her husband be dead, she is not an adulteress, though she be married to another man".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1706
verses.text: Here he shows that there is a spiritual adultery in being united to Christ before repudiating the author of the law, and counting him, as it were, as dead.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1707
verses.text: This applies chiefly to the Jews who believe in Christ, and who ought to forget their former superstition.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1708
verses.text: We who have been converted to Christ from heathenism, look upon the God of the Hebrews not merely as dead, but as never having existed, and do not need to be told to forget him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1709
verses.text: A Jew, when he believes, should regard Adonai as dead; a Gentile should regard his idol as dead; and so with everything that has been held sacred before conversion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1710
verses.text: One who, after giving up idolatry, worships both the God of the Hebrews and Christ, is like an abandoned woman, who after the death of one husband marries two others.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1711
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1712
verses.text: Augustin replied: Let all who have given their hearts to Christ say whether they can listen patiently to these things, unless Christ Himself enable them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1713
verses.text: Faustus, full of the new honey, rejects the old vinegar; and Paul, full of the old vinegar, has poured out half that the new honey may be poured in, not to be kept, but to be corrupted.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1714
verses.text: When the apostle calls himself a servant of Jesus Christ, called to be an apostle, separated unto the gospel of God, this is the new honey.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1715
verses.text: But when he adds, "which He promised before by His prophets in the Holy Scriptures of His Son, who was made of the seed of David according to the flesh,"  this is the old vinegar.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1716
verses.text: Who could bear to hear this, unless the apostle himself consoled us by saying: "There must be heresies, that they which are approved may be made manifest among you?"  Why should we repeat what we said already? —that the new cloth and the old garment, the new wine and the old bottles, mean not two Testaments, but two lives and two hopes,—that the relation of the two Testaments is figuratively described by the Lord when He says: "Therefore every scribe instructed in the kingdom of God is like an householder bringing out of his treasure things new and old".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1717
verses.text: The reader may remember this as said before, or he may find it on looking back.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1718
verses.text: For if any one tries to serve God with two hopes, one of earthly felicity, and the other of the kingdom of heaven, the two hopes cannot agree; and when the latter is shaken by some affliction, the former will be lost too.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1719
verses.text: Thus it is said, No man can serve two masters; which Christ explains thus: "Ye cannot serve God and Mammon".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1720
verses.text: But to those who rightly understand it, the Old Testament is a prophecy of the New.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1721
verses.text: Even in that ancient people, the holy patriarchs and prophets, who understood the part they performed, or which they were instrumental in performing, had this hope of eternal life in the New Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1722
verses.text: They belonged to the New Testament, because they understood and loved it, though revealed only in figure.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1723
verses.text: Those belonging to the Old Testament were the people who cared for nothing else but the temporal promises, without understanding them as significant of eternal things.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1724
verses.text: But all this has already been more than enough insisted on.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1725
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1726
verses.text: It is amazingly bold in the impious and impure sect of the Manich aeans to boast of being the chaste bride of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1727
verses.text: All the effect of such a boast on the really chaste members of the holy Church is to remind them of the apostle's warning against deceivers: "I have joined you to one husband, to present you as a chaste virgin to Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1728
verses.text: But I fear lest, as the serpent deceived Eve by his guile, so your minds also should be corrupted from the purity which is in Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1729
verses.text: What else do those preachers of another gospel than that which we have received try to do, but to corrupt us from the purity which we preserve for Christ, when they stigmatize the law of God as old, and praise their own falsehoods as new, as if all that is new must be good, and all that is old bad? The Apostle John, however, praises the old commandment, and the Apostle Paul bids us avoid novelties in doctrine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1730
verses.text: As an unworthy son and servant of the Catholic Church, the true bride of the true Christ, I too, as appointed to give out food to my fellow-servants, would speak to her a word of counsel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1731
verses.text: Continue ever to shun the profane errors of the Manich aeans, which have been tried by the experience of thine own children, and condemned by their recovery.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1732
verses.text: By that heresy I was once separated from thy fellowship, and after running into danger which ought to have been avoided, I escaped.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1733
verses.text: Restored to thy service, my experience may perhaps be profitable to thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1734
verses.text: Unless thy true and truthful Bridegroom, from whose side thou wert made, had obtained the remission of sins through His own real blood, the gulf of error would have swallowed me up; I should have become dust, and been devoured by the serpent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1735
verses.text: Be not misled by the name of truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1736
verses.text: The truth is in thine own milk, and in thine own bread.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1737
verses.text: They have the name only, and not the thing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1738
verses.text: Thy full-grown children, indeed, are secure; but I speak to thy babes, my brothers, and sons, and masters, whom thou, the virgin mother, fertile as pure, dost cherish into life under thine anxious wings, or dost nourish with the milk of infancy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1739
verses.text: I call upon these, thy tender offspring, not to be seduced by noisy vanities, but rather to pronounce accursed any one that preaches to them another gospel than that which they have received in thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1740
verses.text: I call upon these not to leave the true and truthful Christ, in whom are hid all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge; not to forsake the abundance of His goodness which He has laid up for them that fear Him, and has wrought for them that trust in Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1741
verses.text: How can they expect to find truthful words in one who preaches an untruthful Christ? Scorn the reproaches cast on thee, for thou knowest well that the gift which thou desirest from thy Bridegroom is eternal life, for He Himself is eternal life.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1742
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1743
verses.text: It is a silly falsehood that thou hast been seduced to another God, who promises abundance of food and the land of Canaan.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1744
verses.text: For thou canst perceive how the saints of old, who were also thy children, were enlightened by these figures which were prophecies of thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1745
verses.text: Thou needest not regard the poor jest against the stone tablets, for the stony heart of which they were in old times a figure is not in thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1746
verses.text: For thou art an epistle of the apostles, "written not with ink, but with the Spirit of the living God; not on tables of stone, but on the fleshy tables of the heart".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1747
verses.text: Our opponents ignorantly think that these words are in their favor, and that the apostle finds fault with the dispensation of the Old Testament, whereas they are the words of the prophet.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1748
verses.text: This utterance of the apostles was a fulfillment of the long anterior utterances of the prophet whom the Manich aeans reject, for they believe the apostles without understanding them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1749
verses.text: The prophet says: "I will take away from them the stony heart, and I will give them a heart of flesh".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1750
verses.text: What is this but "Not on tables of stones but on the fleshy tables of the heart"? For by the heart of flesh and the fleshy tables is not meant a carnal understanding: but as flesh feels, whereas a stone cannot, the insensibility of stone signifies an unintelligent heart, and the sensibility of flesh signifies an intelligent heart.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1751
verses.text: Instead, then, of scoffing at thee, they deserve to be ridiculed who say that earth, and wood, and stones have sense, and that their life is more intelligent than animal life.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1752
verses.text: So, not to speak of the truth, even their own fiction obliges them to confess that the law written on tables of stone was purer than their sacred parchments.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1753
verses.text: Or perhaps they prefer sheepskin to stone, because their legends make stones the bones of princes.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1754
verses.text: In any case, the ark of the Old Testament was a cleaner covering for the tables of stone than the goatskin of their manuscripts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1755
verses.text: Laugh at these things, while pitying them, to show their falsehood and absurdity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1756
verses.text: With a heart no longer stony, thou canst see in these stone tablets a suitableness to that hard-hearted people; and at the same time thou canst find even there the stone, thy Bridegroom, described by Peter as "a living stone, rejected by men, but chosen of God, and precious".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1757
verses.text: To them He was "a stone of stumbling and a rock of offence;" but to thee, "the stone which the builders rejected has become the head of the corner".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1758
verses.text: This is all explained by Peter, and is quoted from the prophets, with whom these heretics have nothing to do.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1759
verses.text: Fear not, then, to read these tablets—they are from thy Husband; to others the stone was a sign of insensibility, but to thee of strength and stability.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1760
verses.text: With the finger of God these tablets were written; with the finger of God thy Lord cast out devils; with the finger of God drive thou away the doctrines of lying devils which sear the conscience.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1761
verses.text: With these tablets thou canst confound the seducer who calls himself the Paraclete, that he may impose upon thee by a sacred name.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1762
verses.text: For on the fiftieth day after the passover the tables were given; and on the fiftieth day after the passion of thy Bride-groom—of whom the passover was a type—the finger of God, the Holy Spirit, the promised Paraclete, was given.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1763
verses.text: Fear not the tablets which convey to thee ancient writings now made plain.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1764
verses.text: Only be not under the law, lest fear prevent thy fulfilling it; but be under grace, that love, which is the fulfilling of the law, may be in thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1765
verses.text: For it was in a review of these very tablets that the friend of thy Bridegroom said: "For thou shalt not commit adultery, Thou shalt not murder, Thou shalt not covet, and if there be any other commandment, it is contained in this word, Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1766
verses.text: Love worketh no ill to his neighbor; therefore love is the fulfilling of the law".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1767
verses.text: One table contains the precept of love to God, and the other of love to man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1768
verses.text: And He who first sent these tablets Himself came to enjoin those precepts on which hang the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1769
verses.text: In the first precept is the chastity of thy espousals; in the second is the unity of thy members.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1770
verses.text: In the one thou art united to divinity; in the other thou dost gather a society.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1771
verses.text: And these two precepts are identical with the ten, of which three relate to God, and seven to our neighbor.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1772
verses.text: Such is the chaste tablet in which thy Lover and thy Beloved of old prefigured to thee the new song on a psaltery of ten strings; Himself to be extended on the cross for thee, that by sin He might condemn sin in the flesh, and that the righteouness of the law might be fulfilled in thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1773
verses.text: Such is the conjugal tablet, which may well be hated by the unfaithful wife.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1774
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1775
verses.text: I turn now to thee, thou deluded and deluding congregation of Manich aeus,—wedded to so many elements, or rather prostituted to so many devils, and impregnated with blasphemous falsehoods,—dost thou dare to slander as unchaste the marriage of the Catholic Church with thy Lord? Behold thy lovers, one balancing creation, and the other bearing it up like Atlas.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1776
verses.text: For one, by thy account, holds the sources of the elements, and hangs the world in space; while the other keeps him up by kneeling down and carrying the weight on his shoulders.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1777
verses.text: Where are those beings? And if they are so occupied, how can they come to visit thee, to spend an idle hour in getting their shoulders or their fingers relieved by thy soft, soothing touch? But thou art deceived by evil spirits which commit adultery with thee, that thou mayest conceive falsehoods and bring forth vanities.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1778
verses.text: Well mayest thou reject the message of the true God, as opposed to thy parchments, where in the vain imaginations of a wanton mind thou hast gone after so many false gods.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1779
verses.text: The fictions of the poets are more respectable than thine, in this at least, that they deceive no one; while the fables in thy books, by assuming an appearance of truth, mislead the childish, both young and old, and pervert their minds.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1780
verses.text: As the apostle says, they have itching ears, and turn away from hearing the truth to listen to fables.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1781
verses.text: How shouldest thou bear the sound doctrine of these tables, where the first commandment is, "Hear, O Israel, the Lord thy God is one Lord,"  when thy corrupt affections find shameful delight in so many false deities? Dost thou not remember thy love-song, where thou describest the chief ruler in perennial majesty, crowned with flowers, and of fiery countenance? To have even one such lover is shameful; for a chaste wife seeks not a husband crowned with flowers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1782
verses.text: And thou canst not say that this description or representation has a typical meaning, for thou art wont to praise Manich aeus for nothing more than for speaking to thee the simple naked truth without the disguise of figures.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1783
verses.text: So the God of thy song is a real king, bearing a sceptre and crowned with flowers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1784
verses.text: When he wears a crown of flowers, he ought to put aside his sceptre; for effeminacy and majesty are incongruous.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1785
verses.text: And then he is not thy only lover; for the song goes on to tell of twelve seasons clothed in flowers, and filled with song, throwing their flowers at their father's face.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1786
verses.text: These are twelve great gods of thine, three in each of the four regions surrounding the first deity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1787
verses.text: How this deity can be infinite, when he is thus circumscribed, no one can say.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1788
verses.text: Besides, there are countless principalities, and hosts of gods, and troops of angels, which thou sayest were not created by God, but produced from His substance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1789
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1790
verses.text: Thou art thus convicted of worshipping gods without number; for thou canst not bear the sound doctrine which teaches that there is one Son of one God, and one Spirit of both.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1791
verses.text: And these, instead of being without number, are not three Gods; for not only is their substance one and the same, but their operation by means of this substance is also one and the same, while they have a separate manifestation in the material creation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1792
verses.text: These things thou dost not understand, and canst not receive.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1793
verses.text: Thou art full, as thou sayest, for thou art steeped in blasphemous absurdities.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1794
verses.text: Will thou continue burying thyself under such crudities? Sing on, then, and open thine eyes, if thou canst, to thine own shame.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1795
verses.text: In this doctrine of lying devils thou art invited to fabulous dwellings of angels in a happy clime, and to fragrant fields where nectar flows for ever from trees and hills, in seas and rivers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1796
verses.text: These are the fictions of thy foolish heart, which revels in such idle fancies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1797
verses.text: Such expressions are sometimes used as figurative descriptions of the abundance of spiritual enjoyments; and they lead the mind of the student to inquire into their hidden meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1798
verses.text: Sometimes there is a material representation to the bodily senses, as the fire in the bush, the rod becoming a serpent, and the serpent a rod, the garment of the Lord not divided by His persecutors, the anointing of His feet or of His head by a devout woman, the branches of the multitude preceding and following Him when riding on the ass.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1799
verses.text: Sometimes, either in sleep or in a trance, the spirit is informed by means of figures taken from material things, as Jacob's ladder, and the stone in Daniel cut out without hands and growing into a mountain, and Peter's vessel, and all that John saw.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1800
verses.text: Sometimes the figures are only in the language; as in the Song of Songs, and in the parable of a householder making a marriage for his son, or that of the prodigal son, or that of the man who planted a vineyard and let it out to husbandmen.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1801
verses.text: Thou boastest of Manich aeus as having come last, not to use figures, but to explain them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1802
verses.text: His expositions throw light on ancient types, and leave no problem unsolved.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1803
verses.text: This idea is supported by the assertion that the ancient types, in vision or in action or in words, had in view the coming of Manich aeus, by whom they were all to be explained; while he, knowing that no one is to follow him, makes use of a style free from all figurative expressions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1804
verses.text: What, then, are those fields, and shady hills, and crowns of flowers, and fragrant odors, in which the desires of thy fleshly mind take pleasure? If they are not significant figures, they are either idle fancies or delirious dreams.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1805
verses.text: If they are figures, away with the impostor who seduces thee with the promise of naked truth, and then mocks thee with idle tales.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1806
verses.text: His ministers and his wretched deluded followers are wont to bait their hook with that saying of the apostle, "Now we see through a glass in a figure, but then face to face".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1807
verses.text: As if, forsooth, the Apostle Paul knew in part, and prophesied in part, and saw through a glass in a figure; whereas all this is removed at the coming of Manich aeus, who brings that which is perfect, and reveals the truth face to face.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1808
verses.text: O fallen and shameless! still to continue uttering such folly, still feeding on the wind, still embracing the idols of thine own heart.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1809
verses.text: Hast thou, then, seen face to face the king with the sceptre, and the crown of flowers, and the hosts of gods, and the great worldholder with six faces and radiant with light, and that other exalted ruler surrounded with troops of angels, and the invincible warrior with a spear in his right hand and a shield in his left, and the famous sovereign who moves the three wheels of fire, water, and wind, and Atlas, chief of all, bearing the world on his shoulders, and supporting himself on his arms? These, and a thousand other marvels, hast thou seen face to face, or are thy songs doctrines learned from lying devils, though thou knowest it not? Alas! miserable prostitute to these dreams, such are the vanities which thou drinkest up instead of the truth; and, drunk with this deadly poison, thou darest with this jest of the tablets to affront the matronly purity of the spouse of the only Son of God; because no longer under the tutorship of the law, but under the control of grace, neither proud in activity nor crouching in fear, she lives by faith, and hope, and love, the Israel in whom there is no guile, who hears what is written: "The Lord thy God is one God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1810
verses.text: This thou hearest not, and art gone a whoring after a multitude of false gods.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1811
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1812
verses.text: Of necessity these tables are against thee, for the second commandment is, "Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain;" whereas thou dost attribute the vanity of falsehood to Christ Himself, who, to remove the vanity of the fleshly mind, rose in a true body, visible to the bodily eye.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1813
verses.text: So also the third commandment about the rest of the Sabbath is against thee, for thou art tossed about by a multitude of restless fancies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1814
verses.text: How these three commandments relate to the love of God, thou hast neither the power nor the will to understand.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1815
verses.text: Shamefully headstrong and turbulent, thou hast reached the height of folly, vanity, and worthlessness; thy beauty is spoiled, and thine order perished.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1816
verses.text: I know thee, for I was once the same.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1817
verses.text: How shall I now teach thee that these three precepts relate to the love of God, of whom, and by whom, and in whom are all things? How canst thou understand this, when thy pernicious doctrines prevent thee from understanding and from obeying the seven precepts relating to the love of our neighbor, which is the bond of human society? The first of these precepts is, "Honor thy father and mother;" which Paul quotes as the first commandment with promise, and himself repeats the injunction.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1818
verses.text: But thou art taught by thy doctrine of devils to regard thy parents as thine enemies, because their union brought thee into the bonds of flesh, and laid impure fetters even on thy god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1819
verses.text: The doctrine that the production of children is an evil, directly opposes the next precept, "Thou shall not commit adultery;" for those who believe this doctrine, in order that their wives may not conceive, are led to commit adultery even in marriage.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1820
verses.text: They take wives, as the law declares, for the procreation of children; but from this erroneous fear of polluting the substance of the deity, their intercourse with their wives is not of a lawful character; and the production of children, which is the proper end of marriage, they seek to avoid.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1821
verses.text: As the apostle long ago predicted of thee, thou dost indeed forbid to marry, for thou seekest to destroy the purpose of marriage.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1822
verses.text: Thy doctrine turns marriage into an adulterous connection, and the bed-chamber into a brothel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1823
verses.text: This false doctrine leads in a similar way to the transgression of the commandment, "Thou shall not kill".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1824
verses.text: For thou dost not give bread to the hungry, from fear of imprisoning in flesh the member of thy God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1825
verses.text: From fear of fancied murder, thou dost actually commit murder.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1826
verses.text: For if thou wast to meet a beggar starving for want of food, by the law of God to refuse him food would be murder; while to give food would be murder by the law of Manich aeus.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1827
verses.text: Not one commandment in the decalogue dost thou observe.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1828
verses.text: If thou wert to abstain from theft, thou wouldst be guilty of allowing bread or food, whatever it might be, to undergo the misery of being devoured by a man of no merit, instead of running off with it to the laboratory of the stomach of thine elect; and so by theft saving thy god from the imprisonment with which he is threatened, and also from that from which he already suffers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1829
verses.text: Then, if thou art caught in the theft, wilt thou not swear by this god that thou art not guilty? For what will he do to thee when thou sayest to him, I swore by thee falsely, but it was for thy benefit; a regard for thine honor would have been fatal to thee? So the precept, Thou shall not bear false witness, will be broken, not only in thy testimony, but in thine oath, for the sake of the liberation of the members of thy god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1830
verses.text: The commandment, "Thou shall not covet thy neighbor's wife," is the only one which thy false doctrine does not oblige thee to break.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1831
verses.text: But if it is unlawful to covet our neighbor's wife, what must it be to excite covetousness in others? Remember thy beautiful gods and goddesses presenting themselves with the purpose of exciting desire in the male and female leaders of darkness, in order that the gratification of this passion might effect the liberation of this god, who is in confinement everywhere, and who requires the assistance of such self-degradation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1832
verses.text: The last commandment, "Thou shall not covet the possessions of thy neighbor," it is wholly impossible for thee to obey.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1833
verses.text: Does not this god of thine delude thee with the promise of making new worlds in a region belonging to another, to be the scene of thine imaginary triumph after thine imaginary conquest? In the desire for the accomplishment of these wild fancies, while at the same time thou believest that this land of darkness is in the closest neighborhood with thine own substance, thou certainly covetest the possessions of thy neighbor.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1834
verses.text: Well indeed mayest thou dislike the tables which contain such good precepts in opposition to thy false doctrine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1835
verses.text: The three relating to the love of God thou dost entirely set aside.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1836
verses.text: The seven by which human society is preserved thou keepest only from a regard to the opinion of men, or from fear of human laws; or good customs make thee averse to some crimes; or thou art restrained by the natural principle of not doing to another what thou wouldst not have done to thyself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1837
verses.text: But whether thou doest what thou wouldst not have done to thyself, or refrainest from doing what thou wouldst not have done to thyself, thou seest the opposition of the heresy to the law, whether thou actest according to it or not.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1838
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1839
verses.text: The true bride of Christ, whom thou hast the audacity to taunt with the stone tablets, knows the difference between the letter and the spirit, or in other words, between law and grace; and serving God no longer in the oldness of the letter, but in newness of spirit, she is not under the law, but under grace.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1840
verses.text: She is not blinded by a spirit of controversy, but learns meekly from the apostle what is this law which we are not to be under; for "it was given," he says, "on account of transgression, till the seed should come to whom the promise was made".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1841
verses.text: And again: "It entered, that the offence might abound; but where sin abounded, grace has much more abounded".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1842
verses.text: [19] Not that the law is sin, though it cannot give life without grace, but rather increases the guilt; for "where there is no law, there is no transgression".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1843
verses.text: The letter without the spirit, the law without grace, can only condemn.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1844
verses.text: So the apostle explains his meaning, in case any should not understand: "What shall we say then? Is the law sin? God forbid.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1845
verses.text: For I had not known sin but by the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1846
verses.text: For I had not known lust unless the law had said, Thou shalt not covet.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1847
verses.text: But sin, taking occasion by the commandment, deceived me, and by it slew me.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1848
verses.text: Therefore the law is holy, and the commandment holy, and just, and good.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1849
verses.text: Was then that which is good made death unto me? God forbid.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1850
verses.text: But sin, that it might appear sin, wrought death in me by that which is good".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1851
verses.text: She at whom thou scoffest knows what this means; for she asks earnestly, and seeks humbly, and knocks meekly.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1852
verses.text: She sees that no fault is found with the law, when it is said, "The letter killeth, but the spirit giveth life," any more than with knowledge, when it is said, "Knowledge puffeth up, but love edifieth".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1853
verses.text: The passage runs thus: "We know that we all have knowledge.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1854
verses.text: Knowledge puffeth up, but love edifieth".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1855
verses.text: The apostle certainly had no desire to be puffed up; but he had knowledge, because knowledge joined with love not only does not puff up, but strengthens.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1856
verses.text: So the letter when joined with the spirit, and the law when joined with grace, is no longer the letter and the law in the same sense as when by itself it kills by abounding sin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1857
verses.text: In this sense the law is even called the strength of sin, because its strict prohibitions increase the fatal pleasure of sin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1858
verses.text: Even thus, however, the law is not evil; but "sin, that it may appear sin, works death by that which is good".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1859
verses.text: So things that are not evil may often be hurtful to certain people.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1860
verses.text: The Manich aeans, when they have sore eyes, will shut out their god the sun.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1861
verses.text: The bride of Christ, then, is dead to the law, that is, to sin, which abounds more from the prohibition of the law; for the law apart from grace commands, but does not enable.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1862
verses.text: Being dead to the law in this sense, that she may be married to another who rose from the dead, she makes this distinction without any reproach to the law, which would be blasphemy against its author.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1863
verses.text: This is thy crime; for though the apostle tells thee that the law is holy, and the commandment holy, and just, and good, thou dost not acknowledge it as the production of a good being.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1864
verses.text: Its author thou makest to be one of the princes of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1865
verses.text: Here the truth confronts thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1866
verses.text: They are the words of the Apostle Paul: "The law is holy, and the commandment holy, and just, and good".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1867
verses.text: Such is the law given by Him who appointed for a great symbolical use the tablets which thou foolishly deridest.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1868
verses.text: The same law which was given by Moses becomes through Jesus Christ grace and truth; for the spirit is joined to the letter, that the righteousness of the law might begin to be fulfilled, which when unfulfilled only added the guilt of transgression.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1869
verses.text: The law which is holy, and just, and good, is the same law by which sin works death, and to which we must die, that we may be married to another who rose from the dead.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1870
verses.text: Hear what the apostle adds: "But sin, that it might appear sin, wrought death in me by that which is good, that sin by the commandment might become exceeding sinful".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1871
verses.text: Deaf and blind, dost thou not now hear and see? "Sin wrought death in me," he says, "by that which is good".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1872
verses.text: The law is always good: whether it hurts those who are destitute of grace, or benefits those who are filled with grace, itself is always good; as the sun is always good, for every creature of God is good, whether it hurts weak eyes or gladdens the sight of the healthy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1873
verses.text: Grace fits the mind for keeping the law, as health fits the eyes for seeing the sun.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1874
verses.text: And as healthy eyes die not to the pleasure of seeing the sun, but to that painful effect of the rays which beat upon the eye so as to increase the darkness; so the mind, healed by the love of the spirit, dies not to the justice of the law, but to the guilt and transgression which followed on the law in the absence of grace.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1875
verses.text: So it is said "The law is good, if used lawfully;" and immediately after of the same law, "Knowing this, that the law is not made for a righteous man".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1876
verses.text: The man who delights in righteousness itself, does not require the restraint of the letter.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1877
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1878
verses.text: The bride of Christ rejoices in the hope of full salvation, and desires for thee a happy conversion from fables to truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1879
verses.text: She desires that the fear of Adoneus, as if he were a strange lover, may not prevent thy escape from the seductions of the wily serpent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1880
verses.text: Adonai is a Hebrew word, meaning Lord, as applied only to God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1881
verses.text: In the same way the Greek word latria means service, in the sense of the service of God; and Amen means true, in a special sacred sense.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1882
verses.text: This is to be learned only from the Hebrew Scriptures, or from a translation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1883
verses.text: The Church of Christ understands and loves these names, without regarding the evils of those who scoff because they are ignorant.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1884
verses.text: What she does not yet understand, she believes may be explained, as similar things have already been explained to her.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1885
verses.text: If she is charged with loving Emmanuel, she laughs at the ignorance of the accuser, and holds fast by the truth of this name.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1886
verses.text: If she is charged with loving Messiah, she scorns her powerless adversary, and clings to her anointed Master.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1887
verses.text: Her prayer for thee is, that thou also mayest be cured of thy errors, and be built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1888
verses.text: The monstrosity with which thou ignorantly chargest the true doctrine, is really to be found in the world which, according to thy fanciful stories, is made partly of thy god and partly of the world of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1889
verses.text: This world, half savage and half divine, is worse than monstrous.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1890
verses.text: The view of such follies should make thee humble and penitent, and should lead thee to shun the serpent, who seduces thee into such errors.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1891
verses.text: If thou dost not believe what Moses says of the guile of the serpent, thou mayest be warned by Paul, who, when speaking of presenting the Church as a chaste virgin to Christ, says, "I fear lest, as the serpent beguiled Eve through his craftiness, your minds also should be corrupted from the simplicity and purity which is in Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1892
verses.text: In spite of this warning, thou hast been so misled, so infatuated by the serpent's fatal enchantments, that while he has persuaded other heretics to believe various falsehoods, he has persuaded thee to believe that he is Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1893
verses.text: Others, though fallen into the maze of manifold error, still admit the truth of the apostle's warning.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1894
verses.text: But thou art so far gone in corruption, and so lost to shame, that thou holdest as Christ the very being by whom the apostle declares that Eve was beguiled, and against whom he thus seeks to put the virgin bride of Christ on her guard.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1895
verses.text: Thy heart is darkened by the deceiver, who intoxicates thee with dreams of glittering groves.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1896
verses.text: What are these promises but dreams? What reason is there to believe them true? O drunken, but not with wine!  10.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1897
verses.text: Thou hast the impious audacity to accuse the God of the prophets of not fulfilling His promises even to His servants the Jews.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1898
verses.text: Thou dost not mention, however, any promise that is unfulfilled; otherwise it might be shown, either that the promise has been fulfilled, and so that thou dost not understand it, or that it is yet to be fulfilled, and so that thou dost not believe it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1899
verses.text: What promise has been fulfilled to thee, to make it probable that thou wilt obtain new worlds gained from the region of darkness? If there are prophets who predict the Manich aeans with praise, and if it is said that the existence of the sect is a fulfillment of this prediction, it must first be proved that these predictions were not forged by Manich aeus in order to gain followers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1900
verses.text: He does not consider falsehood sinful.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1901
verses.text: If he declares in praise of Christ that He showed false marks of wounds in His body, he can have no scruple about showing false predictions in his sheepskin volumes.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1902
verses.text: Assuredly there are predictions of the Manich aeans, less clear in the prophets, and most explicit in the apostle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1903
verses.text: For example: "The Spirit," he says, "speaketh expressly, that in the last times some shall depart from the faith, giving heed to seducing spirits, and to doctrines of devils, speaking lies in hypocrisy, having their conscience seared, forbidding to marry, abstaining from meats, which God has created to be received with thanksgiving by believers, and those who know the truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1904
verses.text: For every creature of God is good, and nothing to be refused, if it be received with thanksgiving".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1905
verses.text: The fulfillment of this in the Manich aeans is as clear as day to all that know them, and has already been proved as fully as time permits.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1906
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1907
verses.text: She whom the apostle warns against the guile of the serpent by which thou hast been corrupted, that he may present her as a chaste virgin to Christ, her only husband, acknowledges the God of the prophets as the true God, and her own God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1908
verses.text: So many of His promises have already been fulfilled to her, that she looks confidently for the fulfillment of the rest.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1909
verses.text: Nor can any one say that these prophecies have been forged to suit the present time, for they are found in the books of the Jews.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1910
verses.text: What could be more unlikely than that all nations should be blessed in Abraham's seed, as it was promised? And yet how plainly is this promise now fulfilled! The last promise is made in the following short prophecy: "Blessed are they that dwell in Thy house: they shall ever praise Thee".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1911
verses.text: When trial is past, and death, the last enemy, is destroyed, there will be rest in the constant occupation of praising God, where there shall be no arrivals and no departures.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1912
verses.text: So the prophet says elsewhere: "Praise the Lord, O Jerusalem; celebrate thy God, O Zion: for He hath strengthened the bars of thy gates; He hath blessed thy children within thee".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1913
verses.text: The gates are shut, so that none can go in or out.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1914
verses.text: The Bridegroom Himself says in the Gospel, that He will not open to the foolish virgins though they knock.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1915
verses.text: This Jerusalem, the holy Church, the bride of Christ, is described fully in the Revelation of John.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1916
verses.text: And that which commends the promises of future bliss to the belief of this chaste virgin is, that now she is in possession of what was foretold of her by the same prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1917
verses.text: For she is thus described: "Hearken, O daughter, and regard, and incline thine ear; forget also thine own people, and thy father's house.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1918
verses.text: For the King hath greatly desired thy beauty; and He is thy God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1919
verses.text: The daughters of Tyre shall worship Him with gifts; the rich among the people shall entreat thy favor.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1920
verses.text: The daughter of the King is all glorious within; her clothing is of wrought gold.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1921
verses.text: The virgins following her shall be brought unto the King: her companions shall be brought unto thee; with gladness and rejoicing shall they be brought into the temple of the King.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1922
verses.text: Instead of thy fathers, children shall be born to thee, whom thou shall make princes over all the earth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1923
verses.text: Thy name shall be remembered to all generations: therefore shall the people praise thee for ever and ever".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1924
verses.text: Unhappy victim of the serpent's guile, the inward beauty of the daughter of the King is not for thee even to think of.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1925
verses.text: For this purity of mind is that which thou hast lost in opening thine eyes to love and worship the sun and moon.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1926
verses.text: And so by the just judgment of God thou art estranged from the tree of life, which is eternal and internal wisdom; and with thee nothing is called or accounted truth or wisdom but that light which enters the eyes opened to evil, and which in thy impure mind expands and shapes itself into fanciful images.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1927
verses.text: These are thy abominable whoredoms.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1928
verses.text: Still the truth calls on thee to reflect and return.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1929
verses.text: Return to me, and thou shall be cleansed and restored, if thy shame leads thee to repentance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1930
verses.text: Hear these words of the true Truth, who neither with feigned shapes fought against the race of darkness, nor with feigned blood redeemed thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1931
verses.text: Book XVI.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1932
verses.text: Faustus willing to believe not only that the Jewish but that all Gentile prophets wrote of Christ, if it should be proved; but he would none the less insist upon rejecting their superstitions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1933
verses.text: Augustin maintains that all Moses wrote is of Christ, and that his writings must be either accepted or rejected as a whole.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1934
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1935
verses.text: Faustus said: You ask why we do not believe Moses, when Christ says, "Moses wrote of me; and if ye believed Moses, ye would also believe me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1936
verses.text: I should be glad if not only Moses, but all prophets, Jew and Gentile, had written of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1937
verses.text: It would be no hindrance, but a help to our faith, if we could cull testimonies from all hands agreeing in favor of our God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1938
verses.text: You could extract the prophecies of Christ out of the superstition which we should hate as much as ever.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1939
verses.text: I am quite willing to believe that Moses, though so much the opposite of Christ, may seem to have written of Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1940
verses.text: No one but would gladly find a flower in every thorn, and food in every plant, and honey in every insect, although we would not feed on insects or on grass, nor wear thorns as a crown.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1941
verses.text: No one but would wish pearls to be found in every deep, and gems in every land, and fruit on every tree.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1942
verses.text: We may eat fish from the sea without drinking the water.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1943
verses.text: We may take the useful, and reject what is hurtful.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1944
verses.text: And why may we not take the prophecies of Christ from a religion the rites of which we condemn as useless? This need not make us liable to be led into the bondage of the errors; for we do not hate the unclean spirits less because they confessed plainly and openly that Jesus was the Son of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1945
verses.text: If any similar testimony is found in Moses, I will accept it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1946
verses.text: But I will not on this account be brought into subjection to his law, which to my mind is pure Paganism.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1947
verses.text: There is no reason whatever for thinking that I can have any objections to receiving prophecies of Christ from every spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1948
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1949
verses.text: Since you have proved that Christ declared that Moses wrote of him, I should be very grateful if you would show me what he has written.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1950
verses.text: I have searched the Scriptures, as we are told to do, and have found no prophecies of Christ, either because there are none, or because I could not understand them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1951
verses.text: The only escape from this perplexity was in one or other of two conclusions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1952
verses.text: Either this verse must be spurious, or Jesus a liar.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1953
verses.text: As it is not consistent with piety to suppose God a liar, I preferred to attribute falsehood to the writers, rather than to the Author, of truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1954
verses.text: Moreover, He Himself tells that those who came before him were thieves and robbers, which applies first of all to Moses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1955
verses.text: And when, on the occasion of His speaking of His own majesty, and calling Himself the light of the world, the Jews angrily rejoined, "Thou bearest witness of thyself, thy witness is not true," I do not find that He appealed to the prophecies of Moses, as might have been expected.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1956
verses.text: Instead of this, as having no connection with the Jews, and receiving no testimony from their fathers, He replied: "It is written in your law, that the testimony of two men is true.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1957
verses.text: I am one who bear witness of myself, and the Father who sent me beareth witness of me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1958
verses.text: He referred to the voice from heaven which all had heard: "This is my beloved Son, believe Him".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1959
verses.text: I think it likely that if Christ had said that Moses wrote of Him, the ingenious hostility of the Jews would have led them at once to ask what He supposed Moses to have written.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1960
verses.text: The silence of the Jews is a proof that Jesus never made such a statement.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1961
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1962
verses.text: My chief reason, however, for suspecting the genuineness of this verse is what I said before, that in all my search of the writings of Moses I have found no prophecy of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1963
verses.text: But now that I have found in you a reader of superior intelligence, I hope to learn something; and I promise to be grateful if no feeling of ill-will prevents you from giving me the benefit of your higher attainments, as your lofty style of reproof entitles me to expect from you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1964
verses.text: I ask for instruction in whatever the writings of Moses contain about our God and Lord which has escaped me in reading.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1965
verses.text: I beseech you not to use the ignorant argument that Christ affirms Moses to have written of Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1966
verses.text: For suppose you had not to deal with me, as in my case there is an obligation to believe Him whom I profess to follow, but with a Jew or a Gentile, in reply to the statement that Moses wrote of Christ, they will ask for proofs.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1967
verses.text: What shall we say to them? We cannot quote Christ's authority, for they do not believe in Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1968
verses.text: We must point out what Moses wrote.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1969
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1970
verses.text: What, then, shall we point to? Shall it be that passage which you often quote where the God of Moses says to him: "I will raise up unto them from among their brethren a prophet like unto thee?"  But the Jew can see that this does not refer to Christ, and there is every reason against our thinking that it does.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1971
verses.text: Christ was not a prophet, nor was He like Moses: for Moses was a man, and Christ was God; Moses was a sinner, and Christ sinless; Moses was born by ordinary generation, and Christ of a virgin according to you, or, as I hold, not born at all: Moses, for offending his God, was put to death on the mountain; and Christ suffered voluntarily, and the Father was well pleased in Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1972
verses.text: If we were to assert that Christ was a prophet like Moses, the Jew would either deride us as ignorant or pronounce us untruthful.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1973
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1974
verses.text: Or shall we take another favorite passage of yours: "They shall see their life hanging, and shall not believe their life?"  You insert the words "on a tree," which are not in the original.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1975
verses.text: Nothing can be easier than to show that this has no reference to Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1976
verses.text: Moses is uttering dire threatenings in case the people should depart from his law, and says among other things that they would be taken captive by their enemies, and would be expecting death day and night, having no confidence in the life allowed them by their conquerors, so that their life would hang in uncertainty from fear of impending danger.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1977
verses.text: This passage will not do, we must try others.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1978
verses.text: I cannot admit that the words, "Cursed is every one that hangeth on a tree," refer to Christ, or when it is said that the prince or prophet must be killed who should try to turn away the people from their God, or should break any of the commandments.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1979
verses.text: That Christ did this I am obliged to grant.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1980
verses.text: But if you assert that these things were written of Christ, it may be asked in reply, What spirit dictated these prophecies in which Moses curses Christ and orders him to be killed? If he had the Spirit of God, these things are not written of Christ; if they are written of Christ, he had not the Spirit of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1981
verses.text: The Spirit of God would not curse Christ, or order Him to be killed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1982
verses.text: To vindicate Moses, you must confess that these passages too have no reference to Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1983
verses.text: So, if you have no others to show, there are none.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1984
verses.text: If there are none, Christ could not have said that there were; and if Christ did not say so, that verse is spurious.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1985
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1986
verses.text: The next verse too is suspicious, "If ye believed Moses, ye would also believe me;" for the religion of Moses is so entirely different from that of Christ, that if the Jews believed one, they could not believe the other.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1987
verses.text: Moses strictly forbids any work to be done on Sabbath, and gives as a reason for this prohibition that God made the world and all that is therein in six days, and rested on the seventh day, which is Sabbath; and therefore blessed or sanctified it as His haven of repose after toil, and commanded that breaking the Sabbath should be punished with death.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1988
verses.text: The Jews, in obedience to Moses, insisted strongly on this, and so would not even listen to Christ when He told them that God always works, and that no day is appointed for the intermission of His pure and unwearied energy, and that accordingly He Himself had to work incessantly even on Sabbath.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1989
verses.text: "My Father," he says, "worketh always, and I too must work".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1990
verses.text: Again, Moses places circumcision among the rites pleasing to God, and commands every male to be circumcised in the foreskin of his flesh, and declares that this is a necessary sign of the covenant which God made with Abraham, and that every male not circumcised would be cut off from his tribe, and from his part in the inheritance promised to Abraham and to his seed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1991
verses.text: In this observance, too, the Jews were very zealous, and consequently could not believe in Christ, who made light of these things, and declared that a man when circumcised became twofold a child of hell.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1992
verses.text: Again, Moses is very particular about the distinction in animal foods, and discourses like an epicure on the merits of fish, and birds, and quadrupeds, and orders some to be eaten as clean, and others which are unclean not to be touched.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1993
verses.text: Among the unclean he reckons the swine and the hare, and fish without scales, and quadrupeds that neither divide the hoof nor chew the cud.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1994
verses.text: In this also the Jews carefully obeyed Moses, and so could not believe in Christ, who taught that all food is alike, and though he allowed no animal food to his own disciples, gave full liberty to the laity to eat whatever they pleased, and taught that men are polluted not by what goes into the mouth, but by the evil things which come out of it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1995
verses.text: In these and many other things the doctrine of Jesus, as everybody knows, contradicts that of Moses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1996
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1997
verses.text: Not to enumerate all the points of difference, it is enough to mention this one fact, that most Christian sects, and, as is well known, the Catholics, pay no regard to what is prescribed in the writings of Moses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1998
verses.text: If this does not originate in some error, but in the doctrine correctly transmitted from Christ and His disciples, you surely must acknowledge that the teaching of Jesus is opposed to that of Moses, and that the Jews did not believe in Christ on account of their attachment to Moses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:1999
verses.text: How can it be otherwise than false that Jesus said to the Jews, "If ye believed Moses, ye would believe me also," when it is perfectly clear that their belief in Moses prevented them from believing in Jesus, which they might have done if they had left off believing in Moses? Again I ask you to show me anything that Moses wrote of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2000
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2001
verses.text: Elsewhere Faustus says: When you find no passage to point to, you use this weak and inappropriate argument, that a Christian is bound to believe Christ when he says that Moses wrote of Him, and that whoever does not believe this is not a Christian.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2002
verses.text: It would be far better to confess at once that you cannot find any passage.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2003
verses.text: This argument might be used with me, because my reverence for Christ compels me to believe what He says.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2004
verses.text: Still it may be a question whether this is Christ's own declaration, requiring absolute belief, or only the writer's, to be carefully examined.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2005
verses.text: And disbelief in falsehood is no offence to Christ, but to impostors.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2006
verses.text: But of whatever use this argument may be with Christians, it is wholly inapplicable in the case of the Jew or Gentile, with whom we are supposed to be discussing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2007
verses.text: And even with Christians the argument is objectionable.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2008
verses.text: When the Apostle Thomas was in doubt, Christ did not spurn him from Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2009
verses.text: Instead of saying, "Believe, if thou art a disciple; whoever does not believe is not a disciple," Christ sought to heal the wounds of his mind by showing him the marks of the wounds in His own body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2010
verses.text: Does it become you then to tell me that I am not a Christian because I am in doubt, not about Christ, but about the genuineness of a remark attributed to Christ? But, you say, He calls those especially blessed, who have not seen, and yet have believed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2011
verses.text: If you think that this refers to believing without the use of judgment and reason, you are welcome to this blind blessedness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2012
verses.text: I shall be content with rational blessedness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2013
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2014
verses.text: Augustin replied: Your idea of taking any prophecies of Christ to be found in Moses, as a fish out of the sea, while you throw away the water from which the fish is taken, is a clever one.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2015
verses.text: But since all that Moses wrote is of Christ, or relates to Christ, either as predicting Him by words and actions, or as illustrating His grace and glory, you, with your faith in the untrue and untruthful Christ from the writings of Manich aeus, and your unbelief in Moses, will not even eat the fish.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2016
verses.text: Moreover, though you are sincere in your hostility to Moses, you are hypocritical in your praise of fish.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2017
verses.text: For how can you say that there is no harm in eating a fish taken out of the sea, when your doctrine is that such food is so hurtful, that you would rather starve than make use of it?
