If all flesh is unclean, as you say it is, and if the wretched life of your god is confined in all water or plants, from which it is liberated by your using them for food, according to your own vile superstition, you must throw away the fish you have praised, and drink the water and eat the thistles you speak of as useless.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2018
verses.text: As for your comparison of the servant of God to devils, as if his prophecies of Christ resembled their confession, the servant does not refuse to bear the reproach of his master.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2019
verses.text: If the Master of the house was called Beelzebub, how much more they of His household!  You have learned this reproach from Christ's enemies; and you are worse than they were.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2020
verses.text: They did not believe that Jesus was Christ, and therefore thought Him an impostor.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2021
verses.text: But the only doctrine you believe in is that which dares to make Christ a liar.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2022
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2023
verses.text: What reason have you for saying that the law of Moses is pure Paganism? Is it because it speaks of a temple, and an altar of sacrifices, and priests? But all these names are found also in the New Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2024
verses.text: "Destroy," Christ says, "this temple, and in three days I will raise it up;"  and again, "When thou offerest thy gift at the altar;"  and again, "Go, show thyself to the priest, and offer for thyself a sacrifice as Moses commanded, for a testimony unto them".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2025
verses.text: What these things prefigured the Lord Himself partly tells us, when He calls His own body the temple; and we learn also from the apostle, who says, "The temple of God is holy, which temple ye are;"  and again, "I beseech you therefore by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable to God;"  and in similar passages.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2026
verses.text: As the same apostle says, in words which cannot be too often quoted, these things were our examples, for they were not the work of devils, but of the one true God who made heaven and earth, and who, though not needing such things, yet, suiting His requirements to the time, made ancient observances significant of future realities.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2027
verses.text: Since you pretend to abhor Paganism, though it is only that you may lead astray by your deception unlearned Christians or those not established in the faith, show us any authority in Christian books for your worship and service of the sun and moon.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2028
verses.text: Your heresy is liker Paganism than the law of Moses is.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2029
verses.text: For you do not worship Christ, but only something that you call Christ, a fiction of your own fancy; and the gods you serve are either the bodies visible in the heavens, or hosts of your own contrivance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2030
verses.text: If you do not build shrines for these worthless idols, the creatures of the imagination, you make your hearts their temple.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2031
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2032
verses.text: You ask me to show what Moses wrote of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2033
verses.text: Many passages have already been pointed out.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2034
verses.text: But who could point out all? Besides, when any quotation is made, you are ready perversely to try to give the words another meaning; or if the evidence is too strong to be resisted, you will say that you take the passage as a sweet fish out of the salt water, and that you will not therefore consent to drink all the brine of the books of Moses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2035
verses.text: It will be enough, then, to take those passages in the Hebrew law which Faustus has chosen for criticism, and to show that, when rightly understood, they apply to Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2036
verses.text: For if the things which our adversary ridicules and condemns are made to prove that he himself is condemned by Christian truth, it will be evident that either the mere quotation or the careful examination of the other passages will be enough to show their agreement with Christian faith.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2037
verses.text: Well, then, O thou full of all subtilty, when the Lord in the Gospel says, "If ye believed Moses, ye would believe me also, for he wrote of me,"  there is no occasion for the great perplexity you pretend to be in, or for the alternative of either pronouncing this verse spurious or calling Jesus a liar.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2038
verses.text: The verse is as genuine as its words are true.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2039
verses.text: I preferred, says Faustus, to attribute falsehood to the writers, rather than to the Author of truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2040
verses.text: What sort of faith can you have in Christ as the author of truth, when your doctrine is that His flesh and His death, His wounds and their marks, were feigned? And where is your authority for saying that Christ is the author of truth, if you dare to attribute falsehood to those who wrote of Him, whose testimony has come down to us with the confirmation of those immediately succeeding them? You have not seen Christ, nor has He conversed with you as with the apostles, nor called you from heaven as He did Saul.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2041
verses.text: What knowledge or belief can we have of Christ, but on the authority of Scripture? Or if there is falsehood in the Gospel which has been widely published among all nations, and has been held in such high sacredness in all churches since the name of Christ was first preached, where shall we find a trustworthy record of Christ? If the Gospel is called in question in spite of the general consent regarding it, there can be no writing which a man may not call spurious if he does not wish to believe it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2042
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2043
verses.text: You go on to quote Christ's words, that all who came before Him were thieves and robbers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2044
verses.text: How do you know that these were Christ's words, but from the Gospel? You profess faith in these words, as if you had heard them from the mouth of the Lord Himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2045
verses.text: But if any one declares the verse to be spurious, and denies that Christ said this, you will have, in reply, to exert yourself in vindication of the authority of the Gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2046
verses.text: Unhappy being! what you refuse to believe is written in the same place as that which you quote as spoken by the Lord Himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2047
verses.text: We believe both, for we believe the sacred narrative in which both are contained.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2048
verses.text: We believe both that Moses wrote of Christ, and that all that came before Christ were thieves and robbers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2049
verses.text: By their coming He means their not being sent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2050
verses.text: Those who were sent, as Moses and the holy prophets, came not before Him, but with Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2051
verses.text: They did not proudly wish to precede Him, but were the humble bearers of the message which He uttered by them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2052
verses.text: According to the meaning which you give to the Lord's words, it is plain that with you there can be no prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2053
verses.text: And so you have made a Christ for yourselves who should prophesy a Christ to come.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2054
verses.text: If you have any prophets of your own, they will have, of course, no authority, as not being recognized by any others; but if there are any that you dare to quote as prophesying that Christ would come in an unreal body, and would suffer an unreal death, and would show to His doubting disciples unreal marks of wounds, not to speak of the abominable nature of such prophecies, and of the evident untruthfulness of those who commend falsehood in Christ, by your own interpretation those prophets must have been thieves and robbers, for they could not have spoken of Christ as coming in any manner unless they had come before Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2055
verses.text: If by those who came before Christ we understand those who would not come with Him,—that is, with the Word of God,—but without being sent by God brought their own falsehoods to men, you yourselves, although you are born in this world after the death and the resurrection of Christ, are thieves and robbers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2056
verses.text: For, without waiting for His illumination that you might preach His truth, you have come before Him to preach up your own deceits.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2057
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2058
verses.text: In the passage where we read of the Jews saying to Christ, Thou bearest witness of thyself, thy witness is not true, you do not see that Christ replies by saying that Moses wrote of Him, simply because you have not got the eye of piety to see with.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2059
verses.text: The answer of Christ is this: "It is written in your law, that the testimony of two men is true; I am one who bear witness of myself, and the Father that sent me beareth witness of me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2060
verses.text: What does this mean, if rightly understood, but that this number of witnesses required by the law was fixed upon and consecrated in the spirit of prophecy, that even thus might be prefigured the future revelation of the Father and Son, whose spirit is the Holy Spirit of the inseparable Trinity? So it is written: "In the mouth of two or three witnesses shall every word be established".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2061
verses.text: As a matter of fact, one witness generally speaks the truth, while a number tell lies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2062
verses.text: And the world, in its conversion to Christianity, believed one apostle preaching the gospel rather than the mistaken multitude who persecuted him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2063
verses.text: There was a special reason for requiring this number of witnesses, and in His answer the Lord implied that Moses prophesied of Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2064
verses.text: Do you carp at His saying your law instead of the law of God? But, as every one knows, this is the common expression in Scripture.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2065
verses.text: Your law means the law given to you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2066
verses.text: So the apostle speaks of his gospel, while at the same time he declares that he received it not from man, but by the revelation of Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2067
verses.text: You might as well say that Christ denies God to be His Father, when He uses the words your Father instead of our Father.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2068
verses.text: Again, you should refuse to believe the voice which you allude to as having come from heaven, This is my beloved Son, believe Him, because you did not hear it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2069
verses.text: But if you believe this because you find it in the sacred Scriptures, you will also find there what you deny, that Moses wrote of Christ, besides many other things that you do not acknowledge as true.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2070
verses.text: Do you not see that your own mischievous argument may be used to prove that this voice never came from heaven? To your own destruction, and to the detriment of the welfare of mankind, you try to weaken the authority of the gospel, by arguing that it cannot be true that Christ said that Moses wrote of Him; because if He had said this, the ingenious hostility of the Jews would have led them at once to ask what He supposed Moses to have written of Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2071
verses.text: In the same way, it might be impiously argued that if that voice had really come from heaven, all the Jews who heard it would have believed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2072
verses.text: Why are you so unreasonable as not to consider that, as it was possible for the Jews to remain hardened in unbelief after hearing the voice from heaven, so it was possible for them, when Christ said that Moses wrote of Him, to refrain from asking what Moses wrote, because in their ingenious hostility they were afraid of being proved to be in the wrong?  14.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2073
verses.text: Besides that this argument is an impious assault on the gospel, Faustus himself is aware of its feebleness, and therefore insists more on what he calls his chief difficulty,—that in all his search of the writings of Moses he has found no prophecies of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2074
verses.text: The obvious reply is, that he does not understand.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2075
verses.text: And if any one asks why he does not understand, the answer is that he reads with a hostile, unbelieving mind; he does not search in order to know, but thinks he knows when he is ignorant.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2076
verses.text: This vainglorious presumption either blinds the eye of his understanding so as to prevent his seeing anything, or distorts his vision, so that his remarks of approval or disapproval are misdirected.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2077
verses.text: I ask, he says, for instruction in whatever the writings of Moses contain about our God and Lord, which has escaped me in reading.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2078
verses.text: I reply at once that it has all escaped him, for all is written of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2079
verses.text: As we cannot go through the whole, I will, with the help of God, comply with your request, to the extent I have already promised, by showing that the passages which you specially criticise refer to Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2080
verses.text: You tell me not to use the ignorant argument that Christ affirms Moses to have written of Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2081
verses.text: But if I use this argument, it is not because I am ignorant, but because I am a believer.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2082
verses.text: I acknowledge that this argument will not convince a Gentile or a Jew.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2083
verses.text: But, in spite of all your evasions, you are obliged to confess that it tells against you, who boast of possessing a kind of Christianity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2084
verses.text: You say, Suppose you had not to deal with me, as in my case there is an obligation to believe Him whom I profess to follow, but with a Jew or a Gentile.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2085
verses.text: This is as much as to say that you, at any rate, with whom I have at present to do, are satisfied that Moses wrote of Christ; for you are not bold enough to discard altogether the well-grounded authority of the Gospel where Christ's own declaration is recorded.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2086
verses.text: Even when you attack this authority indirectly, you feel that you are attacking your own position.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2087
verses.text: You are aware that if you refuse to believe the Gospel, which is so generally known and received, you must fail utterly in the attempt to substitute for it any trustworthy record of the sayings and doings of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2088
verses.text: You are afraid that the loss of the Christian name might lead to the exposure of your absurdities to universal scorn and condemnation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2089
verses.text: Accordingly you try to recover yourself, by saying that your profession of Christianity obliges you to believe these words of the Gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2090
verses.text: So you, at any rate, which is all that we need care for just now, are caught and slain in this death blow to your errors.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2091
verses.text: You are forced to confess that Moses wrote of Christ, because the Gospel, which your profession obliges you to believe, states that Christ said so.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2092
verses.text: As regards a discussion with a Jew or a Gentile, I have already shown as well as I could how I think it should be conducted.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2093
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2094
verses.text: I still hold that there is a reference to Christ in the passage which you select for refutation, where God says to Moses, "I will raise up unto them from among their brethren a prophet like unto thee".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2095
verses.text: The string of showy antitheses with which you try to ornament your dull discourse does not at all affect my belief of this truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2096
verses.text: You attempt to prove, by a comparison of Christ and Moses, that they are unlike, and that therefore the words, "I will raise up a prophet like unto thee," cannot be understood of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2097
verses.text: You specify a number of particulars in which you find a diversity: that the one is man, and the other God; that one is a sinner, the other sinless; that one is born of ordinary generation, the other, as we hold, of a virgin, and, as you hold, not even of a virgin; the one incurs God's anger, and is put to death on a mountain, the other suffers voluntarily, having throughout the approval of His Father.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2098
verses.text: But surely things may be said to be like, although they are not like in every respect.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2099
verses.text: Besides the resemblance between things of the same nature, as between two men, or between parents and children, or between men in general, or any species of animals, or in trees, between one olive and another, or one laurel and another, there is often a resemblance in things of a different nature, as between a wild and a tame olive, or between wheat and barley.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2100
verses.text: These things are to some extent allied.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2101
verses.text: But there is the greatest possible distance between the Son of God, by whom all things were made, and a beast or a stone.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2102
verses.text: And yet in the Gospel we read, "Behold the Lamb of God,"  and in the apostle, "That rock was Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2103
verses.text: [19] This could not be said except on the supposition of some resemblance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2104
verses.text: What wonder, then, if Christ condescended to become like Moses, when He was made like the lamb which God by Moses commanded His people to eat as a type of Christ, enjoining that its blood should be used as a means of protection, and that it should be called the Passover, which every one must admit to be fulfilled in Christ? The Scripture, I acknowledge, shows points of difference; and the Scripture also, as I call on you to acknowledge, shows points of resemblance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2105
verses.text: There are points of both kinds, and one can be proved as well as the other.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2106
verses.text: Christ is unlike man, for He is God; and it is written of Him that He is "over all, God blessed for ever".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2107
verses.text: Christ is also like man, for He is man; and it is likewise written of Him, that He is the "Mediator between God and man, the man Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2108
verses.text: Christ is unlike a sinner, for He is ever holy; and He is like a sinner, for "God sent His Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, that by sin He might condemn sin in the flesh".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2109
verses.text: Christ is unlike a man born in ordinary generation, for He was born of a virgin; and yet He is like, for He too was born of a woman, to whom it was said, "That holy thing which shall be born of thee shall be called the Son of God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2110
verses.text: Christ is unlike a man, who dies on account of his own sin, for He died without sin, and of His own free-will; and again, He is like, for He too died a real death of the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2111
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2112
verses.text: You ought not to say, in disparagement of Moses, that he was a sinner, and that he was put to death on a mountain because his God was angry with him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2113
verses.text: For Moses could glory in the Lord as his Saviour, who is also the Saviour of him who says, "Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners, of whom I am chief".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2114
verses.text: Moses, indeed, is accused by the voice of God, because his faith showed signs of weakness when he was commanded to draw water out of the rock.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2115
verses.text: In this he may have sinned as Peter did, when from the weakness of his faith he became afraid in the midst of the waves.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2116
verses.text: But we cannot think from this, that he who, as the Gospel tells us, was counted worthy to be present with the Lord along with holy Elias on the mount of transfiguration, was separated from the eternal fellowship of the saints.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2117
verses.text: The sacred history shows in what favor he was with God even after his sin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2118
verses.text: But since you may ask why God speaks of this sin as deserving the punishment of death, and as I have promised to point out prophecies of Christ in those passages which you select for criticism, I will try, with the Lord's help, to show that what you object to in the death of Moses is, when rightly understood, prophetical of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2119
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2120
verses.text: We often find in the symbolical passages of Scripture, that the same person appears in different characters on different occasions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2121
verses.text: So, on this occasion, Moses represents and prefigures the Jewish people as placed under the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2122
verses.text: As, then, Moses, when he struck the rock with his rod, doubted the power of God, so the people who were under the law given by Moses, when they nailed Christ to the cross, did not believe Him to be the power of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2123
verses.text: And as water flowed from the smitten rock for those that were athirst, so life comes to believers from the stroke of the Lord's passion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2124
verses.text: The testimony of the apostle is clear and decisive on this point, when he says, "This rock was Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2125
verses.text: In the command of God, that the death of the flesh of Moses should take place on the mountain, we see the divine appointment that the carnal doubt of the divinity of Christ should die on Christ's exaltation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2126
verses.text: As the rock is Christ, so is the mountain.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2127
verses.text: The rock is the fortitude of His humiliation; the mountain the height of His exaltation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2128
verses.text: For as the apostle says, "This rock was Christ," so Christ Himself says, "A city set upon an hill cannot be hid,"   showing that He is the hill, and believers the city built upon the glory of His name.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2129
verses.text: The carnal mind lives when, like the smitten rock, the humiliation of Christ on the cross is despised.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2130
verses.text: For Christ crucified is to the Jews a stumbling-block, and to the Greeks foolishness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2131
verses.text: And the carnal mind dies when, like the mountain-top, Christ is seen in His exaltation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2132
verses.text: "For to them that are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ is the power of God, and the wisdom of God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2133
verses.text: Moses therefore ascended the mount, that in the death of the flesh he might be received by the living spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2134
verses.text: If Faustus had ascended, he would not have uttered carnal objections from a dead mind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2135
verses.text: It was the carnal mind that made Peter dread the smiting of the rock, when, on the occasion of the Lord's foretelling His passion, he said, "Be it far from Thee, Lord; spare Thyself".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2136
verses.text: And this sin too was severely rebuked, when the Lord replied, "Get thee behind me, Satan; thou art an offense unto me: for thou savorest not the things which be of God, but those which be of men".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2137
verses.text: And where did this carnal distrust die but in the glorification of Christ, as on a mountain height? If it was alive when Peter timidly denied Christ, it was dead when he fearlessly preached Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2138
verses.text: It was alive in Saul, when, in his aversion to the offense of the cross, he made havoc of the Christian faith, and where but on this mountain had it died, when Paul was able to say, "I live no longer, but Christ liveth in me?"  18.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2139
verses.text: What other reason has your heretical folly to give for thinking that there is no prophecy of Christ in the words, "I will raise up unto them a Prophet from among their brethren, like unto thee?" Your showing Christ to be unlike Moses is no reason; for we can show that in other respects He is like.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2140
verses.text: How can you object to Christ's being called a prophet, since He condescended to be a man, and actually foretold many future events? What is a prophet, but one who predicts events beyond human foresight? So Christ says of Himself: "A prophet is not without honor, save in his own country".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2141
verses.text: But, turning from you, since you have already acknowledged that your profession of Christianity obliges you to believe the Gospel, I address myself to the Jew, who enjoys the poor privilege of liberty from the yoke of Christ, and who therefore thinks it allowable to say: Your Christ spoke falsely; Moses wrote nothing of him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2142
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2143
verses.text: Let the Jews say what prophet is meant in this promise of God to Moses: "I will raise up unto them a Prophet from among their brethren, like unto thee".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2144
verses.text: Many prophets appeared after Moses; but one in particular is here pointed out.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2145
verses.text: The Jews will perhaps naturally think of the successor of Moses, who led into the promised land the people that Moses had brought out of Egypt.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2146
verses.text: Having this successor of Moses in his mind, he may perhaps laugh at me for asking to what prophet the words of the promise refer, since it is recorded who followed Moses in ruling and leading the people.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2147
verses.text: When he has laughed at my ignorance, as Faustus supposes him to do, I will still continue my inquiries, and will desire my laughing opponent to give me a serious answer to the question why Moses changed the name of this successor, who was preferred to himself as the leader of the people into the promised land, to show that the law given by Moses not to save, but to convince the sinner, cannot lead us into heaven, but only the grace and truth which are by Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2148
verses.text: This successor was called Osea, and Moses gave him the name of Jesus.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2149
verses.text: Why then did he give him this name when he sent him from the valley of Pharan into the land into which he was to lead the people?  The true Jesus says, "If I go and prepare a place for you, I will come again, and receive you unto myself".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2150
verses.text: I will ask the Jew if the prophet does not show the prophetical meaning of these things when he says, "God shall come from Africa, and the Holy One from Pharan".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2151
verses.text: Does this not mean that the holy God would come with the name of him who came from Africa by Pharan, that is, with the name of Jesus? Then, again, it is the Word of God Himself who speaks when He promises to provide this successor to Moses, speaking of him as an angel,—a name commonly given in Scripture to those carrying any message.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2152
verses.text: The words are: "Behold I send my angel before thy face, to preserve thee in the way, and to bring thee into the land which I have sworn to give thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2153
verses.text: Take heed unto him, and obey, and beware of unbelief in him; for he will not take anything from thee wrongfully, for my name is in him".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2154
verses.text: Consider these words.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2155
verses.text: Let the Jew, not to speak of the Manich aean, say what other angel he can find in Scripture to whom these words apply, but this leader who was to bring the people into the land of promise.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2156
verses.text: Then let him inquire who it was that succeeded Moses, and brought in the people.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2157
verses.text: He will find that it was Jesus, and that this was not his name at first, but after his name was changed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2158
verses.text: It follows that He who said, "My name is in him," is the true Jesus, the leader who brings His people into the inheritance of eternal life, according to the New Testament, of which the Old was a figure.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2159
verses.text: No event or action could have a more distinctly prophetical character than this, where the very name is a prediction.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2160
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2161
verses.text: It follows that this Jew, if he wishes to be a Jew inwardly, in the spirit, and not in the letter, if he wishes to be thought a true Israelite, in whom is no guile, will recognize in this dead Jesus, who led the people into the land of mortality, a figure of the true living Jesus, whom he may follow into the land of life.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2162
verses.text: In this way, he will no longer in a hostile spirit resist so plain a prophecy, but, influenced by the allusion to the Jesus of the Old Testament, he will be prepared to listen meekly to Him whose name he bore, and who leads to the true land of promise; for He says, "Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the land".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2163
verses.text: The Gentile also, if his heart is not too stony, if he is one of those stones from which God raises up children unto Abraham, must allow it to be wonderful that in the ancient books of the people of whom Jesus was born, so plain a prophecy, including His very name, is found recorded; and must remark at the same time, that it is not any man of the name of Jesus who is prophesied of, but a divine person, because God said that His name was in that man who was appointed to rule the people, and to lead them into the kingdom, and who by a change of name was called Jesus.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2164
verses.text: In His being sent with this new name, He brings a great and divine message, and is therefore called an Angel, which, as every tyro in Greek knows, means messenger.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2165
verses.text: No Gentile, therefore, if he were not perverse and obstinate, would despise these books merely because he is not subject to the law of the Hebrews, to whom the books belong; but would think highly of the books, no matter whose they were, on finding in them prophecies of such ancient date, and of what he sees now taking place.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2166
verses.text: Instead of despising Christ Jesus because He is foretold in the Hebrew Scriptures, he would conclude that one thought worthy of being the subject of prophetic description, whoever the writers might be, for so many ages before His coming into the world,—sometimes in plain announcements, sometimes in figure by symbolic actions and utterances,—must claim to be regarded with profound admiration and reverence, and to be followed with implicit reliance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2167
verses.text: Thus the facts of Christian history would prove the truth of the prophecy, and the prophecy would prove the claims of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2168
verses.text: Call this fancy, if it is not actually the case that men all over the world have been led, and are now led, to believe in Christ by reading these books.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2169
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2170
verses.text: In view of the multitudes from all nations who have become zealous believers in these books, it is laughably absurd to tell us that it is impossible to persuade a Gentile to learn the Christian faith from Jewish books.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2171
verses.text: Indeed, it is a great confirmation of our faith that such important testimony is borne by enemies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2172
verses.text: The believing Gentiles cannot suppose these testimonies to Christ to be recent forgeries; for they find them in books held sacred for so many ages by those who crucified Christ, and still regarded with the highest veneration by those who every day blaspheme Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2173
verses.text: If the prophecies of Christ were the production of the preachers of Christ, we might suspect their genuineness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2174
verses.text: But now the preacher expounds the text of the blasphemer.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2175
verses.text: In this way the Most High God orders the blindness of the ungodly for the profit of the saint, in His righteous government bringing good out of evil, that those who by their own choice live wickedly may be, in His just judgment, made the instruments of His will.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2176
verses.text: So, lest those that were to preach Christ to the world should be thought to have forged the prophecies which speak of Christ as to be born, to work miracles, to suffer unjustly, to die, to rise again, to ascend to heaven, to publish the gospel of eternal life among all nations, the unbelief of the Jews has been made of signal benefit to us; so that those who do not receive in their heart for their own good these truths, carry, in their hands for our benefit the writings in which these truths are contained.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2177
verses.text: And the unbelief of the Jews increases rather than lessens the authority of the books, for this blindness is itself foretold.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2178
verses.text: They testify to the truth by their not understanding it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2179
verses.text: By not understanding the books which predict that they would not understand, they prove these books to be true.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2180
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2181
verses.text: In the passage, "Thou shalt see thy life hanging, and shalt not believe thy life,"  Faustus is deceived by the ambiguity of the words.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2182
verses.text: The words may be differently interpreted; but that they cannot be understood of Christ is not said by Faustus, nor can be said by anyone who does not deny that Christ is life, or that He was seen by the Jews hanging on the cross, or that they did not believe Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2183
verses.text: Since Christ Himself says, "I am the life,"  and since there is no doubt that He was seen hanging by the unbelieving Jews, I see no reason for doubting that this was written of Christ; for, as Christ says, Moses wrote of Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2184
verses.text: Since we have already refuted Faustus' arguments by which he tries to show that the words, "I will raise up from among their brethren a prophet like unto thee," do not apply to Christ, because Christ is not like Moses, we need not insist on this other prophecy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2185
verses.text: Since, in the one case, his argument is that Christ is unlike Moses, so here he ought to argue that Christ is not the life, or that He was not seen hanging by the unbelieving Jews.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 1:2186
verses.text: But as he has not said this, and as no one will now venture.

chapters.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1
verses.text: to say so, there should be no difficulty in accepting this too as a prophecy of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, uttered by His servant.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2
verses.text: These words, says Faustus, occur in a chapter of curses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:3
verses.text: But why should it be the less a prophecy because it occurs in the midst of prophecies? Or why should it not be a prophecy of Christ, although the context does not seem to refer to Christ? Indeed, among all the curses which the Jews brought on themselves by their sinful pride, nothing could be worse than this, that they should see their Life—that is, the Son of God —hanging, and should not believe their Life.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:4
verses.text: For the curses of prophecy are not hostile imprecations, but announcements of coming judgment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:5
verses.text: Hostile imprecations are forbidden, for it is said, "Bless, and curse not".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:6
verses.text: But prophetic announcements are often found in the writings of the saints, as when the Apostle Paul says: "Alexander the coppersmith has done me much evil; the Lord shall reward him according to his works".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:7
verses.text: So it might be thought that the apostle was prompted by angry feeling to utter this imprecation: "I would that they were even made eunuchs that trouble you".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:8
verses.text: But if we remember who the writer is, we may see in this ambiguous expression an ingenious style of benediction.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:9
verses.text: For there are eunuchs which have made themselves eunuchs for the kingdom of heaven's sake.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:10
verses.text: If Faustus had a pious appetite for Christian food, he would have found a similar ambiguity in the words of Moses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:11
verses.text: By the Jews the declaration, "Thou shalt see thy life hanging, and shalt not believe thy life," may have been understood to mean that they would see their life to be in danger from the threats and plots of their enemies, and would not expect to live.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:12
verses.text: But the child of the Gospel, who has heard Christ say, "He wrote of me," distinguishes in the ambiguity of the prophecy between what is thrown to swine and what is addressed to man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:13
verses.text: To his mind the thought immediately suggests itself of Christ hanging as the life of man, and of the Jews not believing in Him for this very reason, that they saw Him hanging.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:14
verses.text: As to the objection that these words, "Thou shalt see thy life hanging, and shalt not believe thy life," are the only words referring to Christ in a passage containing maledictions not applicable to Christ, some might grant that this is true.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:15
verses.text: For this prophecy might very well occur among the curses pronounced by the prophet upon the ungodly people, for these curses are of different kinds.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:16
verses.text: But I, and those who with me consider more closely the saying of the Lord in His Gospel, which is not, He wrote also of me, as admitting that Moses wrote other things not referring to Christ, but, "He wrote of me," as teaching that in searching the Scriptures we should view them as intended solely to illustrate the grace of Christ, see a reference to Christ in the rest of the passage also.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:17
verses.text: But it would take too much time to explain this here.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:18
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:19
verses.text: So far from these words of Faustus' quotation being proved not to refer to Christ by their occurring among the other curses, these curses cannot be rightly understood except as prophecies of the glory of Christ, in which lies the happiness of man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:20
verses.text: And what is true of these curses is still more true of this quotation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:21
verses.text: If it could be said of Moses that his words have a different meaning from what was in his mind, I would rather suppose him to have prophesied without knowing it, than allow that the words, "Thou shalt see thy life hanging, and shalt not believe thy life," are not applicable to Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:22
verses.text: So the words of Caiaphas had a different meaning from what he intended, when, in his hostility to Christ, he said that it was expedient that one man should die for the people, and that the whole nation should not perish, where the Evangelist added that he said this not of himself, but, since he was high priest, he prophesied.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:23
verses.text: But Moses was not Caiaphas; and therefore when Moses said to the Hebrew people, "Thou shalt see thy life hanging, and shalt not believe thy life," he not only spoke of Christ, as he certainly did, even though he spoke without knowing the meaning of what he said, but he knew that he spoke of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:24
verses.text: For he was a most faithful steward of the prophetic mystery, that is, of the priestly unction which gives the knowledge of the name of Christ; and in this mystery even Caiaphas, wicked as he was, was able to prophesy without knowing it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:25
verses.text: The prophetic unction enabled him to prophesy, though his wicked life prevented him from knowing it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:26
verses.text: Who then can say that there are no prophecies of Christ in Moses, with whom began that unction to which we owe the knowledge of Christ's name, and by which even Caiaphas, the persecutor of Christ, prophesied of Christ without knowing it?  24.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:27
verses.text: We have already said as much as appeared desirable of the curse pronounced on every one that hangs on a tree.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:28
verses.text: Enough has been said to show that the command to kill any prophet or prince who tried to turn away the children of Israel from their God, or to break any commandment, is not directed against Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:29
verses.text: The more we consider the words and actions of our Lord Jesus Christ, the more clearly will this appear; for Christ never tried to turn away any of the Israelites from their God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:30
verses.text: The God whom Moses taught the people to love and serve, is the God of Abraham, of Isaac, and of Jacob, whom the Lord Jesus Christ speaks of by this name, using the name in refutation of the Sadducees, who denied the resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:31
verses.text: He says, "Of the resurrection of the dead, have ye not read what God said from the bush to Moses, I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob? God is not the God of the dead, but of the living; for all live unto Him".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:32
verses.text: In the same words with which Christ answered the Sadducees we may answer the Manich aeans, for they too deny the resurrection, though in a different way.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:33
verses.text: Again, when Christ said, in praise of the centurion's faith, "Verily I say unto you, I have not found so great faith, no, not in Israel," He added, "And I say unto you, that many shall come from the east and from the west, and shall sit down with Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, in the kingdom of heaven; but the children of the kingdom shall go into outer darkness".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:34
verses.text: If, then, as Faustus must admit, the God of whom Moses spoke was the God of Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, of whom Christ also spoke, as these passages prove, it follows that Christ did not try to turn away the people from their God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:35
verses.text: On the contrary, He warned them that they would go into outer darkness, because He saw that they were turned away from their God, in whose kingdom He says the Gentiles called from the whole world will sit down with Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob; implying that they would believe in the God of Abraham, and of Isaac, and of Jacob.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:36
verses.text: So the apostle also says: "The Scripture, foreseeing that God would justify the Gentiles by faith, preached the gospel beforehand to Abraham, saying, In thy seed shall all nations be blessed".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:37
verses.text: It is implied that those who are blessed in the seed of Abraham shall imitate the faith of Abraham.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:38
verses.text: Christ, then, did not try to turn away the Israelites from their God, but rather charged them with being turned away.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:39
verses.text: The idea that Christ broke one of the commandments given by Moses is not a new one, for the Jews thought so; but it is a mistake, for the Jews were in the wrong.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:40
verses.text: Let Faustus mention the commandment which he supposes the Lord to have broken, and we will point out his mistake, as we have done already, when it was required.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:41
verses.text: Meanwhile it is enough to say, that if the Lord had broken any commandment, He could not have found fault with the Jews for doing so.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:42
verses.text: For when the Jews blamed His disciples for eating with unwashen hands, in which they transgressed not a commandment of God, but the traditions of the elders, Christ said, "Why do ye also transgress the commandment of God, that ye may observe your traditions?" He then quotes a commandment of God, which we know to have been given by Moses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:43
verses.text: "For God said," He adds, "Honor thy father and mother, and he that curseth father or mother shall die the death.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:44
verses.text: But ye say, Whoever shall say to his father or mother, It is a gift, by whatsoever thou mightest be profited by me, is not obliged to honor his father.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:45
verses.text: So ye make the word of God of none effect by your traditions".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:46
verses.text: From this several things maybe learned: that Christ did not turn away the Jews from their God; that He not only did not Himself break God's commandments, but found fault with those who did so; and that it was God Himself who gave these commandments by Moses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:47
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:48
verses.text: In fulfillment of our promise that we would prove the reference to Christ in those passages selected by Faustus from the writings of Moses for adverse criticism, since we cannot here point out the reference to Christ which we believe to exist in all the writings of Moses, it becomes our duty to show that this commandment of Moses, that every prophet or prince should be killed who tried to turn away the people from their God, or to break any commandment, refers to the preservation of the faith which is taught in the Church of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:49
verses.text: Moses no doubt knew in the spirit of prophecy, and from what he himself heard from God, that many heretics would arise to teach errors of all kinds against the doctrine of Christ, and to preach another Christ than the true Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:50
verses.text: For the true Christ is He that was foretold in the prophecies uttered by Moses himself, and by the other holy men of that nation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:51
verses.text: Moses accordingly commanded that whoever tried to teach another Christ should be put to death.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:52
verses.text: In obedience to this command, the voice of the Catholic Church, as with the spiritual two-edged sword of both Testaments, puts to death all who try to turn us away from our God, or to break any of the commandments.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:53
verses.text: And chief among these is Manich aeus himself; for the truth of the law and the prophets convinces him of error as trying to turn us away from our God, the God of Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, whom Christ acknowledges, and as trying to break the commandments of the law, which, even when they are only figurative, we regard as prophetic of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:54
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:55
verses.text: Faustus uses an argument which is either very deceitful or very stupid.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:56
verses.text: And as Faustus is not stupid, it is probable that he used the argument intentionally, with the design of misleading the careless reader.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:57
verses.text: He says: If these things are not written of Christ, and if you cannot show any others, it follows that there are none at all.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:58
verses.text: The proposition is true; but it remains to be proved, both that these things are not written of Christ, and that no other can be shown.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:59
verses.text: Faustus has not proved this; for we have shown both how these things are to be understood of Christ, and that there are many other things which have no meaning but as applied to Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:60
verses.text: So it does not follow, as Faustus says, that nothing was written by Moses of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:61
verses.text: Let us repeat Faustus' argument: If these things are not written of Christ, and if you cannot show any others, it follows that there are none at all.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:62
verses.text: Perfectly so.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:63
verses.text: But as both these things and many others have been shown to be written of Christ, or with reference to Christ, the true conclusion is that Faustus' argument is worthless.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:64
verses.text: In the passages quoted by Faustus, he has tried, though without success, to show that they were not written of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:65
verses.text: But in order to draw the conclusion that there are none at all, he should first have proved that no others can be shown.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:66
verses.text: Instead of this, he takes for granted that the readers of his book will be blind, or the hearers deaf, so that the omission will be overlooked, and runs on thus: If there are none, Christ could not have asserted that there were any.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:67
verses.text: And if Christ did not make this assertion, it follows that this verse is spurious.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:68
verses.text: Here is a man who thinks so much of what he says himself, that he does not consider the possibility of another person saying the opposite.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:69
verses.text: Where is your wit? Is this all you could say for a bad cause? But if the badness of the cause made you utter folly, the bad cause was your own choice.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:70
verses.text: To prove your antecedent false, we have only to show some other things written of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:71
verses.text: If there are some, it will not be true that there are none.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:72
verses.text: And if there are some, Christ may have asserted that there were.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:73
verses.text: And if Christ may have asserted this, it follows that this verse of the Gospel is not spurious.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:74
verses.text: Coming back, then, to Faustus' proposition, If you cannot show any other, it follows that there are none at all, it requires to be proved that we cannot show any other.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:75
verses.text: We need only refer to what we showed before, as sufficient to prove the truth of the text in the Gospel, in which Christ says, "If ye believed Moses, ye would also believe me; for he wrote of me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:76
verses.text: And even though from dullness of mind we could find nothing written of Christ by Moses, still, so strong is the evidence in support of the authority of the Gospel, that it would be incumbent on us to believe that not only some things, but everything written by Moses, refers to Christ; for He says not, He wrote also of me, but, He wrote of me.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:77
verses.text: The truth then is this, that even though there were doubts, which God forbid, of the genuineness of this verse, the doubt would be removed by the number of testimonies to Christ which we find in Moses; while, on the other hand, even if we could find none, we should still be bound to believe that these are to be found, because no doubts can be admitted regarding any verse in the Gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:78
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:79
verses.text: As to your argument that the doctrine of Moses was unlike that of Christ, and that therefore it was improbable that if they believed Moses, they would believe Christ too; and that it would rather follow that their belief in one would imply of necessity opposition to the other,—you could not have said this if you had turned your mind's eye for a moment to see men all the world over, when they are not blinded by a contentious spirit, learned and unlearned, Greek and barbarian, wise and unwise, to whom the apostle called himself a debtor,  believing in both Christ and Moses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:80
verses.text: If it was improbable that the Jews would believe both Christ and Moses, it is still more improbable that all the world would do so.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:81
verses.text: But as we see all nations believing both, and in a common and well-grounded faith holding the agreement of the prophecy of the one with the gospel of the other, it was no impossible thing to which this one nation was called, when Christ said to them, "If ye believed Moses, ye would also believe me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:82
verses.text: Rather we should be amazed at the guilty obstinacy of the Jews, who refused to do what we see the whole world has done.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:83
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:84
verses.text: Regarding the Sabbath and circumcision, and the distinction in foods, in which you say the teaching of Moses differs from what Christians are taught by Christ, we have already shown that, as the apostle says, "all those things were our examples".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:85
verses.text: The difference is not in the doctrine, but in the time.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:86
verses.text: There was a time when it was proper that these things should be figuratively predicted; and there is now a different time when it is proper that they should be openly declared and fully accomplished.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:87
verses.text: It is not surprising that the Jews, who understood the Sabbath in a carnal sense, should oppose Christ, who began to open up its spiritual meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:88
verses.text: Reply, if you can, to the apostle, who declares that the rest of the Sabbath was a shadow of something future.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:89
verses.text: If the Jews opposed Christ because they did not understand what the true Sabbath is, there is no reason why you should oppose Him, or refuse to learn what true innocence is.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:90
verses.text: For on that occasion when Jesus appears especially to set aside the Sabbath, when His disciples were hungry, and pulled the ears of corn through which they were passing, and ate them, Jesus, in replying to the Jews, declared His disciples to be innocent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:91
verses.text: "If you knew," He said "what this meaneth, I will have mercy, and not sacrifice, you would not have condemned the innocent".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:92
verses.text: They should rather have pitied the wants of the disciples, for hunger forced them to do what they did.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:93
verses.text: But pulling ears of corn, which is innocence in the teaching of Christ, is murder in the teaching of Manich aeus.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:94
verses.text: Or was it an act of charity in the apostles to pull the ears of corn, that they might in eating set free the members of God, as in your foolish notions? Then it must be cruelty in you not to do the same.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:95
verses.text: Faustus' reason for setting aside the Sabbath is because he knows that God's power is exercised without cessation, and without weariness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:96
verses.text: It is for those to say this, who believe that all times are the production of an eternal act of God's will.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:97
verses.text: But you will find it difficult to reconcile this with your doctrine, that the rebellion of the race of darkness broke your god's rest, which was also disturbed by a sudden attack of the enemy; or perhaps God never had rest, as he foresaw this from eternity, and could not feel at ease in the prospect of so dire a conflict, with such loss and disaster to his members.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:98
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:99
verses.text: Unless Christ had considered this Sabbath—which in your want of knowledge and of piety you laugh at—one of the prophecies written of Himself, He would not have borne such a testimony to it as He did.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:100
verses.text: For when, as you say in praise of Christ, He suffered voluntarily, and so could choose His own time for suffering and for resurrection, He brought it about that His body rested from all its works on Sabbath in the tomb, and that His resurrection on the third day, which we call the Lord's day, the day after the Sabbath, and therefore the eighth, proved the circumcision of the eighth day to be also prophetical of Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:101
verses.text: For what does circumcision mean, but the eradication of the mortality which comes from our carnal generation? So the apostle says: "Putting off from Himself His flesh, He made a show of principalities and powers, triumphing over them in Himself".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:102
verses.text: The flesh here said to be put off is that mortality of flesh on account of which the body is properly called flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:103
verses.text: The flesh is the mortality, for in the immortality of the resurrection there will be no flesh; as it is written, "Flesh and blood shall not inherit the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:104
verses.text: You are accustomed to argue from these words against our faith in the doctrine of the resurrection of the body, which has already taken place in the Lord Himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:105
verses.text: You keep out of view the following words, in which the apostle explains his meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:106
verses.text: To show what he here means by flesh, he adds, "Neither shall corruption inherit incorruption".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:107
verses.text: For this body, which from its mortality is properly called flesh, is changed in the resurrection, so as to be no longer corruptible and mortal.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:108
verses.text: This is the apostle's statement, and not a supposition of ours, as his next words prove.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:109
verses.text: "Lo" he says, "I show you a mystery: we shall all rise again, but we shall not all be changed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:110
verses.text: In a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trump; for the last trumpet shall sound, and the dead shall rise incorruptible, and we shall be changed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:111
verses.text: For this corruptible must put on incorruption, and this mortal must put on immortality".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:112
verses.text: To put on immortality, the body puts off mortality.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:113
verses.text: This is the mystery of circumcision, which by the law took place on the eighth day; and on the eighth day, the Lord's day, the day after the Sabbath, was fulfilled in its true meaning by the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:114
verses.text: Hence it is said, "Putting off His flesh, He made a show of principalities and powers".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:115
verses.text: For by means of this mortality the hostile powers of hell ruled over us.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:116
verses.text: Christ is said to have made a show or example of these, because in Himself, our Head, He gave an example which will be fully realized in the liberation of His whole body, the Church, from the power of the devil at the last resurrection.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:117
verses.text: This is our faith.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:118
verses.text: And according to the prophetic declaration quoted by Paul, "The just shall live by faith".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:119
verses.text: This is our justification.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:120
verses.text: Even Pagans believe that Christ died.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:121
verses.text: But only Christians believe that Christ rose again.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:122
verses.text: "If thou confess with thy mouth," says the apostle, "that Jesus is the Lord, and believest in thy heart that God raised Him from the dead, thou shalt be saved".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:123
verses.text: Again, because we are justified by faith in Christ's resurrection, the apostle says, "He died for our offenses, and rose again for our justification".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:124
verses.text: And because this resurrection by faith in which we are justified was prefigured by the circumcision of the eighth day, the apostle says of Abraham, with whom the observance began, "He received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of faith".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:125
verses.text: Circumcision, then, is one of the prophecies of Christ, written by Moses, of whom Christ said, "He wrote of me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:126
verses.text: In the words of the Lord, "Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye compass sea and land to make one proselyte; and when he is made, ye make him twofold more the child of hell than yourselves,"  it is not the circumcision of the proselyte which is meant, but his imitation of the conduct of the scribes and Pharisees, which the Lord forbids His disciples to imitate, when He says: "The scribes and Pharisees sit on Moses' seat: what they say unto you, do; but do not after their works; for they say, and do not".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:127
verses.text: These words of the Lord teach us both the honor due to the teaching of Moses, in whose seat even bad men were obliged to teach good things, and the reason of the proselyte becoming a child of hell, which was not that he heard from the Pharisees the words of the law, but that he copied their example.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:128
verses.text: Such a circumcised proselyte might have been addressed in the words of Paul: "Circumcision verily profiteth, if thou keep the law".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:129
verses.text: His imitation of the Pharisees in not keeping the law made him a child of hell.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:130
verses.text: And he was twofold more than they, probably because of his neglecting to fulfill what he voluntarily undertook, when, not being born a Jew, he chose to become a Jew.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:131
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:132
verses.text: Your scoff is very inappropriate, when you say that Moses discusses like a glutton what should be eaten, and commands some things to be freely used as clean, and other things as unclean to be not even touched.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:133
verses.text: A glutton makes no distinction, except in choosing the sweetest food.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:134
verses.text: Perhaps you wish to commend to the admiration of the uninitiated the innocence of your abstemious habits, by appearing not to know, or to have forgotten, that swine's flesh tastes better than mutton.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:135
verses.text: But as this too was written by Moses of Christ in figurative prophecy, in which the flesh of animals signifies those who are to be united to the body of Christ, which is the Church, or who are to be cast out, you are typified by the unclean animals; for your disagreement with the Catholic faith shows that you do not ruminate on the word of wisdom, and that you do not divide the hoof, in the sense of making a correct distinction between the Old Testament and the New.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:136
verses.text: But you show still more audacity in adopting the erroneous opinions of your Adimantus.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:137
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:138
verses.text: You follow Adimantus in saying that Christ made no distinction in food, except in entirely prohibiting the use of animal food to His disciples, while He allowed the laity to eat anything that is eatable; and declared that they were not polluted by what enters into the mouth, but that the unseemly things which come out of the mouth are the things which defile a man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:139
verses.text: These words of yours are unseemly indeed, for they express notorious falsehood.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:140
verses.text: If Christ taught that the evil things which come out of the mouth are the only things that defile a man, why should they not be the only things to defile His disciples, so as to make it unnecessary that any food should be forbidden or unclean? Is it only the laity that are not polluted by what goes into the mouth, but by what comes out of it? In that case, they are better protected from impurity than the saints, who are polluted both by what goes in and by what comes out.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:141
verses.text: But as Christ, comparing Himself with John, who came neither eating nor drinking, says that He came eating and drinking, I should like to know what He ate and drank.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:142
verses.text: When exposing the perversity which found fault with both, He says: "John came neither eating nor drinking; and ye say, He hath a devil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:143
verses.text: The Son of man cometh eating and drinking; and ye say, Behold a glutton and a wine-bibber, a friend of publicans and sinners".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:144
verses.text: We know what John ate and drank.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:145
verses.text: For it is not said that he drank nothing, but that he drank no wine or strong drink; so he must have drunk water.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:146
verses.text: He did not live without food, but his food was locusts and wild honey.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:147
verses.text: When Christ says that John did not eat or drink, He means that he did not use the food which the Jews used.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:148
verses.text: And because the Lord used this food, He is spoken of, in contrast with John, as eating and drinking.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:149
verses.text: Will it be said that it was bread and vegetables which the Lord ate, and which John did not eat? It would be strange if one was said not to eat, because he used locusts and honey, while the other is said to eat simply because he used bread and vegetables.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:150
verses.text: But whatever may be thought of the eating, certainly no one could be called a wine-bibber unless he used wine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:151
verses.text: Why then do you call wine unclean? It is not in order to subdue the body by abstinence that you prohibit these things, but because they are unclean, for you say that they are the poisonous filth of the race of darkness; whereas the apostle says, "To the pure all things are pure".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:152
verses.text: Christ, according to this doctrine, taught that all food was alike, but forbade His disciples to use what the Manich aeans call unclean.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:153
verses.text: Where do you find this prohibition? You are not afraid to deceive men by falsehood; but in God's righteous providence, you are so blinded that you provide us with the means of refuting you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:154
verses.text: For I cannot resist quoting for examination the whole of that passage of the Gospel which Faustus uses against Moses; that we may see from it the falsehood of what was said first by Adimantus, and here by Faustus, that the Lord Jesus forbade the use of animal food to His disciples, and allowed it to the laity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:155
