verses.text: After Christ's reply to the accusation that His disciples ate with unwashen hands, we read in the Gospel as follows: "And He called the multitude, and said unto them, Hear and understand.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:156
verses.text: Not that which goeth into the mouth defileth a man: but that which cometh out of the mouth, this defileth a man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:157
verses.text: Then came His disciples, and said unto Him, Knowest Thou that the Pharisees were offended after they heard this saying?" Here, when addressed by His disciples, He ought certainly, according to the Manich aeans, to have given them special instructions to abstain from animal food, and to show that His words, "Not that which goeth into the mouth defileth a man, but that which goeth out of the mouth," applied to the multitude only.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:158
verses.text: Let us hear, then, what, according to the evangelist, the Lord replied, not to the multitude, but to His disciples: "But He answered and said, Every plant which my heavenly Father hath not planted shall be rooted up.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:159
verses.text: Let them alone: they be blind leaders of the blind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:160
verses.text: And if the blind lead the blind, both shall fall into the ditch".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:161
verses.text: The reason of this was, that in their desire to observe their own traditions, they did not understand the commandments of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:162
verses.text: As yet the disciples had not asked the Master how they were to understand what He had said to the multitude.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:163
verses.text: But now they do so; for the evangelist adds: "Then answered Peter and said unto Him, Declare unto us this parable".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:164
verses.text: This shows that Peter thought that when the Lord said, "Not that which goeth into the mouth defileth a man, but that which goeth out of the mouth," He did not speak plainly and literally, but, as usual, wished to convey some instruction under the guise of a parable.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:165
verses.text: When His disciples, then, put this question in private, does He tell them, as the Manich aeans say, that all animal food is unclean, and that they must never touch it? Instead of this, He rebukes them for not understanding His plain language, and for thinking it a parable when it was not.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:166
verses.text: We read: "And Jesus said, Are ye also yet without understanding? Do not ye yet understand, that whatsoever entereth in at the mouth goeth into the belly, and is cast out into the drought? But those things which proceed out of the mouth come forth from the heart, and they defile the man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:167
verses.text: For out of the heart proceed evil thoughts, murders, adulteries, fornications, thefts, false witness, blasphemies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:168
verses.text: These are the things which defile a man: but to eat with unwashen hands defileth not a man".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:169
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:170
verses.text: Here we have a complete exposure of the falsehood of the Manich aeans: for it is plain that the Lord did not in this matter teach one thing to the multitude, and another in private to His disciples.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:171
verses.text: Here is abundant evidence that the error and deceit are in the Manich aeans, and not in Moses, nor in Christ, nor in the doctrine taught figuratively in one Testament and plainly in the other,—prophesied in one, and fulfilled in the other.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:172
verses.text: How can the Manich aeans say that the Catholics regard none of the things that Moses wrote, when in fact they observe them all, not now in the figures, but in what the figures were intended to foretell? No one would say that one who reads the Scripture subsequently to its being written does not observe it because he does not form the letters which he reads.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:173
verses.text: The letters are the figures of the sounds which he utters; and though he does not form the letters, he cannot read without examining them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:174
verses.text: The reason why the Jews did not believe in Christ, was because they did not observe even the plain literal precepts of Moses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:175
verses.text: So Christ says to them: "Ye pay tithe of mint and cummin, and omit the weightier matters of the law, mercy and judgment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:176
verses.text: Ye strain out a gnat and swallow a camel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:177
verses.text: These ought ye to have done, and not to leave the other undone".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:178
verses.text: So also He told them that by their traditions they made of none effect the commandment of God to give honor to parents.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:179
verses.text: On account of this pride and perversity in neglecting what they understood, they were justly blinded, so that they could not understand the other things.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:180
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:181
verses.text: You see, my argument is not that if you are a Christian you must believe Christ when He says that Moses wrote of Him, and that if you do not believe this you are no Christian.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:182
verses.text: The account you give of yourself in asking to be dealt with as a Jew or a Gentile is your own affair.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:183
verses.text: My endeavor is to leave no avenue of error open to you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:184
verses.text: I have shut you out, too, from that precipice to which you rush as a last resort, when you say that these are spurious passages in the Gospel; so that, freed from the pernicious influence of this opinion, you may be reduced to the necessity of believing in Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:185
verses.text: You say you wish to be taught like the Christian Thomas, whom Christ did not spurn from Him because he doubted of Him, but, in order to heal the wounds of his mind, showed him the marks of the wounds in His own body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:186
verses.text: These are your own words.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:187
verses.text: It is well that you desire to be taught as Thomas was.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:188
verses.text: I feared you would make out this passage too to be spurious.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:189
verses.text: Believe, then, the marks of Christ's wounds.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:190
verses.text: For if the marks were real, the wounds must have been real.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:191
verses.text: And the wounds could not have been real, unless His body had been capable of real wounds; which upsets at once the whole error of the Manich aeans.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:192
verses.text: If you say that the marks were unreal which Christ showed to His doubting disciple, it follows that He must be a deceitful teacher, and that you wish to be deceived in being taught by Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:193
verses.text: But as no one wishes to be deceived, while many wish to deceive, it is probable that you would rather imitate the teaching which you ascribe to Christ than the learning you ascribe to Thomas.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:194
verses.text: If, then, you believe that Christ deceived a doubting inquirer by false marks of wounds, you must yourself be regarded, not as a safe teacher, but as a dangerous impostor.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:195
verses.text: On the other hand, if Thomas touched the real marks of Christ's wounds, you must confess that Christ had a real body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:196
verses.text: So, if you believe as Thomas did, you are no more a Manich aean.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:197
verses.text: If you do not believe even with Thomas, you must be left to your infidelity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:198
verses.text: Book XVII.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:199
verses.text: Faustus rejects Christ's declaration that He came not to destroy the law and the prophets but to fulfill them, on the ground that it is found only in Matthew, who was not present when the words purport to have been spoken.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:200
verses.text: Augustin rebukes the folly of refusing to believe Matthew and yet believing Manich aeus, and shows what the passage of scripture really means.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:201
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:202
verses.text: Faustus said: You ask why we do not receive the law and the prophets, when Christ said that he came not to destroy them, but to fulfill them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:203
verses.text: Where do we learn that Jesus said this? From Matthew, who declares that he said it on the mount.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:204
verses.text: In whose presence was it said? In the presence of Peter, Andrew, James, and John—only these four; for the rest, including Matthew himself, were not yet chosen.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:205
verses.text: Is it not the case that one of these four—John, namely—wrote a Gospel? It is.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:206
verses.text: Does he mention this saying of Jesus? No.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:207
verses.text: How, then, does it happen that what is not recorded by John, who was on the mount, is recorded by Matthew, who became a follower of Christ long after He came down from the mount? In the first place, then, we must doubt whether Jesus ever said these words, since the proper witness is silent on the matter, and we have only the authority of a less trustworthy witness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:208
verses.text: But, besides this, we shall find that it is not Matthew that has imposed upon us, but some one else under his name, as is evident from the indirect style of the narrative.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:209
verses.text: Thus we read: "As Jesus passed by, He saw a man, named Matthew, sitting at the receipt of custom, and called him; and he immediately rose up, and followed Him".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:210
verses.text: No one writing of himself would say, He saw a man, and called him; and he followed Him; but, He saw me, and called me, and I followed Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:211
verses.text: Evidently this was written not by Matthew himself, but by some one else under his name.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:212
verses.text: Since, then, the passage already quoted would not be true even if it had been written by Matthew, since he was not present when Jesus spoke on the mount; much more is its falsehood evident from the fact that the writer was not Matthew himself, but some one borrowing the names both of Jesus and of Matthew.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:213
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:214
verses.text: The passage itself, in which Christ tells the Jews not to think that He came to destroy the law, is rather designed to show that He did destroy it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:215
verses.text: For, had He not done something of the kind, the Jews would not have suspected Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:216
verses.text: His words are: "Think not that I am come to destroy the law".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:217
verses.text: Suppose the Jews had replied, What actions of thine might lead us to suspect this? Is it because thou exposest circumcision, breakest the Sabbath, discardest sacrifices, makest no distinction in foods? this would be the natural answer to the words, Think not.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:218
verses.text: The Jews had the best possible reason for thinking that Jesus destroyed the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:219
verses.text: If this was not to destroy the law, what is? But, indeed, the law and the prophets consider themselves already so faultlessly perfect, that they have no desire to be fulfilled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:220
verses.text: Their author and father condemns adding to them as much as taking away anything from them; as we read in Deuteronomy: "These precepts which I deliver unto thee this day, O Israel, thou shalt observe to do; thou shalt not turn aside from them to the right hand or to the left; thou shalt not add thereto nor diminish from it, that thy God may bless thee".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:221
verses.text: Whether, therefore, Jesus turned aside to the right by adding to the law and the prophets in order to fulfill them, or to the left in taking away from them to destroy them, either way he offended the author of the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:222
verses.text: So this verse must either have some other meaning, or be spurious.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:223
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:224
verses.text: Augustin replied: What amazing folly, to disbelieve what Matthew records of Christ, while you believe Manich aeus! If Matthew is not to be believed because he was not present when Christ said, "I came not to destroy the law and the prophets, but to fulfill," was Manich aeus present, was he even born, when Christ appeared among men? According, then, to your rule, you should not believe anything that Manich aeus says of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:225
verses.text: On the other hand, we refuse to believe what Manich aeus says of Christ; not because he was not present as a witness of Christ's words and actions, but because he contradicts Christ's disciples, and the Gospel which rests on their authority.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:226
verses.text: The apostle, speaking in the Holy Spirit, tells us that such teachers would arise.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:227
verses.text: With reference to such, he says to believers: "If any man preaches to you another gospel than that ye have received, let him be accursed".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:228
verses.text: If no one can say what is true of Christ unless he has himself seen and heard Him, no one now can be trusted.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:229
verses.text: But if believers can now say what is true of Christ because the truth has been handed down in word or writing by those who saw and heard, why might not Matthew have heard the truth from his fellow-disciple John, if John was present and he himself was not, as from the writings of John both we who are born so long after and those who shall be born after us can learn the truth about Christ? In this way, the Gospels of Luke and Mark, who were companions of the disciples, as well as the Gospel of Matthew, have the same authority as that of John.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:230
verses.text: Besides, the Lord Himself might have told Matthew what those called before him had already been witnesses of.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:231
verses.text: Your idea is, that John should have recorded this saying of the Lord, as he was present on the occasion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:232
verses.text: As if it might not happen that, since it was impossible to write all that be heard from the Lord, he set himself to write some, omitting this among others.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:233
verses.text: Does he not say at the close of his Gospel: "And there are also many other things which Jesus did, the which, if they should be written every one, I suppose that even the world itself could not contain the books that should be written"?  This proves that he omitted many things intentionally.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:234
verses.text: But if you choose John as an authority regarding the law and the prophets, I ask you only to believe his testimony to them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:235
verses.text: It is John who writes that Isaiah saw the glory of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:236
verses.text: It is in his Gospel we find the text already treated of: "If ye believed Moses, ye would also believe me; for he wrote of me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:237
verses.text: Your evasions are met on every side.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:238
verses.text: You ought to say plainly that you do not believe the gospel of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:239
verses.text: For to believe what you please, and not to believe what you please, is to believe yourselves, and not the gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:240
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:241
verses.text: Faustus thinks himself wonderfully clever in proving that Matthew was not the writer of this Gospel, because, when speaking of his own election, he says not, He saw me, and said to me, Follow me; but, He saw him, and said to him, Follow me.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:242
verses.text: This must have been said either in ignorance or from a design to mislead.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:243
verses.text: Faustus can hardly be so ignorant as not to have read or heard that narrators, when speaking of themselves, often use a construction as if speaking of another.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:244
verses.text: It is more probable that Faustus wished to bewilder those more ignorant than himself, in the hope of getting hold on not a few unacquainted with these things.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:245
verses.text: It is needless to resort to other writings to quote examples of this construction from profane authors for the information of our friends, and for the refutation of Faustus.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:246
verses.text: We find examples in passages quoted above from Moses by Faustus himself, without any denial, or rather with the assertion, that they were written by Moses, only not written of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:247
verses.text: When Moses, then, writes of himself, does he say, I said this, or I did that, and not rather, Moses said, and Moses did? Or does he say, The Lord called me, The Lord said to me, and not rather, The Lord called Moses, The Lord said to Moses, and so on? So Matthew, too, speaks of himself in the third person.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:248
verses.text: And John does the same; for towards the end of his book he says: "Peter, turning, saw the disciple whom Jesus loved, who also lay on His breast at supper, and who said to the Lord, Who is it that shall betray Thee?" Does he say, Peter, turning, saw me? Or will you argue from this that John did not write this Gospel? But he adds a little after: "This is the disciple that testifies of Jesus, and has written these things; and we know that his testimony is true".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:249
verses.text: Does he say, I am the disciple who testify of Jesus, and who have written these things, and we know that my testimony is true? Evidently this style is common in writers of narratives.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:250
verses.text: There are innumerable instances in which the Lord Himself uses it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:251
verses.text: "When the Son of man," He says, "cometh, shall He find faith on the earth?"  Not, When I come, shall I find? Again, "The Son of man came eating and drinking;"  not, I came.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:252
verses.text: Again, "The hour shall come, and now is, when the dead shall hear the voice of the Son of God, and they that hear shall live;"  not, My voice.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:253
verses.text: And so in many other places.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:254
verses.text: This may suffice to satisfy inquirers and to refute scoffers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:255
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:256
verses.text: Every one can see the weakness of the argument that Christ could not have said, "Think not that I am come to destroy the law and the prophets: I came not to destroy, but to fulfill," unless He had done something to create a suspicion of this kind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:257
verses.text: Of course, we grant that the unenlightened Jews may have looked upon Christ as the destroyer of the law and the prophets; but their very suspicion makes it certain that the true and truthful One, in saying that He came not to destroy the law and the prophets, referred to no other law than that of the Jews.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:258
verses.text: This is proved by the words that follow: "Verily, verily, I say unto you, Till heaven and earth pass, one jot or one tittle shall in no wise pass from the law till all be fulfilled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:259
verses.text: Whosoever therefore shall break one of the least of these commandments, and shall teach men so, shall be called the least in the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:260
verses.text: But whosoever shall do and teach them, shall be called great in the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:261
verses.text: This applied to the Pharisees, who taught the law in word, while they broke it in deed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:262
verses.text: Christ says of the Pharisees in another place, "What they say, that do; but do not after their works: for they say, and do not".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:263
verses.text: So here also He adds, "For I say unto you, Except your righteousness exceed the righteousness of the scribes and Pharisees, ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven;"  that is, Unless ye shall both do and teach what they teach without doing, ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:264
verses.text: This law, therefore, which the Pharisees taught without keeping it, Christ says He came not to destroy, but to fulfill; for this was the law connected with the seat of Moses in which the Pharisees sat, who because they said without doing, are to be heard, but not to be imitated.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:265
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:266
verses.text: Faustus does not understand, or pretends not to understand, what it is to fulfill the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:267
verses.text: He supposes the expression to mean the addition of words to the law, regarding which it is written that nothing is to be added to or taken away from the Scriptures of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:268
verses.text: From this Faustus argues that there can be no fulfillment of what is spoken of as so perfect that nothing can be added to it or taken from it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:269
verses.text: Faustus requires to be told that the law is fulfilled by living as it enjoins.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:270
verses.text: "Love is the fulfilling of the law,"  as the apostle says.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:271
verses.text: The Lord has vouchsafed both to manifest and to impart this love, by sending the Holy Spirit to His believing people.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:272
verses.text: So it is said by the same apostle: "The love of God is shed abroad in our heart by the Holy Ghost, which is given unto us".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:273
verses.text: And the Lord Himself says: "By this shall all men know that ye are my disciples, if ye have love one to another".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:274
verses.text: The law, then, is fulfilled both by the observance of its precepts and by the accomplishment of its prophecies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:275
verses.text: For "the law was given by Moses, but grace and truth came by Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:276
verses.text: The law itself, by being fulfilled, becomes grace and truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:277
verses.text: Grace is the fulfillment of love, and truth is the accomplishment of the prophecies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:278
verses.text: And as both grace and truth are by Christ, it follows that He came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it; not by supplying any defects in the law, but by obedience to what is written in the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:279
verses.text: Christ's own words declare this.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:280
verses.text: For He does not say, One jot or one tittle shall in no wise pass from the law till its defects are supplied, but "till all be fulfilled".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:281
verses.text: Book XVIII.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:282
verses.text: The relation of Christ to prophecy, continued.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:283
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:284
verses.text: Faustus said: "I came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:285
verses.text: If these are Christ's words, unless they have some other meaning, they are as much against you as against me.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:286
verses.text: Your Christianity as well as mine is based on the belief that Christ came to destroy the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:287
verses.text: Your actions prove this, even though in words you deny it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:288
verses.text: It is on this ground that you disregard the precepts of the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:289
verses.text: It is on this ground that we both acknowledge Jesus as the founder of the New Testament, in which is implied the acknowledgment that the Old Testament is destroyed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:290
verses.text: How, then, can we believe that Christ said these words without first confessing that hitherto we have been wholly in error, and without showing our repentance by entering on a course of obedience to the law and the prophets, and of careful observance of their requirements, whatever they may be? This done, we may honestly believe that Jesus said that he came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:291
verses.text: As it is, you accuse me of not believing what you do not believe yourself, and what therefore is false.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:292
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:293
verses.text: But grant that we have been in the wrong hitherto.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:294
verses.text: What is to be done now? Shall we come under the law, since Christ has not destroyed, but fulfilled it? Shall we by circumcision add shame to shame, and believe that God is pleased with such sacraments? Shall we observe the rest of the Sabbath, and bind ourselves in the fetters of Saturn? Shall we glut the demon of the Jews, for he is not God, with the slaughter of bulls, rams, and goats, not to say of men; and adopt, only with greater cruelty, in obedience to the law and the prophets, the practices on account of which we abandoned idolatry? Shall we, in fine, call the flesh of some animals clean, and that of others unclean, among which, according to the law and the prophets, swine's flesh has a particular defilement? Of course you will allow that as Christians we must not do any of these things, for you remember that Christ says that a man when circumcised becomes twofold a child of hell.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:295
verses.text: It is plain also that Christ neither observed the Sabbath himself, nor commanded it to be observed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:296
verses.text: And regarding foods, he says expressly that man is not defiled by anything that goes into his mouth, but rather by the things which come out of it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:297
verses.text: Regarding sacrifices, too, he often says that God desires mercy, and not sacrifice.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:298
verses.text: What becomes, then, of the statement that he came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it? If Christ said this, he must have meant something else, or, what is not to be thought of, he told a lie, or he never said it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:299
verses.text: No Christian will allow that Jesus spoke falsely; therefore he must either not have said this, or said it with another meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:300
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:301
verses.text: For my part, as a Manich aean, this verse has little difficulty for me, for at the outset I am taught to believe that many things which pass in Scripture under the name of the Saviour are spurious, and that they must therefore be tested to find whether they are true, and sound, and genuine; for the enemy who comes by night has corrupted almost every passage by sowing tares among the wheat.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:302
verses.text: So I am not alarmed by these words, notwithstanding the sacred name affixed to them; for I still claim the liberty to examine whether this comes from the hand of the good sower, who sows in the day-time, or of the evil one, who sows in the night.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:303
verses.text: But what escape from this difficulty can there be for you, who receive everything without examination, condemning the use of reason, which is the prerogative of human nature, and thinking it impiety to distinguish between truth and falsehood, and as much afraid of separating between what is good and what is not as children are of ghosts? For suppose a Jew or any one acquainted with these words should ask you why you do not keep the precepts of the law and the prophets, since Christ says that he came not to destroy but to fulfill them: you will be obliged either to join in the superstitious follies of the Jews, or to declare this verse false, or to deny that you are a follower of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:304
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:305
verses.text: Augustin replied: Since you continue repeating what has been so often exposed and refuted, we must be content to repeat the refutation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:306
verses.text: The things in the law and the prophets which Christians do not observe, are only the types of what they do observe.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:307
verses.text: These types were figures of things to come, and are necessarily removed when the things themselves are fully revealed by Christ, that in this very removal the law and the prophets may be fulfilled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:308
verses.text: So it is written in the prophets that God would give a new covenant, "not as I gave to their fathers".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:309
verses.text: Such was the hardness of heart of the people under the Old Testament, that many precepts were given to them, not so much because they were good, as because they suited the people.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:310
verses.text: Still, in all these things the future was foretold and prefigured, although the people did not understand the meaning of their own observances.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:311
verses.text: After the manifest appearance of the things thus signified, we are not required to observe the types; but we read them to see their meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:312
verses.text: So, again, it is foretold in the prophets, "I will take away their stony heart, and will give them a heart of flesh," —that is, a sensible heart, instead of an insensible one.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:313
verses.text: To this the apostle alludes in the words: "Not in tables of stone, but in the fleshy tables of the heart".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:314
verses.text: The fleshy tables of the heart are the same as the heart of flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:315
verses.text: Since, then, the removal of these observances is foretold, the law and the prophets could not have been fulfilled but by this removal.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:316
verses.text: Now, however, the prediction is accomplished, and the fulfillment of the law and the prophets is found in what at first sight seems the very opposite.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:317
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:318
verses.text: We are not afraid to meet your scoff at the Sabbath, when you call it the fetters of Saturn.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:319
verses.text: It is a silly and unmeaning expression, which occurred to you only because you are in the habit of worshipping the sun on what you call Sunday.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:320
verses.text: What you call Sunday we call the Lord's day, and on it we do not worship the sun, but the Lord's resurrection.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:321
verses.text: And in the same way, the fathers observed the rest of the Sabbath, not because they worshipped Saturn, but because it was incumbent at that time, for it was a shadow of things to come, as the apostle testifies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:322
verses.text: The Gentiles, of whom the apostle says that they "worshipped and served the creature rather than the Creator,"  gave the names of their gods to the days of the week.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:323
verses.text: And so far you do the same, except that you worship only the two brightest luminaries, and not the rest of the stars, as the Gentiles did.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:324
verses.text: Besides, the Gentiles gave the names of their gods to the months.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:325
verses.text: In honor of Romulus, whom they believed to be the son of Mars, they dedicated the first month to Mars, and called it March.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:326
verses.text: The next month, April, is named not from any god, but from the word for opening, because the buds generally open in this month.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:327
verses.text: The third month is called May, in honor of Maia the mother of Mercury.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:328
verses.text: The fourth is called June, from Juno.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:329
verses.text: The rest to December used to be named according to their number.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:330
verses.text: The fifth and sixth, however, got the names of July and August from men to whom divine honors were decreed; while the others, from September to December, continued to be named from their number.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:331
verses.text: January, again, is named from Janus, and February from the rites of the Luperci called Febru ae.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:332
verses.text: Must we say that you worship the god Mars in the month of March? But that is the month in which you hold the feast you call Bema with great pomp.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:333
verses.text: But if you think it allowable to observe the month of March without thinking of Mars, why do you try to bring in the name of Saturn in connection with the rest of the seventh day enjoined in Scripture, merely because the Gentiles call the day Saturday? The Scripture name for the day is Sabbath, which means rest.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:334
verses.text: Your scoff is as unreasonable as it is profane.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:335
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:336
verses.text: As regards animal sacrifices, every Christian knows that they were enjoined as suitable to a perverse people, and not because God had any pleasure in them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:337
verses.text: Still, even in these sacrifices there were types of what we enjoy; for we cannot obtain purification or the propitiation of God without blood.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:338
verses.text: The fulfillment of these types is in Christ, by whose blood we are purified and redeemed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:339
verses.text: In these figures of the divine oracles, the bull represents Christ, because with the horns of His cross He scatters the wicked; the lamb, from His matchless innocence; the goat, from His being made in the likeness of sinful flesh, that by sin He might condemn sin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:340
verses.text: Whatever kind of sacrifice you choose to specify, I will show you a prophecy of Christ in it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:341
verses.text: Thus we have shown regarding circumcision, and the Sabbath, and the distinction of food, and the sacrifice of animals, that all these things were our examples, and our prophecies, which Christ came not to destroy, but to fulfill, by fulfilling what was thus foretold.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:342
verses.text: Your opponent is the apostle, whose opinion I give in his own words: "All these things were our examples".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:343
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:344
verses.text: If you have learned from Manich aeus the willful impiety of admitting only those parts of the Gospel which do not contradict your errors, while you reject the rest, we have learned from the apostle the pious caution of looking on every one as accursed that preaches to us another gospel than that which we have received.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:345
verses.text: Hence Catholic Christians look upon you as among the tares; for, in the Lord's exposition of the meaning of the tares, they are not falsehood mixed with truth in the Scriptures, but children of the wicked one—that is, people who imitate the deceitfulness of the devil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:346
verses.text: It is not true that Catholic Christians believe everything; for they do not believe Manich aeus or any of the heretics.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:347
verses.text: Nor do they condemn the use of human reason; but what you call reasoning they prove to be fallacious.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:348
verses.text: Nor do they think it profane to distinguish truth from falsehood; for they distinguish between the truth of the Catholic faith and the falsehood of your doctrines.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:349
verses.text: Nor do they fear to separate good from evil; but they contend that evil, instead of being natural, is unnatural.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:350
verses.text: They know nothing of your race of darkness, which, you say, is produced from a principle of its own, and fights against the kingdom of God, and of which your god seems really to be more frightened than children are of ghosts; for, according to you, he covered himself with a veil, that he might not see his own members taken and plundered by the assault of the enemy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:351
verses.text: To conclude, Catholic Christians are in no difficulty regarding the words of Christ, though in one sense they may be said not to observe the law and the prophets; for by the grace of Christ they keep the law by their love to God and man; and on these two commandments hang all the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:352
verses.text: Besides, they see in Christ and the Church the fulfillment of all the prophecies of the Old Testament, whether in the form of actions, or of symbolic rites, or of figurative language.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:353
verses.text: So we neither join in superstitious follies, nor declare this verse false; nor deny that we are followers of Christ; for on those principles which I have set forth to the best of my power, the law and the prophets which Christ came not to destroy, but to fulfill, are no other than those recognized by the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:354
verses.text: Book XIX.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:355
verses.text: Faustus is willing to admit that Christ may have said that He came not to destroy the law and the prophets, but to fulfill them; but if He did, it was to pacify the Jews and in a modified sense.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:356
verses.text: Augustin replies, and still further elaborates the Catholic view of prophecy and its fulfillment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:357
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:358
verses.text: Faustus said: I will grant that Christ said that he came not to destroy the law and the prophets, but to fulfill them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:359
verses.text: But why did Jesus say this? Was it to pacify the Jews, who were enraged at seeing their sacred institutions trampled upon by Christ, and regarded him as a wild blasphemer, not to be listened to, much less to be followed? Or was it for our instruction as Gentile believers, that we might learn meekly and patiently to bear the yoke of commandment laid on our necks by the law and the prophets of the Jews? You yourself can hardly suppose that Christ's words were intended to bring us under the authority of the law and the prophets of the Hebrews.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:360
verses.text: So that the other explanation which I have given of the words must be the true one.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:361
verses.text: Every one knows that the Jews were always ready to attack Christ, both with words and with actual violence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:362
verses.text: Naturally, then, they would be enraged at the idea that Christ was destroying their law and their prophets; and, to appease them, Christ might very well tell them not to think that he came to destroy the law, but that he came to fulfill it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:363
verses.text: There was no falsehood or deceit in this, for he used the word law in a general sense, not of any particular law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:364
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:365
verses.text: There are three laws.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:366
verses.text: One is that of the Hebrews, which the apostle calls the law of sin and death.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:367
verses.text: The second is that of the Gentiles, which he calls the law of nature.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:368
verses.text: "For the Gentiles," he says, "do by nature the things contained in the law; and, not having the law, they are a law into themselves; who show the work of the law written on their hearts".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:369
verses.text: The third law is the truth of which the apostle speaks when he says, "The law of the spirit of life in Christ Jesus hath made me free from the law of sin and death".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:370
verses.text: Since, then, there are three laws, we must carefully inquire which of the three Christ spoke of when He said that He came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:371
verses.text: In the same way, there are prophets of the Jews, and prophets of the Gentiles, and prophets of truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:372
verses.text: With the prophets of the Jews, of course, every one is acquainted.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:373
verses.text: If any one is in doubt about the prophets of the Gentiles, let him hear what Paul says when writing of the Cretans to Titus: "A prophet of their own has said, The Cretans are always liars, evil beasts, slow bellies".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:374
verses.text: This proves that the Gentiles also had their prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:375
verses.text: The truth also has its prophets, as we learn from Jesus as well as from Paul.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:376
verses.text: Jesus says: "Behold, I send unto you wise men and prophets, and some of them ye shall kill in divers places".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:377
verses.text: And Paul says: "The Lord Himself appointed first apostles, and then prophets".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:378
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:379
verses.text: As "the law and the prophets" may have three different meanings, it is uncertain in what sense the words are used by Jesus, though we may form a conjecture from what follows.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:380
verses.text: For if Jesus had gone on to speak of circumcision, and Sabbaths, and sacrifices, and the observances of the Hebrews, and had added something as a fulfillment, there could have been no doubt that it was the law and the prophets of the Jews of which He said that He came not to destroy, but to fulfill them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:381
verses.text: But Christ, without any allusion to these, speaks only of commandments which date from the earliest times: "Thou shall not kill; Thou shalt not commit adultery; Thou shalt not bear false witness".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:382
verses.text: These, it can be proved, were of old promulgated in the world by Enoch and Seth, and the other righteous men, to whom the precepts were delivered by angels of lofty rank, in order to tame the savage nature of men.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:383
verses.text: From this it appears that Jesus spoke of the law and the prophets of truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:384
verses.text: And so we find him giving a fulfillment of those precepts already quoted.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:385
verses.text: "Ye have heard," He says, "that it was said by them of old time, Thou shalt not kill; but I say unto you, Be not even angry".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:386
verses.text: This is the fulfillment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:387
verses.text: Again: "Ye have heard that it was said, Thou shalt not commit adultery; but I say unto you, Do not lust even".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:388
verses.text: This is the fulfillment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:389
verses.text: Again: "It has been said, Thou shalt not bear false witness; but I say unto you, Swear not".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:390
verses.text: This too is the fulfillment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:391
verses.text: He thus both confirms the old precepts and supplies their defects.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:392
verses.text: Where He seems to speak of some Jewish precepts, instead of fulfilling them, He substitutes for them precepts of an opposite tendency.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:393
verses.text: He proceeds thus: "Ye have heard that it has been said, An eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth; but I say unto you, Whosoever shall smite thee on thy right cheek, turn to him the other also".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:394
verses.text: This is not fulfillment, but destruction.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:395
verses.text: Again: "It has been said, Thou shall love thy friend, and hate thine enemy; but I say unto you, Love your enemies, and pray for your persecutors".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:396
verses.text: This too is destruction.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:397
verses.text: Again: "It has been said, Whosoever shall put away his wife, let him give her a writing of divorcement; but I say unto you, That whosoever shall put away his wife, saving for the cause of fornication, causeth her to commit adultery, and is himself an adulterer if he afterwards marries another woman".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:398
verses.text: These precepts are evidently destroyed because they are the precepts of Moses; while the others are fulfilled because they are the precepts of the righteous men of antiquity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:399
verses.text: If you agree to this explanation, we may allow that Jesus said that he came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:400
verses.text: If you disapprove of this explanation, give one of your own.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:401
verses.text: Only beware of making Jesus a liar, and of making yourself a Jew, by binding yourself to fulfill the law because Christ did not destroy it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:402
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:403
verses.text: If one of the Nazareans, or Symmachians, as they are sometimes called, were arguing with me from these words of Jesus that he came not to destroy the law, I should find some difficulty in answering him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:404
verses.text: For it is undeniable that, at his coming, Jesus was both in body and mind subject to the influence of the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:405
verses.text: Those people, moreover, whom I allude to, practise circumcision, and keep the Sabbath, and abstain from swine's flesh and such like things, according to the law, although they profess to be Christians.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:406
verses.text: They are evidently misled as well as you, by this verse in which Christ says that he came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:407
verses.text: It would not be easy to reply to such opponents without first getting rid of this troublesome verse.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:408
verses.text: But with you I have no difficulty, for you have nothing to go upon; and instead of using arguments, you seem disposed, in mere mischief, to induce me to believe that Christ said what you evidently do not yourself believe him to have said.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:409
verses.text: On the strength of this verse you accuse me of dullness and evasiveness, without yourself giving any indication of keeping the law instead of destroying it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:410
verses.text: Do you too, like a Jew or a Nazarean, glory in the obscene distinction of being circumcised? Do you pride yourself in the observance of the Sabbath? Can you congratulate yourself on being innocent of swine's flesh? Or can you boast of having gratified the appetite of the Deity by the blood of sacrifices and the incense of Jewish offerings? If not, why do you contend that Christ came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it?  5.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:411
verses.text: I give unceasing thanks to my teacher, who prevented me from falling into this error, so that I am still a Christian.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:412
verses.text: For I, like you, from reading this verse without sufficient consideration, had almost resolved to become a Jew.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:413
verses.text: And with reason; for if Christ came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it, and as a vessel in order to be filled full must not be empty, but partly filled already, I concluded that no one could become a Christian but an Israelite, nearly filled already with the law and the prophets, and coming to Christ to be filled to the full extent of his capacity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:414
verses.text: I concluded, too, that in thus coming he must not destroy what he already possesses; otherwise it would be a case, not of fulfilling, but of emptying.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:415
verses.text: Then it appeared that I, as a Gentile, could get nothing by coming to Christ, for I brought nothing that he could fill up by his additions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:416
verses.text: This preparatory supply is found, on inquiry, to consist of Sabbaths, circumcision, sacrifices, new moons, baptisms, feasts of unleavened bread, distinctions of foods, drink, and clothes, and other things, too many to specify.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:417
verses.text: This, then, it appeared, was what Christ came not to destroy, but to fulfill.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:418
verses.text: Naturally it must appear so: for what is a law without precepts, or prophets without predictions? Besides, there is that terrible curse pronounced upon those who abide not in all things that are written in the book of the law to do them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:419
verses.text: With the fear of this curse appearing to come from God on the one side, and with Christ on the other side, seeming, as the Son of God, to say that he came not to destroy these things, but to fulfill them, what was to prevent me from becoming a Jew? The wise instruction of Manich aeus saved me from this danger.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:420
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:421
verses.text: But how can you venture to quote this verse against me? Or why should it be against me only, when it is as much against yourself? If Christ does not destroy the law and the prophets, neither must Christians do so.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:422
verses.text: Why then do you destroy them? Do you begin to perceive that you are no Christian? How can you profane with all kinds of work the day pronounced sacred in the law and in all the prophets, on which they say that God, the maker of the world, himself rested, without dreading the penalty of death pronounced against Sabbath-breakers, or the curse on the transgressor? How can you refuse to receive in your person the unseemly mark of circumcision, which the law and all the prophets declare to be honorable, especially in the case of Abraham, after what was thought to be his faith; for does not the God of the Jews proclaim that whosoever is without this mark of infamy shall perish from his people? How can you neglect the appointed sacrifices, which were made so much of both by Moses and the prophets under the law, and by Abraham in his faith? And how can you defile your souls by making no distinction in foods, if you believe that Christ came not to destroy these things, but to fulfill them? Why do you discard the annual feast of unleavened bread, and the appointed sacrifice of the lamb, which, according to the law and the prophets, is to be observed for ever? Why, in a word, do you treat so lightly the new moons, the baptisms, and the feast of tabernacles, and all the other carnal ordinances of the law and the prophets, if Christ did not destroy them? I have therefore good reason for saying that, in order to justify your neglect of these things, you must either abandon your profession of being Christ's disciple, or acknowledge that Christ himself has already destroyed them; and from this acknowledgment it must follow, either that this text is spurious in which Christ is made to say that he came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it, or that the words have an entirely different meaning from what you suppose.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:423
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:424
verses.text: Augustin replied: If you allow, in consideration of the authority of the Gospel, that Christ said that He came not to destroy the law and the prophets, but to fulfill them, you should show the same consideration to the authority of the apostle, when he says, "All these things were our examples;" and again of Christ, "He was not yea and nay, but in Him was yea; for all the promises of God are in Him yea;"  that is, they are set forth and fulfilled in Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:425
verses.text: In this way you will see in the clearest light both what law Christ fulfilled, and how He fulfilled it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:426
verses.text: It is a vain attempt that you make to escape by your three kinds of law and your three kinds of prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:427
verses.text: It is quite plain, and the New Testament leaves no doubt on the matter, what law and what prophets Christ came not to destroy, but to fulfill.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:428
verses.text: The law given by Moses is that which by Jesus Christ became grace and truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:429
verses.text: The law given by Moses is that of which Christ says, "He wrote of me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:430
verses.text: For undoubtedly this is the law which entered that the offence might abound;  words which you often ignorantly quote as a reproach to the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:431
verses.text: Read what is there said of this law: "The law is holy, and the commandment holy, and just, and good.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:432
verses.text: Was then that which is good made death unto me? God forbid.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:433
verses.text: But sin, that it might appear sin, wrought death in me by that which is good".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:434
verses.text: The entrance of the law made the offense abound, not because the law required what was wrong, but because the proud and self-confident incurred additional guilt as transgressors after their acquaintance with the holy, and just, and good commandments of the law; so that, being thus humbled, they might learn that only by grace through faith could they be freed from subjection to the law as transgressors, and be reconciled to the law as righteous.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:435
verses.text: So the same apostle says: "For before faith came, we were kept under the law, shut up unto the faith which was afterwards revealed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:436
verses.text: Therefore the law was our schoolmaster in Christ Jesus; but after faith came, we are no longer under a schoolmaster".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:437
verses.text: That is, we are no longer subject to the penalty of the law, because we are set free by grace.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:438
verses.text: Before we received in humility the grace of the Spirit, the letter was only death to us, for it required obedience which we could not render.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:439
verses.text: Thus Paul also says: "The letter killeth, but the spirit giveth life".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:440
verses.text: Again, he says: "For if a law had been given which could have given life, verily righteousness should have been by the law; but the Scripture hath concluded all under sin, that the promise by faith of Jesus Christ might be given to them that believe".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:441
verses.text: And once more: "What the law could not do, in that it was weak through the flesh, God sent His Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, that by sin He might condemn sin in the flesh, that the righteousness of the law might be fulfilled in us, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:442
verses.text: Here we see Christ coming not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:443
verses.text: As the law brought the proud under the guilt of transgression, increasing their sin by commandments which they could not obey, so the righteousness of the same law is fulfilled by the grace of the Spirit in those who learn from Christ to be meek and lowly in heart; for Christ came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:444
verses.text: Moreover, because even for those who are under grace it is difficult in this mortal life perfectly to keep what is written in the law, Thou shall not covet, Christ, by the sacrifice of His flesh, as our Priest obtains pardon for us.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:445
verses.text: And in this also He fulfills the law; for what we fail in through weakness is supplied by His perfection, who is the Head, while we are His members.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:446
verses.text: Thus John says: "My little children, these things write I unto you, that ye sin not; and if any man sin, we have an Advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous: He is the propitiation for our sins".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:447
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:448
verses.text: Christ also fulfilled the prophecies, because the promises of God were made good in Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:449
verses.text: As the apostle says in the verse quoted above, "The promises of God are in Him yea".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:450
verses.text: Again, he says: "Now I say that Jesus Christ was a minister of the circumcision for the truth of God, to confirm the promises made unto the fathers".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:451
verses.text: [19] Whatever, then, was promised in the prophets, whether expressly or in figure, whether by words or by actions, was fulfilled in Him who came not to destroy the law and the prophets, but to fulfill them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:452
verses.text: You do not perceive that if Christians were to continue in the use of acts and observances by which things to come were prefigured, the only meaning would be that the things prefigured had not yet come.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:453
verses.text: Either the thing prefigured has not come, or if it has, the figure becomes superfluous or misleading.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:454
verses.text: Therefore, if Christians do not practise some things enjoined in the Hebrews by the prophets, this, so far from showing, as you think, that Christ did not fulfill the prophets, rather shows that He did.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:455
verses.text: So completely did Christ fulfill what these types prefigured, that it is no longer prefigured.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:456
verses.text: So the Lord Himself says: "The law and the prophets were until John".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:457
verses.text: For the law which shut up transgressors in increased guilt, and to the faith which was afterwards revealed, became grace through Jesus Christ, by whom grace superabounded.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:458
verses.text: Thus the law, which was not fulfilled in the requirement of the letter, was fulfilled in the liberty of grace.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:459
verses.text: In the same way, everything in the law that was prophetic of the Saviour's advent, whether in words or in typical actions, became truth in Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:460
verses.text: For "the law was given by Moses, but grace and truth came by Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:461
verses.text: At Christ's advent the kingdom of God began to be preached; for the law and the prophets were until John: the law, that its transgressors might desire salvation; the prophets, that they might foretell the Saviour.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:462
verses.text: No doubt there have been prophets in the Church since the ascension of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:463
verses.text: Of these prophets Paul says: "God hath set some in the Church, first apostles, secondarily prophets, thirdly teachers," and so on.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:464
verses.text: It is not of these prophets that it was said, "The law and the prophets were until John," but of those who prophesied the first coming of Christ, which evidently cannot be prophesied now that it has taken place.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:465
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:466
verses.text: Accordingly, when you ask why a Christian is not circumcised if Christ came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it, my reply is, that a Christian is not circumcised precisely for this reason, that what was prefigured by circumcision is fulfilled in Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:467
verses.text: Circumcision was the type of the removal of our fleshly nature, which was fulfilled in the resurrection of Christ, and which the sacrament of baptism teaches us to look forward to in our own resurrection.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:468
verses.text: The sacrament of the new life is not wholly discontinued, for our resurrection from the dead is still to come; but this sacrament has been improved by the substitution of baptism for circumcision, because now a pattern of the eternal life which is to come is afforded us in the resurrection of Christ, whereas formerly there was nothing of the kind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:469
verses.text: So, when you ask why a Christian does not keep the Sabbath, if Christ came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it, my reply is, that a Christian does not keep the Sabbath precisely because what was prefigured in the Sabbath is fulfilled in Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:470
verses.text: For we have our Sabbath in Him who said, "Come unto me, all ye that labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:471
verses.text: Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me; for I am meek and lowly in heart, and ye shall find rest unto your souls".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:472
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:473
verses.text: When you ask why a Christian does not observe the distinction in food as enjoined in the law, if Christ came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it, I reply, that a Christian does not observe this distinction precisely because what was thus prefigured is now fulfilled in Christ, who admits into His body, which in His saints He has predestined to eternal life, nothing which in human conduct corresponds to the characteristics of the forbidden animals.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:474
verses.text: When you ask, again, why a Christian does not offer sacrifices to God of the flesh and blood of slain animals, if Christ came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it, I reply, that it would be improper for a Christian to offer such sacrifices, now that what was thus prefigured has been fulfilled in Christ's offering of His own body and blood.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:475
verses.text: When you ask why a Christian does not keep the feast of unleavened bread as the Jews did, if Christ came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it, I reply, that a Christian does not keep this feast precisely because what was thus prefigured is fulfilled in Christ, who leads us to a new life by purging out the leaven of the old life.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:476
verses.text: When you ask why a Christian does not keep the feast of the paschal lamb, if Christ came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it, my reply is, that he does not keep it precisely because what was thus prefigured has been fulfilled in the sufferings of Christ, the Lamb without spot.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:477
verses.text: When you ask why a Christian does not keep the feasts of the new moon appointed in the law, if Christ came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it, I reply, that he does not keep them precisely because what was thus prefigured is fulfilled in Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:478
verses.text: For the feast of the new moon prefigured the new creature, of which the apostle says: "If therefore there is any new creature in Christ Jesus, the old things have passed away; behold, all things are become new".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:479
verses.text: When you ask why a Christian does not observe the baptisms for various kinds of uncleanness according to the law, if Christ came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it, I reply, that he does not observe them precisely because they were figures of things to come, which Christ has fulfilled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:480
verses.text: For He came to bury us with Himself by baptism into death, that as Christ rose again from the dead, so we also should walk in newness of life.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:481
verses.text: When you ask why Christians do not keep the feast of tabernacles, if the law is not destroyed, but fulfilled by Christ, I reply that believers are God's tabernacle, in whom, as they are united and built together in love, God condescends to dwell, so that Christians do not keep this feast precisely because what was thus prefigured is now fulfilled by Christ in His Church.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:482
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:483
verses.text: I touch upon these things merely in passing with the utmost brevity, rather than omit them altogether.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:484
verses.text: The subjects, taken separately, have filled many large volumes, written to prove that these observances were typical of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:485
verses.text: So it appears that all the things in the Old Testament which you think are not observed by Christians because Christ destroyed the law, are in fact not observed because Christ fulfilled the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:486
verses.text: The very intention of the observances was to prefigure Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:487
verses.text: Now that Christ has come, instead of its being strange or absurd that what was done to prefigure His advent should not be done any more, it is perfectly right and reasonable.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:488
verses.text: The typical observances intended to prefigure the coming of Christ would be observed still, had they not been fulfilled by the coming of Christ; so far is it from being the case that our not observing them now is any proof of their not being fulfilled by Christ's coming.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:489
verses.text: There can be no religious society, whether the religion be true or false, without some sacrament or visible symbol to serve as a bond of union.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:490
verses.text: The importance of these sacraments cannot be overstated, and only scoffers will treat them lightly.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:491
verses.text: For if piety requires them, it must be impiety to neglect them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:492
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:493
verses.text: It is true, the ungodly may partake in the visible sacraments of godliness, as we read that Simon Magus received holy baptism.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:494
verses.text: Such are they of whom the apostle says that "they have the form of godliness, but deny the power of it".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:495
verses.text: The power of godliness is the end of the commandment, that is, love out of a pure heart, and of a good conscience, and of faith unfeigned.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:496
verses.text: So the Apostle Peter, speaking of the sacrament of the ark, in which the family of Noah was saved from the deluge, says, "So by a similar figure baptism also saves you".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:497
verses.text: And lest they should rest content with the visible sacrament, by which they had the form of godliness, and should deny its power in their lives by profligate conduct, he immediately adds, "Not the putting away of the filth of the flesh, but the answer of a good conscience".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:498
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:499
verses.text: Thus the sacraments of the Old Testament, which were celebrated in obedience to the law, were types of Christ who was to come; and when Christ fulfilled them by His advent they were done away, and were done away because they were fulfilled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:500
verses.text: For Christ came not to destroy, but to fulfill.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:501
verses.text: And now that the righteousness of faith is revealed, and the children of God are called into liberty, and the yoke of bondage which was required for a carnal and stiffnecked people is taken away, other sacraments are instituted, greater in efficacy, more beneficial in their use, easier in performance, and fewer in number.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:502
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:503
