verses.text: And if the righteous men of old, who saw in the sacraments of their time the promise of a future revelation of faith, which even then their piety enabled them to discern in the dim light of prophecy, and by which they lived, for the just can live only by faith;  if, then, these righteous men of old were ready to suffer, as many actually did suffer, all trials and tortures for the sake of those typical sacraments which prefigured things in the future; if we praise the three children and Daniel, because they refused to be defiled by meat from the king's table, from their regard for the sacrament of their day; if we feel the strongest admiration for the Maccabees, who refused to touch food which Christians lawfully use;   how much more should a Christian in our day be ready to suffer all things for Christ's baptism, for Christ's Eucharist, for Christ's sacred sign, since these are proofs of the accomplishment of what the former sacraments only pointed forward to in the future! For what is still promised to the Church, the body of Christ, is both clearly made known, and in the Saviour Himself, the Head of the body, the Mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus, has already been accomplished.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:504
verses.text: Is not the promise of eternal life by resurrection from the dead? This we see fulfilled in the flesh of Him of whom it is said, that the Word became flesh and dwelt among us.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:505
verses.text: In former days faith was dim, for the saints and righteous men of those times all believed and hoped for the same things, and all these sacraments and ceremonies pointed to the future; but now we have the revelation of the faith to which the people were shut up under the law;  and what is now promised to believers in the judgment is already accomplished in the example of Him who came not to destroy the law and the prophets, but to fulfill them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:506
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:507
verses.text: It is a question among the students of the sacred Scriptures, whether the faith in Christ before His passion and resurrection, which the righteous men of old learned by revelation or gathered from prophecy, had the same efficacy as faith has now that Christ has suffered and risen; or whether the actual shedding of the blood of the Lamb of God, which was, as He Himself says, for many for the remission of sins,  conferred any benefit in the way of purifying or adding to the purity of those who looked forward in faith to the death of Christ, but left the world before it took place; whether, in fact, Christ's death reached to the dead, so as to effect their liberation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:508
verses.text: To discuss this question here, or to prove what has been ascertained on the subject, would take too long, besides being foreign from our present purpose.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:509
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:510
verses.text: Meanwhile it is sufficient to prove, in opposition to Faustus' ignorant cavils, how greatly they mistake who conclude, from the change in signs and sacraments, that there must be a difference in the things which were prefigured in the rites of a prophetic dispensation, and which are declared to be accomplished in the rites of the gospel; or those, on the other hand, who think that as the things are the same, the sacraments which announce their accomplishment should not differ from the sacraments which foretold that accomplishment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:511
verses.text: For if in language the form of the verb changes in the number of letters and syllables according to the tense, as done signifies the past, and to be done the future, why should not the symbols which declare Christ's death and resurrection to be accomplished, differ from those which predicted their accomplishment, as we see a difference in the form and sound of the words, past and future, suffered and to suffer, risen and to rise? For material symbols are nothing else than visible speech, which, though sacred, is changeable and transitory.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:512
verses.text: For while God is eternal, the water of baptism, and all that is material in the sacrament, is transitory: the very word "God," which must be pronounced in the consecration, is a sound which passes in a moment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:513
verses.text: The actions and sounds pass away, but their efficacy remains the same, and the spiritual gift thus communicated is eternal.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:514
verses.text: To say, therefore, that if Christ had not destroyed the law and the prophets, the sacraments of the law and the prophets would continue to be observed in the congregations of the Christian Church, is the same as to say that if Christ had not destroyed the law and the prophets, He would still be predicted as about to be born, to suffer, and to rise again; whereas, in fact, it is proved that He did not destroy, but fulfill those things, because the prophecies of His birth, and passion, and resurrection, which were represented in these ancient sacraments, have ceased, and the sacraments now observed by Christians contain the announcement that He has been born, has suffered, has risen.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:515
verses.text: He who came not to destroy the law and the prophets, but to fulfill them, by this fulfillment did away with those things which foretold the accomplishment of what is thus shown to be now accomplished.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:516
verses.text: Precisely in the same way, he might substitute for the expressions, "He is to be born, is to suffer, is to rise," which were in these times appropriate, the expressions, "He has been born, has suffered, has risen," which are appropriate now that the others are accomplished, and so done away.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:517
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:518
verses.text: Corresponding to this change in words is the change which naturally took place in the substitution of new sacraments instead of those of the Old Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:519
verses.text: In the case of the first Christians, who came to the faith as Jews, it was by degrees that they were brought to change their customs, and to have a clear perception of the truth; and permission was given them by the apostle to preserve their hereditary worship and belief, in which they had been born and brought up; and those who had to do with them were required to make allowance for this reluctance to accept new customs.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:520
verses.text: So the apostle circumcised Timothy, the son of a Jewish mother and a Greek father, when they went among people of this kind; and he himself accommodated his practice to theirs, not hypocritically, but for a wise purpose.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:521
verses.text: For these practices were harmless in the case of those born and brought up in them, though they were no longer required to prefigure things to come.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:522
verses.text: It would have done more harm to condemn them as hurtful in the case of those to whose time it was intended that they should continue.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:523
verses.text: Christ, who came to fulfill all these prophecies, found those people trained in their own religion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:524
verses.text: But in the case of those who had no such training, but were brought to Christ, the corner-stone, from the opposite wall of circumcision, there was no obligation to adopt Jewish customs.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:525
verses.text: If, indeed, like Timothy, they chose to accommodate themselves to the views of those of the circumcision who were still wedded to their old sacraments, they were free to do so.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:526
verses.text: But if they supposed that their hope and salvation depended on these works of the law, they were warned against them as a fatal danger.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:527
verses.text: So the apostle says: "Behold, I Paul say unto you, that if ye be circumcised, Christ shall profit you nothing;"  that is, if they were circumcised, as they were intending to be, in compliance with some corrupt teachers, who told them that without these works of the law they could not be saved.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:528
verses.text: For when, chiefly through the preaching of the Apostle Paul, the Gentiles were coming to the faith of Christ, as it was proper that they should come, without being burdened with Jewish observances—for those who were grown up were deterred from the faith by fear of ceremonies to which they were not accustomed, especially of circumcision; and if they who had not been trained from their birth to such observances had been made proselytes in the usual way, it would have implied that the coming of Christ still required to be predicted as a future event;—when, then, the Gentiles were admitted without these ceremonies, those of the circumcision who believed, not understanding why the Gentiles were not required to adopt their customs, nor why they themselves were still allowed to retain them, began to disturb the Church with carnal contentions, because the Gentiles were admitted into the people of God without being made proselytes in the usual way by circumcision and the other legal observances.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:529
verses.text: Some also of the converted Gentiles were bent on these ceremonies, from fear of the Jews among whom they lived.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:530
verses.text: Against these Gentiles the Apostle Paul often wrote, and when Peter was carried away by their hypocrisy, he corrected him with a brotherly rebuke.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:531
verses.text: Afterwards, when the apostles met in council, decreed that these works of the law were not obligatory in the case of the Gentiles,  some Christians of the circumcision were displeased, because they failed to understand that these observances were permissible only in those who had been trained in them before the revelation of faith, to bring to a close the prophetic life in those who were engaged in it before the prophecy was fulfilled, lest by a compulsory abandonment it should seem to be condemned rather than closed; while to lay these things on the Gentiles would imply either that they were not instituted to prefigure Christ, or that Christ was still to be prefigured.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:532
verses.text: The ancient people of God, before Christ came to fulfill the law and the prophets, were required to observe all these things by which Christ was prefigured.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:533
verses.text: It was freedom to those who understood the meaning of the observance, but it was bondage to those who did not.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:534
verses.text: But the people in those latter times who come to believe in Christ as having already come, and suffered, and risen, in the case of those whom this faith found trained to those sacraments, are neither required to observe them, nor prohibited from doing so; while there is a prohibition in the case of those who were not bound by the ties of custom, or by any necessity, to accommodate themselves to the practice of others, so that it might become manifest that these things were instituted to prefigure Christ, and that after His coming they were to cease, because the promises had been fulfilled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:535
verses.text: Some believers of the circumcision who did not understand this were displeased with this tolerant arrangement which the Holy Spirit effected through the apostles, and stubbornly insisted on the Gentiles becoming Jews.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:536
verses.text: These are the people of whom Faustus speaks under the name of Symmachians or Nazareans.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:537
verses.text: Their number is now very small, but the sect still continues.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:538
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:539
verses.text: The Manich aeans, therefore have no ground for saying, in disparagement of the law and the prophets, that Christ came to destroy rather than to fulfill them, because Christians do not observe what is there enjoined: for the only things which they do not observe are those that prefigured Christ, and these are not observed because their fulfillment is in Christ, and what is fulfilled is no longer prefigured; the typical observances having properly come to a close in the time of those who, after being trained in such things, had come to believe in Christ as their fulfillment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:540
verses.text: Do not Christians observe the precept of Scripture "Hear, O Israel; the Lord thy God is one God;" "Thou shalt not make unto thee an image," and so on? Do make Christians not observe the precept, "Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain?" Do Christians not observe the Sabbath, even in the sense of a true rest? Do Christians not honor their parents, according to the commandment? Do Christians not abstain from fornication, and murder, and theft, and false witness, from coveting their neighbor's wife, and from coveting his property,—all of which things are written in the law? These moral precepts are distinct from typical sacraments: the former are fulfilled by the aid of divine grace, the latter by the accomplishment of what they promise.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:541
verses.text: Both are fulfilled in Christ, who has ever been the bestower of this grace, which is also now revealed in Him, and who now makes manifest the accomplishment of what He in former times promised; for "the law was given by Moses, but grace and truth came by Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:542
verses.text: Again, these things which concern the keeping of a good conscience are fulfilled in the faith which worketh by love;  while types of the future pass away when they are accomplished.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:543
verses.text: But even the types are not destroyed, but fulfilled; for Christ, in bringing to light what the types signified, does not prove them vain or illusory.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:544
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:545
verses.text: Faustus, therefore, is wrong in supposing that the Lord Jesus fulfilled some precepts of righteous men who lived before the law of Moses, such as, "Thou shall not kill," which Christ did not oppose, but rather confirmed by His prohibition of anger and abuse; and that He destroyed some things apparently peculiar to the Hebrew law, such as, "An eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth," which Christ seems rather to abolish than to confirm, when He says, "But I say unto you, that ye resist not evil; but if any one smite thee on thy right cheek, turn to him the other also,"  and so on.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:546
verses.text: But we say that even these things which Faustus thinks Christ destroyed by enjoining the opposite, were suitable to the times of the Old Testament, and were not destroyed, but fulfilled by Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:547
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:548
verses.text: In the first place let me ask our opponents if these ancient righteous men, Enoch and Seth, whom Faustus mentions particularly, and any others who lived before Moses, or even, if you choose, before Abraham, were angry with their brother without a cause, or said to their brother, Thou fool.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:549
verses.text: If not, why may they not have taught these things as well as preached them? And if they taught these things, how can Christ be said to have fulfilled their righteousness or their teaching, any more than that of Moses, by adding, "But I say unto you, if any man is angry with his brother, or if he says Racha, or if he says, Thou fool, he shall be in danger of the judgment, or of the council, or of hell-fire," since these men did these very things themselves, and enjoined them upon others? Will it be said that they were ignorant of its being the duty of a righteous man to restrain his passion, and not to provoke his brother with angry abuse; or that, knowing this, they were unable to act accordingly? In that case, they deserved the punishment of hell, and could not have been righteous.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:550
verses.text: But no one will venture to say that in their righteousness there was such ignorance of duty, and such a want of self-control, as to make them liable to the punishment of hell.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:551
verses.text: How, then, can Christ be said to have fulfilled the law, by which these men lived by means of adding things without which they could have had no righteousness at all? Will it be said that a hasty temper and bad language are sinful only since the time of Christ, while formerly such qualities of the heart and speech were allowable; as we find some institutions vary according to the times, so that what is proper at one time is improper at another, and vice versa? You will not be so foolish as to make this assertion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:552
verses.text: But even were you to do so, the reply will be that, according to this idea, Christ came not to fulfill what was defective in the old law, but to institute a law which did not previously exist; if it is true that with the righteous men of old it was not a sin to say to their brother, Thou fool, which Christ pronounces so sinful, that whoever does so is in danger of hell.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:553
verses.text: So, then, you have not succeeded in finding any law of which it can be said that Christ supplied its defect by these additions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:554
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:555
verses.text: Will it be said that the law in these early times was incomplete as regards not committing adultery, till it was completed by the Lord, who added that no one should look on a woman to lust after her? This is what you imply in the way you quote the words, "Ye have heard that it has been said, Thou shalt not commit adultery: but I say unto you, Do not lust even".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:556
verses.text: "Here," you say, "is the fulfillment".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:557
verses.text: But let us take the words as they stand in the Gospel, without any of your modifications, and see what character you give to those righteous men of antiquity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:558
verses.text: The words are: "Ye have heard that it has been said, thou shall not commit adultery; but I say unto you, that whosoever looketh on a woman to lust after her, hath committed adultery with her already in his heart".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:559
verses.text: In your opinion, then, Enoch and Seth, and the rest, committed adultery in their hearts; and either their heart was not the temple of God, or they committed adultery in the temple of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:560
verses.text: But if you dare not say this, how can you say that Christ, when He came, fulfilled the law, which was already in the time of those men complete?  22.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:561
verses.text: As regards not swearing, in which also you say that Christ completed the law given to these righteous men of antiquity, I cannot be certain that they did not swear, for we find that Paul the apostle swore.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:562
verses.text: With you, swearing is still a common practice, for you swear by the light, which you love as flies do; for the light of the mind which lighteth every man that cometh into the world, as distinct from mere natural light, you know nothing of.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:563
verses.text: You swear, too, by your master Manich aeus, whose name in his own tongue was Manes.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:564
verses.text: As the name Manes seemed to be connected with the Greek word for madness, you have changed it by adding a suffix, which only makes matters worse, by giving the new meaning of pouring forth madness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:565
verses.text: One of your own sect told me that the name Manich aeus was intended to be derived from the Greek words for pouring forth manna; for χέειν means to pour.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:566
verses.text: But, as it is, you only express the idea of madness with greater emphasis.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:567
verses.text: For by adding the two syllables, while you have forgotten to insert another letter in the beginning of the word, you make it not Mannich aeus, but Manich aeus; which must mean that he pours forth madness in his long unprofitable discourses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:568
verses.text: Again, you often swear by the Paraclete,—not the Paraclete promised and sent by Christ to His disciples, but this same madness-pourer himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:569
verses.text: Since, then, you are constantly swearing, I should like to know in what sense you make Christ to have fulfilled this part of the law, which is one you mention as belonging to the earliest times.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:570
verses.text: And what do you make of the oaths of the apostle? For as to your authority, it cannot weigh much with yourselves, not to speak of me or any other person.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:571
verses.text: It is therefore evident that Christ's words, "I am come not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it," have not the meaning which you give them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:572
verses.text: Christ makes no reference in these words to His comments on the ancient sayings which He quotes, and of which His discourse was an explanation, but not a fulfillment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:573
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:574
verses.text: Thus, as regards murder, which was understood to mean merely the destruction of the body, by which a man is deprived of life, the Lord explained that every unjust disposition to injure our brother is a kind of murder.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:575
verses.text: So John also says, "He that hateth his brother is a murderer".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:576
verses.text: And as it was thought that adultery meant only the act of unlawful intercourse with a woman, the Master showed that the lust He describes is also adultery.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:577
verses.text: Again, because perjury is a heinous sin, while there is no sin either in not swearing at all or in swearing truly, the Lord wished to secure us from departing from the truth by not swearing at all, rather than that we should be in danger of perjury by being in the habit of swearing truly.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:578
verses.text: For one who never swears is less in danger of swearing falsely than one who is in the habit of swearing truly.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:579
verses.text: So, in the discourses of the apostle which are recorded, he never used an oath, lest he should ever fall unawares into perjury from being in the habit of swearing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:580
verses.text: In his writings, on the other hand, where he had more leisure and opportunity for caution, we find him using oaths in several places,  to teach us that there is no sin in swearing truly, but that, on account of the infirmity of human nature, we are best preserved from perjury by not swearing at all.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:581
verses.text: These considerations will also make it evident that the things which Faustus supposes to be peculiar to Moses were not destroyed by Christ, as he says they were.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:582
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:583
verses.text: To take, for instance, this saying of the ancients, "Thou shalt love thy neighbor, and hate thine enemy," how does Faustus make out that this is peculiar to Moses? Does not the Apostle Paul speak of some men as hateful to God?  And, indeed, in connection with this saying, the Lord enjoins on us that we should imitate God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:584
verses.text: His words are: "That ye may be the children of your Father in heaven, who maketh the sun to rise upon the evil and the good, and sendeth rain on the just and the unjust".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:585
verses.text: In one sense we must hate our enemies, after the example of God, to whom Paul says some men are hateful; while, at the same time, we must also love our enemies after the example of God, who makes the sun to rise on the evil and the good, and sendeth rain on the just and the unjust.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:586
verses.text: If we understand this, we shall find that the Lord, in explaining to those who did not rightly understand the saying, Thou shalt hate thine enemy, made use of it to show that they should love their enemy, which was a new idea to them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:587
verses.text: It would take too long to show the consistency of the two things here.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:588
verses.text: But when the Manich aeans condemn without exception the precept, Thou shall hate thine enemy, they may easily be met with the question whether their god loves the race of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:589
verses.text: Or, if we should love our enemies now, because they have a part of good, should we not also hate them as having a part of evil? So even in this way it would appear that there is no opposition between the saying of ancient times, Thou shall hate thine enemy, and that of the Gospel, Love your enemies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:590
verses.text: For every wicked man should be hated as far as he is wicked; while he should be loved as a man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:591
verses.text: The vice which we rightly hate in him is to be condemned, that by its removal the human nature which we rightly love in him may be amended.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:592
verses.text: This is precisely the principle we maintain, that we should hate our enemy for what is evil in him, that is, for his wickedness; while we also love our enemy for that which is good in him, that is, for his nature as a social and rational being.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:593
verses.text: The difference between us and the Manich aeans is, that we prove the man to be wicked, not by nature, either his own or any other, but by his own will; whereas they think that a man is evil on account of the nature of the race of darkness, which, according to them, was an object of dread to God when he existed entire, and by which also he was partly conquered, so that he cannot be entirely set free.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:594
verses.text: The intention of the Lord, then, is to correct those who, from knowing without understanding what was said by them of old time, Thou shalt hate thine enemy, hated their fellow-men instead of only hating their wickedness; and for this purpose He says, Love your enemies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:595
verses.text: Instead of destroying what is written about hatred of enemies in the law, of which He said, "I am come not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it," He would have us learn, from the duty of loving our enemies, how it is possible in the case of one and the same person, both to hate him for his sin, and to love him for his nature.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:596
verses.text: It is too much to expect our perverse opponents to understand this.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:597
verses.text: But we can silence them, by showing that by their irrational objection they condemn their own god, of whom they cannot say that he loves the race of darkness; so that in enjoining on every one to love his enemy, they cannot quote his example.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:598
verses.text: There would appear to be more love of their enemy in the race of darkness than in the god of the Manich aeans.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:599
verses.text: The story is, that the race of darkness coveted the domain of light bordering on their territory, and, from a desire to possess it, formed the plan of invading it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:600
verses.text: Nor is there any sin in desiring true goodness and blessedness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:601
verses.text: For the Lord says, "The kingdom of heaven suffereth violence, and the violent take it by force".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:602
verses.text: This fabulous race of darkness, then, wished to take by force the good they desired, for its beautiful and attractive appearance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:603
verses.text: But God, instead of returning the love of those who wished to possess Him, hated it so as to endeavor to annihilate them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:604
verses.text: If, therefore, the evil love the good in the desire to possess it, while the good hate the evil in fear of being defiled, I ask the Manich aeans, which of these obeys the precept of the Lord, "Love your enemies"? If you insist on making these precepts opposed to one another, it will follow that your god obeyed what is written in the law of Moses, "Thou shall hate thine enemy"; while the race of darkness obeyed what is written in the Gospel, "Love your enemies".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:605
verses.text: However, you have never succeeded in explaining the difference between the flies that fly in the day-time and the moths that fly at night; for both, according to you, belong to the race of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:606
verses.text: How is it that one kind love the light, contrary to their nature; while the other kind avoid it, and prefer the darkness from which they sprung? Strange, that filthy sewers should breed a cleaner sort than dark closets!  25.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:607
verses.text: Nor, again, is there any opposition between that which was said by them of old time, "An eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth," and what the Lord says, "But I say unto you, that ye resist not evil; but if any one smiteth thee on thy right cheek, turn to him the other also," and so on.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:608
verses.text: The old precept as well as the new is intended to check the vehemence of hatred, and to curb the impetuosity of angry passion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:609
verses.text: For who will of his own accord be satisfied with a revenge equal to the injury? Do we not see men, only slightly hurt, eager for slaughter, thirsting for blood, as if they could never make their enemy suffer enough? If a man receives a blow, does he not summon his assailant, that he may be condemned in the court of law? Or if he prefers to return the blow, does he not fall upon the man with hand and heel, or perhaps with a weapon, if he can get hold of one? To put a restraint upon a revenge so unjust from its excess, the law established the principle of compensation, that the penalty should correspond to the injury inflicted.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:610
verses.text: So the precept, "an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth," instead of being a brand to kindle a fire that was quenched, was rather a covering to prevent the fire already kindled from spreading.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:611
verses.text: For there is a just revenge due to the injured person from his assailant; so that when we pardon, we give up what we might justly claim.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:612
verses.text: Thus, in the Lord's prayer, we are taught to forgive others their debts that God may forgive us our debts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:613
verses.text: There is no injustice in asking back a debt, though there is kindness in forgiving it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:614
verses.text: But as, in swearing, one who swears, even though truly, is in danger of perjury, of which one is in no danger who never swears; and while swearing truly is not a sin, we are further from sin by not swearing; so that the command not to swear is a guard against perjury: in the same way since it is sinful to wish to be revenged with an unjust excess, though there is no sin in wishing for revenge within the limits of justice, the man who wishes for no revenge at all is further from the sin of an unjust revenge.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:615
verses.text: It is sin to demand more than is due, though it is no sin to demand a debt.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:616
verses.text: And the best security against the sin of making an unjust demand is to demand nothing, especially considering the danger of being compelled to pay the debt to Him who is indebted to none.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:617
verses.text: Thus, I would explain the passage as follows: It has been said by them of old time, Thou shall not take unjust revenge; but I say, Take no revenge at all: here is the fulfillment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:618
verses.text: It is thus that Faustus, after quoting, "It has been said, Thou shall not swear falsely; but I say unto you, swear not at all," adds: here is the fulfillment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:619
verses.text: I might use the same expression if I thought that by the addition of these words Christ supplied a defect in the law, and not rather that the intention of the law to prevent unjust revenge is best secured by not taking revenge at all, in the same way as the intention to prevent perjury is best secured by not swearing at all.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:620
verses.text: For if "an eye for an eye" is opposed to "If any one smite thee on the cheek, turn to him the other also," is there not as much opposition between "Thou shalt perform unto the Lord thine oath," and "Swear not at all?"  If Faustus thinks that there is not destruction, but fulfillment, in the one case, he ought to think the same of the other.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:621
verses.text: For if "Swear not" is the fulfillment of "Swear truly," why should not "Take no revenge" be the fulfillment of "Take revenge justly"?  So, according to my interpretation, there is in both cases a guard against sin, either of false swearing or of unjust revenge; though, as regards giving up the right to revenge, there is the additional consideration that, by forgiving such debts, we shall obtain the forgiveness of our debts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:622
verses.text: The old precept was required in the case of a self-willed people, to teach them not to be extravagant in their demands.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:623
verses.text: Thus, when the rage eager for unrestrained vengeance, was subdued, there would be leisure for any one so disposed to consider the desirableness of having his own debt cancelled by the Lord, and so to be led by this consideration to forgive the debt of his fellow-servant.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:624
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:625
verses.text: Again, we shall find on examination, that there is no opposition between the precept of the Lord about not putting away a wife, and what was said by them of old time: "Whosoever putteth away his wife, let him give her a writing of divorcement".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:626
verses.text: The Lord explains the intention of the law, which required a bill of divorce in every case where a wife was put away.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:627
verses.text: The precept not to put away a wife is the opposite of saying that a man may put away his wife if he pleases; which is not what the law says.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:628
verses.text: On the contrary, to prevent the wife from being put away, the law required this intermediate step, that the eagerness for separation might be checked by the writing of the bill, and the man might have time to think of the evil of putting away his wife; especially since, as it is said, among the Hebrews it was unlawful for any but the scribes to write Hebrew: for the scribes claimed the possession of superior wisdom; and if they were men of upright and pious character, their pursuits might justly entitle them to make this claim.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:629
verses.text: In requiring, therefore, that in putting away his wife, a man should give her a writing of divorcement, the design was that he should be obliged to have recourse to those from whom he might expect to receive a cautious interpretation of the law, and suitable advice against separation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:630
verses.text: Having no other way of getting the bill written, the man should be obliged to submit to their direction, and to allow of their endeavors to restore peace and harmony between him and his wife.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:631
verses.text: In a case where the hatred could not be overcome or checked, the bill would of course be written.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:632
verses.text: A wife might with reason be put away when wise counsel failed to restore the proper feeling and affection in the mind of her husband.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:633
verses.text: If the wife is not loved, she is to be put away.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:634
verses.text: And that she may not be put away, it is the husband's duty to love her.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:635
verses.text: Now, while a man cannot be forced to love against his will, he may be influenced by advice and persuasion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:636
verses.text: This was the duty of the scribe, as a wise and upright man; and the law gave him the opportunity, by requiring the husband in all cases of quarrel to go to him, to get the bill of divorcement written.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:637
verses.text: No good or prudent man would write the bill unless it were a case of such obstinate aversion as to make reconciliation impossible.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:638
verses.text: But according to your impious notions, there can be nothing in putting away a wife; for matrimony, according to you, is a criminal indulgence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:639
verses.text: The word "matrimony" shows that a man takes a wife in order that she may become a mother, which would be an evil in your estimation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:640
verses.text: According to you, this would imply that part of your god is overcome and captured by the race of darkness, and bound in the fetters of flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:641
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:642
verses.text: But, to explain the point in hand: If Christ, in adding the words, "But I say unto you," to the quotations He makes of ancient sayings, neither fulfilled the law of primitive times by His additions, nor destroyed the law given to Moses by opposite precepts, but rather paid such deference to the Hebrew law in all the quotations He made from it, as to make His own remarks chiefly explanatory of what the law stated less distinctly, or a means of securing the design intended by the law, it follows that from the words, "I came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it" we are not to understand that Christ by His precepts filled up what was wanting in the law; but that what the literal command failed in doing from the pride and disobedience of men, is accomplished by grace in those who are brought to repentance and humility.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:643
verses.text: The fulfillment is not in additional words, but in acts of obedience.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:644
verses.text: So the apostle says "Faith worketh by love;"   and again, He that loveth another hath fulfilled the law".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:645
verses.text: This love, by which also the righteousness of the law can be fulfilled was bestowed in its significance by Christ in His coming, through the spirit which He sent according to His promise; and therefore He said, "I came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:646
verses.text: This is the New Testament in which the promise of the kingdom of heaven is made to this love; which was typified in the Old Testament, suitably to the times of that dispensation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:647
verses.text: So Christ says again; "A new commandment I give unto you, that ye love one another".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:648
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:649
verses.text: So we find in the Old Testament all or nearly all the counsels and precepts which Christ introduces with the words "But I say unto you".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:650
verses.text: Against anger it is written, "Mine eyes troubled because of anger;"  and again, "Better is he that conquers his anger, than he that taketh a city".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:651
verses.text: Against hard words, "The stroke of a whip maketh a wound; but the stroke of the tongue breaketh the bones".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:652
verses.text: Against adultery in the heart, "Thou shall not covet thy neighbor's wife".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:653
verses.text: It is not, "Thou shall not commit adultery;" but, "Thou shall not covet".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:654
verses.text: The apostle, in quoting this, says: "I had not known lust, unless the law had said, Thou shalt not covet".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:655
verses.text: Regarding patience in not offering resistance, a man is praised who "giveth his cheek to him that smiteth him, and who is filled full with reproach".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:656
verses.text: Of love to enemies it is said: "If thine enemy hunger, feed him; if he thirst, give him drink".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:657
verses.text: This also is quoted by the apostle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:658
verses.text: In the Psalm, too, it is said, "I was a peace maker among them that hated peace;"  and in many similar passages.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:659
verses.text: In connection also with our imitating God in refraining from taking revenge, and in loving even the wicked, there is a passage containing a full description of God in this character; for it is written: "To Thee alone ever belongeth great strength, and who can withstand the power of Thine arm? For the whole world before Thee is as a little grain of the balance; yea, as a drop of the morning dew that falleth down upon the earth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:660
verses.text: But Thou hast mercy upon all, for Thou canst do all things, and winkest at the sins of men, because of repentance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:661
verses.text: For Thou lovest all things that are, and abhorrest nothing which Thou hast made; for never wouldest Thou have made anything if Thou hadst hated it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:662
verses.text: And how could anything have endured, if it had not been Thy will? or been preserved, if not called by Thee? But Thou sparest all; for they are Thine, O Lord, Thou lover of souls.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:663
verses.text: For Thy good Spirit is in all things; therefore chastenest Thou them by little and little that offend, and warnest them by putting them in remembrance wherein they have offended, that learning their wickedness, they may believe in Thee, O Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:664
verses.text: Christ exhorts us to imitate this long-suffering goodness of God, who maketh the sun to rise upon the evil and the good, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust; that we may not be careful to revenge, but may do good to them that hate us, and so may be perfect, even as our Father in heaven is perfect.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:665
verses.text: From another passage in these ancient books we learn that, by not exacting the vengeance due to us, we obtain the remission of our own sins; and that by not forgiving the debts of others, we incur the danger of being refused forgiveness when we pray for the remission of our own debts: "He that revengeth shall find vengeance from the Lord, and He will surely keep his sin in remembrance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:666
verses.text: Forgive thy neighbor the hurt that he hath done to thee; so shall thy sins also be forgiven when thou prayest.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:667
verses.text: One man beareth hatred against another, and doth he seek pardon of the Lord? He showeth no mercy to a man who is like himself; and doth he ask forgiveness of his own sins? If he that is but flesh nourishes hatred, and asks for favor from the Lord, who will entreat for the pardon of his sins?"  29.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:668
verses.text: As regards not putting away a wife, there is no need to quote any other passage of the Old Testament than that referred to most appropriately in the Lord's reply to the Jews when they questioned Him on this subject.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:669
verses.text: For when they asked whether it is lawful for a man to put away his wife for any reason, the Lord answered: "Have ye not read, that He that made them at the beginning made them male and female, and said, For this cause shall a man leave his father and mother, and shall cleave to his wife, and they two shall be one flesh? Therefore they are no longer twain, but one flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:670
verses.text: What therefore God hath joined, let no man put asunder".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:671
verses.text: Here the Jews, who thought that they acted according to the intention of the law of Moses in putting away their wives, are made to see from the book of Moses that a wife should not be put away.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:672
verses.text: And, by the way, we learn here, from Christ's own declaration, that God made and joined male and female; so that by denying this, the Manich aeans are guilty of opposing the gospel of Christ as well as the writings of Moses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:673
verses.text: And supposing their doctrine to be true, that the devil made and joined male and female, we see the diabolical cunning of Faustus in finding fault with Moses for dissolving marriages by granting a bill of divorce, and praising Christ for strengthening the union by the precept in the Gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:674
verses.text: Instead of this, Faustus, consistently with his own foolish and impious notions, should have praised Moses for separating what was made and joined by the devil, and should have blamed Christ for ratifying a bond of the devil's workmanship.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:675
verses.text: To return, let us hear the good Master explain how Moses, who wrote of the conjugal chastity in the first union of male and female as so holy and inviolable, afterwards allowed the people to put away their wives.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:676
verses.text: For when the Jews replied, "Why did Moses then command to give a writing of divorcement, and to put her away?" Christ said unto them, "Moses, because of the hardness of your heart, suffered you to put away your wives".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:677
verses.text: This passage we have already explained.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:678
verses.text: The hardness must have been great indeed which could not be induced to admit the restoration of wedded love, even though by means of the writing an opportunity was afforded for advice to be given to this effect by wise and upright men.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:679
verses.text: Then the Lord quoted the same law, to show both what was enjoined on the good and what was permitted to the hard; for, from what is written of the union of male and female, He proved that a wife must not be put away, and pointed out the divine authority for the union; and shows from the same Scriptures that a bill of divorcement was to be given because of the hardness of the heart, which might be subdued or might not.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:680
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:681
verses.text: Since, then, all these excellent precepts of the Lord, which Faustus tries to prove to be contrary to the old books of the Hebrews, are found in these very books, the only sense in which the Lord came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it, is this, that besides the fulfillment of the prophetic types, which are set aside by their actual accomplishment, the precepts also, in which the law is holy, and just, and good, are fulfilled in us, not by the oldness of the letter which commands, and increases the offence of the proud by the additional guilt of transgression, but by the newness of the Spirit, who aids us, and by the obedience of the humble, through the saving grace which sets us free.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:682
verses.text: For, while all these sublime precepts are found in the ancient books, still the end to which they point is not there revealed; although the holy men who foresaw the revelation lived in accordance with it, either veiling it in prophecy as suited the time, or themselves discovering the truth thus veiled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:683
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:684
verses.text: I am disposed, after careful examination, to doubt whether the expression so often used by the Lord, "the kingdom of heaven," can be found in these books.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:685
verses.text: It is said, indeed, "Love wisdom, that ye may reign for ever".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:686
verses.text: And if eternal life had not been clearly made known in the Old Testament, the Lord would not have said, as He did even to the unbelieving Jews: "Search the Scriptures, for in them ye think that ye have eternal life, and they are they that testify of me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:687
verses.text: And to the same effect are the words of the Psalmist: "I shall not die, but live, and declare the works of the Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:688
verses.text: And again: "Enlighten mine eyes, lest I sleep the sleep of death".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:689
verses.text: Again, we read, "The souls of the righteous are in the hand of the Lord, and pain shall not touch them;" and immediately following: "They are in peace; and if they have suffered torture from men, their hope is full of immortality; and after a few trouble, they shall enjoy many rewards".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:690
verses.text: Again, in another place: "The righteous shall live for ever, and their reward is with the Lord, and their concern with the Highest; therefore shall they receive from the hand of the Lord a kingdom of glory and a crown of beauty".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:691
verses.text: These and many similar declarations of eternal life, in more or less explicit terms, are found in these writings.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:692
verses.text: Even the resurrection of the body is spoken of by the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:693
verses.text: The Pharisees, accordingly, were fierce opponents of the Sadducees, who disbelieved the resurrection.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:694
verses.text: This we learn not only from the canonical Acts of the Apostles, which the Manich aeans reject, because it tells of the advent of the Paraclete promised by the Lord, but also from the Gospel, when the Sadducees question the Lord about the woman who married seven brothers, one dying after the other, whose wife she would be in the resurrection.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:695
verses.text: As regards, then, eternal life and the resurrection of the dead, numerous testimonies are to be found in these Scriptures.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:696
verses.text: But I do not find there the expression, "the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:697
verses.text: This expression belongs properly to the revelation of the New Testament, because in the resurrection our earthly bodies shall, by that change which Paul fully describes, become spiritual bodies, and so heavenly, that thus we may possess the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:698
verses.text: And this expression was reserved for Him whose advent as King to govern and Priest to sanctify His believing people, was ushered in by all the symbolism of the old covenant, in its genealogies, its typical acts and words, its sacrifices and ceremonies and feasts, and in all its prophetic utterances and events and figures.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:699
verses.text: He came full of grace and truth, in His grace helping us to obey the precepts, and in His truth securing the accomplishment of the promises.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:700
verses.text: He came not to destroy the law, but to fulfill it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:701
verses.text: Book XX.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:702
verses.text: Faustus repels the charge of sun-worship, and maintains that while the Manich aeans believe that God's power dwells in the sun and his wisdom in the moon, they yet worship one deity, Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:703
verses.text: They are not a schism of the Gentiles, nor a sect.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:704
verses.text: Augustin emphasizes the charge of polytheism, and goes into an elaborate comparison of Manich aean and pagan mythology.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:705
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:706
verses.text: Faustus said: You ask why we worship the sun, if we are a sect or separate religion, and not Pagans, or merely a schism of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:707
verses.text: It may therefore be as well to inquire into the matter, that we may see whether the name of Gentiles is more applicable to you or to us.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:708
verses.text: Perhaps, in giving you in a friendly way this simple account of my faith, I shall appear to be making an apology for it, as if I were ashamed, which God forbid, of doing homage to the divine luminaries.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:709
verses.text: You may take it as you please; but I shall not regret what I have done if I succeed in conveying to some at least this much knowledge, that our religion has nothing in common with that of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:710
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:711
verses.text: We worship, then, one deity under the threefold appellation of the Almighty God the Father, and his son Christ, and the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:712
verses.text: While these are one and the same, we believe also that the Father properly dwells in the highest or principal light, which Paul calls "light inaccessible,"  and the Son in his second or visible light.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:713
verses.text: And as the Son is himself twofold, according to the apostle, who speaks of Christ as the power of God and the wisdom of God,  we believe that His power dwells in the sun, and His wisdom in the moon.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:714
verses.text: We also believe that the Holy Spirit, the third majesty, has His seat and His home in the whole circle of the atmosphere.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:715
verses.text: By His influence and spiritual infusion, the earth conceives and brings forth the mortal Jesus, who, as hanging from every tree, is the life and salvation of men.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:716
verses.text: Though you oppose these doctrines so violently, your religion resembles ours in attaching the same sacredness to the bread and wine that we do to everything.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:717
verses.text: This is our belief, which you will have an opportunity of hearing more of, if you wish to do so.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:718
verses.text: Meanwhile there is some force in the consideration that you or any one that is asked where his God dwells, will say that he dwells in light; so that the testimony in favor of my worship is almost universal.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:719
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:720
verses.text: As to your calling us a schism of the Gentiles, and not a sect, I suppose the word schism applies to those who have the same doctrines and worship as other people, and only choose to meet separately.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:721
verses.text: The word sect, again, applies to those whose doctrine is quite unlike that of others, and who have made a form of divine worship peculiar to themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:722
verses.text: If this is what the words mean, in the first place, in our doctrine and worship we have no resemblance to the Pagans.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:723
verses.text: We shall see presently whether you have.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:724
verses.text: The Pagan doctrine is, that all things good and evil, mean and glorious, fading and unfading, changeable and unchangeable, material and divine, have only one principle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:725
verses.text: In opposition to this, my belief is that God is the principle of all good things, and Hyle [matters] of the opposite.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:726
verses.text: Hyle is the name given by our master in divinity to the principle or nature of evil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:727
verses.text: The Pagans accordingly think it right to worship God with altars, and shrines, and images, and sacrifices, and incense.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:728
verses.text: Here also my practice differs entirely from theirs: for I look upon myself as a reasonable temple of God, if I am worthy to be so; and I consider Christ his Son as the living image of his living majesty; and I hold a mind well cultivated to be the true altar, and pure and simple prayers to be the true way of paying divine honors and of offering sacrifices.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:729
verses.text: Is this being a schism of the Pagans?  4.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:730
verses.text: As regards the worship of the Almighty God, you might call us a schism of the Jews, for all Jews are bold enough to profess this worship, were it not for the difference in the form of our worship, though it may be questioned whether the Jews really worship the Almighty.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:731
verses.text: But the doctrine I have mentioned is common to the Pagans in their worship of the sun, and to the Jews in their worship of the Almighty.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:732
verses.text: Even in relation to you, we are not properly a schism, though we acknowledge Christ and worship Him; for our worship and doctrine are different from yours.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:733
verses.text: In a schism, little or no change is made from the original; as, for instance, you, in your schism from the Gentiles, have brought with you the doctrine of a single principle, for you believe that all things are of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:734
verses.text: The sacrifices you change into love-feasts, the idols into martyrs, to whom you pray as they do to their idols.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:735
verses.text: You appease the shades of the departed with wine and food.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:736
verses.text: You keep the same holidays as the Gentiles; for example, the calends and the solstices.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:737
verses.text: In your way of living you have made no change.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:738
verses.text: Plainly you are a mere schism; for the only difference from the original is that you meet separately.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:739
verses.text: In this you have followed the Jews, who separated from the Gentiles, but differed only in not having images.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:740
verses.text: For they used temples, and sacrifices, and altars, and a priesthood, and the whole round of ceremonies the same as those of the Gentiles, only more superstitious.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:741
verses.text: Like the Pagans, they believe in a single principle; so that both you and the Jews are schisms of the Gentiles, for you have the same faith, and nearly the same worship, and you call yourselves sects only because you meet separately.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:742
verses.text: The fact is, there are only two sects, the Gentiles and ourselves.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:743
verses.text: We and the Gentiles are as contrary in our belief as truth and falsehood, day and night, poverty and wealth, health and sickness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:744
verses.text: You, again, are not a sect in relation either to truth or to error.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:745
verses.text: You are merely a schism and a schism not of truth, but of error.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:746
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:747
verses.text: Augustin replied: O hateful mixture of ignorance and cunning! Why do you put arguments in the mouth of your opponent, which no one that knows you would use? We do not call you Pagans, or a schism of Pagans; but we say that you resemble them in worshipping many gods.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:748
verses.text: But you are far worse than Pagans, for they worship things which exist, though they should not be worshipped: for idols have an existence, though for salvation they are nought.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:749
verses.text: So, to worship a tree with prayers, instead of improving it by cultivation, is not to worship nothing, but to worship in a wrong way.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:750
verses.text: When the apostle says that "the things which the Gentiles sacrifice, they sacrifice to demons, and not to God,"  he means that these demons exist to whom the sacrifices are made, and with whom he wishes us not to be partakers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:751
verses.text: So, too, heaven and earth, the sea and air, the sun and moon, and the other heavenly bodies, are all objects which have a sensible existence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:752
verses.text: When the Pagans worship these as gods, or as parts of one great God (for some of them identify the universe with the Supreme Deity), they worship things which have an existence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:753
verses.text: In arguing with Pagans, we do not deny the existence of these things, but we say that they should not be worshipped; and we recommend the worship of the invisible Creator of all these things, in whom alone man can find the happiness which all allow that he desires.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:754
verses.text: To those, again, who worship what is invisible and immaterial, but still is created, as the soul or mind of man, we say that happiness is not to be found in the creature even under this form, and that we must worship the true God, who is not only invisible, but unchangeable; for He alone is to be worshipped, in the enjoyment of whom the worshipper finds happiness, and without whom the soul must be wretched, whatever else it possesses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:755
verses.text: You, on the other hand, who worship things which have no existence at all except in your fictitious legends, would be nearer true piety and religion if you were Pagans, or if you were worshippers of what has an existence, though not a proper object of worship.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:756
verses.text: In fact, you do not properly worship the sun, though he carries your prayers with him in his course round the heavens.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:757
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:758
verses.text: Your statements about the sun himself are so false and absurd, that if he were to repay you for the injury done to him, he would scorch you to death.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:759
verses.text: First of all, you call the sun a ship, so that you are not only astray worlds off, as the saying is, but adrift.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:760
verses.text: Next, while every one sees that the sun is round, which is the form corresponding from its perfection to his position among the heavenly bodies, you maintain that he is triangular, that is, that his light shines on the earth through a triangular window in heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:761
verses.text: Hence it is that you bend and bow your heads to the sun, while you worship not this visible sun, but some imaginary ship which you suppose to be shining through a triangular opening.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:762
verses.text: Assuredly this ship would never have been heard of, if the words required for the composition of heretical fictions had to be paid for, like the wood required for the beams of a ship.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:763
verses.text: All this is comparatively harmless, however ridiculous or pitiable.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:764
verses.text: Very different is your wicked fancy about youths of both sexes proceeding from this ship, whose beauty excites eager desire in the princes and princesses of darkness; and so the members of your god are released from this humiliating confinement in the members of the race of darkness, by means of sinful passion and sensual appetite.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:765
verses.text: And to these filthy rags of yours you would unite the mystery of the Trinity; for you say that the Father dwells in a secret light, the power of the Son in the sun, and His wisdom in the moon, and the Holy Spirit in the air.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:766
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:767
verses.text: As for this threefold or rather fourfold fiction, what shall I say of the secret light of the Father, but that you can think of no light except what you have seen? From your knowledge of visible light, with which beasts and insects as well as men are familiar, you form some vague idea in your mind, and call it the light in which God the Father dwells with His subjects.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:768
verses.text: How can you distinguish between the light by which we see, and that by which we understand, when, according to your ideas, to understand truth is nothing else than to form the conception of material forms, either finite or in some cases infinite; and you actually believe in these wild fancies? It is manifest that the act of my mind in thinking of your region of light which has no existence, is entirely different from my conception of Alexandria, which exists, though I have not seen it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:769
verses.text: And, again, the act of forming a conception of Alexandria, which I have never seen, is very different from thinking of Carthage, which I know.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:770
verses.text: But this difference is insignificant as compared with that between my thinking of material things which I know from seeing them, and my understanding justice, chastity, faith, truth, love, goodness, and things of this nature.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:771
verses.text: Can you describe this intellectual light, which gives us a clear perception of the distinction between itself and other things, as well as of the distinction between those things themselves? And yet even this is not the sense in which it can be said that God is light, for this light is created, whereas God is the Creator; the light is made, and He is the Maker; the light is changeable.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:772
verses.text: For the intellect changes from dislike to desire, from ignorance to knowledge, from forgetfulness to recollection; whereas God remains the same in will, in truth, and in eternity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:773
verses.text: From God we derive the beginning of existence, the principle of knowledge, the law of affection.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:774
verses.text: From God all animals, rational and irrational, derive the nature of their life, the capacity of sensation, the faculty of emotion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:775
verses.text: From God all bodies derive their subsistence in extension, their beauty in number, and their order in weight.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:776
verses.text: This light is one divine being, in an inseparable triune existence; and yet, without supposing the assumption of any bodily form, you assign to separate places parts of the immaterial, spiritual, and unchangeable substance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:777
verses.text: And instead of three places for the Trinity, you have four: one, the light inaccessible, which you know nothing about, for the Father; two, the sun and moon, for the Son; and again one, the circle of the atmosphere, for the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:778
verses.text: Of the inaccessible light of the Father I shall say nothing further at present, for orthodox believers do not separate the Son and the Spirit from the Father in relation to this light.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:779
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:780
verses.text: It is difficult to understand how you have been taken with the absurd idea of placing the power of the Son in the sun, and His wisdom in the moon.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:781
verses.text: For, as the Son remains inseparably in the Father, His wisdom and power cannot be separated from one another, so that one should be in the sun and the other in the moon.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:782
verses.text: Only material things can be thus assigned to separate places.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:783
verses.text: If you only understood this, it would have prevented you from taking the productions of a diseased fancy as the material for so many fictions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:784
verses.text: But there is inconsistency and improbability as well as falsehood in your ideas.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:785
verses.text: For, according to you, the seat of wisdom is inferior in brightness to the seat of power.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:786
verses.text: Now energy and productiveness are the qualities of power, whereas light teaches and manifests; so that if the sun had the greater heat, and the moon the greater light, these absurdities might appear to have some likelihood to men of carnal minds, who know nothing except through material conceptions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:787
verses.text: From the connection between great heat and motion, they might identify power with heat; while light from its brightness, and as making things discernible, they might represent wisdom.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:788
verses.text: But what folly as well as profanity, in placing power in the sun, which excels so much in light, and wisdom in the moon, which is so inferior in brightness! And while you separate Christ from Himself, you do not distinguish between Christ and the Holy Spirit; whereas Christ is one, the power of God, and the wisdom of God, and the Spirit is a distinct person.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:789
verses.text: But according to you, the air, which you make the seat of the Spirit, fills and pervades the universe.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:790
verses.text: So the sun and moon in their course are always united to the air.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:791
verses.text: But the moon approaches the sun at one time, and recedes from it at another.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:792
verses.text: So that, if we may believe you, or rather, if we may allow ourselves to be imposed on by you, wisdom recedes from power by half the circumference of a circle, and again approaches it by the other half.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:793
verses.text: And when wisdom is full, it is at a distance from power.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:794
verses.text: For when the moon is full, the distance between the two bodies is so great, that the moon rises in the east while the sun is setting in the west.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:795
verses.text: But as the loss of power produces weakness, the fuller the moon is, the weaker must wisdom be.
