verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:796
verses.text: If, as is certainly true, the wisdom of God is unchangeable in power, and the power of God unchangeable in wisdom, how can you separate them so as to assign them to different places? And how can the place be different when the substance is the same? Is this not the infatuation of subjection to material fancies; showing such a want of power and wisdom that your wisdom is as weak as your power is foolish? This execrable absurdity would divide Christ between the sun and the moon,—His power in one, and His wisdom in the other; so that He would be incomplete in both, lacking wisdom in the sun, and power in the moon, while in both He supplies youths, male and female, to excite the affection of the princes and princesses of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:797
verses.text: Such are the tenets which you learn and profess.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:798
verses.text: Such is the faith which directs your conduct.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:799
verses.text: And can you wonder that you are regarded with abhorrence?  9.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:800
verses.text: But besides your errors regarding these conspicuous and familiar luminaries, which you worship not for what they are, but for what your wild fancy makes them to be, your other absurdities are still worse than this.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:801
verses.text: Your illustrious World-bearer, and Atlas who helps to hold him up, are unreal beings.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:802
verses.text: Like innumerable other creatures of your fancy, they have no existence, and yet you worship them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:803
verses.text: For this reason we say that you are worse than Pagans, while you resemble them in worshipping many gods.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:804
verses.text: You are worse, because, while they worship things which exist though they are not gods, you worship things which are neither gods nor anything else, for they have no existence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:805
verses.text: The Pagans, too, have fables, but they know them to be fables; and either look upon them as amusing poetical fancies, or try to explain them as representing the nature of things, or the life of man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:806
verses.text: Thus they say that Vulcan is lame, because flame in common fire has an irregular motion: that Fortune is blind, because of the uncertainty of what are called fortuitous occurrences: that there are three Fates, with distaff, and spindle, and fingers spinning wool into thread, because there are three times,—the past, already spun and wound on the spindle; the present, which is passing through the fingers of the spinner; and the future, still in wool bound to the distaff, and soon to pass through the fingers to the spindle, that is, through the present into the future: and that Venus is the wife of Vulcan, because pleasure has a natural connection with heat; and that she is the mistress of Mars, because pleasure is not properly the companion of warriors: and that Cupid is a boy with wings and a bow, from the wounds inflicted by thoughtless, inconstant passion in the hearts of unhappy beings: and so with many other fables.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:807
verses.text: The great absurdity is in their continuing to worship these beings, after giving such explanations; for the worship without the explanations, though criminal, would be a less heinous crime.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:808
verses.text: The very explanations prove that they do not worship that God, the enjoyment of whom can alone give happiness, but things which He has created.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:809
verses.text: And even in the creature they worship not only the virtues, as in Minerva, who sprang from the head of Jupiter, and who represents prudence,—a quality of reason which, according to Plato, has its seat in the head,—but their vices, too, as in Cupid.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:810
verses.text: Thus one of their dramatic poets says, "Sinful passion, in favor of vice, made Love a god".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:811
verses.text: Even bodily evils had temples in Rome, as in the case of pallor and fever.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:812
verses.text: Not to dwell on the sin of the worshippers of these idols, who are in a way affected by the bodily forms, so that they pay homage to them as deities, when they see them set up in some lofty place, and treated with great honor and reverence, there is greater sin in the very explanations which are intended as apologies for these dumb, and deaf, and blind, and lifeless objects.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:813
verses.text: Still, though, as I have said, these things are nothing in the way of salvation or of usefulness, both they and the things they are said to represent are real existences.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:814
verses.text: But your First Man, warring with the five elements; and your Mighty Spirit, who constructs the world from the captive bodies of the race of darkness, or rather from the members of your god in subjection and bondage; and your World-holder, who has in his hand the remains of these members, and who bewails the capture and bondage and pollution of the rest; and your giant Atlas, who keeps up the World-holder on his shoulders, lest he should from weariness throw away his burden, and so prevent the completion of the final imitation of the mass of darkness, which is to be the last scene in your drama;—these and countless other absurdities are not represented in painting or sculpture, or in any explanation; and yet you believe and worship things which have no existence, while you taunt the Christians with being credulous for believing in realities with a faith which pacifies the mind under its influence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:815
verses.text: The objects of your worship can be shown to have no existence by many proofs, which I do not bring forward here, because, though I could without difficulty discourse philosophically on the construction of the world, it would take too long to do so here.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:816
verses.text: One proof suffices.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:817
verses.text: If these things are real, God must be subject to change, and corruption, and contamination; a supposition as blasphemous as it is irrational.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:818
verses.text: All these things, therefore, are vain, and false, and unreal.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:819
verses.text: Thus you are much worse than those Pagans, with whom all are familiar, and who still preserve traces of their old customs, of which they themselves are ashamed; for while they worship things which are not gods, you worship things which do not exist.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:820
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:821
verses.text: If you think that your doctrines are true because they are unlike the errors of the Pagans, and that we are in error because we perhaps differ more from you than from them, you might as well say that a dead man is in good health because he is not sick; or that good health is undesirable, because it differs less from sickness than from death.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:822
verses.text: Or if the Pagans should be viewed in many cases as rather dead than sick, you might as well praise the ashes in the tomb because they have no longer the human shape, as compared with the living body, which does not differ so much from a corpse as from ashes.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:823
verses.text: It is thus we are reproached for having more resemblance to the dead body of Paganism than to the ashes of Manich aeism.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:824
verses.text: But in division, it often happens that a thing is placed in different classes, according to the point of resemblance on which the division proceeds.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:825
verses.text: For instance, if animals are divided into those that fly and those that cannot fly, in this division men and beasts are classed together as distinct from birds, because they are both unable to fly.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:826
verses.text: But if they are divided into rational and irrational, beasts and birds are classed together as distinct from men, for they are both destitute of reason.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:827
verses.text: Faustus did not think of this when he said: There are in fact only two sects, the Gentiles and ourselves, for we are directly opposed to them in our belief.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:828
verses.text: The opposition he means is this, that the Gentiles believe in a single principle, whereas the Manich aeans believe also in the principle of the race of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:829
verses.text: Certainly, according to this division we agree in general with the Pagans.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:830
verses.text: But if we divide all who have a religion into those who worship one God and those who worship many gods, the Manich aeans must be classed along with the Pagans, and we along with the Jews.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:831
verses.text: This is another distinction, which may be said to make only two sects.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:832
verses.text: Perhaps you will say that you hold all your gods to be of one substance, which the Pagans do not.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:833
verses.text: But you at least resemble them in assigning to your gods different powers, and functions, and employments.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:834
verses.text: One does battle with the race of darkness; another constructs the world from the part which is captured; another, standing above, has the world in his hand; another holds him up from below; another turns the wheels of the fires and winds and waters beneath; another, in his circuit of the heavens, gathers with his beams the members of your god from cesspools.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:835
verses.text: Indeed, your gods have innumerable occupations, according to your fabulous descriptions, which you neither explain nor represent in a visible form.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:836
verses.text: But again, if men were divided into those who believe that God takes an interest in human affairs and those who do not, the Pagans and Jews, and you and all heretics that have anything of Christianity, will be classed together, as opposed to the Epicureans, and any others holding similar views.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:837
verses.text: As this is a principle of importance, here again we may say that there are only two sects, and you belong to the same sect as we do.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:838
verses.text: You will hardly venture to dissent from us in the opinion that God is concerned in human affairs, so that in this matter your opposition to the Epicureans makes you side with us.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:839
verses.text: Thus, according to the nature of the division, what is in one class at one time, is in another at another time: things joined here are separated there: in some things we are classed with others, and they with us; in other things we are classed separately, and stand alone.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:840
verses.text: If Faustus thought of this, he would not talk such eloquent nonsense.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:841
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:842
verses.text: But what are we to make of these words of Faustus: The Holy Spirit, by his influence and spiritual infusion, makes the earth conceive and bring forth the mortal Jesus, who, as hanging from every tree, is the life and salvation of men? Letting pass for a moment the absurdity of this statement, we observe the folly of believing that the mortal Jesus can be conceived through the power of the Holy Spirit by the earth, but not by the Virgin Mary.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:843
verses.text: Dare you compare the holiness of that chaste virgin's womb with any piece of ground where trees and plants grow? Do you pretend to look with abhorrence upon a pure virgin, while you do not shrink from believing that Jesus is produced in gardens watered by the filthy drains of a city? For plants of all kinds spring up and are nourished in such moisture.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:844
verses.text: You will have Jesus to be born in this way, while you cry out against the idea of His being born of a virgin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:845
verses.text: Do you think flesh more unclean than the excrements which its nature rejects? Is the filth cleaner than the flesh which expels it? Are you not aware how fields are manured in order to make them productive? Your folly comes to this, that the Holy Spirit, who, according to you, despised the womb of Mary, makes the earth conceive more fruitfully in proportion as it is carefully enriched with animal off-scourings.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:846
verses.text: Do you reply that the Holy Spirit preserves His incorruptible purity everywhere? I ask again, Why not also in the virgin's womb? Passing from the conception, you maintain in regard to the mortal Jesus—who, as you say, is born from the earth, which has conceived by the power of the Holy Spirit—that He hangs in the shape of fruit from every tree: so that, besides this pollution, He suffers additional defilement from the flesh of the countless animals that eat the fruit; except, indeed, the small amount that is purified by your eating it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:847
verses.text: While we believe and confess Christ the Son of God, and the Word of God, to have become flesh without suffering defilement, because the divine substance is not defiled by flesh, as it is not defiled by anything, your fanciful notions would make Jesus to be defiled even as hanging on the tree, before entering the flesh of any animal; for if He were not defiled, there would be no need of His being purified by your eating Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:848
verses.text: And if all trees are the cross of Christ, as Faustus seems to imply when he says that Jesus hangs from every tree, why do you not pluck the fruit, and so take Jesus down from hanging on the tree to bury Him in your stomach, which would correspond to the good deed of Joseph of Arimathea, when he took down the true Jesus from the cross to bury Him?  Why should it be impious to take Christ from the tree, while it is pious to lay Him in the tomb? Perhaps you wish to apply to yourselves the words quoted from the prophet by Paul, "Their throat is an open sepulchre:"  and so you wait with open mouth till some one comes to use your throat as the best sepulchre for Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:849
verses.text: Once more, how many Christs do you make? Is there one whom you call the mortal Christ, whom the earth conceives and brings forth by the power of the Holy Spirit; and another crucified by the Jews under Pontius Pilate; and a third whom you divide between the sun and the moon? Or is it one and the same person, part of whom is confined in the trees, to be released by the help of the other part which is not confined? If this is the case, and you allow that Christ suffered under Pontius Pilate, though it is difficult to see how he could have suffered without flesh, as you say he did, the great question is, with whom he left those ships you speak of, that he might come down and suffer these things, which he certainly could not have suffered without having a body of some kind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:850
verses.text: A mere spiritual presence could not have made him liable to these sufferings, and in his bodily presence he could not be at the same time in the sun, in the moon, and on the cross.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:851
verses.text: So, then, if he had not a body, he was not crucified; and if he had a body, the question is, where he got it: for, according to you, all bodies belong to the race of darkness, though you cannot think of the divine substance except as being material.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:852
verses.text: Thus you must say either that Christ was crucified without a body; which is utterly absurd; or that he was crucified in appearance and not in reality, which is blasphemy; or that all bodies do not belong to the race of darkness, but that the divine substance has also a body, and that not an immortal body, but liable to crucifixion and death, which, again, is altogether erroneous; or that Christ had a mortal body from the race of darkness, so that, while you will not allow that Christ's body came from the Virgin Mary, you derive it from the race of demons.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:853
verses.text: Finally, as in Faustus' statement, in which he alludes in the briefest manner possible to the lengthy stories of Manich aean invention, the earth by the power of the Holy Spirit conceives and brings forth the mortal Jesus, who, hanging from every tree, is the life and salvation of men, why should this Saviour be represented by whatever is hanging, because he hung on the tree, and not by whatever is born, because he was born? But if you mean that the Jesus on the trees, and the Jesus crucified under Pontius Pilate, and the Jesus divided between the sun and the moon, are all one and the same substance, why do you not give the name of Jesus to your whole host of deities? Why should not your World-holder be Jesus too, and Atlas, and the King of Honour, and the Mighty Spirit, and the First Man, and all the rest, with their various names and occupations?  12.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:854
verses.text: So, with regard to the Holy Spirit, how can you say that he is the third person, when the persons you mention are innumerable? Or why is he not Jesus himself? And why does Faustus mislead people, in trying to make out an agreement between himself and true Christians, from whom he differs only too widely, by saying, We worship one God under the threefold appellation of the Almighty God the Father, Christ his Son, and the Holy Spirit? Why is the appellation only threefold, instead of being manifold? And why is the distinction in appellation only, and not in reality, if there are as many persons as there are names? For it is not as if you gave three names to the same thing, as the same weapon may be called a short sword, a dagger, or a dirk; or as you give the name of moon, and the lesser ship, and the luminary of night, and so on, to the same thing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:855
verses.text: For you cannot say that the First Man is the same as the Mighty Spirit, or as the World-Holder, or as the giant Atlas.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:856
verses.text: They are all distinct persons, and you do not call any of them Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:857
verses.text: How can there be one Deity with opposite functions? Or why should not Christ himself be the single person, if in one substance Christ hangs on the trees, and was persecuted by the Jews, and exists in the sun and moon? The fact is, your fancies are all astray, and are no better than the dreams of insanity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:858
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:859
verses.text: How can Faustus think that we resemble the Manich aeans in attaching sacredness to bread and wine, when they consider it sacrilege to taste wine? They acknowledge their god in the grape, but not in the cup; perhaps they are shocked at his being trampled on and bottled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:860
verses.text: It is not any bread and wine that we hold sacred as a natural production, as if Christ were confined in corn or in vines, as the Manich aeans fancy, but what is truly consecrated as a symbol.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:861
verses.text: What is not consecrated, though it is bread and wine, is only nourishment or refreshment, with no sacredness about it; although we bless and thank God for every gift, bodily as well as spiritual.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:862
verses.text: According to your notion, Christ is confined in everything you eat, and is released by digestion from the additional confinement of your intestines.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:863
verses.text: So, when you eat, your god suffers; and when you digest, you suffer from his recovery.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:864
verses.text: When he fills you, your gain is his loss.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:865
verses.text: This might be considered kindness on his part, because he suffers in you for your benefit, were it not that he gains freedom by escaping and leaving you empty.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:866
verses.text: There is not the least resemblance between our reverence for the bread and wine, and your doctrines, which have no truth in them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:867
verses.text: To compare the two is even more foolish than to say, as some do, that in the bread and wine we worship Ceres and Bacchus.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:868
verses.text: I refer to this now, to show where you got your silly idea that our fathers kept the Sabbath in honor of Saturn.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:869
verses.text: For as there is no connection with the worship of the Pagan deities Ceres and Bacchus in our observance of the sacrament of the bread and wine, which you approve so highly that you wish to resemble us in it, so there was no subjection to Saturn in the case of our fathers, who observed the rest of the Sabbath in a manner suitable to prophetic times.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:870
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:871
verses.text: You might have found a resemblance in your religion to that of the Pagans as regards Hyle [matter], which the Pagans often speak of.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:872
verses.text: You, on the contrary, maintain that you are directly opposed to them in your belief in the evil principle which your teacher in theology calls Hyle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:873
verses.text: But here you only show your ignorance, and, with an affectation of learning, use this word without knowing what it means.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:874
verses.text: The Greeks, when speaking of nature, give the name Hyle to the subject-matter of things, which has no form of its own, but admits of all bodily forms, and is known only through these changeable phenomena, not being itself an object of sensation or perception.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:875
verses.text: Some Gentiles, indeed, erroneously make this matter co-eternal with God, as not being derived from Him, though the bodily forms are.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:876
verses.text: In this manifest error you resemble the Pagans, for you hold that Hyle has a principle of its own, and does not come from God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:877
verses.text: It is only ignorance that leads you to deny this resemblance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:878
verses.text: In saying that Hyle has no form of its own, and can take its forms only from God, the Pagans come near to the truth which we believe in contradistinction from your errors.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:879
verses.text: Not knowing what Hyle or the subject-matter of things is, you make it the race of darkness, in which you place not only innumerable bodily forms of five different kinds, but also a formative mind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:880
verses.text: Such, indeed, is your ignorance or insanity, that you call this mind Hyle, and make it give forms instead of taking them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:881
verses.text: If there were such a formative mind as you speak of, and bodily elements capable of form, the word Hyle would properly be applicable to the bodily elements, which would be the matter to be formed by the mind, which you make the principle of evil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:882
verses.text: Even this would not be a quite accurate use of the word Hyle, which has no form of any kind; whereas these elements, although capable of new forms, have already the form of elements, and belong to different kinds.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:883
verses.text: Still this use of the word would not be so much amiss, notwithstanding your ignorance; for it would thus be applied, as it properly is, to that which takes form, and not to that which gives it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:884
verses.text: Even here, however, your folly and impiety would appear in tracing so much that is good to the evil principle, from your not knowing that all natures of every kind, all forms in their proportion, and all weights in their order, can come only from the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:885
verses.text: As it is, you know neither what Hyle is, nor what evil is.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:886
verses.text: Would that I could persuade you to refrain from misleading people still more ignorant than yourselves!  15.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:887
verses.text: Every one must see the folly of your boasting of superiority to the Pagans because they use altars and temples, images and sacrifices and incense, in the worship of God, which you do not.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:888
verses.text: As if it were not better to build an altar and offer sacrifice to a stone, which has some kind of existence, than to employ a heated imagination in worshipping things which have no existence at all.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:889
verses.text: And what do you mean by saying that you are a rational temple of God? Can that be God's temple which is partly the construction of the devil? And is this not true of you, as you say that all your members and your whole body were formed by the evil principle which you call Hyle, and that part of this formative mind dwells in the body along with part of your god? And as this part of your god is bound and confined, you should be called the prison of God rather than his temple.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:890
verses.text: Perhaps it is your soul that is the temple of God, as you have it from the region of light.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:891
verses.text: But you generally call your soul not a temple, but a part or member of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:892
verses.text: So, when you say you are the temple of God, it must be in your body, which, you say, was formed by the devil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:893
verses.text: Thus you blaspheme the temple of God, calling it not only the workmanship of Satan, but the prison-house of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:894
verses.text: The apostle, on the other hand, says: "The temple of God is holy, which temple ye are".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:895
verses.text: And to show that this refers not merely to the soul, he says expressly: "Know ye not that your bodies are the temple of the Holy Ghost, which is in you, which ye have of God?"  You call the workmanship of devils the temple of God, and there, to use Faustus' words, you place Christ, the Son of God, the living image of living majesty.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:896
verses.text: Your impiety may well contrive a fabulous temple for a fabulous Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:897
verses.text: The image you speak of must be so called, because it is the creature of your imagination.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:898
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:899
verses.text: If your mind is an altar, you see whose altar it is.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:900
verses.text: You may see from the very doctrines and duties in which you say you are trained.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:901
verses.text: You are taught not to give food to a beggar; and so your altar smokes with the sacrifice of cruelty.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:902
verses.text: Such altars the Lord destroys; for in words quoted from the law He tells us what offering pleases God: "I desire mercy, and not sacrifice".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:903
verses.text: Observe on what occasion the Lord uses these words.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:904
verses.text: It was when, in passing through a field, the disciples plucked the ears of corn because they were hungry.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:905
verses.text: Your doctrine would lead you to call this murder.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:906
verses.text: Your mind is an altar, not of God, but of lying devils, by whose doctrines the evil conscience is seared as with a hot iron,  calling murder what the truth calls innocence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:907
verses.text: For in His words to the Jews, Christ by anticipation deals a fatal blow to you: "If ye had known what this meaneth, I desire mercy, and not sacrifice, ye would not have condemned the guiltless".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:908
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:909
verses.text: Nor can you say that you honor God with sacrifices in the shape of pure and simple prayers: for, in your low, dishonoring notions about the divine nature and substance, you make your god to be the victim in the sacrifices of Pagans; so far are you from pleasing the true God with your sacrifices.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:910
verses.text: For you hold that God is confined not only in trees and plants, or in the human body, but also in the flesh of animals, which contaminates Him with its impurity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:911
verses.text: And how can your soul give praise to God, when you actually reproach Him by calling your soul a particle of His substance taken captive by the race of darkness; as if God could not maintain the conflict except by this corruption of His members, and this dishonorable captivity? Instead of honoring God in your prayers, you insult Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:912
verses.text: For what sin did you commit, when you belonged to Him, that you should be thus punished by the god you cry to, not because you left Him sinfully of your own choice; for he himself gave you to His enemies, to obtain peace for His kingdom? You are not even given as hostages to be honorably guarded.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:913
verses.text: Nor is it as when a shepherd lays a snare to catch a wild beast: for he does not put one of his own members in the snare, but some animal from his flock; and generally, so that the wild beast is caught before the animal is hurt.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:914
verses.text: You, though you are the members of your god, are given to the enemy, whose ferocity you keep off from your god only by being contaminated with their impurity, infected with their corruptions, without any fault of your own.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:915
verses.text: You cannot in your prayers use the words: "Free us, O Lord, for the glory of Thy name; and for Thy name's sake pardon our sins".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:916
verses.text: Your prayer is: "Free us by Thy skill, for we suffer here oppression, and torture, and pollution, only that Thou mayest mourn unmolested in Thy kingdom".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:917
verses.text: These are words of reproach, not of entreaty.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:918
verses.text: Nor can you use the words taught us by the Master of truth: "Forgive us our debts, as we forgive our debtors".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:919
verses.text: For who are the debtors who have sinned against you? If it is the race of darkness, you do not forgive their debts, but make them be utterly cast out and shut up in eternal imprisonment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:920
verses.text: And how can God forgive your debts, when He rather sinned against you by sending you into such a state, than you against Him, whom you obeyed by going? If this was not a sin in Him, because He was compelled to do it, this excuse must apply you, now that you have been overthrown in the conflict, more than to Him before the conflict began.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:921
verses.text: You suffer now from the mixture of evil, which was not the case with Him when nevertheless He was compelled to send you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:922
verses.text: So either He requires that you should forgive Him his debt; or, if He is not in debt to you, still less are you to Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:923
verses.text: It appears that your sacrifices and your pure and simple prayers are false and vile blasphemies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:924
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:925
verses.text: How is it, by the way, that you use the words temple, altar, sacrifice, for the purpose of commending your own practices? If such things can be spoken of as properly belonging to true religion, they must constitute the true worship of the true God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:926
verses.text: And if there is such a thing as true sacrifice to the true God, which is implied in the expression divine honors, there must be some one true sacrifice of which the rest are imitations.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:927
verses.text: On the one hand, we have the spurious imitations in the case of false and lying gods, that is, of devils, who proudly demand divine honors from their deluded votaries, as is or was the case in the temples and idols of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:928
verses.text: On the other hand, we have the prophetic intimations of one most true sacrifice to be offered for the sins of all believers, as in the sacrifices enjoined by God on our fathers; along with which there was also the symbolical anointing typical of Christ, as the name Christ itself means anointed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:929
verses.text: The animal sacrifices, therefore, presumptuously claimed by devils, were an imitation of the true sacrifice which is due only to the one true God, and which Christ alone offered on His altar.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:930
verses.text: Thus the apostle says: "The sacrifices which the Gentiles offer, they offer to devils, and not to God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:931
verses.text: He does not find fault with sacrifices, but with offering to devils.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:932
verses.text: The Hebrews, again, in their animal sacrifices, which they offered to God in many varied forms, suitably to the significance of the institution, typified the sacrifice offered by Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:933
verses.text: This sacrifice is also commemorated by Christians, in the sacred offering and participation of the body and blood of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:934
verses.text: The Manich aeans understand neither the sinfulness of the Gentile sacrifices, nor the importance of the Hebrew sacrifices, nor the use of the ordinance of the Christian sacrifice.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:935
verses.text: Their own errors are the offering they present to the devil who has deceived them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:936
verses.text: And thus they depart from the faith, giving heed to seducing spirits, and to doctrines of devils, speaking lies in hypocrisy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:937
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:938
verses.text: It may be well that Faustus, or at least that those who are charmed with Faustus' writings, should know that the doctrine of a single principle did not come to us from the Gentiles; for the belief in one true God, from whom every kind of nature is derived, is a part of the original truth retained among the Gentiles, notwithstanding their having fallen away to many false gods.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:939
verses.text: For the Gentile philosophers had the knowledge of God, because, as the apostle says, "the invisible things of God, from the creation of the world, are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made, even His eternal power and Godhead; so that they are without excuse".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:940
verses.text: But, as the apostle adds, "when they knew God, they glorified Him not as God, neither were thankful; but became vain in their imaginations, and their foolish heart was darkened.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:941
verses.text: Professing themselves to be wise, they became fools, and changed the glory of the incorruptible God into an image made like to corruptible man, and to birds, and four-footed beasts, and creeping things".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:942
verses.text: These are the idols of the Gentiles, which they cannot explain except by referring to the creatures made by God; so that this very explanation of their idolatry, on which the more enlightened Gentiles were wont to pride themselves as a proof of their superiority, shows the truth of the following words of the apostle: "They worshipped and served the creature rather than the Creator, who is blessed forever".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:943
verses.text: Where you differ from the Gentiles, you are in error; where you resemble them, you are worse than they.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:944
verses.text: You do not believe, as they do, in a single principle; and so you fall into the impiety of believing the substance of the one true God to be liable to subjugation and corruption.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:945
verses.text: As regards the worship of a plurality of gods, the doctrine of lying devils has led the Gentiles to worship many idols, and you to worship many phantasms.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:946
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:947
verses.text: We do not turn the sacrifices of the Gentiles into love-feasts, as Faustus says we do.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:948
verses.text: Our love-feasts are rather a substitute for the sacrifice spoken of by the Lord, in the words already quoted: "I will have mercy, and not sacrifice".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:949
verses.text: At our love-feasts the poor obtain vegetable or animal food; and so the creature of God is used, as far as it is suitable, for the nourishment of man, who is also God's creature.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:950
verses.text: You have been led by lying devils, not in self-denial, but in blasphemous error, "to abstain from meats which God hath created to be received with thanksgiving of them which believe and know the truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:951
verses.text: For every creature of God is good, and nothing to be refused, if it be received with thanksgiving".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:952
verses.text: In return for the bounties of the Creator, you ungratefully insult Him with your impiety; and because in our love-feasts flesh is often given to the poor, you compare Christian charity to Pagan sacrifices.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:953
verses.text: This indeed, is another point in which you resemble some Pagans.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:954
verses.text: You consider it a crime to kill animals, because you think that the souls of men pass into them; which is an idea found in the writings of some Gentile philosophers, although their successors appear to have thought differently.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:955
verses.text: But here again you are most in error: for they dreaded slaughtering a relative in the animal; but you dread the slaughter of your god, for you hold even the souls of animals to be his members.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:956
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:957
verses.text: As to our paying honor to the memory of the martyrs, and the accusation of Faustus, that we worship them instead of idols, I should not care to answer such a charge, were it not for the sake of showing how Faustus, in his desire to cast reproach on us, has overstepped the Manich aean inventions, and has fallen heedlessly into a popular notion found in Pagan poetry, although he is so anxious to be distinguished from the Pagans.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:958
verses.text: For in saying that we have turned the idols into martyrs, he speaks of our worshipping them with similar rites, and appeasing the shades of the departed with wine and food.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:959
verses.text: Do you, then, believe in shades? We never heard you speak of such things, nor have we read of them in your books.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:960
verses.text: In fact, you generally oppose such ideas: for you tell us that the souls of the dead, if they are wicked, or not purified, are made to pass through various changes, or suffer punishment still more severe; while the good souls are placed in ships, and sail through heaven to that imaginary region of light which they died fighting for.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:961
verses.text: According to you, then, no souls remain near the burying-place of the body; and how can there be any shades of the departed? What and where are they? Faustus' love of evil-speaking has made him forget his own creed; or perhaps he spoke in his sleep about ghosts, and did not wake up even when he saw his words in writing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:962
verses.text: It is true that Christians pay religious honor to the memory of the martyrs, both to excite us to imitate them and to obtain a share in their merits, and the assistance of their prayers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:963
verses.text: But we build altars not to any martyr, but to the God of martyrs, although it is to the memory of the martyrs.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:964
verses.text: No one officiating at the altar in the saints' burying-place ever says, We bring an offering to thee, O Peter! or O Paul! or O Cyprian! The offering is made to God, who gave the crown of martyrdom, while it is in memory of those thus crowned.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:965
verses.text: The emotion is increased by the associations of the place, and love is excited both towards those who are our examples, and towards Him by whose help we may follow such examples.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:966
verses.text: We regard the martyrs with the same affectionate intimacy that we feel towards holy men of God in this life, when we know that their hearts are prepared to endure the same suffering for the truth of the gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:967
verses.text: There is more devotion in our feeling towards the martyrs, because we know that their conflict is over; and we can speak with greater confidence in praise of those already victors in heaven, than of those still combating here.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:968
verses.text: What is properly divine worship, which the Greeks call latria, and for which there is no word in Latin, both in doctrine and in practice, we give only to God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:969
verses.text: To this worship belongs the offering of sacrifices; as we see in the word idolatry, which means the giving of this worship to idols.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:970
verses.text: Accordingly we never offer, or require any one to offer, sacrifice to a martyr, or to a holy soul, or to any angel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:971
verses.text: Any one falling into this error is instructed by doctrine, either in the way of correction or of caution.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:972
verses.text: For holy beings themselves, whether saints or angels, refuse to accept what they know to be due to God alone.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:973
verses.text: We see this in Paul and Barnabas, when the men of Lycaonia wished to sacrifice to them as gods, on account of the miracles they performed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:974
verses.text: They rent their clothes, and restrained the people, crying out to them, and persuading them that they were not gods.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:975
verses.text: We see it also in the angels, as we read in the Apocalypse that an angel would not allow himself to be worshipped, and said to his worshipper, "I am thy fellow-servant, and of thy brethen".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:976
verses.text: Those who claim this worship are proud spirits, the devil and his angels, as we see in all the temples and rites of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:977
verses.text: Some proud men, too, have copied their example; as is related of some kings of Babylon.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:978
verses.text: Thus the holy Daniel was accused and persecuted, because when the king made a decree that no petition should be made to any god, but only to the king, he was found worshipping and praying to his own God, that is, the one true God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:979
verses.text: As for those who drink to excess at the feasts of the martyrs, we of course condemn their conduct; for to do so even in their own houses would be contrary to sound doctrine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:980
verses.text: But we must try to amend what is bad as well as prescribe what is good, and must of necessity bear for a time with some things that are not according to our teaching.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:981
verses.text: The rules of Christian conduct are not to be taken from the indulgences of the intemperate or the infirmities of the weak.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:982
verses.text: Still, even in this, the guilt of intemperance is much less than that of impiety.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:983
verses.text: To sacrifice to the martyrs, even fasting, is worse than to go home intoxicated from their feast: to sacrifice to the martyrs, I say, which is a different thing from sacrificing to God in memory of the martyrs, as we do constantly, in the manner required since the revelation of the New Testament, for this belongs to the worship or latria which is due to God alone.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:984
verses.text: But it is vain to try to make these heretics understand the full meaning of these words of the Psalmist: "He that offereth the sacrifice of praise glorifieth me, and in this way will I show him my salvation".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:985
verses.text: [19] Before the coming of Christ, the flesh and blood of this sacrifice were foreshadowed in the animals slain; in the passion of Christ the types were fulfilled by the true sacrifice; after the ascension of Christ, this sacrifice is commemorated in the sacrament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:986
verses.text: Between the sacrifices of the Pagans and of the Hebrews there is all the difference that there is between a false imitation and a typical anticipation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:987
verses.text: We do not despise or denounce the virginity of holy women because there were vestal virgins.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:988
verses.text: And, in the same way, it is no reproach to the sacrifices of our fathers that the Gentiles also had sacrifices.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:989
verses.text: The difference between the Christian and vestal virginity is great, yet it consists wholly in the being to whom the vow is made and paid; and so the difference in the being to whom the sacrifices of the Pagans and Hebrews are made and offered makes a wide difference between them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:990
verses.text: In the one case they are offered to devils, who presumptuously make this claim in order to be held as gods, because sacrifice is a divine honor.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:991
verses.text: In the other case they are offered to the one true God, as a type of the true sacrifice, which also was to be offered to Him in the passion of the body and blood of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:992
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:993
verses.text: Faustus is wrong in saying that our Jewish forefathers, in their separation from the Gentiles, retained the temple, and sacrifices, and altars, and priesthood, and abandoned only graven images or idols, for they might have sacrificed, as some do, without any graven image, to trees and mountains, or even to the sun and moon and the stars.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:994
verses.text: If they had thus rendered to these objects the worship called latria, they would have served the creature instead of the Creator, and so would have fallen into the serious error of heathenish superstition; and even without idols, they would have found devils ready to take advantage of their error, and to accept their offerings.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:995
verses.text: For these proud and wicked spirits feed not, as some foolishly suppose, on the smell of the sacrifice, and the smoke, but on the errors of men.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:996
verses.text: They enjoy not bodily refreshment, but a malevolent gratification, when they in any way deceive people, or when, with a bold assumption of borrowed majesty, they boast of receiving divine honors.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:997
verses.text: It was not, therefore, only the idols of the Gentiles that our Jewish forefathers abandoned.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:998
verses.text: They sacrificed neither to the earth nor to any earthly thing, nor to the sea, nor to heaven, nor to the hosts of heaven, but laid the victims on the altar of the one God, Creator of all, who required these offerings as a means of foreshadowing the true victim, by whom He has reconciled us to Himself in the remission of sins through our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:999
verses.text: So Paul, addressing believers, who are made the body of which Christ is the Head, says: "I beseech you, therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable to God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1000
verses.text: The Manich aeans, on the other hand, say that human bodies are the workmanship of the race of darkness, and the prison in which the captive deity is confined.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1001
verses.text: Thus Faustus' doctrine is very different from Paul's.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1002
verses.text: But since whosover preaches to you another gospel than that ye have received must be accursed, what Christ says in Paul is the truth, while Manich aeus in Faustus is accursed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1003
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1004
verses.text: Faustus says also, without knowing what he says, that we have retained the manners of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1005
verses.text: But seeing that the just lives by faith, and that the end of the commandment is love out of a pure heart, and a good conscience, and faith unfeigned, and that these three, faith, hope, and love, abide to form the life of believers, it is impossible that there should be similarity in the manners of those who differ in these three things.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1006
verses.text: Those who believe differently, and hope differently, and love differently, must also live differently.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1007
verses.text: And if we resemble the Gentiles in our use of such things as food and drink, and houses and clothes and baths, and those of us who marry, in taking and keeping wives, and in begetting and bringing up children as our heirs, there is still a great difference between the man who uses these things for some end of his own, and the man who, in using them, gives thanks to God, having no unworthy or erroneous ideas about God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1008
verses.text: For as you, according to your own heresy, though you eat the same bread as other men, and live upon the produce of the same plants and the water of the same fountain, and are clothed like others in wool and linen, yet lead a different life, not because you eat or drink, or dress differently, but because you differ from others in your ideas and in your faith, and in all these things have in view an end of your own—the end, namely, set forth in your false doctrines; in the same way we, though we resemble the Gentiles in the use of this and other things, do not resemble them in our life; for while the things are the same, the end is different: for the end we have in view is, according to the just commandment of God, love out of a pure heart, and a good conscience, and faith unfeigned; from which some having erred, are turned to vain jangling.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1009
verses.text: In this vain jangling you bear the palm, for you do not attend to the fact that so great is the difference of life produced by a different faith, even when the things in possession and use are the same, that though your followers have wives, and in spite of themselves get children, for whom they gather and store up wealth; though they eat flesh, drink wine, bathe, reap harvests, gather vintages, engage in trade, and occupy high official positions, you nevertheless reckon them as belonging to you, and not to the Gentiles, though in their actions they approach nearer to the Gentiles than to you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1010
verses.text: And though some of the Gentiles in some things resemble you more than your own followers,—those, for instance, who in superstitious devotion abstain from flesh, and wine, and marriage,—you still count your own followers, even though they use all these things, and so are unlike you, as belonging to the flock of Manich aeus rather than those who resemble you in their practices.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1011
verses.text: You consider as belonging to you a woman that believes in Manich aeus, though she is a mother, rather than a Sibyl, though she never marries.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1012
verses.text: But you will say that many who are called Catholic Christians are adulterers, robbers, misers, drunkards, and whatever else is contrary to sound doctrine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1013
verses.text: I ask if none such are to be found in your company, which is almost too small to be called a company.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1014
verses.text: And because there are some among the Pagans who are not of this character, do you consider them as better than yourselves? And yet, in fact, your heresy is so blasphemous, that even your followers who are not of such a character are worse than the Pagans who are.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1015
verses.text: It is therefore no impeachment to sound doctrine, which alone is Catholic, that many wish to take its name, who will not yield to its beneficial influence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1016
verses.text: We must bear in mind the true meaning of the contrast which the Lord makes between the little company and the mass of mankind, as spread over all the world; for the company of saints and believers is small, as the amount of grain is small when compared with the heap of chaff; and yet the good grain is quite sufficient far to outnumber you, good and bad together, for good and bad are both strangers to the truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1017
verses.text: In a word, we are not a schism of the Gentiles, for we differ from them greatly for the better; nor are you, for you differ from them greatly for the worse.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1018
verses.text: Book XXI.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1019
verses.text: Faustus denies that Manich aeans believe in two gods.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1020
verses.text: Hyle no god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1021
verses.text: Augustin discusses at large the doctrine of God and Hyle, and fixes the charge of dualism upon the Manich aeans.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1022
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1023
verses.text: Faustus said: Do we believe in one God or in two? In one, of course.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1024
verses.text: If we are accused of making two gods, I reply that it cannot be shown that we ever said anything of the kind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1025
verses.text: Why do you suspect us of this? Because, you say, you believe in two principles, good and evil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1026
verses.text: It is true, we believe in two principles; but one we call God, and the other Hyle, or, to use common popular language, the devil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1027
verses.text: If you think this means two gods, you may as well think that the health and sickness of which doctors speak are two kinds of health, or that good and evil are two kinds of good, or that wealth and poverty are two kinds of wealth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1028
verses.text: If I were describing two things, one white and the other black, or one hot and the other cold, or one sweet and the other bitter, it would appear like idiocy or insanity in you to say that I was describing two white things, or two hot things, or two sweet things.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1029
verses.text: So, when I assert that there are two principles, God and Hyle, you have no reason for saying that I believe in two gods.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1030
verses.text: Do you think that we must call them both gods because we attribute, as is proper, all the power of evil to Hyle, and all the power of good to God? If so, you may as well say that a poison and the antidote must both be called antidotes, because each has a power of its own, and certain effects follow from the action of both.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1031
verses.text: So also, you may say that a physician and a poisoner are both physicians; or that a just and an unjust man are both just, because both do something.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1032
verses.text: If this is absurd, it is still more absurd to say that God and Hyle must both be gods, because they both produce certain effects.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1033
verses.text: It is a very childish and impotent way of arguing, when you cannot refute my statements, to make a quarrel about names.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1034
verses.text: I grant that we, too, sometimes call the hostile nature God; not that we believe it to be God, but that this name is already adopted by the worshippers of this nature, who in their error suppose it to be God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1035
verses.text: Thus the apostle says: "The god of this world has blinded the minds of them that believe not".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1036
verses.text: He calls him God, because he would be so called by his worshippers; adding that he blinds their minds, to show that he is not the true God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1037
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1038
verses.text: Augustin replied: You often speak in your discourses of two gods, as indeed you acknowledge, though at first you denied it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1039
verses.text: And you give as a reason for thus speaking the words of the apostle: "The god of this world has blinded the minds of them that believe not".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1040
verses.text: Most of us punctuate this sentence differently, and explain it as meaning that the true God has blinded the minds of unbelievers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1041
verses.text: They put a stop after the word God, and read the following words together.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1042
verses.text: Or without this punctuation you may, for the sake of exposition, change the order of the words, and read, "In whom God has blinded the minds of unbelievers of this world," which gives the same sense.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1043
verses.text: The act of blinding the minds of unbelievers may in one sense be ascribed to God, as the effect not of malice, but of justice.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1044
verses.text: Thus Paul himself says elsewhere, "Is God unjust, who taketh vengeance?"   and again, "What shall we say then? Is there unrighteousness with God? God forbid.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1045
verses.text: For Moses saith, I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy, and will have compassion on whom I will have compassion".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1046
verses.text: Observe what he adds, after asserting the undeniable truth that there is no unrighteousness with God: "But what if God, willing to show His wrath, and to make His power known, endured with much long-suffering the vessels of wrath fitted for destruction, and that He might manifest the riches of His grace towards the vessels of mercy, which He hath before prepared unto glory?"  etc.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1047
verses.text: Here it evidently cannot be said that it is one God who shows his wrath, and makes known his power in the vessels of wrath fitted for destruction, and another God who shows his riches in the vessels of mercy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1048
verses.text: According to the apostle's doctrine, it is one and the same God who does both.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1049
verses.text: Hence he says again, "For this cause God gave them up to the lusts of their own heart, to uncleanness, to dishonor their own bodies between themselves;" and immediately after, "For this cause God gave them up unto vile affections;" and again, "And even as they did not like to retain God in their knowledge, God gave them over to a reprobate mind".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1050
verses.text: Here we see how the true and just God blinds the minds of unbelievers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1051
verses.text: For in all these words quoted from the apostle no other God is understood than He whose Son, sent by Him, came saying, "For judgment am I come into this world, that they which see not might see, and that they which see might be made blind".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1052
verses.text: Here, again, it is plain to the minds of believers how God blinds the minds of unbelievers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1053
verses.text: For among the secret things, which contain the righteous principles of God's judgment, there is a secret which determines that the minds of some shall be blinded, and the minds of some enlightened.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1054
verses.text: Regarding this, it is well said of God, "Thy judgments are a great deep".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1055
verses.text: The apostle, in admiration of the unfathomable depth of this abyss, exclaims: "O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and of the knowledge of God! How unsearchable are His judgments, and His ways past finding out!"  3.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1056
verses.text: You cannot distinguish between what God does in mercy and what He does in judgment, because you can neither understand nor use the words of our Psalter: "I will sing of mercy and judgment unto Thee, O Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1057
verses.text: Accordingly, whatever in the feebleness of your frail humanity seems amiss to you, you separate entirely from the will and judgment of God: for you are provided with another evil god, not by a discovery of truth, but by an invention of folly; and to this god you attribute not only what you do unjustly, but also what you suffer justly.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1058
verses.text: Thus you assign to God the bestowal of blessings, and take from Him the infliction of judgments, as if He of whom Christ says that He has prepared everlasting fire for the wicked were a different being from Him who makes His sun to rise upon the evil and the good, and sends rain on the just and on the unjust.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1059
verses.text: Why do you not understand that this great goodness and great severity belong to one God, but because you have not learned to sing of mercy and judgment? Is not He who causes the sun to rise on the evil and the good, and sends rain on the just and on the unjust, the same who also breaks off the natural branches, and engrafts contrary to nature the wild olive tree? Does not the apostle, in reference to this, say of this one God: "Thou seest, then, the goodness and severity of God: to them which were broken off, severity; but toward thee, goodness, if thou continue in His goodness?"  Here it is to be observed how the apostle takes away neither judicial severity from God, nor free-will from man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1060
verses.text: It is a profound mystery, impenetrable by human thought, how God both condemns the ungodly and justifies the ungodly; for both these things are said of Him in the truth of the Holy Scriptures.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1061
verses.text: But is the mysteriousness of the divine judgments any reason for taking pleasure in cavilling against them? How much more becoming, and more suitable to the limitation of our powers, to feel the same awe which the apostle felt, and to exclaim, "O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and of the knowledge of God! How unsearchable are His judgments, and His ways past finding out!" How much better thus to admire what you cannot explain, than to try to make an evil god in addition to the true God, simply because you cannot understand the one good God! For it is not a question of names, but of actions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1062
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1063
verses.text: Faustus glibly defends himself by saying, "We speak not of two gods, but of God and Hyle".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1064
verses.text: But when you ask for the meaning of Hyle, you find that it is in fact another god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1065
verses.text: If the Manich aeans gave the name of Hyle, as the ancients did, to the unformed matter which is susceptible of bodily forms, we should not accuse them of making two gods.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1066
verses.text: But it is pure folly and madness to give to matter the power of forming bodies, or to deny that what has this power is God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1067
verses.text: When you give to some other being the power which belongs to the true God of making the qualities and forms, by which bodies, elements, and animals exist, according to their respective modes, whatever name you choose to give to this being, you are chargeable with making another god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1068
verses.text: There are indeed two errors in this blasphemous doctrine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1069
verses.text: In the first place, you ascribe the act of God to a being whom you are ashamed to call god; though you must call him god as long as you make him do things which only God can do.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1070
verses.text: In the second place, the good things done by a good God you call bad, and ascribe to an evil god, because you feel a childish horror of whatever shocks the frailty of fallen humanity, and a childish pleasure in the opposite.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1071
verses.text: So you think snakes are made by an evil being; while you consider the sun so great a good, that you believe it to be not the creature of God, but an emission from His substance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1072
verses.text: You must know that the true God, in whom, alas, you have not yet come to believe, made both the snake along with the lower creatures, and the sun along with other exalted creatures.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1073
verses.text: Moreover, among still more exalted creatures, not heavenly bodies, but spiritual beings, He has made what far surpasses the light of the sun, and what no carnal man can perceive, much less you, who, in your condemnation of flesh, condemn the very principle by which you determine good and evil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1074
verses.text: For your only idea of evil is from the disagreeableness of some things to the fleshly sense; and your only idea of good is from sensual gratification.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1075
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1076
verses.text: When I consider the things lowest in the scale of nature, which are within our view, and which, though earthly, and feeble, and mortal, are still the works of God, I am lost in admiration of the Creator, who is so great, in the great works and no less great in the small.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1077
verses.text: For the divine skill seen in the formation of all creatures in heaven and earth is always like itself, even in those things that differ from one another; for it is everywhere perfect, in the perfection which it gives to everything in its own kind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1078
verses.text: We see each creature made not as a whole by itself, but in relation to the rest of the creation; so that the whole divine skill is displayed in the formation of each, arranging each in its proper place and order, and providing what is suitable for all, both separately and unitedly.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1079
verses.text: See here, lowest in the scale, the animals which fly, and swim, and walk, and creep.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1080
verses.text: These are mortal creatures, whose life, as it is written, "is as a vapor which appeareth for a little time".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1081
verses.text: Each of these, according to the capacity of its kind, contributes the measure appointed in the goodness of the Creator to the completeness of the whole, so that the lowest partake in the good which the highest possess in a greater degree.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1082
verses.text: Show me, if you can, any animal, however despicable, whose soul hates its own flesh, and does not rather nourish and cherish it, by its vital motion minister to its growth and direct its activity, and exercise a sort of management over a little universe of its own, which it makes subservient to its own preservation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1083
verses.text: Even in the discipline of his own body by a rational being, who brings his body under, that earthly passion may not hinder his perception of wisdom, there is love for his own flesh, which he then reduces to obedience, which is its proper condition.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1084
verses.text: Indeed, you yourselves, although your heresy teaches you a fleshly abhorrence of the flesh, cannot help loving your own flesh, and caring for its safety and comfort, both by avoiding all injury from blows, and falls, and inclement weather, and by seeking for the means of keeping it in health.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1085
verses.text: Thus the law of nature is too strong for your false doctrine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1086
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1087
verses.text: Looking at the flesh itself, do we not see in the construction of its vital parts, in the symmetry of form, in the position and arrangement of the limbs of action and the organs of sensation, all acting in harmony; do we not see in the adjustment of measures, in the proportion of numbers, in the order of weights, the handiwork of the true God, of whom it is truly said, "Thou hast ordered all things in measure, and number, and weight"?   If your heart was not hardened and corrupted by falsehood, you would understand the invisible things of God from the things which He has made, even in these feeble creatures of flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1088
verses.text: For who is the author of the things I have mentioned, but He whose unity is the standard of all measure, whose wisdom is the model of all beauty, and whose law is the rule of all order? If you are blind to these things, hear at least the words of the apostle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1089
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1090
verses.text: For the apostle, in speaking of the love which husbands ought to have for their wives gives, as an example, the love of the soul for the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1091
verses.text: The words are: "He that loveth his wife, loveth himself: for no man ever yet hated his own flesh, but nourisheth and cherisheth it, even as Christ the Church".
