verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1092
verses.text: Look at the whole animal creation, and you find in the instinctive self-preservation of every animal this natural principle of love to its own flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1093
verses.text: It is so not only with men, who, when they live aright, both provide for the safety of their flesh, and keep their carnal appetites in subjection to the use of reason; the brutes also avoid pain, and shrink from death, and escape as rapidly as they can from whatever might break up the construction of their bodies, or dissolve the connection of spirit and flesh; for the brutes, too, nourish and cherish their own flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1094
verses.text: "For no one ever yet," says the apostle, "hated his own flesh, but nourisheth and cherisheth it, even as Christ the Church".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1095
verses.text: See where the apostle begins, and to what he ascends.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1096
verses.text: Consider, if you can, the greatness which creation derives from its Creator, embracing as it does the whole extent from the host of heaven down to flesh and blood, with the beauty of manifold form, and the order of successive gradations.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1097
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1098
verses.text: The same apostle again, when speaking of spiritual gifts as diverse, and yet tending to harmonious action, to illustrate a matter so great, and divine, and mysterious, makes a comparison with the human body,—thus plainly intimating that this flesh is the handiwork of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1099
verses.text: The whole passage, as found in the Epistle to the Corinthians, is so much to the point, that though it is long, I think it not amiss to insert it all: "Now concerning spiritual gifts, brethren, I would not have you ignorant.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1100
verses.text: Ye know that ye were Gentiles, carried away unto these dumb idols, even as ye were led.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1101
verses.text: Wherefore I give you to understand, that no man speaking by the Spirit of God calleth Jesus accursed; and that no man can say that Jesus is the Lord, but by the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1102
verses.text: Now there are diversities of gifts, but the same Spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1103
verses.text: And there are diversities of administrations, but the same Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1104
verses.text: And there are diversities of operations, but it is the same God which worketh all in all.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1105
verses.text: But the manifestation of the Spirit is given to every man to profit withal.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1106
verses.text: For to one is given by the Spirit the word of wisdom; to another the word of knowledge by the same Spirit; to another faith by the same Spirit; to another the gifts of healing by the same Spirit; to another the working of miracles; to another prophecy; to another discerning of spirits; to another divers kinds of tongues; to another the interpretation of tongues: but all these worketh that one and the self-same Spirit, dividing to every man severally as He will.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1107
verses.text: For as the body is one, and hath many members, and all the members of that one body, being many, are one body: so also is Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1108
verses.text: For by one Spirit are we all baptized into one body, whether we be Jews or Gentiles, whether we be bond or free; and have been all made to drink into one Spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1109
verses.text: For the body is not one member, but many.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1110
verses.text: If the foot shall say, Because I am not the hand, I am not of the body; is it therefore not of the body? And if the ear shall say, Because I am not the eye, I am not of the body; is it therefore not of the body? If the whole body were an eye, where were the hearing? If the whole were hearing, where were the smelling? But now hath God set the members every one of them in the body, as it hath pleased Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1111
verses.text: And if they were all one member, where were the body? But now are they many members, yet but one body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1112
verses.text: And the eye cannot say unto the hand, I have no need of thee; nor again the head to the feet, I have no need of you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1113
verses.text: Nay, much more those members of the body, which seem to be more feeble, are necessary; and those members of the body which we think to be less honorable, upon these we bestow more abundant honor; and our uncomely parts have more abundant comeliness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1114
verses.text: For our comely parts have no need; but God hath tempered the body together, having given more abundant honor to that part which lacked: that there should be no schism in the body, but that the members should have the same care one for another.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1115
verses.text: And whether one member suffer, all the members suffer with it; or one member be honored, all the members rejoice with it".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1116
verses.text: Apart altogether from Christian faith, which would lead you to believe the apostle, if you have common sense to perceive what is self-evident, let each examine and see for himself the plain truth regarding those things of which the apostle speaks,—what greatness belongs to the least, and what goodness to the lowest; for these are the things which the apostle extols, in order to illustrate by means of these common and visible bodily objects, unseen spiritual realities of the most exalted nature.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1117
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1118
verses.text: Whoever, then, denies that our body and its members, which the apostle so approves and extols, are the handiwork of God, you see whom he contradicts, preaching contrary to what you have received.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1119
verses.text: So, instead of refuting his opinions, I may leave him to be accursed of all Christians.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1120
verses.text: The apostle says, God tempered the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1121
verses.text: Faustus says, Not God, but Hyle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1122
verses.text: Anathemas are more suitable than arguments to such contradictions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1123
verses.text: You cannot say that God is here called the God of this world.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1124
verses.text: And if any one understands the passage where this expression does occur to mean that the devil blinds the minds of unbelievers, we grant that he does so by his evil suggestions, from yielding to which, men lose the light of righteousness in God's righteous retribution.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1125
verses.text: This is all in accordance with sacred Scripture.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1126
verses.text: The apostle himself speaks of temptation from without: "I fear lest, as the serpent beguiled Eve through his subtilty, so your minds should be corrupted from the simplicity and purity that is in Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1127
verses.text: To the same purpose are the words, "Evil communications corrupt good manners;"  and when he speaks of a man deceiving himself, "Whoever thinketh himself to be anything, when he is nothing, deceiveth himself;"  or again, in the passage already quoted of the judgment of God, "God gave them over to a reprobate mind, to do those things which are not convenient".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1128
verses.text: Similarly, in the Old Testament, after the words, "God did not create death, nor hath He pleasure in the destruction of the living," we read, "By the envy of the devil death entered into the world".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1129
verses.text: And again of death, that men may not put the blame from themselves, "The wicked invite her with hands and voice; and thinking her a friend, they are drawn down".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1130
verses.text: [19] Elsewhere, however, it is said, "Good and evil, life and death, riches and poverty, are from the Lord God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1131
verses.text: This seems perplexing to people who do not understand that, apart from the manifest judgment to follow hereafter upon every evil work, there is an actual judgment at the time; so that in one action, besides the craft of the deceiver and the wickedness of the voluntary agent, there is also the just penalty of the judge: for while the devil suggests, and man consents, God abandons.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1132
verses.text: So, if you join the words, God of this world, and understand that the devil blinds unbelievers by his mischievous delusions, the meaning is not a bad one.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1133
verses.text: For the word God is not used by itself, but with the qualification of this world, that is, of wicked men, who seek to prosper only in this age.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1134
verses.text: In this sense the world is also called evil, where it is written, "that He might deliver us from this present evil age".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1135
verses.text: In the same way, in the expression, "whose god is their belly," it is only in connection with the word whose that the belly is called god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1136
verses.text: So also, in the Psalms, the devils would not be called gods without adding "of the nations".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1137
verses.text: But in the passage we are now considering it is not said, The god of this world, or, Whose god is their belly, or, The gods of the nations are devils; but simply, God has tempered the body, which can be understood only of the true God, the Creator of all.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1138
verses.text: There is no disparaging addition here, as in the other cases.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1139
verses.text: But perhaps Faustus will say that God tempered the body, not as the maker of it, in the arrangement of its members, but by mixing His light with it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1140
verses.text: Thus Faustus would attribute to some other being than God the construction of the body, and the arrangement of its members, while God tempered the evil of the construction by the mixture of His goodness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1141
verses.text: Such are the inventions with which the Manich aeans cram feeble minds.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1142
verses.text: But God, in aid of the feeble, by the mouth of the sacred writers rebukes this opinion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1143
verses.text: For we read a few verses before: "God has placed the members every one of them in the body, as it has pleased Him".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1144
verses.text: Evidently, God is said to have tempered the body, because He has constructed it of many members, which in their union preserve the variety of their respective functions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1145
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1146
verses.text: Do the Manich aeans suppose that the animals which, according to their wild notions, were constructed by Hyle in the race of darkness, had not this harmonious action of their members, commended by the apostle, before God mixed His light with them; so that then the head did say to the feet, or the eye to the hand, I have no need of thee? This is not and cannot be the Manich aean doctrine, for they describe the animals as using all these members, and speak of them as creeping, walking, swimming, flying, each in its own kind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1147
verses.text: They could all see, too, and hear, and use the other senses, and nourish and cherish their own bodies with appropriate means and appliances.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1148
verses.text: Hence, moreover, they had the power of reproduction, for they are spoken of as having offspring.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1149
verses.text: All these things, of which Faust speaks disparagingly as the works of Hyle, could not be done without that harmonious arrangement which the apostle praises and ascribes to God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1150
verses.text: Is it not now plain who is to be followed, and who is to be pronounced accursed? Indeed, the Manich aeans tell us of animals that could speak; and their speeches were heard and understood and approved of by all creatures, whether creeping things, or quadrupeds, or birds, or fish.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1151
verses.text: Amazing and supernatural eloquence! Especially as they had no grammarian or elocutionist to teach them, and had not passed through the painful experience of the cane and the birch.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1152
verses.text: Why, Faustus himself began late in life to learn oratory, that he might discourse eloquently on these absurdities; and with all his cleverness, after ruining his health by study, his preaching has gained a mere handful of followers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1153
verses.text: What a pity that he was born in the light, and not in that region of darkness! If he had discoursed there against the light, the whole animal creation, from the biped to the centipede, from the dragon to the shell-fish, would have listened eagerly, and obeyed at once; whereas, when he discourses here against the race of darkness, he is oftener called eloquent than learned, and oftener still a false teacher of the worst kind.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1154
verses.text: And among the few Manich aeans who extol him as a great teacher, he has none of the lower animals as his disciples; and not even his horse is any the wiser for his master's instructions, so that the mixture of a part of deity seems only to make the animals more stupid.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1155
verses.text: What absurdity is this! When will these deluded beings have the sense to compare the description in the Manich aean fiction of what the animals were formerly in their own region, with what they are now in this world? Then their bodies were strong, now they are feeble; then their power of vision was such that they were induced to invade the region of God on account of the beauty which they saw, now it is too weak to face the rays of the sun; then they had intelligence sufficient to understand a discourse addressed to them, now they have no ability of the kind; then this astonishing and effective eloquence was natural, now eloquence of the most meagre kind requires diligent study and preparation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1156
verses.text: How many good things did the race of darkness lose by the mixture of good!  11.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1157
verses.text: Faustus has displayed his ingenuity, in the remarks to which I am now replying, by making for himself a long list of opposites—health and sickness, riches and poverty, white and black, cold and hot, sweet and bitter.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1158
verses.text: We need not say much about black and white.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1159
verses.text: Or, if there is a character for good or evil in colors, so that white must be ascribed to God and black to Hyle; if God threw a white color on the wings of birds, when Hyle, as the Manich aeans say, created them, where had the crows gone to when the swans got whitened? Nor need we discuss heat and cold, for both are good in moderation, and dangerous in excess.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1160
verses.text: With regard to the rest, Faustus probably intended that good and evil, which he might as well have put first, should be understood as including the rest, so that health, riches, white, hot, sweet, should belong to good; and sickness, poverty, black, cold, bitter, to evil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1161
verses.text: The ignorance and folly of this is obvious.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1162
verses.text: It might look like reviling if I were to take up separately white and black, hot and cold, sweet and bitter, health and sickness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1163
verses.text: For if white and sweet are both good, and black and bitter evil, how is it that most grapes and all olives become black as they become sweet, and so get good by getting evil? And if heat and health are both good, and cold and sickness evil, why do bodies become sick when heated? Is it healthy to have fever? But I let these things pass, for they may have been put down hastily, or they may have been given as merely instances of opposition, and not as being good and bad, especially as it is nowhere stated that the fire among the race of darkness is cold, so that heat in this case must unquestionably be evil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1164
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1165
verses.text: We pass on, then, to health, riches, sweetness, which Faustus evidently accounts good in his contrasts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1166
verses.text: Was there no health of body in the race of darkness where animals were born and grew up and brought forth, and had such vitality, that when some that were with child were taken, as the story is, and were put in bonds in heaven, even the abortive offspring of a premature birth, falling from heaven to earth, nevertheless lived, and grew, and produced the innumerable kinds of animals which now exist? Or were there no riches where trees could grow not only in water and wind, but in smoke and fire, and could bear such a rich produce, that animals, according to their several kinds, sprang from the fruit, and were provided with the means of subsistence from those fertile trees, and showed how well fed they were by a numerous progeny? And all this where there was no toil in cultivation, and no inclement change from summer to winter, for there was no sun to give variety to the seasons by his annual course.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1167
verses.text: There must have been perennial productiveness where the trees were not only born in their own element, but had a supply of appropriate nourishment to make them constantly fertile; as we see orange-trees bearing fruit all the year round if they are well watered.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1168
verses.text: The riches must have been abundant, and they must have been secure from harm; for there could be no fear of hailstorms when there were no light-gatherers who, in your fable, set the thunder in motion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1169
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1170
verses.text: Nor would the beings in this race of darkness have sought for food if it had not been sweet and pleasant, so that they would have died from want.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1171
verses.text: For we find that all bodies have their peculiar wants, according to which food is either agreeable or offensive.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1172
verses.text: If it is agreeable, it is said to be sweet or pleasant; if it is offensive, it is said to be bitter or sour, or in some way disagreeable.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1173
verses.text: In human beings we find that one desires food which another dislikes, from a difference in constitution or habit or state of health.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1174
verses.text: Still more, animals of quite different make can find pleasure in food which is disagreeable to us.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1175
verses.text: Why else should the goats feed so eagerly on the wild olives? This food is sweet to them, as in some sicknesses honey tastes bitter to us.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1176
verses.text: To a thoughtful inquirer these things suggest the beauty of the arrangement in which each finds what suits it, and the greatness of the good which extends from the lowest to the highest, and from the material to the spiritual.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1177
verses.text: As for the race of darkness, if an animal sprung from any element fed on what was produced by that element, doubtless the food must have been sweet from its appropriateness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1178
verses.text: Again, if this animal had found food of another element, the want of appropriateness would have appeared in its offensiveness to the taste.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1179
verses.text: Such offensiveness is called sourness, or bitterness, or disagreeableness, or something of the kind; or if its adverse nature is such as to destroy the harmony of the bodily constitution, and so take away life or reduce the strength, it is called poison, simply on account of this want of appropriateness, while it may nourish the kind of life to which it is appropriate.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1180
verses.text: So, if a hawk eat the bread which is our daily food, it dies; and we die if we eat hellebore, which cattle often feed on, and which may itself in a certain form be used as a medicine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1181
verses.text: If Faustus had known or thought of this, he would not have given poison and antidote as an example of the two natures of good and evil, as if God were the antidote and Hyle the poison.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1182
verses.text: For the same thing, of one and the same nature, kills or cures, as it is used appropriately or inappropriately.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1183
verses.text: In the Manich aean legends, their god might be said to have been poison to the race of darkness; for he so injured their bodies, that from being strong, they became utterly feeble.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1184
verses.text: But then again, as the light was itself taken, and subjected to loss and injury, it may be said to have been poison to itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1185
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1186
verses.text: Instead of one good and one evil principle, you seem to make both good or both evil, or rather two good and two evil; for they are good in themselves, and evil to one another.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1187
verses.text: We may see afterwards which is the better or the worse; but meanwhile we may think of them as both good in themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1188
verses.text: Thus God reigned in one region, while Hyle reigned in the other.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1189
verses.text: There was health in both kingdoms, and rich produce in both; both had a numerous progeny, and both tasted the sweetness of pleasures suitable to their respective natures.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1190
verses.text: But the race of darkness, say the Manich aeans, excepting the part which was evil to the light which it bordered on, was also evil to itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1191
verses.text: As, however, I have already pointed out many good things in it, if you can point out its evils, there will still be two good kingdoms, though the one where there are no evils will be the better of the two.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1192
verses.text: What, then, do you call its evils? They plundered, and killed, and devoured one another, according to Faustus.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1193
verses.text: But if they did nothing else than this, how could such numerous hosts be born and grow up to maturity? They must have enjoyed peace and tranquillity too.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1194
verses.text: But, allowing the kingdom where there is no discord to be the better of the two, still they should both be called good, rather than one good and the other bad.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1195
verses.text: Thus the better kingdom will be that where they killed neither themselves nor one another; and the worse, or less good, where, though they fought with one another, each separate animal preserved its own nature in health and safety.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1196
verses.text: But we cannot make much difference between your god and the prince of darkness, whom no one opposed, whose reign was acknowledged by all, and whose proposals were unanimously agreed to.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1197
verses.text: All this implies great peace and harmony.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1198
verses.text: Those kingdoms are happy where all agree heartily in obedience to the king.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1199
verses.text: Moreover, the rule of this prince extended not only to his own species, or to bipeds whom you make the parents of mankind, but to all kinds of animals, who waited in his presence, obeying his commands, and believing his declarations.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1200
verses.text: Do you think people are so stupid as not to recognize the attributes of deity in your description of this prince, or to think it possible that you can have another? If the authority of this prince rested on his resources, he must have been very powerful; if on his fame, he must have been renowned; if on love, the regard must have been universal; if on fear, he must have kept the strictest order.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1201
verses.text: If some evils, then, were mixed with so many good things, who that knows the meaning of words would call this the nature of evil? Besides, if you call this the nature of evil, because it was not only evil to the other nature, but was also evil in itself, was there no evil, think you, in the dire necessity to which your god was subjected before the mixture with the opposite nature, so that he was compelled to fight with it, and to send his own members to be swallowed up so mercilessly as to be beyond the hope of complete recovery? This was a great evil in that nature before its mixture with the only thing you allow to be evil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1202
verses.text: Your god must either have had it in his power not to be injured and sullied by the race of darkness, in which case his own folly must have brought him into trouble; or if his substance was liable to corruption, the object of your worship is not the incorruptible God of whom the apostle speaks.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1203
verses.text: Does not, then this liability to corruption, even apart from the actual experience, seem to you to be an evil in your god?  15.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1204
verses.text: It is plain, moreover, that either he must have been destitute of prescience,—a great defect, surely, in the Deity, not to know what is coming; or if he had prescience, he can never have felt secure, but must have been in constant terror, which you must allow to be a serious evil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1205
verses.text: There must have been the fear at every moment, that the time might be come for that conflict in which his members suffered such loss and contamination, that to liberate and purify them costs infinite labor, and, after all, can be done only partially.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1206
verses.text: If it is going too far to attribute this state of alarm to the Deity himself, his members at least must have dreaded the prospect of suffering all these evils.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1207
verses.text: Then, again, if they were ignorant of what was to happen, the substance of your god must have been so far wanting in prescience.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1208
verses.text: How many evils do you reckon in your chief good? Perhaps you will say that they had no fear, because they foresaw, along with the suffering, their liberation and triumph.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1209
verses.text: But still they must have feared for their companions, if they knew that they were to be cut off from their kingdom, and bound for ever in the mass of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1210
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1211
verses.text: Had they not the charity to feel a kindly sympathy for those who were doomed to suffer eternal punishment, without having committed any sin? These souls that were to be bound up with the mass, were not they too part of your god? Were they not of the same origin, the same substance? They at least must have felt grief or fear in the prospect of their own eternal bondage.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1212
verses.text: To say that they did not know what was to happen, while the others did, is to make one and the same substance partly acquainted with the future, and partly ignorant.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1213
verses.text: How can you call this substance the pure, and perfect, and supreme good, if there were such evils in it, even before its mixture with the evil principle? You will have to confess your two principles either both good or both evil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1214
verses.text: If you make two evils, you may make either of them the worse, as you please.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1215
verses.text: But if you make two goods, we shall have to inquire which you make the better.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1216
verses.text: Meanwhile there is an end to your doctrine of two principles, one good and the other evil, which are in fact two gods, one good and the other evil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1217
verses.text: But if hurting another is evil, they both hurt one another.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1218
verses.text: Perhaps the greater evil was in the principle that first began the attack.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1219
verses.text: But if one began the injury, the other returned it; and not by the law of compensation, an eye for an eye, which you are foolish enough to find fault with, but with far greater severity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1220
verses.text: You must choose which you will call the worse,—the one that began the injury, or the one that had the will and the power to do still greater injury.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1221
verses.text: The one tried to get a share in the enjoyment of light; the other effected the entire overthrow of its opponent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1222
verses.text: If the one had got what it desired, it would certainly have done no harm to itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1223
verses.text: But the other, in the discomfiture of its adversary, did great mischief to part of itself; reminding us of the well-known passionate exclamation, which is on record as having been actually used, "Perish our friends, if that will rid us of our enemies".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1224
verses.text: For part of your god was sent to suffer hopeless contamination, that there might be a covering for the mass in which the enemy is to be buried for ever alive.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1225
verses.text: So much will he continue to be dreaded even when conquered and bound, that the security, such as it is, of one part of the deity must be purchased by the eternal misery of the other parts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1226
verses.text: Such is the harmlessness of the good principle! Your god, it appears, is guilty of the crime with which you charge the race of darkness—of injuring both friends and enemies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1227
verses.text: The charge is proved in the case of your god, by that final mass in which his enemies are confined, while his own subjects are involved in it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1228
verses.text: In fact, the principle that you call god is the more injurious of the two, both to friends and to enemies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1229
verses.text: In the case of Hyle, there was no desire to destroy the opposite kingdom, but only to possess it; and though some of its subjects were put to death by the violence of others, they appeared again in other forms, so that in the alternation of life and death they had intervals of enjoyment in their history.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1230
verses.text: But your god, with all the omnipotence and perfect excellence that you ascribe to him, dooms his enemies to eternal destruction, and his friends to eternal punishment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1231
verses.text: And the height of insanity is in believing that while internal contest occasions the injury of the members of Hyle, victory brings punishment to the members of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1232
verses.text: What means this folly? To use Faustus' comparison of God and Hyle to the antidote and poison, the antidote seems to be more mischievous than the poison.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1233
verses.text: We do not hear of Hyle shutting up God for ever in a mass of darkness, or driving its own members into it; or, which is worst of all, slandering this unfortunate remnant, as an excuse for not effecting its purification.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1234
verses.text: For Manich aeus, in his Fundamental Epistle, says that these souls deserved to be thus punished, because they allowed themselves to be led away from their original brightness, and became enemies of holy light; whereas it was God himself that sent them to lose themselves in the region of darkness, that light might be opposed to light: which was unjust, if he forced them against their will; while, if they went willingly, he is ungrateful in punishing them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1235
verses.text: These souls can never have been happy, if they were tormented with fear before the conflict, from knowing that they were to become enemies to their original principle, and then in the conflict were hopelessly contaminated, and afterwards eternally condemned.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1236
verses.text: On the other hand, they can never have been divine, if before the conflict they were unaware of what was coming, from want of prescience, and then showed feebleness in the conflict, and suffered misery afterwards.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1237
verses.text: And what is true of them must be true of God, since they are of the same substance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1238
verses.text: Is there any hope of your seeing the folly of these blasphemies? You attempt, indeed, to vindicate the goodness of God, by asserting that Hyle when shut up is prevented from doing any more injury to itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1239
verses.text: Hyle, it seems, is to get some good, when it has no longer any good mixed with it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1240
verses.text: Perhaps, as God before the conflict had the evil of necessity, when the good was unmixed with evil, so Hyle after the conflict is to have the good of rest, when the evil is unmixed with good.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1241
verses.text: Your principles are thus either two evils, one worse than the other; or two goods, both imperfect, but one better than the other.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1242
verses.text: The better, however, is the more miserable; for if the issue of this great conflict is that the enemy gets some good by the cessation of mutual injuries in Hyle, while God's own subjects suffer the serious evil of being driven into the mass of darkness, we may ask who has got the victory.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1243
verses.text: The poison, we are to understand, is Hyle, where, nevertheless, animal life found a plentiful supply of the means of growth and productiveness; while the antidote is God, who could condemn his own members, but could not restore them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1244
verses.text: In reality, it is as absurd to call the one Hyle, as it is to call the other God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1245
verses.text: These are the follies of men who turn to fables because they cannot bear sound doctrine.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1246
verses.text: Book XXII.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1247
verses.text: Faustus states his objections to the morality of the law and the prophets, and Augustin seeks by the application of the type and the allegory to explain away the moral difficulties of the Old Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1248
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1249
verses.text: Faustus said: You ask why we blaspheme the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1250
verses.text: We are so far from professing or feeling any hostility to the law and the prophets, that we are ready, if you will allow us, to declare the falsehood of all the writings which make the law and the prophets appear objectionable.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1251
verses.text: But this you refuse to admit, and by maintaining the authority of your writers, you bring a perhaps unmerited reproach upon the prophets; you slander the patriarchs, and dishonor the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1252
verses.text: You are so unreasonable as to deny that your writers are false, while you uphold the piety and sanctity of those who are described in these writings as guilty of the worst crimes, and as leading wicked lives.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1253
verses.text: These opinions are inconsistent; for either these were bad characters, or the writers were untruthful.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1254
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1255
verses.text: Supposing, then, that we agree in condemning the writers, we may succeed in vindicating the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1256
verses.text: By the law must be understood not circumcision, or Sabbaths, or sacrifices, or the other Jewish observances, but the true law, viz.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1257
verses.text: , Thou shall not kill, Thou shalt not commit adultery, Thou shalt not bear false witness, and so on.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1258
verses.text: To this law, promulgated throughout the world, that is, at the commencement of the present constitution of the world, the Hebrew writers did violence, by infecting it with the pollution of their disgusting precepts about circumcision and sacrifice.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1259
verses.text: As a friend of the law, you should join with me in condemning the Jews for injuring the law by this mixture of unsuitable precepts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1260
verses.text: Plainly, you must be aware that these precepts are not the law, or any part of the law, since you claim to be righteous, though you make no attempt to keep the precepts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1261
verses.text: In seeking to lead a righteous life, you pay great regard to the commandments which forbid sinful actions, while you take no notice of the Jewish observances; which would be unjustifiable if they were one and the same law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1262
verses.text: You resent as a foul reproach being called negligent of the precept, "Thou shalt not kill," or "Thou shall not commit adultery".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1263
verses.text: And if you showed the same resentment at being called uncircumcised, or negligent of the Sabbath, it would be evident that you considered both to be the law and the commandment of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1264
verses.text: In fact, however, you consider the honor and glory of keeping the one no way endangered by disregard of the other.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1265
verses.text: It is plain, as I have said, that these observances are not the law, but a disfigurement of the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1266
verses.text: If we condemn them, it is not as being genuine, but as spurious.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1267
verses.text: In this condemnation there is no reproach of the law, or of God its author, but only of those who published their shocking superstitions under these names.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1268
verses.text: If we sometimes abuse the venerable name of law in attacking the Jewish precepts, the fault is yours, for refusing to distinguish between Hebrew observances and the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1269
verses.text: Only restore to the law its proper dignity, by removing these foul Israelitish blots; grant that these writers are guilty of disfiguring the law, and you will see at once that we are the enemies not of the law, but of Judaism.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1270
verses.text: You are misled by the word law; for you do not know to what that name properly belongs.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1271
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1272
verses.text: For my part, I see no reason for your thinking that we blaspheme your prophets and patriarchs.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1273
verses.text: There would indeed be some ground for the charge, if we had been directly or remotely the authors of the account given of their actions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1274
verses.text: But as this account is written either by themselves, in a criminal desire to be famous for their misdeeds, or by their companions and coevals, why should you blame us? You condemn them in abhorrence of the wicked actions of which they have voluntarily declared themselves guilty, though there was no occasion for such a confession.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1275
verses.text: Or if the narrative is only a malicious fiction, let its authors be punished, let the books be condemned, let the prophetic name be cleared from this foul reproach, let the patriarchs recover the respect due to their simplicity and purity of managers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1276
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1277
verses.text: These books, moreover, contain shocking calumnies against God himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1278
verses.text: We are told that he existed from eternity in darkness, and admired the light when he saw it; that he was so ignorant of the future, that he gave Adam a command, not foreseeing that it would be broken; that his perception was so limited that he could not see Adam when, from the knowledge of his nakedness, he hid himself in a corner of Paradise; that envy made him afraid lest his creature man should taste of the tree of life, and live for ever; that afterwards he was greedy for blood, and fat from all kinds of sacrifices, and jealous if they were offered to any one but himself; that he was enraged sometimes against his enemies, sometimes against his friends; that he destroyed thousands of men for a slight offense, or for nothing; that he threatened to come with a sword and spare nobody, righteous or wicked.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1279
verses.text: The authors of such bold libels against God might very well slander the men of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1280
verses.text: You must join with us in laying the blame on the writers if you wish to vindicate the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1281
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1282
verses.text: Again, we are not responsible for what is said of Abraham, that in his irrational craving to have children, and not believing God, who promised that his wife Sara should have a son, he defiled himself with a mistress, with the knowledge of his wife, which only made it worse;  or that, in sacrilegious profanation of his marriage, he on different occasions, from avarice and greed, sold his wife Sara for the gratification of the kings Abimelech and Pharas, telling them that she was his sister, because she was very fair.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1283
verses.text: The narrative is not ours, which tells how Lot, Abraham's brother, after his escape from Sodom, lay with his two daughters on the mountain  (better for him to have perished in the conflagration of Sodom, than to have burned with incestuous passion); or how Isaac imitated his father's conduct, and called his wife Rebecca his sister, that he might gain a shameful livelihood by her;  or how his son Jacob, husband of four wives—two full sisters, Rachel and Leah, and their handmaids—led the life of a goat among them, so that there was a daily strife among his women who should be the first to lay hold of him when he came from the field, ending sometimes in their hiring him from one another for the night;  or, again, how his son Judah slept with his daughter-in-law Tamar, after she had been married to two of his sons, deceived, we are told, by the harlot's dress which Tamar put on, knowing that her father-in-law was in the habit of associating with such characters;  or how David, after having a number of wives, seduced the wife of his soldier Uriah, and caused Uriah himself to be killed in the battle;  or how his son Solomon had three hundred wives, and seven hundred concubines, and princesses without number;  or how the first prophet Hosea got children from a prostitute, and, what is worse, it is said that this disgraceful conduct was enjoined by God;  or how Moses committed murder,  and plundered Egypt,  and waged wars, and commanded, or himself perpetrated, many cruelties.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1284
verses.text: And he too was not content with one wife.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1285
verses.text: We are neither directly nor remotely the authors of these and similar narratives, which are found in the books of the patriarchs and the prophets.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1286
verses.text: Either your writers forged these things, or the fathers are really guilty.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1287
verses.text: Choose which you please; the crime in either case is detestable, for vicious conduct and falsehood are equally hateful.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1288
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1289
verses.text: Augustin replied: You understand neither the symbols of the law nor the acts of the prophets, because you do not know what holiness or righteousness means.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1290
verses.text: We have repeatedly shown at great length, that the precepts and symbols of the Old Testament contained both what was to be fulfilled in obedience through the grace bestowed in the New Testament, and what was to be set aside as a proof of its having been fulfilled in the truth now made manifest.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1291
verses.text: For in the love of God and of our neighbor is secured the accomplishment of the precepts of the law, while the accomplishment of its promises is shown in the abolition of circumcision, and of other typical observances formerly practised.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1292
verses.text: By the precept men were led, through a sense of guilt to desire salvation; by the promise they were led to find in the typical observances the assurance that the Saviour would come.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1293
verses.text: The salvation desired was to be obtained through the grace bestowed on the appearance of the New Testament; and the fulfillment of the expectation rendered the types no longer necessary.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1294
verses.text: The same law that was given by Moses became grace and truth in Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1295
verses.text: By the grace in the pardon of sin, the precept is kept in force in the case of those supported by divine help.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1296
verses.text: By the truth the symbolic rites are set aside, that the promise might, in those who trust in the divine faithfulness, be brought to pass.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1297
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1298
verses.text: Those, accordingly, who, finding fault with what they do not understand, call the typical institutions of the law disfigurements and excrescences, are like men displeased with things of which they do not know the use.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1299
verses.text: As if a deaf man, seeing others move their lips in speaking, were to find fault with the motion of the mouth as needless and unsightly; or as if a blind man, on hearing a house commended, were to test the truth of what he heard by passing his hand over the surface of the wall, and on coming to the windows were to cry out against them as flaws in the level, or were to suppose that the wall had fallen in.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1300
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1301
verses.text: How shall I make those whose minds are full of vanity understand that the actions of the prophets were also mystical and prophetic? The vanity of their minds is shown in their thinking that we believe God to have once existed in darkness, because it is written, "Darkness was over the deep".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1302
verses.text: As if we called the deep God, where there was darkness, because the light did not exist there before God made it by His word.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1303
verses.text: From their not distinguishing between the light which is God, and the light which God made, they imagine that God must have been in darkness before He made light, because darkness was over the deep before God said, "Let there be light, and there was light".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1304
verses.text: In the New Testament both these things are ascribed to God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1305
verses.text: For we read, "God is light, and in Him is no darkness at all;"  and again, "God, who commanded the light to shine out of darkness, hath shined in our hearts".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1306
verses.text: So also, in the Old Testament, the name "Brightness of eternal light"  is given to the wisdom of God, which certainly was not created, for by it all things were made; and of the light which exists only as the production of this wisdom it is said, "Thou wilt light my candle, O Lord; my God, Thou wilt enlighten my darkness".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1307
verses.text: In the same way, in the beginning, when darkness was over the deep, God said, "Let there be light, and there was light," which only the light-giving light, which is God Himself, could have made.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1308
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1309
verses.text: For as God is His own eternal happiness, and is besides the bestower of happiness, so He is His own eternal light, and is also the bestower of light.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1310
verses.text: He envies the good of none, for He is Himself the source of happiness to all good beings; He fears the evil of none, for the loss of all evil beings is in their being abandoned by Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1311
verses.text: He can neither be benefited by those on whom He Himself bestows happiness, nor is He afraid of those whose misery is the doom awarded by His own judgment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1312
verses.text: Very different, O Manich aeus, is the object of your worship.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1313
verses.text: You have departed from God in the pursuit of your own fancies, which of all kinds have increased and multiplied in your foolish roving hearts, drinking in through the sense of sight the light of the heavenly bodies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1314
verses.text: This light, though it too is made by God, is not to be compared to the light created in the minds of the pious, whom God brings out of darkness into light, as He brings them out of sinfulness into righteousness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1315
verses.text: Still less can it be compared to that inaccessible light from which all kinds of light are derived.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1316
verses.text: Nor is this light inaccessible to all; for "blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1317
verses.text: "God is light, and in Him is no darkness at all;" but the wicked shall not see light, as is said in Isaiah.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1318
verses.text: [19] To them the light-giving light is inaccessible.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1319
verses.text: From the light comes not only the spiritual light in the minds of the pious, but also the material light, which is not denied to the wicked, but is made to rise on the evil and on the good.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1320
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1321
verses.text: So, when darkness was over the deep, He who was light said, "Let there be light".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1322
verses.text: From what light this light came is clear; for the words are, "God said".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1323
verses.text: What light is that which was made, is not so clear.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1324
verses.text: For there has been a friendly discussion among students of the sacred Scriptures, whether God then made the light in the minds of the angels, or, in other words, these rational spirits themselves, or some material light which exists in the higher regions of the universe beyond our ken.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1325
verses.text: For on the fourth day He made the visible luminaries of heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1326
verses.text: And it is also a question whether these bodies were made at the same time as their light, or were somehow kindled from the light made already.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1327
verses.text: But whoever reads the sacred writings in the pious spirit which is required to understand them, must be convinced that whatever the light was which was made when, at the time that darkness was over the deep, God said, "Let there be light," it was created light, and the creating Light was the maker of it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1328
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1329
verses.text: Nor does it follow that God, before He made light, abode in darkness, because it is said that darkness was over the deep, and then that the Spirit of God moved on the waters.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1330
verses.text: The deep is the unfathomable abyss of the waters.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1331
verses.text: And the carnal mind might suppose that the Spirit abode in the darkness which was over the deep, because it is said that He moved on the waters.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1332
verses.text: This is from not understanding how the light shineth in darkness, and the darkness comprehendeth it not, till by the word of God those who were darkness are made light, and it is said to them, "Ye were once darkness, but now are ye light in the Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1333
verses.text: But if rational minds which are in darkness through a sinful will cannot comprehend the light of the wisdom of God, though it is present everywhere, because they are separated from it not in place, but in disposition: why may not the Spirit of God have moved on the darkness of the waters, when He moved on the waters, though at an immeasurable distance from it, not in place, but in nature?  12.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1334
verses.text: In all this I know I am singing to deaf ears; but the Lord, from whom is the truth which we speak, can open some ears to catch the strain.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1335
verses.text: But what shall we say of those critics of the Holy Scriptures who object to God's being pleased with His own works, and find fault with the words, "God saw the light that it was good," as if this meant that God admired the light as something new? God's seeing His works that they were good, means that the Creator approved of His own works as pleasing to Himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1336
verses.text: For God cannot be forced to do anything against His will, so that He should not be pleased with His own work; nor can He do anything by mistake, so that He should regret having done it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1337
verses.text: Why should the Manich aeans object to our God seeing His work that it was good, when their god placed a covering before himself when he mingled his own members with the darkness? For instead of seeing his work that it is good, he refuses to look at it because it is evil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1338
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1339
verses.text: Faustus speaks of our God as astonished, which is not said in Scripture; nor does it follow that one must be astonished when he sees anything to be good.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1340
verses.text: There are many good things which we see without being astonished, as if they were better than we expected; we merely approve of them as being what they ought to be.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1341
verses.text: We can, however, give an instance of God being astonished, not from the Old Testament, which the Manich aeans assail with undeserved reproach, but from the New Testament, which they profess to believe in order to entrap the unwary.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1342
verses.text: For they acknowledge Christ as God, and use this as a bait to entice Christ's followers into their snares.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1343
verses.text: God, then, was astonished when Christ was astonished.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1344
verses.text: For we read in the Gospel, that when Christ heard the faith of a certain centurion, He was astonished, and said to His disciples, "Verily I have not found so great faith, no, not in Israel".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1345
verses.text: We have already given our explanation of the words, "God saw that it was good".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1346
verses.text: Better men may give a better explanation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1347
verses.text: Meanwhile let the Manich aeans explain Christ's being astonished at what He foresaw before it happened, and knew before He heard it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1348
verses.text: For though seeing a thing to be good is quite different from being astonished at it, in this case there is some resemblance, for Jesus was astonished at the light of faith which He Himself had created in the heart of the centurion; for Jesus is the true light, which enlighteneth every man that cometh into the world.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1349
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1350
verses.text: Thus an irreligious Pagan might bring the same reproaches against Christ in the Gospel, as Faustus brings against God in the Old Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1351
verses.text: He might say that Christ lacked foresight, not only because He was astonished at the faith of the centurion, but because He chose Judas as a disciple who proved disobedient to His commands; as Faustus objects to the precept given in Paradise, which, as it turned out, was not obeyed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1352
verses.text: He might also cavil at Christ's not knowing who touched Him, when the woman suffering from an issue of blood touched the hem of His garment; as Faustus blames God for not knowing where Adam had hid himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1353
verses.text: If this ignorance is implied in God's saying, "Where art thou, Adam?"  the same may be said of Christ's asking, "Who touched me?"  The Pagans also might call Christ timid and envious, in not wishing five of the ten virgins to gain eternal life by entering into His kingdom, and in shutting them out, so that they knocked in vain in their entreaty to have the door opened, as if forgetful of His own promise, "Knock, and it shall be opened unto you;"  as Faustus charges God with fear and envy in not admitting man after his sin to eternal life.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1354
verses.text: Again, he might call Christ greedy of the blood, not of beasts, but of men, because he said, "He that loseth his life for my sake, shall keep it unto life eternal;"  as Faustus reproaches God in reference to those animal sacrifices which prefigured the sacrifice of blood-shedding by which we are redeemed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1355
verses.text: He might also accuse Christ of jealousy, because in narrating His driving the buyers and sellers out of the temple, the evangelist quotes as applicable to Him the words, "The jealousy of Thine house hath eaten me up;"  as Faustus accuses God of jealousy in forbidding sacrifices to be offered to other gods.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1356
verses.text: He might say that Christ was angry with both His friends and His enemies: with His friends, because He said, "The servant that knows his lord's will, and doeth it not, shall be beaten with many stripes;" and with His enemies, because He said, "If any one shall not receive you, shake off against him the dust of your shoes; verily I say unto you, that it shall be more tolerable for Sodom in the day of judgment than for that city;"  as Faustus accuses God of being angry at one time with His friends, and at another with His enemies; both of whom are spoken of thus by the apostle: "They that have sinned without law shall perish without law, and they that have sinned in the law shall be judged by the law".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1357
verses.text: Or he might say that Christ shed the blood of many without mercy, for a slight offense or for nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1358
verses.text: For to a Pagan there would appear to be little or no harm in not having a wedding garment at the marriage feast, for which our King in the Gospel commanded a man to be bound hand and foot, and cast into outer darkness;  or in not wishing to have Christ for a king, which is the sin of which Christ says, "Those that would not have me to reign over them, bring hither and slay before me;"  as Faustus blames God in the Old Testament for slaughtering thousands of human beings for slight offenses, as Faustus calls them, or for nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1359
verses.text: Again, if Faustus finds fault with God's threatening to come with the sword, and to spare neither the righteous nor the wicked, might not the Pagan find as much fault with the words of the Apostle Paul, when he says of our God," He spared not His own Son, but gave Him up for us all;"  or of Peter, when, in exhorting the saints to be patient in the midst of persecution and slaughter, he says, "It is time that judgment begin from the house of God; and if it first begin at us, what shall the end be of them that believe not the gospel of the Lord? And if the righteous scarcely be saved, where shall the ungodly and sinner appear?"  What can be more righteous than the Only-Begotten, whom nevertheless the Father did not spare? And what can be plainer than that the righteous also are not spared, but chastised with manifold afflictions, as is clearly implied in the words, "If the righteous scarcely are saved"? As it is said in the Old Testament, "Whom the Lord loveth He correcteth, and chastiseth every son whom He receiveth;"  and, "If we receive good at the hand of the Lord, shall we not also receive evil?"  So we read also in the New Testament, "Whom I love I rebuke and chasten;"  and, "If we judge ourselves, we shall not be judged of the Lord; but when we are judged, we are corrected of the Lord, that we may not be condemned with the world".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1360
verses.text: If a Pagan were to make such objections to the New Testament, would not the Manich aeans try to answer them, though they themselves make similar objections to the Old Testament? But supposing them able to answer the Pagan, how absurd it would be to defend in the one Testament what they find fault with in the other! But if they could not answer the objections of the Pagan, why should they not allow in both Testaments, instead of in one only, that what appears wrong to unbelievers, from their ignorance, should be believed to be right by pious readers even when they also are ignorant?  15.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1361
verses.text: Perhaps our opponents will maintain that these parallel passages quoted from the New Testament are themselves neither authoritative nor true: for they claim the impious liberty of holding and teaching, that whatever they deem favorable to their heresy was said by Christ and the apostles; while they have the profane boldness to say, that whatever in the same writings is unfavorable to them is a spurious interpolation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1362
verses.text: I have already at some length, as far as the intention of the present work required, exposed the unreasonableness of this assault upon the authority of the whole of Scripture.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1363
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1364
verses.text: At present I would call attention to the fact, that when the Manich aeans, although they disguise their blasphemous absurdities under the name of Christianity, bring such objections against the Christian Scriptures, we have to defend the authority of the divine record in both Testaments against the Manich aeans as much as against the Pagans.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1365
verses.text: A Pagan might find fault with passages in the New Testament in the same way as Faustus does with what he calls unworthy representations of God in the Old Testament; and the Pagan might be answered by the quotation of similar passages from his own authors, as in Paul's speech at Athens.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1366
verses.text: Even in Pagan writings we might find the doctrine that God created and constructed the world, and that He is the giver of light, which does not imply that before light was made He abode in darkness; and that when His work was finished He was elated with joy, which is more than saying that He saw that it was good; and that He made a law with rewards for obedience, and punishments for disobedience, by which they do not mean to say that God was ignorant of the future, because He gave a law to those by whom it was to be broken.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1367
verses.text: Nor could they make asking questions a proof of a want of foresight even in a human being; for in their books many questions are asked only for the purpose of using the answers for the conviction of the persons addressed: for the questioner knows not only what answer he desires, but what will actually be given.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1368
verses.text: Again, if the Pagan tried to make out God to be envious of any one, because He will not give happiness to the wicked, he would find many passages in the writings of his own authors in support of this principle of the divine government.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1369
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1370
verses.text: The only objection that a Pagan would make on the subject of sacrifice would refer to our reason for finding fault with Pagan sacrifices, when in the Old Testament God is described as requiring men to offer sacrifice to Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1371
verses.text: If I were to reply at length on this subject, I might prove to him that sacrifice is due only to the one true God, and that this sacrifice was offered by the one true Priest, the Mediator of God and man; and that it was proper that this sacrifice should be pre-figured by animal sacrifices, in order to foreshadow the flesh and blood of the one sacrifice for the remission of sins contracted by flesh and blood, which shall not inherit the kingdom of God: for the natural body will be endowed with heavenly attributes, as the fire in the sacrifice typified the swallowing up of death in victory.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1372
verses.text: Those observances properly belonged to the people whose kingdom and priesthood were prophetic of the King and Priest who should come to govern and to consecrate believers in all nations, and to lead them into the kingdom of heaven, and the holy society of angels and eternal life.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1373
verses.text: And as this true sacrifice was piously set forth in the Hebrew observances, so it was impiously caricatured by the Pagans, because, as the apostle says, what they offer they offer to devils, and not to God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1374
verses.text: The typical rite of blood-shedding in sacrifice dates from the earliest ages, pointing forward from the outset of human history to the passion of the Mediator.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1375
verses.text: For Abel is mentioned in the sacred Scripture as the first who offered such sacrifices.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1376
verses.text: We need not therefore wonder that fallen angels who occupy the air, and whose chief sins are pride and falsehood, should demand from their worshippers by whom they wished to be considered as gods what they knew to be due to God only.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1377
verses.text: This deception was favored by the folly of the human heart, especially when regret for the dead led to the making of likenesses, and so to the use of images.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1378
verses.text: By the increase of this homage, divine honors came to be paid to the dead as dwelling in heaven, while devils took their place on earth as the objects of worship, and required that their deluded and degraded votaries should present sacrifices to them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1379
verses.text: Thus the nature of sacrifice as due only to God appears not only when God righteously claims it, but also when a false god proudly arrogates it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1380
verses.text: If the Pagan was slow to believe these things, I should argue from the prophecies, and point out that, though uttered long ago, they are now fulfilled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1381
verses.text: If he still remained in unbelief, this is rather to be expected than to be wondered at; for the prophecy itself intimates that all would not believe.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1382
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1383
verses.text: If the Pagan, in the next place, were to find fault with both Testaments as attributing jealousy to God and Christ, he would only show his own ignorance of literature, or his forgetfulness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1384
verses.text: For though their philosophers distinguish between desire and passion, joy and gratification, caution and fear, gentleness and tender-heartedness, prudence and cunning, boldness and daring, and so on, giving the first name in each pair to what is good, and the second to what is bad, their books are notwithstanding full of instances in which, by the abuse of these words, virtues are called by the names which properly belong to vices; as passion is used for desire, gratification for joy, fear for caution, tender-heartedness for gentleness, cunning for prudence, daring for boldness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1385
verses.text: The cases are innumerable in which speech exhibits similar inaccuracies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1386
verses.text: Moreover, each language has its own idioms.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1387
verses.text: For in religious writings I remember no instance of the word tender-heartedness being used in a bad sense.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1388
verses.text: And common usage affords examples of similar peculiarities in the use of words.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1389
verses.text: In Greek, one word stands for two distinct things, labor and pain; while we have a separate name for each.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1390
verses.text: Again, we use the word in two senses, as when we say of what is not dead, that it has life; and again, of any one that he is a man of good life, whereas in Greek each of these meanings has a word of its own.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1391
