verses.text: So that, apart from the abuse of words which prevails in all languages, it may be an Hebrew idiom to use jealousy in two senses, as a man is called jealous when he suffers from a diseased state of mind caused by distress on account of the faithlessness of his wife, in which sense the word cannot be applied to God; or as when diligence is manifested in guarding conjugal chastity, in which sense it is profitable for us not only unhesitatingly to admit, but thankfully to assert, that God is jealous of His people when He calls them His wife, and warns them against committing adultery with a multitude of false gods.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1392
verses.text: The same may be said of the anger of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1393
verses.text: For God does not suffer perturbation when He visits men in anger; but either by an abuse of the word, or by a peculiarity of idiom, anger is used in the sense of punishment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1394
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1395
verses.text: The slaughter of multitudes would not seem strange to the Pagan, unless he denied the judgment of God, which Pagans do not; for they allow that all things in the universe, from the highest to the lowest, are governed by God's providence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1396
verses.text: But if he would not allow this, he would be convinced either by the authority of Pagan writers, or by the more tedious method of demonstration; and if still obstinate and perverse, he would be left to the judgment which he denies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1397
verses.text: Then, if he were to give instances of the destruction of men for no offense, or for a very slight one, we should show that these were offenses, and that they were not slight.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1398
verses.text: For instance, to take the case already referred to of the wedding garment, we should prove that it was a great crime in a man to attend the sacred feast, seeking not the bridegroom's glory, but his own, or whatever the garment may be found on better interpretation to signify.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1399
verses.text: And in the case of the slaughter before the king of those who would not have him to reign over them, we might perhaps easily prove that, though it may be no sin in a man to refuse to obey his fellow-man, it is both a fault and a great one to reject the reign of Him in whose reign alone is there righteousness, and happiness, and continuance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1400
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1401
verses.text: Lastly, as regards Faustus' crafty insinuation, that the Old Testament misrepresents God as threatening to come with a sword which will spare neither the righteous nor the wicked, if the words were explained to the Pagan, he would perhaps disagree neither with the Old Testament nor with the New; and he might see the beauty of the parable in the Gospel, which people who pretend to be Christians either misunderstand from their blindness, or reject from their perversity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1402
verses.text: The great husbandman of the vine uses his pruning-hook differently in the fruitful and in the unfruitful branches; yet he spares neither good nor bad, pruning one and cutting off the other.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1403
verses.text: There is no man so just as not to require to be tried by affliction to advance, or to establish, or to prove his virtue.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1404
verses.text: Do the Manich aeans not reckon Paul as righteous, who, while confessing humbly and honestly his past sins, still gives thanks for being justified by faith in Jesus Christ? Was Paul then spared by Him whom fools misunderstand, when He says, "I will spare neither the righteous nor the sinner"? Hear the apostle himself: "Lest I should be exalted above measure by the abundance of the revelation, there was given me a thorn in the flesh, a messenger of Satan to buffet me.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1405
verses.text: For this I besought the Lord thrice, that He would remove it from me; and He said unto me, My grace is sufficient for thee: for strength is perfected in weakness".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1406
verses.text: Here a just man is not spared that his strength might be perfected in weakness by Him who had given him an angel of Satan to buffet him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1407
verses.text: If you say that the devil gave this angel, it follows that the devil sought to prevent Paul's being exalted above measure by the abundance of the revelation, and to perfect his strength.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1408
verses.text: This is impossible.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1409
verses.text: Therefore He who gave up this righteous man to be buffeted by the messenger of Satan, is the same as He who, through Paul, gave up to Satan himself the wicked persons of whom Paul says: "I have delivered them to Satan, that they may learn not to blaspheme".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1410
verses.text: Do you see now how the Most High spares neither the righteous nor the wicked? Or is it the sword that frightens you? For to be buffeted is not so bad as to be put to death.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1411
verses.text: But did not the thousands of martyrs suffer death in various forms? And could their persecutors have had this power against them except it had been given them by God, who thus spared neither the righteous nor the wicked? For the Lord Himself, the chief martyr, says expressly to Pilate: "Thou couldst have no power at all against me, except it were given thee from above".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1412
verses.text: Paul also, besides recording his own experience, says that the afflictions and persecutions of the righteous exhibit the judgment of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1413
verses.text: This truth is set forth at length by the Apostle Peter in the passage already quoted, where he says: "It is time that judgment should begin at the house of the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1414
verses.text: And if it first begin at us, what shall the end be of those that believe not the gospel of God? And if the righteous scarcely are saved, where shall the ungodly and the sinner appear?"  Peter also explains how the wicked are not spared, for they are branches broken off to be burnt; while the righteous are not spared, because their purification is to be brought to perfection.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1415
verses.text: He ascribes these things to the will of Him who says in the Old Testament, I will spare neither the righteous nor the wicked; for he says: "It is better, if the will of the Spirit of God be so, that we suffer for well-doing than for evil-doing".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1416
verses.text: So, when by the will of the Spirit of God men suffer for well-doing, the righteous are not spared; when they suffer for evil-doing, the wicked are not spared.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1417
verses.text: In both cases it is according to the will of Him who says: I will spare neither the righteous nor the wicked; correcting the one as a son, and punishing the other as a transgressor.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1418
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1419
verses.text: I have thus shown, to the best of my power, that the God we worship did not abide from eternity in darkness, but is Himself light, and in Him is no darkness at all; and in Himself dwells in light inaccessible; and the brightness of this light is His coeternal wisdom.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1420
verses.text: From what we have said, it appears that God was not taken by surprise by the unexpected appearance of light, but that light owes its existence to Him as its Creator, as its owes its continued existence to His approval.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1421
verses.text: Neither was God ignorant of the future, but the author of the precept as well as the punisher of disobedience; that by showing His righteous anger against transgression, He might provide a restraint for the time, and a warning for the future.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1422
verses.text: Nor does He ask questions from ignorance, but by His very inquiry declares His judgment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1423
verses.text: Nor is He curious or timid, but excludes the transgressor from eternal life, which is the just reward of obedience.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1424
verses.text: Nor is He greedy for blood and fat; but by requiring from a carnal people sacrifices, suited to their character, He by certain types prefigures the true sacrifice.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1425
verses.text: Nor is His jealousy an emotion of pale anxiety, but of quiet benevolence, in desire to keep the soul, which owes chastity to the one true God, from being defiled and prostituted by serving many false gods.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1426
verses.text: Nor is He enraged with a passion similar to human anger, but is angry, not in the sense of desiring vengeance, but in the peculiar sense of giving full effect to the sentence of a righteous retribution.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1427
verses.text: Nor does He destroy thousands of men for trifling offenses, or for nothing, but manifests to the world the benefit to be obtained from fearing Him, by the temporal death of those already mortal.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1428
verses.text: Nor does He punish the righteous and sinners indiscriminately, but chastises the righteous for their good, in order to perfect them, and gives to sinners the punishment justly due to them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1429
verses.text: Thus, ye Manich aeans, do your suspicions lead you astray, when, by misunderstanding our Scriptures, or by hearing bad interpreters, you form a mistaken judgment of Catholics.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1430
verses.text: Hence you leave sound doctrine, and turn to impious fables; and in your perversity and estrangement from the society of saints, you reject the instruction of the New Testament, which, as we have shown, contains statements similar to those which you condemn in the Old Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1431
verses.text: So we are obliged to defend both Testaments against you as well as against the Pagans.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1432
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1433
verses.text: But supposing that there is some one so deluded by carnality as to worship not the God whom we worship, who is one and true, but the fiction of your suspicions or your slanders, whom you say we worship, is not even this god better than yours? Observe, I beseech you, what must be plain to the feeblest understanding; for here there is no need of great perspicacity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1434
verses.text: I address all, wise and unwise.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1435
verses.text: I appeal to the common sense and judgment of all alike.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1436
verses.text: Hear, consider, judge.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1437
verses.text: Would it not have been better for your god to have remained in darkness from eternity, than to have plunged the light coeternal with him and cognate to him into darkness? Would it not have been better to have expressed admiration in surprise at the appearance of a new light coming to scatter the darkness, than to have been unable to baffle the assault of darkness except by the concession of his own light? Unhappy if he did this in alarm, and cruel if there was no need of it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1438
verses.text: Surely it would have been better to see light, made by himself, and to admire it as good, than to make the light begotten by himself evil; better than that his own light should become hostile to himself in repelling the forces of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1439
verses.text: For this will be the accusation against those who will be condemned for ever to the mass of darkness, that they suffered themselves to lose their original brightness, and became the enemies of sacred light.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1440
verses.text: If they did not know from eternity that they would be thus condemned, they must have suffered the darkness of eternal ignorance; or if they did know, the darkness of eternal fear.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1441
verses.text: Thus part of the substance of your god really did remain from eternity in its own darkness; and instead of admiring new light on its appearance, it only met with another and a hostile darkness, of which it had always been in fear.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1442
verses.text: Indeed, God himself must have been in the darkness of fear for this part of himself, if he was dreading the evil coming upon it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1443
verses.text: If he did not foresee the evil, he must have been in the darkness of ignorance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1444
verses.text: If he foresaw it, and was not in fear, the darkness of such cruelty is worse than the darkness either of ignorance or of fear.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1445
verses.text: Your god appears to be destitute of the quality which the apostle commends in the body, which you insanely believe to be made not by God, but by Hyle: "If one member suffers, all the members suffer with it".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1446
verses.text: But suppose he did suffer; he foresaw, he feared, he suffered, but he could not help himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1447
verses.text: Thus he remained from eternity in the darkness of his own misery; and then, instead of admiring a new light which was to drive away the darkness, he came in contact, to the injury of his own light, with another darkness which he had always dreaded.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1448
verses.text: Again, would it not have been much better, I say, not to have given a commandment like God, but even to have received a commandment like Adam, which he would be rewarded for keeping and punished for breaking, acting either way by his own free-will, than to be forced by inevitable necessity to admit darkness into his light in spite of himself? Surely it would have been better to have given a precept to human nature, not knowing that it would become sinful, than to have been driven by necessity to sin contrary to his own divine nature.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1449
verses.text: Think for a moment, and say how darkness could be conquered by one who was himself conquered by necessity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1450
verses.text: Conquered already by this greater enemy, he fought under his conqueror's orders against a less formidable opponent.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1451
verses.text: Would it not have been better not to know where Adam had hid himself, than to have been himself destitute of any means of escape, first from a hard and hateful necessity, and then from a dissimilar and hostile race? Would it not have been better to grudge eternal life to human nature, than to consign to misery the divine nature; to desire the blood and fat of sacrifices, than to be himself slaughtered in so many forms, on account of his mixture with the blood and fat of every victim; to be disturbed by jealousy at these sacrifices being offered to other gods as well as to himself, than to be himself offered on all altars to all devils, as mixed up not only with all fruits, but also with all animals? Would it not have been much better to be affected even with human anger, so as to be enraged against both his friends and his enemies for their sins, than to be himself influenced by fear as well as by anger wherever these passions exist, or than to share in all the sin that is committed, and in all punishment that is suffered? For this is the doom of that part of your god which is in confinement everywhere, condemned to this by himself, not as guilty, but in order to conquer his dreaded enemy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1452
verses.text: Doomed himself to such a fatal necessity, the part of himself which he has given over to condemnation might pardon him, if he were as humble as he is miserable.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1453
verses.text: But how can you pretend to find fault with God for His anger against both friends and enemies when they sin, when the god of your fancies first under compulsion compels his own members to go to be devoured by sin, and then condemns them to remain in darkness? Though he does this, you say that it will not be in anger.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1454
verses.text: But will he not be ashamed to punish, or to appear to punish, those from whom he should ask pardon in words such as these: "Forgive me, I beseech you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1455
verses.text: You are my members; could I treat you thus, except from necessity? You know yourselves, that you were sent here because a formidable enemy had arisen; and now you must remain here to prevent his rising again"? Again, is it not better to slay thousands of men for trifling faults, or for nothing, than to cast into the abyss of sin, and to condemn to the punishment of eternal imprisonment, God's own members, his substance—in fact, God himself? It cannot properly be said of the real substance of God that it has the choice of sinning or not sinning, for God's substance is absolutely unchangeable.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1456
verses.text: God cannot sin, as He cannot deny Himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1457
verses.text: Man, on the contrary, can sin and deny God, or he can choose not to do so.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1458
verses.text: But suppose the members of your god had, like a rational human soul, the choice of sinning or not sinning; they might perhaps be justly punished for heinous offenses by confinement in the mass of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1459
verses.text: But you cannot attribute to these parts a liberty which you deny to God himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1460
verses.text: For if God had not given them up to sin, he would have been forced to sin himself, by the prevalence of the race of darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1461
verses.text: But if there was no danger of being thus forced, it was a sin to send these parts to a place where they incurred this danger.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1462
verses.text: To do so, indeed, from free choice is a crime deserving the torment which your god unnaturally inflicts upon his own parts, more than the conduct of these parts in going by his command to a place where they lost the power of living in righteousness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1463
verses.text: But if God himself was in danger of being forced to sin by invasion and capture, unless he had secured himself first by the misconduct and then by the punishment of his own parts, there can have been no free-will either in your god or in his parts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1464
verses.text: Let him not set himself up as judge, but confess himself a criminal.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1465
verses.text: For though he was forced against his own will, he professes to pass a righteous sentence in condemning those whom he knows to have suffered evil rather than done it; making this profession that he may not be thought of as having been conquered; as if it could do a beggar any good to be called prosperous and happy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1466
verses.text: Surely it would have been better for your god to have spared neither righteous nor wicked in indiscriminate punishment (which is Faustus' last charge against our God), than to have been so cruel to his own members,—first giving them up to incurable contamination, and then, as if that was not enough, accusing them falsely of misconduct.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1467
verses.text: Faustus declares that they justly suffer this severe and eternal punishment, because they allowed themselves to be led astray from their original brightness, and became hostile to sacred light.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1468
verses.text: But the reason of this, as Faustus says, was that they were so greedily devoured in the first assault of the princes of darkness, that they were unable to recover themselves, or to separate themselves from the hostile principle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1469
verses.text: These souls, therefore, did no evil themselves, but in all this were innocent sufferers.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1470
verses.text: The real agent was he who sent them away from himself into this wretchedness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1471
verses.text: They suffered more from their father than from their enemy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1472
verses.text: Their father sent them into all this misery; while their enemy desired them as something good, wishing not to hurt them, but to enjoy them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1473
verses.text: The one injured them knowingly, the other in ignorance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1474
verses.text: This god was so weak and helpless that he could not otherwise secure himself first against an enemy threatening attack, and then against the same enemy in confinement.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1475
verses.text: Let him, then, not condemn those parts whose obedience defended him, and whose death secures his safety.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1476
verses.text: If he could not avoid the conflict, why slander his defenders? When these parts allowed themselves to be led astray from their original brightness, and became hostile to sacred light, this must have been from the force of the enemy; and if they were forced against their will, they are innocent; while, if they could have resisted had they chosen, there is no need of the origin of evil in an imaginary evil nature, since it is to be found in free-will.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1477
verses.text: Their not resisting, when they could have done so, is plainly their own fault, and not owing to any force from without.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1478
verses.text: For, supposing them able to do a thing, to do which is right, while not to do it is great and heinous sin, their not doing it is their own choice.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1479
verses.text: So, then, if they choose not to do it, the fault is in their will not in necessity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1480
verses.text: The origin of sin is in the will; therefore in the will is also the origin of evil, both in the sense of acting against a just precept, and in the sense of suffering under a just sentence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1481
verses.text: There is thus no reason why, in your search for the origin of evil, you should fall into so great an evil as that of calling a nature so rich in good things the nature of evil, and of attributing the terrible evil of necessity to the nature of perfect good, before any commixture with evil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1482
verses.text: The cause of this erroneous belief is your pride, which you need not have unless you choose; but in your wish to defend at all hazards the error into which you have fallen, you take away the origin of evil from free-will, and place it in a fabulous nature of evil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1483
verses.text: And thus you come at last to say, that the souls which are to be doomed to eternal confinement in the mass of darkness became enemies to sacred light not from choice, but by necessity; and to make your god a judge with whom it is of no use to prove, in behalf of your clients.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1484
verses.text: that they were under compulsion, and a king who will make no allowance for your brethren, his own sons and members, whose hostility against you and against himself you ascribe not to choice, but to necessity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1485
verses.text: What shocking cruelty! unless you proceed in the next place to defend your god, as also acting not from choice, but by necessity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1486
verses.text: So, if there could be found another judge free from necessity, who could decide the question on the principles of equity, he would sentence your god to be bound to this mass, not by being fastened on the outside, but by being shut up inside along with the formidable enemy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1487
verses.text: The first in the guilt of necessity ought to be first in the sentence of condemnation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1488
verses.text: Would it not be much better, then, in comparison with such a god as this, to choose the god whom we indeed do not worship, but whom you think or pretend to think we worship? Though he spares not his servants, whether righteous or sinful, making no proper separation, and not distinguishing between punishment and discipline, is he not better than the god who spares not his own members though innocent, if necessity is no crime, or guilty from their obedience to him, if necessity itself is criminal; so that they are condemned eternally by him, along with whom they should have been released, if any liberty was recovered by the victory, while he should have been condemned along with them if the victory reduced the force of necessity even so far as to give this small amount of force to justice? Thus the god whom you represent us as worshipping, though he is not the one true God whom we really worship, is far better than your god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1489
verses.text: Neither, indeed, has any existence; but both are the creatures of your imaginations.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1490
verses.text: But, according to your own representations, the one whom you call ours, and find fault with, is better than the one whom you call your own, and whom you worship.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1491
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1492
verses.text: So also the patriarchs and prophets whom you cry out against are not the men whom we honor, but men whose characters are drawn from your fancy, prompted by ill-will.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1493
verses.text: And yet even thus as you paint them, I will not be content with showing them to be superior to your elect, who keep all the precepts of Manich aeus, but will prove their superiority to your god himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1494
verses.text: Before proving this, however, I must, with the help of God, defend our holy fathers the patriarchs and prophets against your accusations, by a clear exposition of the truth as opposed to the carnality of your hearts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1495
verses.text: As for you Manich aeans, it would be enough to say that the faults you impute to our fathers are preferable to what you praise in your own, and to complete your shame by adding that your god can be proved far inferior to our fathers as you describe them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1496
verses.text: This would be a sufficient reply for you.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1497
verses.text: But as, even apart from your perversities, some minds are of themselves disturbed when comparing the life of the prophets in the Old Testament with that of the apostles in the New,—not discerning between the manner of the time when the promise was under a veil, and that of the time when the promise is revealed,—I must first of all reply to those who either have the boldness to pride themselves as superior in temperance to the prophets, or quote the prophets in defence of their own bad conduct.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1498
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1499
verses.text: First of all, then, not only the speech of these men, but their life also, was prophetic; and the whole kingdom of the Hebrews was like a great prophet, corresponding to the greatness of the Person prophesied.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1500
verses.text: So, as regards those Hebrews who were made wise in heart by divine instruction, we may discover a prophecy of the coming of Christ and of the Church, both in what they said and in what they did; and the same is true as regards the divine procedure towards the whole nation as a body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1501
verses.text: For, as the apostle says, "all these things were our examples".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1502
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1503
verses.text: Those who find fault with the prophets, accusing them of adultery for instance, in actions which are above their comprehension, are like those Pagans who profanely charge Christ with folly or madness because He looked for fruit from a tree out of the season;  or with childishness, because He stooped down and wrote on the ground, and, after answering the people who were questioning Him, began writing again.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1504
verses.text: Such critics are incapable of understanding that certain virtues in great minds resemble closely the vices of little minds, not in reality, but in appearance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1505
verses.text: Such criticism of the great is like that of boys at school, whose learning consists in the important rule, that if the nominative is in the singular, the verb must also be in the singular; and so they find fault with the best Latin author, because he says, Pars in frusta secant.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1506
verses.text: He should have written, say they, secat.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1507
verses.text: And again, knowing that religio is spelt with one l, they blame him for writing relligio, when he says, Relligione patrum.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1508
verses.text: Hence it may with reason be said, that as the poetical usage of words differs from the solecisms and barbarisms of the unlearned, so, in their own way, the figurative actions of the prophets differ from the impure actions of the vicious.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1509
verses.text: Accordingly, as a boy guilty of a barbarism would be whipped if he pled the usage of Virgil; so any one quoting the example of Abraham begetting a son from Hagar, in defence of his own sinful passion for his wife's handmaid, ought to be corrected not by caning only, but by severe scourging, that he may not suffer the doom of adulterers in eternal punishment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1510
verses.text: This indeed is a comparison of great and important subjects with trifles; and it is not intended that a peculiar usage in speech should be put on a level with a sacrament, or a solecism with adultery.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1511
verses.text: Still, allowing for the difference in the character of the subjects, what is called learning or ignorance in the proprieties and improprieties of speech, resembles wisdom or the want of it in reference to the grand moral distinction between virtue and vice.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1512
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1513
verses.text: Instead of entering on the distinctions between the praiseworthy and the blameworthy, the criminal and the innocent, the dangerous and the harmless, the guilty and the guiltless, the desirable and the undesirable, which are all illustrations of the distinction between sin and righteousness, we must first consider what sin is, and then examine the actions of the saints as recorded in the holy books, that, if we find these saints described as sinning, we may if possible discover the true reason for keeping these sins in memory by putting them on record.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1514
verses.text: Again, if we find things recorded which, though they are not sins, appear so to the foolish and the malevolent, and in fact do not exhibit any virtues, here also we have to see why these things are put into the Scriptures which we believe to contain wholesome doctrine as a guide in the present life, and a title to the inheritance of the future.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1515
verses.text: As regards the examples of righteousness found among the acts of the saints, the propriety of recording these must be plain even to the ignorant.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1516
verses.text: The question is about those actions the mention of which may seem useless if they are neither righteous nor sinful, or even dangerous if the actions are really sinful, as leading people to imitate them, because they are not condemned in these books, and so may be supposed not to be sinful, or because, though they are condemned, men may copy them from the idea that they must be venial if saints did them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1517
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1518
verses.text: Sin, then, is any transgression in deed, or word, or desire, of the eternal law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1519
verses.text: And the eternal law is the divine order or will of God, which requires the preservation of natural order, and forbids the breach of it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1520
verses.text: But what is this natural order in man? Man, we know, consists of soul and body; but so does a beast.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1521
verses.text: Again, it is plain that in the order of nature the soul is superior to the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1522
verses.text: Moreover, in the soul of man there is reason, which is not in a beast.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1523
verses.text: Therefore, as the soul is superior to the body, so in the soul itself the reason is superior by the law of nature to the other parts which are found also in beasts; and in reason itself, which is partly contemplation and partly action, contemplation is unquestionably the superior part.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1524
verses.text: The object of contemplation is the image of God, by which we are renewed through faith to sight.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1525
verses.text: Rational action ought therefore to be subject to the control of contemplation, which is exercised through faith while we are absent from the Lord, as it will be hereafter through sight, when we shall be like Him, for we shall see Him as He is.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1526
verses.text: Then in a spiritual body we shall by His grace be made equal to angels, when we put on the garment of immortality and incorruption, with which this mortal and corruptible shall be clothed, that death may be swallowed up of victory, when righteousness is perfected through grace.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1527
verses.text: For the holy and lofty angels have also their contemplation and action.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1528
verses.text: They require of themselves the performance of the commands of Him whom they contemplate, whose eternal government they freely because sweetly obey.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1529
verses.text: We, on the other hand, whose body is dead because of sin, till God quicken also our mortal bodies by His Spirit dwelling in us, live righteously in our feeble measure, according to the eternal law in which the law of nature is preserved, when we live by that faith unfeigned which works by love, having in a good conscience a hope of immortality and incorruption laid up in heaven, and of the perfecting of righteousness to the measure of an inexpressible satisfaction, for which in our pilgrimage we must hunger and thirst, while we walk by faith and not by sight.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1530
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1531
verses.text: A man, therefore, who acts in obedience to the faith which obeys God, restrains all mortal affections, and keeps them within the natural limit, regulating his desires so as to put the higher before the lower.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1532
verses.text: If there was no pleasure in what is unlawful, no one would sin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1533
verses.text: To sin is to indulge this pleasure instead of restraining it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1534
verses.text: And by unlawful is meant what is forbidden by the law in which the order of nature is preserved.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1535
verses.text: It is a great question whether there is any rational creature for which there is no pleasure in what is unlawful.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1536
verses.text: If there is such a class of creatures, it does not include man, nor that angelic nature which abode not in the truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1537
verses.text: These rational creatures were so made, that they had the potentiality of restraining their desires from the unlawful; and in not doing this they sinned.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1538
verses.text: Great, then, is the creature man, for he is restored by this potentiality, by which, if he had so chosen, he would not have fallen.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1539
verses.text: And great is the Lord, and greatly to be praised, who created man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1540
verses.text: For He created also inferior natures which cannot sin, and superior natures which will not sin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1541
verses.text: Beasts do not sin, for their nature agrees with the eternal law from being subject to it, without being in possession of it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1542
verses.text: And again, angels do not sin, because their heavenly nature is so in possession of the eternal law that God is the only object of its desire, and they obey His will without any experience of temptation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1543
verses.text: But man, whose life on this earth is a trial on account of sin, subdues to himself what he has in common with beasts, and subdues to God what he has in common with angels; till, when righteousness is perfected and immortality attained, he shall be raised from among beasts and ranked with angels.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1544
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1545
verses.text: The exercise or indulgence of the bodily appetites is intended to secure the continued existence and the invigoration of the individual or of the species.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1546
verses.text: If the appetites go beyond this, and carry the man, no longer master of himself, beyond the limits of temperance, they become unlawful and shameful lusts, which severe discipline must subdue.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1547
verses.text: But if this unbridled course ends in plunging the man into such a depth of evil habits that he supposes that there will be no punishment of his sinful passions, and so refuses the wholesome discipline of confession and repentance by which he might be rescued; or, from a still worse insensibility, justifies his own indulgences in profane opposition to the eternal law of Providence; and if he dies in this state, that unerring law sentences him now not to correction, but to damnation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1548
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1549
verses.text: Referring, then, to the eternal law which enjoins the preservation of natural order and forbids the breach of it, let us see how our father Abraham sinned, that is, how he broke this law, in the things which Faustus has charged him with as highly criminal.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1550
verses.text: In his irrational craving to have children, says Faustus, and not believing God, who promised that his wife Sara should have a son, he defiled himself with a mistress.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1551
verses.text: But here Faustus, in his irrational desire to find fault, both discloses the impiety of his heresy, and in his error and ignorance praises Abraham's intercourse with the handmaid.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1552
verses.text: For as the eternal law—that is, the will of God the Creator of all—for the preservation of the natural order, permits the indulgence of the bodily appetite under the guidance of reason in sexual intercourse, not for the gratification of passion, but for the continuance of the race through the procreation of children; so, on the contrary, the unrighteous law of the Manich aeans, in order to prevent their god, whom they bewail as confined in all seeds, from suffering still closer confinement in the womb, requires married people not on any account to have children, their great desire being to liberate their god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1553
verses.text: Instead, therefore, of an irrational craving in Abraham to have children, we find in Manich aeus an irrational fancy against having children.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1554
verses.text: So the one preserved the natural order by seeking in marriage only the production of a child; while the other, influenced by his heretical notions, thought no evil could be greater than the confinement of his god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1555
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1556
verses.text: So, again, when Faustus says that the wife's being privy to her husband's conduct made the matter worse, while he is prompted only by the uncharitable wish to reproach Abraham and his wife, he really, without intending it, speaks in praise of both.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1557
verses.text: For Sara did not connive at any criminal action in her husband for the gratification of his unlawful passions; but from the same natural desire for children that he had, and knowing her own barrenness, she warrantably claimed as her own the fertility of her handmaid; not consenting with sinful desires in her husband, but requesting of him what it was proper in him to grant.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1558
verses.text: Nor was it the request of proud assumption; for every one knows that the duty of a wife is to obey her husband.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1559
verses.text: But in reference to the body, we are told by the apostle that the wife has power over her husband's body, as he has over hers;  so that, while in all other social matters the wife ought to obey her husband, in this one matter of their bodily connection as man and wife their power over one another is mutual,—the man over the woman, and the woman over the man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1560
verses.text: So, when Sara could not have children of her own, she wished to have them by her handmaid, and of the same seed from which she herself would have had them, if that had been possible.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1561
verses.text: No woman would do this if her love for her husband were merely an animal passion; she would rather be jealous of a mistress than make her a mother.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1562
verses.text: So here the pious desire for the procreation of children was an indication of the absence of criminal indulgence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1563
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1564
verses.text: Abraham, indeed, cannot be defended, if, as Faustus says, he wished to get children by Hagar, because he had no faith in God, who promised that he should have children by Sara.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1565
verses.text: But this is an entire mistake: this promise had not yet been made.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1566
verses.text: Any one who reads the preceding chapters will find that Abraham had already got the promise of the land with a countless number of inhabitants,  but that it had not yet been made known to him how the seed spoken of was to be produced, whether by generation from his own body, or from his choice in the adoption of a son, or, in the case of its being from his own body, whether it would be by Sara or another.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1567
verses.text: Whoever examines into this will find that Faustus has made either an imprudent mistake or an impudent misrepresentation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1568
verses.text: Abraham, then, when he saw that he had no children, though the promise was to his seed, thought first of adoption.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1569
verses.text: This appears from his saying of his slave, when speaking to God, "This is mine heir;" as much as to say, As Thou hast not given me a seed of my own, fulfill Thy promise in this man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1570
verses.text: For the word seed may be applied to what has not come out of a man's own body, else the apostle could not call us the seed of Abraham: for we certainly are not his descendants in the flesh; but we are his seed in following his faith, by believing in Christ, whose flesh did spring from the flesh of Abraham.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1571
verses.text: Then Abraham was told by the Lord "This shall not be thine heir; but he that cometh out of thine own bowels shall be thine heir".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1572
verses.text: The thought of adoption was thus removed; but it still remained uncertain whether the seed which was to come from himself would be by Sara or another.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1573
verses.text: And this God was pleased to keep concealed, till a figure of the Old Testament had been supplied in the handmaid.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1574
verses.text: We may thus easily understand how Abraham, seeing that his wife was barren, and that she desired to obtain from her husband and her handmaid the offspring which she herself could not produce, acted not in compliance with carnal appetite, but in obedience to conjugal authority, believing that Sara had the sanction of God for her wish; because God had already promised him an heir from his own body, but had not foretold who was to be the mother.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1575
verses.text: Thus, when Faustus shows his own infidelity in accusing Abraham of unbelief, his groundless accusation only proves the madness of the assailant.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1576
verses.text: In other cases, Faustus' infidelity has prevented him from understanding; but here, in his love of slander, he has not even taken time to read.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1577
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1578
verses.text: Again, when Faustus accuses a righteous and faithful man of a shameless profanation of his marriage from avarice and greed, by selling his wife Sara at different times to the two kings Abimelech and Pharaoh, telling them that she was his sister, because she was very fair, he does not distinguish justly between right and wrong, but unjustly condemns the whole transaction.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1579
verses.text: Those who think that Abraham sold his wife cannot discern in the light of the eternal law the difference between sin and righteousness; and so they call perseverance obstinacy, and confidence presumption, as in these and similar cases men of wrong judgment are wont to blame what they suppose to be wrong actions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1580
verses.text: Abraham did not become partner in crime with his wife by selling her to others: but as she gave her handmaid to her husband, not to gratify his passion, but for the sake of offspring, in the authority she had consistently with the order of nature, requiring the performance of a duty, not complying with a sinful desire; so in this case, the husband, in perfect assurance of the chaste attachment of his wife to himself, and knowing her mind to be the abode of modest and virtuous affection, called her his sister, without saying that she was his wife, lest he himself should be killed, and his wife fall into the hands of strangers and evil-doers: for he was assured by his God that He would not allow her to suffer violence or disgrace.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1581
verses.text: Nor was he disappointed in his faith and hope; for Pharaoh, terrified by strange occurrences, and after enduring many evils on account of her, when he was informed by God that Sara was Abraham's wife, restored her with honor uninjured.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1582
verses.text: Abimelech also did the same, after learning the truth in a dream.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1583
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1584
verses.text: Some people, not scoffers and evil-speakers like Faustus, but men who pay due honor to the Scriptures, which Faustus finds fault with because he does not understand them, or which he fails to understand because of his fault-finding, in commenting on this act of Abraham, are of opinion that he stumbled from weakness of faith, and denied his wife from fear of death, as Peter denied the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1585
verses.text: If this is the correct view, we must allow that Abraham sinned; but the sin should not cancel or obliterate all his merits, any more than in the case of the apostle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1586
verses.text: Besides, to deny his wife is not the same as to deny the Saviour.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1587
verses.text: But when there is another explanation, why not abide by it, instead of giving blame without cause, since there is no proof that Abraham told a lie from fear? He did not deny that Sara was his wife in answer to any question on the subject; but when asked who she was, he said she was his sister, without denying her to be his wife: he concealed part of the truth, but said nothing false.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1588
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1589
verses.text: It is waste of time to observe Faustus' remark, that Abraham falsely called Sara his sister; as if Faustus had discovered the family of Sara, though it is not mentioned in Scripture.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1590
verses.text: In a matter which Abraham knew, and we do not, it is surely better to believe the patriarch when he says what he knows, than to believe Manich aeus when he finds fault with what he knows nothing about.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1591
verses.text: Since, then, Abraham lived at that period in human history, when, though marriage had become unlawful between children of the same parents, or of the same father or mother, no law or authority interfered with the custom of marriage between the children of brothers, or any less degree of consanguinity, why should he not have had as wife his sister, that is, a woman descended from his father? For he himself told the king, when he restored Sara, that she was his sister by his father, and not by his mother.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1592
verses.text: And on this occasion he could not have been led to tell a falsehood from fear, for the king knew that she was his wife, and was restoring her with honor, because he had been warned by God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1593
verses.text: We learn from Scripture that, among the ancients, it was customary to call cousins brothers and sisters.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1594
verses.text: Thus Tobias says in his prayer to God, before having intercourse with his wife, "And now, O Lord, Thou knowest that not in wantonness I take to wife my sister;"  though she was not sprung immediately from the same father or the same mother, but only belonged to the same family.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1595
verses.text: And Lot is called the brother of Abraham, though Abraham was his uncle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1596
verses.text: And, by the same use of the word, those called in the Gospel the Lord's brothers are certainly not children of the Virgin Mary, but all the blood relations of the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1597
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1598
verses.text: Some may say, Why did not Abraham's confidence in God prevent his being afraid to confess his wife? God could have warded off from him the death which he feared, and could have protected both him and his wife while among strangers, so that Sara, although very fair, should not have been desired by any one, nor Abraham killed on account of her.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1599
verses.text: Of course, God could have done this; it would be absurd to deny it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1600
verses.text: But if, in reply to the people, Abraham had told them that Sara was his wife, his trust in God would have included both his own life and the chastity of Sara.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1601
verses.text: Now it is part of sound doctrine, that when a man has any means in his power, he should not tempt the Lord his God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1602
verses.text: So it was not because the Saviour was unable to protect His disciples that He told them, "When ye are persecuted in one city, flee to another".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1603
verses.text: And He Himself set the example.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1604
verses.text: For though He had the power of laying down His own life, and did not lay it down till He chose to do so, still when an infant He fled to Egypt, carried by His parents;  and when He went up to the feast, He went not openly, but secretly, though at other times He spoke openly to the Jews, who in spite of their rage and hostility could not lay hands on Him, because His hour was not come, —not the hour when He would be obliged to die, but the hour when He would consider it seasonable to be put to death.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1605
verses.text: Thus He who displayed divine power by teaching and reproving openly, without allowing the rage of his enemies to hurt Him, did also, by escaping and concealing Himself, exhibit the conduct becoming the feebleness of men, that they should not tempt God when they have any means in their power of escaping threatened danger.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1606
verses.text: So also in the apostle, it was not from despair of divine assistance and protection, or from loss of faith, that he was let down over the wall in a basket, in order to escape being taken by his enemies:  not from want of faith in God did he thus escape, but because not to escape, when this escape was possible, would have been tempting God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1607
verses.text: Accordingly, when Abraham was among strangers, and when, on account of the remarkable beauty of Sara, both his life and her chastity were in danger, since it was in his power to protect not both of these, but one only,—his life, namely,—to avoid tempting God he did what he could; and in what he could not do, he trusted to God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1608
verses.text: Unable to conceal his being a man, he concealed his being a husband, lest he should be put to death; trusting to God to preserve his wife's purity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1609
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1610
verses.text: There might also be a difference of opinion on the nice point whether Sara's chastity would have been violated even if some one had intercourse with her, since she submitted to this to save her husband's life, both with his knowledge and by his authority.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1611
verses.text: In this there would be no desertion of conjugal fidelity or rebellion against her husband's authority; in the same way as Abraham was not an adulterer, when, in submission to the lawful authority of his wife, he consented to be made a father by his wife's handmaid.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1612
verses.text: But, from the nature of the relationship, for a wife to have two husbands, both in life, is not the same thing as for a man to have two wives: so that we regard the explanation already given of Abraham's conduct as the most correct and unobjectionable; that our father Abraham avoided tempting God by taking what measures he could for the preservation of his own life, and that he showed his hope in God by entrusting to Him the chastity of his wife.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1613
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1614
verses.text: But a pleasure which all must feel is obtained from this narrative so faithfully recorded in the Holy Scriptures, when we examine into the prophetic character of the action, and knock with pious faith and diligence at the door of the mystery, that the Lord may open, and show us who was prefigured in the ancient personage, and whose wife this is, who, while in a foreign land and among strangers, is not allowed to be stained or defiled, that she may be brought to her own husband without spot or wrinkle.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1615
verses.text: Thus we find that the righteous life of the Church is for the glory of Christ, that her beauty may bring honor to her husband, as Abraham was honored on account of the beauty of Sara among the inhabitants of that foreign land.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1616
verses.text: To the Church, to whom it is said in the Song of Songs, "O thou fairest among women,"  kings offer gifts in acknowledgment of her beauty; as king Abimelech offered gifts to Sara, admiring the grace of her appearance; all the more that, while he loved, he was not allowed to profane it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1617
verses.text: The holy Church, too is in secret the spouse of the Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1618
verses.text: For it is secretly, and in the hidden depths of the Spirit, that the soul of man is joined to the word of God, so that they two are one flesh; of which the apostle speaks as a great mystery in marriage, as referring to Christ and the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1619
verses.text: Again, the earthly kingdom of this world, typified by the kings which were not allowed to defile Sara, had no knowledge or experience of the Church as the spouse of Christ, that is, of how faithfully she maintained her relation to her Husband, till it tried to violate her, and was compelled to yield to the divine testimony borne by the faith of the martyrs, and in the person of later monarchs was brought humbly to honor with gifts the Bride whom their predecessors had not been able to humble by subduing her to themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1620
verses.text: What, in the type, happened in the reign of one and the same king, is fulfilled in the earlier monarchs of this era and their successors.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1621
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1622
verses.text: Again, when it is said that the Church is the sister of Christ, not by the mother but by the father, we learn the excellence of the relation, which is not of the temporary nature of earthly descent, but of divine grace, which is everlasting.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1623
verses.text: By this grace we shall no longer be a race of mortals when we receive power to be called and to become sons of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1624
verses.text: This grace we obtain not from the synagogue, which is the mother of Christ after the flesh, but from God the Father.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1625
verses.text: And when Christ calls us into another life where there is no death, He teaches us, instead of acknowledging, to deny the earthly relationship, where death soon follows upon birth; for He says to His disciples, "Call no man your father upon earth; for you have one Father, who is in heaven".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1626
verses.text: And He set us an example of this when He said, "Who is my mother, and who are my brethren? And stretching forth His hand to His disciples, He said, These are my brethren".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1627
verses.text: And lest any one should think that He referred to an earthly relationship, He added, "Whosoever shall do the will of my Father, the same is my brother, and sister, and mother;"  as much as to say, I derive this relationship from God my Father, not from the Synagogue my mother; I call you to eternal life, where I have an immortal birth, not to earthly life, for to call you away from this life I have taken mortality.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1628
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1629
verses.text: As for the reason why, though it is concealed among strangers whose wife the Church is, it is not hidden whose sister she is, it is plainly because it is obscure and hard to understand how the human soul and the Word of God are united or mingled, or whatever word may be used to express this connection between God and the creature.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1630
verses.text: It is from this connection that Christ and the Church are called bridegroom and bride, or husband and wife.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1631
verses.text: The other relationship, in which Christ and all the saints are brethren by divine grace and not by earthly consanguinity, or by the father and not by the mother, is more easily expressed in words, and more easily understood.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1632
verses.text: For the same grace makes all the saints to be also brethren of one another; while in their society no one is the bridegroom of all the rest.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1633
verses.text: So also, notwithstanding the surpassing justice and wisdom of Christ, His manhood was much more plainly and readily recognized by strangers, who, indeed, were not wrong in believing Him to be man, but they did not understand His being God as well as man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1634
verses.text: Hence Jeremiah says: "He is both a man, and who shall know Him?"  He is a man, for it is made manifest that He is a brother.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1635
verses.text: And who shall know Him? for it is concealed that He is a husband.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1636
verses.text: This must suffice as a defense of our father Abraham against Faustus' impudence and ignorance and malice.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1637
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1638
verses.text: Lot also, the brother of Abraham, was just and hospitable in Sodom, and was found worthy to escape the conflagration which prefigured the future judgment; for he was free from all participation in the corruption of the people of Sodom.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1639
verses.text: He was a type of the body of Christ, which in the person of all the saints both groans now among the ungodly and wicked, to whose evil deeds it does not consent, and will at the end of the world be rescued from their society, when they are doomed to the punishment of eternal fire.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1640
verses.text: Lot's wife was the type of a different class of men,—of those, namely, who, when called by the grace of God, look back, instead of, like Paul, forgetting the things that are behind, and looking forward to the things that are before.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1641
verses.text: The Lord Himself says: "No man that putteth his hand to the plough, and looketh back, is fit for the kingdom of Heaven".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1642
verses.text: Nor did He omit to mention the case of Lot's wife; for she, for our warning, was turned into a pillar of salt, that being thus seasoned we might not trifle thoughtlessly with this danger, but be on our guard against it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1643
verses.text: So, when the Lord was admonishing every one to get rid of the things that are behind by the most strenuous endeavor to reach the things that are before, He said, "Remember Lot's wife".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1644
verses.text: And, in addition to these, there is still a third type in Lot, when his daughters lay with him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1645
verses.text: For here Lot seems to prefigure the future law; for those who spring from the law, and are placed under the law, by misunderstanding it, stupefy it, as it were, and bring forth the works of unbelief by an unlawful use of the law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1646
verses.text: "The law is good" says the apostle, "if a man use it lawfully".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1647
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1648
verses.text: It is no excuse for this action of Lot or of his daughters that it represented the perversity which was afterwards in certain cases to be displayed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1649
verses.text: The purpose of Lot's daughters is one thing, and the purpose of God is another, in allowing this to happen that He might make some truth manifest; for God both pronounces judgment on the actions of the people of those times, and arranges in His providence for the prefigurement of the future.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1650
verses.text: As a part of Scripture, this action is a prophecy; as part of the history of those concerned, it is a crime.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1651
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1652
verses.text: At the same time there is in this transaction no reason for the torrent of abuse which Faustus' blind hostility discharges on it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1653
verses.text: By the eternal law which requires the preservation of the order of nature and condemns its violation, the judgment in this case is not what it would have been if Lot had been prompted by a criminal passion to commit incest with his daughters, or if they had been inflamed with unnatural desires.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1654
verses.text: In justice, we must ask not only what was done, but with what motive, in order to obtain a fair view of the action as the effect of that motive.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1655
verses.text: The resolution of Lot's daughters to lie with their father was the effect of the natural desire for offspring in order to preserve the race; for they supposed that there were no other men to be found, thinking that the whole world had been consumed in that conflagration, which, for all they knew, had left no one alive but themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1656
verses.text: It would have been better for them never to have been mothers, than to have become mothers by their own father.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1657
verses.text: But still, the fulfillment of a desire like this is very different from the accursed gratification of lust.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1658
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1659
verses.text: Knowing that their father would condemn their design, Lot's daughters thought it necessary to fulfill it without his knowledge.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1660
verses.text: We are told that they made him drunk, so that he was unaware of what happened.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1661
verses.text: His guilt therefore is not that of incest, but of drunkenness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1662
verses.text: This, too, is condemned by the eternal law, which allows meat and drink only as required by nature for the preservation of health.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1663
verses.text: There is, indeed, a great difference between a drunk man and an habitual drunkard; for the drunkard is not always drunk, and a man may be drunk on one occasion without being a drunkard.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1664
verses.text: However, in the case of a righteous man, we require to account for even one instance of drunkenness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1665
verses.text: What can have made Lot consent to receive from his daughters all the cups of wine which they went on mixing for him, or perhaps giving him unmixed? Did they feign excessive grief, and did he resort to this consolation in their loneliness, and in the loss of their mother, thinking that they were drinking too, while they only pretended to drink? But this does not seem a proper method for a righteous man to take in consoling his friends when in trouble.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1666
verses.text: Had the daughters learned in Sodom some vile art which enabled them to intoxicate their father with a few cups, so that in his ignorance he might sin, or rather be sinned against? But it is not likely that the Scripture would have omitted all notice of this, or that God would have allowed His servant to be thus abused without any fault of his own.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1667
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1668
verses.text: But we are defending the sacred Scriptures, not man's sins.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1669
verses.text: Nor are we concerned to justify this action, as if our God had either commanded it or approved of it; or as if, when men are called just in Scripture, it meant that they could not sin if they chose.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1670
verses.text: And as, in the books which those critics find fault with, God nowhere expresses approval of this action, what thoughtless folly it is to bring a charge from this narrative against these writings, when in other places such actions are condemned by express prohibitions! In the story of Lot's daughters the action is related, not commended.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1671
verses.text: And it is proper that the judgment of God should be declared in some cases, and concealed in others, that by its manifestation our ignorance may be enlightened, and that by its concealment our minds may be improved by the exercise of recalling what we already know, or our indolence stimulated to seek for an explanation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1672
verses.text: Here, then, God, who can bring good out of evil, made nations arise from this origin, as He saw good, but did not bring upon His own Scriptures the guilt of man's sin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1673
verses.text: It is God's writing, but not His doing; He does not propose these things for our imitation, but holds them up for our warning.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1674
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1675
verses.text: Faustus' effrontery appears notably in his accusing Isaac also, the son of Abraham of pretending that his wife Rebecca was his sister.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1676
verses.text: For as regards the family of Rebecca Scripture is not silent, and it appears that she was his sister in the well-known sense of the word.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1677
verses.text: His concealing that she was his wife is not surprising, nor is it insignificant, if he did it in imitation of his father, so that he can be justified on the same grounds.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1678
verses.text: We need only refer to the answer already given to Faustus' charge against Abraham, as being equally applicable to Isaac.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1679
verses.text: Perhaps, however some inquirer will ask what typical significance there is in the foreign king discovering Rebecca to be the wife of Isaac by seeing him playing with her; for he would not have known, had he not seen Isaac playing with Rebecca as it would have been improper to do with a woman not his wife.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1680
verses.text: When holy men act thus as husbands, they do it not foolishly, but designedly: for they accommodate themselves to the nature of the weaker sex in words and actions of gentle playfulness; not in effeminacy, but in subdued manliness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1681
verses.text: But such behavior towards any woman except a wife would be disgraceful.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1682
verses.text: This is a question in good manners, which is referred to only in case some stern advocate of insensibility should find fault with the holy man even for playing with his wife.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1683
verses.text: For if these men without humanity see a sedate man chatting playfully with children that he may adapt himself to the childish understanding with kindly sympathy, they think that he is insane; forgetting that they themselves were once children, or unthankful for their maturity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1684
verses.text: The typical meaning, as regards Christ and His Church, which is to be found in this great patriarch playing with his wife, and in the conjugal relation being thus discovered, will be seen by every one who, to avoid offending the Church by erroneous doctrine, carefully studies in Scripture the secret of the Church's Bridegroom.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1685
