verses.text: But knowing that such actions in battle were not murderous but authorized by law, and that the soldiers did not thus avenge themselves, but defend the public safety, he replied, "Do violence to no man, accuse no man falsely, and be content with your wages".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1970
verses.text: But as the Manich aeans are in the habit of speaking evil of John, let them hear the Lord Jesus Christ Himself ordering this money to be given to C aesar, which John tells the soldiers to be content with.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1971
verses.text: "Give," He says, "to C aesar the things that are C aesar's".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1972
verses.text: For tribute-money is given on purpose to pay the soldiers for war.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1973
verses.text: Again, in the case of the centurion who said, "I am a man under authority, and have soldiers under me: and I say to one, Go, and he goeth; and to another, Come, and he cometh; and to my servant, Do this, and he doeth it," Christ gave due praise to his faith;  He did not tell him to leave the service.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1974
verses.text: But there is no need here to enter on the long discussion of just and unjust ways.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1975
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1976
verses.text: A great deal depends on the causes for which men undertake wars, and on the authority they have for doing so; for the natural order which seeks the peace of mankind, ordains that the monarch should have the power of undertaking war if he thinks it advisable, and that the soldiers should perform their military duties in behalf of the peace and safety of the community.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1977
verses.text: When war is undertaken in obedience to God, who would rebuke, or humble, or crush the pride of man, it must be allowed to be a righteous war; for even the wars which arise from human passion cannot harm the eternal well-being of God, nor even hurt His saints; for in the trial of their patience, and the chastening of their spirit, and in bearing fatherly correction, they are rather benefited than injured.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1978
verses.text: No one can have any power against them but what is given him from above.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1979
verses.text: For there is no power but of God,  who either orders or permits.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1980
verses.text: Since, therefore, a righteous man, serving it may be under an ungodly king, may do the duty belonging to his position in the State in fighting by the order of his sovereign,—for in some cases it is plainly the will of God that he should fight, and in others, where this is not so plain, it may be an unrighteous command on the part of the king, while the soldier is innocent, because his position makes obedience a duty,—how much more must the man be blameless who carries on war on the authority of God, of whom every one who serves Him knows that He can never require what is wrong?  76.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1981
verses.text: If it is supposed that God could not enjoin warfare, because in after times it was said by the Lord Jesus Christ, "I say unto you, That ye resist not evil: but if any one strike thee on the right cheek, turn to him the left also,"  the answer is, that what is here required is not a bodily action, but an inward disposition.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1982
verses.text: The sacred seat of virtue is the heart, and such were the hearts of our fathers, the righteous men of old.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1983
verses.text: But order required such a regulation of events, and such a distinction of times, as to show first of all that even earthly blessings (for so temporal kingdoms and victory over enemies are considered to be, and these are the things which the community of the ungodly all over the world are continually begging from idols and devils) are entirely under the control and at the disposal of the one true God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1984
verses.text: Thus, under the Old Testament, the secret of the kingdom of heaven, which was to be disclosed in due time, was veiled, and so far obscured, in the disguise of earthly promises.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1985
verses.text: But when the fullness of time came for the revelation of the New Testament, which was hidden under the types of the Old, clear testimony was to be borne to the truth, that there is another life for which this life ought to be disregarded, and another kingdom for which the opposition of all earthly kingdoms should be patiently borne.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1986
verses.text: Thus the name martyrs, which means witnesses, was given to those who, by the will of God, bore this testimony, by their confessions, their sufferings, and their death.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1987
verses.text: The number of such witnesses is so great, that if it pleased Christ—who called Saul by a voice from heaven, and having changed him from a wolf to a sheep, sent him into the midst of wolves—to unite them all in one army, and to give them success in battle, as He gave to the Hebrews, what nation could withstand them? what kingdom would remain unsubdued? But as the doctrine of the New Testament is, that we must serve God not for temporal happiness in this life, but for eternal felicity hereafter, this truth was most strikingly confirmed by the patient endurance of what is commonly called adversity for the sake of that felicity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1988
verses.text: So in fullness of time the Son of God, made of a woman, made under the law, that He might redeem them that were under the law, made of the seed of David according to the flesh sends His disciples as sheep into the midst of wolves, and bids them not fear those that can kill the body, but cannot kill the soul, and promises that even the body will be entirely restored, so that not a hair shall be lost.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1989
verses.text: Peter's sword He orders back into its sheath, restoring as it was before the ear of His enemy that had been cut off.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1990
verses.text: He says that He could obtain legions of angels to destroy His enemies, but that He must drink the cup which His Father's will had given Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1991
verses.text: He sets the example of drinking this cup, then hands it to His followers, manifesting thus, both in word and deed, the grace of patience.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1992
verses.text: Therefore God raised Him from the dead, and has given Him a name which is above every name; that in the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of things in heaven and of things in earth, and of things under the earth; and that every tongue should confess that Jesus is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1993
verses.text: The patriarchs and prophets, then, have a kingdom in this world, to show that these kingdoms, too, are given and taken away by God: the apostles and martyrs had no kingdom here, to show the superior desirableness of the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1994
verses.text: The prophets, however, could even in those times die for the truth, as the Lord Himself says, "From the blood of Abel to the blood of Zacharia;  and in these days, since the commencement of the fulfillment of what is prophesied in the psalm of Christ, under the figure of Solomon, which means the peacemaker, as Christ is our peace,  "All kings of the earth shall bow to Him, all nations shall serve Him,"  we have seen Christian emperors, who have put all their confidence in Christ, gaining splendid victories over ungodly enemies, whose hope was in the rites of idolatry and devil-worship.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1995
verses.text: There are public and undeniable proofs of the fact, that on one side the prognostications of devils were found to be fallacious, and on the other, the predictions of saints were a means of support; and we have now writings in which those facts are recorded.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1996
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1997
verses.text: If our foolish opponents are surprised at the difference between the precepts given by God to the ministers of the Old Testament, at a time when the grace of the New was still undisclosed, and those given to the preachers of the New Testament, now that the obscurity of the Old is removed, they will find Christ Himself saying one thing at one time, and another at another.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1998
verses.text: "When I sent you," He says, "without scrip, or purse, or shoes, did ye lack anything? And they said, Nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:1999
verses.text: Then saith He to them, But now, he that hath a scrip, let him take it, and also a purse; and he that hath not a sword, let him sell his garment, and buy one".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2000
verses.text: If the Manich aeans found passages in the Old and New Testaments differing in this way, they would proclaim it as a proof that the Testaments are opposed to each other.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2001
verses.text: But here the difference is in the utterances of one and the same person.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2002
verses.text: At one time He says, "I sent you without scrip, or purse, or shoes, and ye lacked nothing;" at another, "Now let him that hath a scrip take it, and also a purse; and he that hath a tunic, let him sell it and buy a sword".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2003
verses.text: Does not this show how, without any inconsistency, precepts and counsels and permissions may be changed, as different times require different arrangements? If it is said that there was a symbolical meaning in the command to take a scrip and purse, and to buy a sword, why may there not be a symbolical meaning in the fact, that one and the same God commanded the prophets in old times to make war, and forbade the apostles? And we find in the passage that we have quoted from the Gospel, that the words spoken by the Lord were carried into effect by His disciples.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2004
verses.text: For, besides going at first without scrip or purse, and yet lacking nothing, as from the Lord's question and their answer it is plain they did, now that He speaks of buying a sword, they say, "Lo, here are two swords;" and He replied, "It is enough".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2005
verses.text: Hence we find Peter with a weapon when he cut off the assailant's ear, on which occasion his spontaneous boldness was checked, because, although he had been told to take a sword, he had not been told to use it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2006
verses.text: Doubtless, it was mysterious that the Lord should require them to carry weapons, and forbid the use of them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2007
verses.text: But it was His part to give the suitable precepts, and it was their part to obey without reserve.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2008
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2009
verses.text: It is therefore mere groundless calumny to charge Moses with making war, for there would have been less harm in making war of his own accord, than in not doing it when God commanded him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2010
verses.text: And to dare to find fault with God Himself for giving such a command, or not to believe it possible that a just and good God did so, shows, to say the least, an inability to consider that in the view of divine providence, which pervades all things from the highest to the lowest, time can neither add anything nor take away; but all things go, or come, or remain according to the order of nature or desert in each separate case, while in men a right will is in union with the divine law, and ungoverned passion is restrained by the order of divine law; so that a good man wills only what is commanded, and a bad man can do only what he is permitted, at the same time that he is punished for what he wills to do unjustly.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2011
verses.text: Thus, in all the things which appear shocking and terrible to human feebleness, the real evil is the injustice; the rest is only the result of natural properties or of moral demerit.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2012
verses.text: This injustice is seen in every case where a man loves for their own sake things which are desirable only as means to an end, and seeks for the sake of something else things which ought to be loved for themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2013
verses.text: For thus, as far as he can, he disturbs in himself the natural order which the eternal law requires us to observe.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2014
verses.text: Again, a man is just when he seeks to use things only for the end for which God appointed them, and to enjoy God as the end of all, while he enjoys himself and his friend in God and for God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2015
verses.text: For to love in a friend the love of God is to love the friend for God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2016
verses.text: Now both justice and injustice, to be acts at all, must be voluntary; otherwise, there can be no just rewards or punishments; which no man in his senses will assert.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2017
verses.text: The ignorance and infirmity which prevent a man from knowing his duty, or from doing all he wishes to do, belong to God's secret penal arrangement, and to His unfathomable judgments, for with Him there is no iniquity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2018
verses.text: Thus we are informed by the sure word of God of Adam's sin; and Scripture truly declares that in him all die, and that by him sin entered into the world, and death by sin.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2019
verses.text: And our experience gives abundant evidence, that in punishment for this sin our body is corrupted, and weighs down the soul, and the clay tabernacle clogs the mind in its manifold activity;  and we know that we can be freed from this punishment only by gracious interposition.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2020
verses.text: So the apostle cries out in distress, "O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death? The grace of God through Jesus Christ our Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2021
verses.text: So much we know; but the reasons for the distribution of divine judgment and mercy, why one is in this condition, and another in that, though just, are unknown.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2022
verses.text: Still, we are sure that all these things are due either to the mercy or the judgment of God, while the measures and numbers and weights by which the Creator of all natural productions arranges all things are concealed from our view.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2023
verses.text: For God is not the author, but He is the controller of sin; so that sinful actions, which are sinful because they are against nature, are judged and controlled, and assigned to their proper place and condition, in order that they may not bring discord and disgrace on universal nature.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2024
verses.text: This being the case, and as the judgments of God and the movements of man's will contain the hidden reason why the same prosperous circumstances which some make a right use of are the ruin of others, and the same afflictions under which some give way are profitable to others, and since the whole mortal life of man upon earth is a trial,  who can tell whether it may be good or bad in any particular case—in time of peace, to reign or to serve, or to be at ease or to die—or in time of war, to command or to fight, or to conquer or to be killed? At the same time, it remains true, that whatever is good is so by the divine blessing, and whatever is bad is so by the divine judgment.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2025
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2026
verses.text: Let no one, then, be so daring as to make rash charges against men, not to say against God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2027
verses.text: If the service of the ministers of the Old Testament, who were also heralds of the New, consisted in putting sinners to death, and that of the ministers of the New Testament, who are also interpreters of the Old, in being put to death by sinners, the service in both cases is rendered to one God, who, varying the lesson to suit the times, teaches both that temporal blessings are to be sought from Him, and that they are to be forsaken for Him, and that temporal distress is both sent by Him and should be endured for Him.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2028
verses.text: There was, therefore, no cruelty in the command, or in the action of Moses, when, in his holy jealousy for his people, whom he wished to be subject to the one true God, on learning that they had fallen away to the worship of an idol made by their own hands, he impressed their minds at the time with a wholesome fear, and gave them a warning for the future, by using the sword in the punishment of a few, whose just punishment God, against whom they had sinned, appointed in the depth of His secret judgment to be immediately inflicted.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2029
verses.text: That Moses acted as he did, not in cruelty, but in great love, may be seen from the words in which he prayed for the sins of the people: "If Thou wilt forgive their sin, forgive it; and if not, blot me out of Thy book".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2030
verses.text: The pious inquirer who compares the slaughter with the prayer will find in this the clearest evidence of the awful nature of the injury done to the soul by prostitution to the images of devils, since such love is roused to such anger.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2031
verses.text: We see the same in the apostle, who, not in cruelty, but in love, delivered a man up to Satan for the destruction of the flesh, that the spirit might be saved in the day of the Lord Jesus.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2032
verses.text: Others, too, he delivered up, that they might learn not to blaspheme.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2033
verses.text: In the apocryphal books of the Manich aeans there is a collection of fables, published by some unknown authors under the name of the apostles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2034
verses.text: The books would no doubt have been sanctioned by the Church at the time of their publication, if holy and learned men then in life, and competent to determine the matter, had thought the contents to be true.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2035
verses.text: One of the stories is, that the Apostle Thomas was once at a marriage feast in a country where he was unknown, when one of the servants struck him, and that he forthwith by his curse brought a terrible punishment on this man.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2036
verses.text: For when he went out to the fountain to provide water for the guests, a lion fell on him and killed him, and the hand with which he had given a slight blow to the apostle was torn off, in fulfillment of the imprecation, and brought by a dog to the table at which the apostle was reclining.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2037
verses.text: What could be more cruel than this? And yet, if I mistake not, the story goes on to say, that the apostle made up for the cruelty by obtaining for the man the blessing of pardon in the next world; so that, while the people of this strange country learned to fear the apostle as being so dear to God, the man's eternal welfare was secured in exchange for the loss of this mortal life.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2038
verses.text: It matters not whether the story is true or false.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2039
verses.text: At any rate, the Manich aeans, who regard as genuine and authentic books which the canon of the Church rejects, must allow, as shown in the story, that the virtue of patience, which the Lord enjoins when He says, "If any one smite thee on the right cheek, turn to him thy left also," may be in the inward disposition, though it is not exhibited in bodily action or in words.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2040
verses.text: For when the apostle was struck, instead of turning his other side to the man, or telling him to repeat the blow, he prayed to God to pardon his assailant in the next world, but not to leave the injury unpunished at the time.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2041
verses.text: Inwardly he preserved a kindly feeling, while outwardly he wished the man to be punished as an example.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2042
verses.text: As the Manich aeans believe this, rightly or wrongly, they may also believe that such was the intention of Moses, the servant of God, when he cut down with the sword the makers and worshippers of the idol; for his own words show that he so entreated for pardon for their sin of idolatry as to ask to be blotted out of God's book if his prayer was not heard.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2043
verses.text: There is no comparison between a stranger being struck with the hand, and the dishonor done to God by forsaking Him for an idol, when He had brought the people out of the bondage of Egypt, had led them through the sea, and had covered with the waters the enemy pursuing them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2044
verses.text: Nor, as regards the punishment, is there any comparison between being killed with the sword and being torn in pieces by wild beasts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2045
verses.text: For judges in administering the law condemn to exposure to wild beasts worse criminals than are condemned to be put to death by the sword.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2046
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2047
verses.text: Another of Faustus' malicious and impious charges which has to be answered, is about the Lord's saying to the prophet Hosea, "Take unto thee a wife of whoredoms and children of whoredoms".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2048
verses.text: As regards this passage, the impure mind of our adversaries is so blinded that they do not understand the plain words of the Lord in His gospel, when He says to the Jews, "The publicans and harlots shall go into the kingdom of heaven before you".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2049
verses.text: There is nothing contrary to the mercifulness of truth, or inconsistent with Christian faith, in a harlot leaving fornication, and becoming a chaste wife.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2050
verses.text: Indeed, nothing could be more unbecoming in one professing to be a prophet than not to believe that all the sins of the fallen woman were pardoned when she changed for the better.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2051
verses.text: So when the prophet took the harlot as his wife, it was both good for the woman to have her life amended, and the action symbolized a truth of which we shall speak presently.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2052
verses.text: But it is plain what offends the Manich aeans in this case; for their great anxiety is to prevent harlots from being with child.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2053
verses.text: It would have pleased them better that the woman should continue a prostitute, so as not to bring their god into confinement, than that she should become the wife of one man, and have children.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2054
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2055
verses.text: As regards Solomon, it need only be said that the condemnation of his conduct in the faithful narrative of holy Scripture is much more serious than the childish vehemence of Faustus' attacks.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2056
verses.text: The Scripture tells us with faithful accuracy both the good that Solomon had at first, and the evil actions by which he lost the good he began with; while Faustus, in his attacks, like a man closing his eyes, or with no eyes at all, seeks no guidance from the light, but is prompted only by violent animosity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2057
verses.text: To pious and discerning readers of the sacred Scriptures evidence of the chastity of the holy men who are said to have had several wives is found in this, that Solomon, who by his polygamy gratified his passions, instead of seeking for offspring, is expressly noted as chargeable with being a lover of women.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2058
verses.text: This, as we are informed by the truth which accepts no man's person, led him down into the abyss of idolatry.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2059
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2060
verses.text: Having now gone over all the cases in which Faustus finds fault with the Old Testament, and having attended to the merit of each, either defending men of God against the calumnies of carnal heretics, or, where the men were at fault, showing the excellence and the majesty of Scripture, let us again take the cases in the order of Faustus' accusations, and see the meaning of the actions recorded, what they typify, and what they foretell.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2061
verses.text: This we have already done in the case of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, of whom God said that He was their God, as if the God of universal nature were the God of none besides them; not honoring them with an unmeaning title, but because He, who could alone have a full and perfect knowledge, knew the sincere and remarkable charity of these men; and because these three patriarchs united formed a notable type of the future people of God, in not only having free children by free women, as by Sarah, and Rebecca, and Leah, and Rachel, but also bond children, as of this same Rebecca was born Esau, to whom it was said, "Thou shalt serve thy brother;"  and in having by bond women not only bond children, as by Hagar, but also free children, as by Bilhah and Zilphah.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2062
verses.text: Thus also in the people of God, those spiritually free not only have children born into the enjoyment of liberty, like those to whom it is said, "Be ye followers of me, as I also am of Christ,"  but they have also children born into guilty bondage, as Simon was born of Philip.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2063
verses.text: Again, from carnal bondmen are born not only children of guilty bondage, who imitate them, but also children of happy liberty, to whom it is said, "What they say, do; but do not after their works".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2064
verses.text: Whoever rightly observes the fulfillment of this type in the people of God, keeps the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace, by continuing to the end in union with some, and in patient endurance of others.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2065
verses.text: Of Lot, also, we have already spoken, and have shown what the Scripture mentions as praiseworthy in him, and what as blameworthy and the meaning of the whole narrative.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2066
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2067
verses.text: We have next to consider the prophetic significance of the action of Judah in lying with his daughter-in-law.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2068
verses.text: But, for the sake of those whose understanding is feeble, we shall begin with observing, that in sacred Scripture evil actions are sometimes prophetic not of evil, but of good.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2069
verses.text: Divine providence preserves throughout its essential goodness, so that, as in the example given above, from adulterous intercourse a man-child is born, a good work of God from the evil of man, by the power of nature, and not due to the misconduct of the parents; so in the prophetic Scriptures, where both good and evil actions are recorded, the narrative being itself prophetic, foretells something good even by the record of what is evil, the credit being due not to the evil-doer, but to the writer.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2070
verses.text: Judah, when, to gratify his sinful passion, he went in to Tamar, had no intention by his licentious conduct to typify anything connected with the salvation of men, any more than Judas, who betrayed the Lord, intended to produce any result connected with the salvation of men.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2071
verses.text: So then if from the evil deed of Judas the Lord brought the good work of our redemption by His own passion, why should not His prophet, of whom He Himself says "He wrote of me," for the sake of instructing us make the evil action of Judah significant of something good? Under the guidance and inspiration of the Holy Spirit, the prophet has compiled a narrative of actions so as to make a continuous prophecy of the things he designed to foretell.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2072
verses.text: In foretelling good, it is of no consequence whether the typical actions are good or bad.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2073
verses.text: If it is written in red ink that the Ethiopians are black, or in black ink that the Gauls are white, this circumstance does not affect the information which the writing conveys.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2074
verses.text: No doubt, if it was a painting instead of a writing, the wrong color would be a fault; so when human actions are represented for example or for warning much depends on whether they are good or bad.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2075
verses.text: But when actions are related or recorded as types, the merit or demerit of the agents is a matter of no importance, as long as there is a true typical relation between the action and the thing signified.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2076
verses.text: So in the case of Caiaphas in the Gospel as regards his iniquitous and mischievous intention, and even as regards his words in the sense in which he used them, that a just man should be put to death unjustly, assuredly they were bad; and yet there was a good meaning in his words which he did not know of when he said, "It is expedient that one man should die for the people and that the whole nation perish not".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2077
verses.text: So it is written of Him, "This he spake not of himself; but being the high priest, he prophesied that Jesus should die for the people".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2078
verses.text: In the same way the action of Judah was bad as regards his sinful passion, but it typified a great good he knew nothing of.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2079
verses.text: Of himself he did evil while it was not of himself that he typified good.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2080
verses.text: These introductory remarks apply not only to Judah, but also to all the other cases where in the narrative of bad actions is contained a prophecy of good.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2081
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2082
verses.text: In Tamar, then, the daughter-in-law of Judah, we see the people of the kingdom of Judah, whose kings, answering to Tamar's husbands, were taken from this tribe.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2083
verses.text: Tamar means bitterness; and the meaning is suitable, for this people gave the cup of gall to the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2084
verses.text: The two sons of Judah represent two classes of kings who governed ill—those who did harm and those who did no good.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2085
verses.text: One of these sons was evil or cruel before the Lord; the other spilled the seed on the ground that Tamar might not become a mother.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2086
verses.text: There are only those two kinds of useless people in the world—the injurious and those who will not give the good they have but lose it or spill it on the ground.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2087
verses.text: And as injury is worse than not doing good, the evil-doer is called the elder and the other the younger.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2088
verses.text: Er, the name of the elder, means a preparer of skins, which were the coats given to our first parents when they were punished with expulsion from paradise.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2089
verses.text: Onan, the name of the younger, means, their grief; that is, the grief of those to whom he does no good, wasting the good he has on the earth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2090
verses.text: The loss of life implied in the name of the elder is a greater evil than the want of help implied in the name of the younger.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2091
verses.text: Both being killed by God typifies the removal of the kingdom from men of this character.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2092
verses.text: The meaning of the third son of Judah not being joined to the woman, is that for a time the kings of Judah were not of that tribe.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2093
verses.text: So this third son did not become the husband of Tamar; as Tamar represents the tribe of Judah, which continued to exist, although the people received no king from it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2094
verses.text: Hence the name of this son, Selom, means, his dismission.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2095
verses.text: None of those types apply to the holy and righteous men who, like David, though they lived in those times, belong properly to the New Testament, which they served by their enlightened predictions.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2096
verses.text: Again, in the time when Judah ceased to have a king of its own tribe, the elder Herod does not count as one of the kings typified by the husbands of Tamar; for he was a foreigner, and his union with the people was never consecrated with the holy oil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2097
verses.text: His was the power of a stranger, given him by the Romans and by C aesar.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2098
verses.text: And it was the same with his sons, the tetrarchs, one of whom, called Herod, like his father, agreed with Pilate at the time of the Lord's passion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2099
verses.text: So plainly were these foreigners considered as distinct from the sacred monarchy of Judah, that the Jews themselves, when raging against Christ, exclaimed openly, "We have no king but C aesar".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2100
verses.text: Nor was C aesar properly their king, except in the sense that all the world was subject to Rome.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2101
verses.text: The Jews thus condemned themselves, only to express their rejection of Christ, and to flatter C aesar.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2102
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2103
verses.text: The time when the kingdom was removed from the tribe of Judah was the time appointed for the coming of Christ our Lord, the true Saviour, who should come not for harm, but for great good.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2104
verses.text: Thus was it prophesied, "A prince shall not fail from Judah, nor a leader from his loins, till He come for whom it is reserved: He is the desire of nations".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2105
verses.text: Not only the kingdom, but all government, of the Jews had ceased, and also, as prophesied by Daniel, the sacred anointing from which the name Christ or Anointed is derived.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2106
verses.text: Then came He for whom it was reserved, the desire of nations; and the holy of holies was anointed with the oil of gladness above His fellows.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2107
verses.text: Christ was born in the time of the elder Herod, and suffered in the time of Herod the tetrarch.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2108
verses.text: He who thus came to the lost sheep of the house of Israel was typified by Judah when he went to shear his sheep in Thamna, which means, failing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2109
verses.text: For then the prince had failed from Judah, with all the government and anointing of the Jews, that He might come for whom it was reserved.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2110
verses.text: Judah, we are told, came with his Adullamite shepherd, whose name was Iras; and Adullamite means, a testimony in water.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2111
verses.text: So it was with this testimony that the Lord came, having indeed greater testimony than that of John;  but for the sake of his feeble sheep he made use of the testimony in water.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2112
verses.text: The name Iras, too, means, vision of my brother.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2113
verses.text: So John saw his brother, a brother in the family of Abraham, and from the relationship of Mary and Elisabeth; and the same person he recognised as his Lord and his God, for, as he himself says, he received of His fullness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2114
verses.text: On account of this vision, among those born of woman, there has arisen no greater than he;  because, of all who foretold Christ, he alone saw what many righteous men and prophets desired to see and saw not.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2115
verses.text: He saluted Christ from the womb;  he knew Him more certainly from seeing the dove; and therefore, as the Adullamite, he gave testimony by water.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2116
verses.text: The Lord came to shear His sheep, in releasing them from painful burdens, as it is said in praise of the Church in the Song of Songs, that her teeth are like a flock of sheep after shearing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2117
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2118
verses.text: Next, we have Tamar changing her dress; for Tamar also means changing.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2119
verses.text: Still, the name of bitterness must be retained—not that bitterness in which gall was given to the Lord, but that in which Peter wept bitterly.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2120
verses.text: For Judah means confession; and bitterness is mingled with confession as a type of true repentance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2121
verses.text: It is this repentance which gives fruitfulness to the Church established among all nations.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2122
verses.text: For "it behoved Christ to suffer, and to rise from the dead, and that repentance and the remission of sins be preached among all nations in His name, beginning at Jerusalem".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2123
verses.text: In the dress Tamar put on there is a confession of sins; and Tamar sitting in this dress at the gate of  aenan or  aenaim, which means fountain, is a type of the Church called from among the nations.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2124
verses.text: She ran as a hart to the springs of water, to meet with the seed of Abraham; and there she is made fruitful by one who knows her not, as it is foretold, "A people whom I have not known shall serve me".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2125
verses.text: Tamar received under her disguise a ring, a bracelet, a staff; she is sealed in her calling, adorned in her justification, raised in her glorification.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2126
verses.text: For "whom He predestinated, them He also called: and whom He called, them He also justified: and whom He justified, them He also glorified".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2127
verses.text: This was while she was still disguised, as I have said; and in the same state she conceives, and becomes fruitful in holiness.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2128
verses.text: Also the kid promised is sent to her as to a harlot.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2129
verses.text: The kid represents rebuke for sin, and it is sent by the Adullamite already mentioned, who, as it were, uses the reproachful words, "O generation of vipers!"  But this rebuke for sin does not reach her, for she has been changed by the bitterness of confession.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2130
verses.text: Afterwards, by exhibiting the pledges of the ring and bracelet and staff, she prevails over the Jews, in their hasty judgment of her, who are now represented by Judah himself; as at this day we hear the Jews saying that we are not the people of Christ, and have not the seed of Abraham.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2131
verses.text: But when we exhibit the sure tokens of our calling and justification and glorification, they will immediately be confounded, and will acknowledge that we are justified rather than they.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2132
verses.text: I should enter into this more particularly, taking, as it were, each limb and joint separately, as the Lord might enable me, were it not that such minute inquiry is prevented by the necessity of bringing this work to a close, for it is already longer than is desirable.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2133
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2134
verses.text: As regards the prophetic significance of David's sin, a single word must suffice.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2135
verses.text: The names occurring in the narrative show what it typifies.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2136
verses.text: David means, strong of hand, or desirable; and what can be stronger than the Lion of the tribe of Judah, who has conquered the world, or more desirable than He of whom the prophet says, "The desire of all nations shall come?"  Bersabee means, well of satisfaction, or seventh well: either of these interpretations will suit our purpose.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2137
verses.text: So, in the Song of Songs, the spouse, who is the Church, is called a well of living water;  or again, the number seven represents the Holy Spirit, as in the number of days in Pentecost, when the Holy Spirit came from heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2138
verses.text: We learn also from the book of Tobit, that Pentecost was the feast of seven weeks.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2139
verses.text: To forty-nine, which is seven times seven, one is added to denote unity.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2140
verses.text: To this effect is the saying of the apostle: "Bearing with one another in love, endeavoring to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2141
verses.text: The Church becomes a well of satisfaction by this gift of the Spirit, the number seven denoting its spirituality; for it is in her a fountain of living water springing up unto everlasting life, and he who has it shall never thirst.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2142
verses.text: Uriah, Bersabee's husband, must, from the meaning of his name, be understood as representing the devil.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2143
verses.text: It is in union to the devil that all are bound whom the grace of God sets free, that the Church without spot or wrinkle may be married to her true Saviour.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2144
verses.text: Uriah means, my light of God; and Hittite means, cut off, referring either to his not abiding in the truth, when he was cut off on account of his pride from the celestial light which he had of God, or to his transforming himself into an angel of light, because after losing his real strength by his fall, he still dares to say, My light is of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2145
verses.text: The literal David, then, was guilty of a heinous crime, which God by the prophet condemned in the rebuke addressed to David, and which David atoned for by his repentance.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2146
verses.text: On the other hand, He who is the desire of all nations loved the Church when washing herself on the roof, that is, when cleansing herself from the pollution of the world, and in spiritual contemplation mounting above her house of clay, and trampling upon it; and after commencing an acquaintance, He puts to death the devil, whom He first entirely removes from her, and joins her to Himself in perpetual union.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2147
verses.text: While we hate the sin, we must not overlook the prophetical significance; and while we love, as is His due, that David who in His mercy has freed us from the devil, we may also love the David who by the humility of his repentance healed the wound made by his transgression.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2148
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2149
verses.text: Little need be said of Solomon, who is spoken of in Holy Scripture in terms of the strongest disapproval and condemnation, while nothing is said of his repentance and restoration to the divine favor.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2150
verses.text: Nor can I find in his lamentable fall even a symbolical connection with anything good.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2151
verses.text: Perhaps the strange women he lusted after may be thought to represent the Churches chosen from among the Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2152
verses.text: This idea might have been admissible, if the women had left their gods for Solomon's sake to worship his God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2153
verses.text: But as he for their sakes offended his God and worshipped their gods, it seems impossible to think of any good meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2154
verses.text: Doubtless, something is typified, but it is something bad, as in the case already explained of Lot's wife and daughters.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2155
verses.text: We see in Solomon a notable pre-eminence and a notable fall.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2156
verses.text: Now, this good and evil which we see in him at different periods, first good and then evil, are in our day found together in the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2157
verses.text: What is good in Solomon represents, I think, the good members of the Church; and what was bad in him represents the bad members.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2158
verses.text: Both are in one man, as the bad and the good are in the chaff and grain of one floor, or in the tares and wheat of one field.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2159
verses.text: A closer inquiry into what is said of Solomon in Scripture might disclose, either to me or to others of greater learning and greater worth, some more probable interpretation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2160
verses.text: But as we are now engaged on a different subject, we must not allow this matter to break the connection of our discourse.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2161
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2162
verses.text: As regards the prophet Hosea, it is unnecessary for me to explain the meaning of the command, or of the prophet's conduct, when God said to him, "Go and take unto thee a wife of whoredoms and produce children of whoredoms," for the Scripture itself informs us of the origin and purpose of this direction.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2163
verses.text: It proceeds thus: "For the land hath committed great whoredom, departing from the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2164
verses.text: So he went and took Gomer the daughter of Diblaim; which conceived, and bare him a son.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2165
verses.text: And the Lord said unto him, Call his name Jezreel; for yet a little while, and I will avenge the blood of Jezreel upon the house of Judah, and will cause to cease the kingdom of the house of Israel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2166
verses.text: And it shall come to pass at that day, that I will break the bow of Israel in the valley of Jezreel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2167
verses.text: And she conceived again, and bare a daughter.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2168
verses.text: And God said unto him, Call her name No-mercy: for I will no more have mercy upon the house of Israel; but I will utterly take them away.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2169
verses.text: But I will have mercy upon the house of Judah, and will save them by the Lord their God, and will not save them by bow, nor by sword, nor by battle, by horses, nor by horsemen.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2170
verses.text: Now when she had weaned No-mercy, she conceived, and bare a son.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2171
verses.text: Then said God, Call his name Not-my-people: for ye are not my people, and I will not be your God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2172
verses.text: Yet the number of the children of Israel shall be as the sand of the sea, which cannot be measured for multitude; and it shall come to pass that in the place where it was said unto them, Ye are not my people, there it shall be said unto them, Ye are the sons of the living God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2173
verses.text: Then shall the children of Israel and the children of Judah be gathered together, and appoint themselves one head, and they shall come up out of the land: for great shall be the day of Jezreel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2174
verses.text: Say ye unto your brethren, My people; and to your sister, She hath found mercy".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2175
verses.text: Since the typical meaning of the command and of the prophet's conduct is thus explained in the same book by the Lord Himself, and since the writings of the apostles declare the fulfillment of this prophecy in the preaching of the New Testament, every one must accept the explanation thus given of the command and of the action of the prophet as the true explanation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2176
verses.text: Thus it is said by the Apostle Paul, "That He might make known the riches of His glory on the vessels of mercy, which He had afore prepared unto glory, even us, whom He hath called, not of the Jews only, but also of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2177
verses.text: As He saith also in Hosea, I will call them my people, which were not my people; and her beloved, which was not beloved.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2178
verses.text: And it shall come to pass, that in the place where it was said unto them, Ye are not my people, there shall they be called the children of the living God".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2179
verses.text: Here Paul applies the prophecy to the Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2180
verses.text: So also Peter, writing to the Gentiles, without naming the prophet, borrows his expressions when he says, "But ye are a chosen generation, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a peculiar people; that ye might show forth the praises of Him who has called you out of darkness into His marvellous light; which in time past were not a people, but are now the people of God: which had not obtained mercy, but now have obtained mercy".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2181
verses.text: From this it is plain that the words of the prophet, "And the number of the children of Israel shall be as the sand of the sea, which cannot be measured for multitude," and the words immediately following, "And it shall be that in the place where it was said unto them, Ye are not my people, there they shall be called the children of the living God," do not apply to that Israel which is after the flesh, but to that of which the apostle says to the Gentiles, "Ye therefore are the seed of Abraham, and heirs according to the promise".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2182
verses.text: But, as many Jews who were of the Israel after the flesh have believed, and will yet believe; for of these were the apostles, and all the thousands in Jerusalem of the company of the apostles, as also the churches of which Paul speaks, when he says to the Galatians, "I was unknown by face to the churches of Jud aea which were in Christ;"  and again, he explains the passage in the Psalms, where the Lord is called the cornerstone,  as referring to His uniting in Himself the two walls of circumcision and uncircumcision, "that He might make in Himself of twain one new man, so making peace; and that He might reconcile both unto God in one body by the cross, having slain the enmity thereby: and that He might come and preach peace to them that are far off, and to them that are nigh," that is, to the Gentiles and to the Jews; "for He is our peace, who hath made of both one;"  to the same purpose we find the prophet speaking of the Jews as the children of Judah, and of the Gentiles as children of Israel, where he says, "The children of Judah and the children of Israel shall be gathered together, and shall make to themselves one head, and shall go up from the land".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2183
verses.text: Therefore, to speak against a prophecy thus confirmed by actual events, is to speak against the writings of the apostles as well as those of the prophets; and not only to speak against writings, but to impugn in the most reckless manner the evidence clear as noonday of established facts.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2184
verses.text: In the case of the narrative of Judah, it is perhaps not so easy to recognize, under the disguise of the woman called Tamar, the harlot representing the Church gathered from among the corruption of Gentile superstition; but here, where Scripture explains itself, and where the explanation is confirmed by the writings of the apostles, instead of dwelling longer on this, we may proceed at once to inquire into the meaning of the very things to which Faustus objects in Moses the servant of God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2185
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2186
verses.text: Moses killing the Egyptian in defending one of his brethren reminds us naturally of the destruction of the devil, our assailant in this land of strangers, by our defender the Lord Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2187
verses.text: And as Moses hid the dead body in the sand, even so the devil, though slain, remains concealed in those who are not firmly settled.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2188
verses.text: The Lord, we know, builds the Church on a rock; and those who hear His word and do it, He compares to a wise man who builds his house upon a rock, and who does not yield or give way before temptation; and those who hear and do not, He compares to a foolish man who builds on the sand, and when his house is tried its ruin is great.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2189
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2190
verses.text: Of the prophetic significance of the spoiling of the Egyptians, which was done by Moses at the command of the Lord his God, who commands nothing but what is most just, I remember to have set down what occurred to me at the time in my book entitled On Christian Doctrine;  to the effect that the gold and silver and garments of the Egyptians typified certain branches of learning which may be profitably learned or taught among the Gentiles.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2191
verses.text: This may be the true explanation; or we may suppose that the vessels of gold and silver represent the precious souls, and the garments the bodies, of those from among the Gentiles who join themselves to the people of God, that along with them they may be freed from the Egypt of this world.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2192
verses.text: Whatever the true interpretation may be, the pious student of the Scriptures will feel certain that in the command, in the action, and in the narrative there is a purpose and a symbolic meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2193
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2194
verses.text: It would take too long to go through all the wars of Moses.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2195
verses.text: It is enough to refer to what has already been said, as sufficient for the purpose in this reply to Faustus of the prophetic and symbolic character of the war with Amalek.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2196
verses.text: There is also the charge of cruelty made against Moses by the enemies of Scriptures, or by those who have never read anything.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2197
verses.text: Faustus does not make any specific charge, but speaks of Moses as commanding and doing many cruel things.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2198
verses.text: But, knowing the things they are in the habit of bringing forward and of misrepresenting, I have already taken a particular case and have defended it, so that any Manich aeans who are willing to be corrected, and all other ignorant and irreligious people, may see that there is no ground for their accusations.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2199
verses.text: We must now inquire into the prophetic significance of the command, that many of those who, while Moses was absent, made an idol for themselves should be slain without regard to relationship.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2200
verses.text: It is easy to see that the slaughter of these men represents the warfare against the evil principles which led the people into the same idolatry.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2201
verses.text: Against such evil we are commanded to wage war in the words of the psalm, "Be ye angry and sin not".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2202
verses.text: And a similar command is given by the apostle, when he says, "Mortify your members which are on earth fornication, uncleanness, luxury, evil concupiscence, and covetousness, which is idolatry".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2203
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2204
verses.text: It requires closer examination to see the meaning of the first action of Moses in burning the calf in fire, and grinding it to powder, and sprinkling it in the water for the people to drink.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2205
verses.text: The tables given to him, written with the finger of God, that is, by the agency of the Holy Spirit, he may have broken, because he judged the people unworthy of having them read to them; and he may have burned the calf, and ground it, and scattered it so as to be carried away by the water, in order to let nothing of it remain among the people.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2206
verses.text: But why should he have made them drink it? Every one must feel anxious to discover the typical significance of this action.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2207
verses.text: Pursuing the inquiry, we may find that in the calf there was an embodiment of the devil, as there is in men of all nations who have the devil as their head or leader in their impious rites.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2208
verses.text: The calf is gold, because there is a semblance of wisdom in the institution of idolatrous worship.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2209
verses.text: Of this the apostle says, "Knowing God, they glorified Him not as God, nor were thankful; but they became vain in their imaginations, and their foolish heart was darkened.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2210
verses.text: Professing themselves to be wise they became foolish, and changed the glory of the incorruptible God into the likeness of corruptible man, and of birds, and of four-footed beasts, and of creeping things".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2211
verses.text: From this so-called wisdom came the golden calf, which was one of the forms of idolatry among the chief men and professed sages of Egypt.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2212
verses.text: The calf, then, represents every body or society of Gentile idolaters.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2213
verses.text: This impious society the Lord Christ burns with that fire of which He says in the Gospel, "I am come to send fire on the earth;"  for, as there is nothing hid from His heat,  when the Gentiles believe in Him they lose the form of the devil in the fire of divine influence.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2214
verses.text: Then all the body is ground, that is, after the dissolution of the combination in the membership of iniquity comes humiliation under the word of truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2215
verses.text: Then the dust is sprinkled in the water, that the Israelites, that is, the preachers of the gospel, may in baptism admit those formerly idolaters into their own body, that is, the body of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2216
verses.text: To Peter, who was one of those Israelites, it was said of the Gentiles, "Kill, and eat".

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2217
verses.text: To kill and eat is much the same as to grind and drink.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2218
verses.text: So this calf, by the fire of zeal, and the keen penetration of the word, and the water of baptism, was swallowed up by the people, instead of their being swallowed up by it.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2219
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2220
verses.text: Thus, when the very passages on which the heretics found their objections to the Scriptures are studied and examined, the more obscure they are the more wonderful are the secrets which we discover in reply to our questions; so that the mouths of blasphemers are completely stopped, and the evidence of the truth so stifles them that they cannot even utter a sound.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2221
verses.text: The unhappy men who will not receive into their hearts the sweetness of the truth must feel its force as a gag in their mouths.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2222
verses.text: All those passages speak of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2223
verses.text: The head now ascended into heaven along with the body still suffering on earth is the full development of the whole purpose of the authors of Scripture, which is well called Sacred Scripture.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2224
verses.text: Every part of the narrative in the prophetical books should be viewed as having a figurative meaning, except what serves merely as a framework for the literal or figurative predictions of this king and of his people.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2225
verses.text: For as in harps and other musical instruments the musical sound does not come from all parts of the instrument, but from the strings, and the rest is only for fastening and stretching the strings so as to tune them, that when they are struck by the musician they may give a pleasant sound; so in these prophetical narratives the circumstances selected by the prophetic spirit either predict some future event, or if they have no voice of their own, they serve to connect together other significant utterances.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2226
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2227
verses.text: Should the heretics reject our exposition of those allegorical narratives, or even insist on understanding them only in a literal sense, to dispute about such a difference of understanding would be as useless as to dispute about a difference of taste.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2228
verses.text: Only, the fact that the divine precepts have either a moral and religious character or a prophetic meaning must be believed, whether intelligently or not.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2229
verses.text: Moreover, the figurative interpretations must all be in the interest of morality and religion.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2230
verses.text: So, if the Manich aeans or any others disagree with our interpretation, or differ from us in method or in any particular opinion, suffice it that the character of the fathers whom God commends for their conduct and obedience to His precepts is vindicated on a principle which all but those inveterate in their hostility will acknowledge to be true; and that the purity and dignity of the Scriptures are maintained in reference to those passages which the enemies of the truth find fault with, where certain actions are either praised or blamed, or merely narrated for us to form a judgment of them.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2231
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2232
verses.text: In fact, nothing could have been devised more likely to instruct and benefit the pious reader of sacred Scripture than that, besides describing praiseworthy characters as examples, and blameworthy characters as warnings, it should also narrate cases where good men have gone back and fallen into evil, whether they are restored to the right path or continue irreclaimable; and also where bad men have changed, and have attained to goodness, whether they persevere in it or relapse into evil; in order that the righteous may be not lifted up in the pride of security, nor the wicked hardened in despair of cure.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2233
verses.text: And even those passages in Scripture which contain no examples or warnings are either required for connection, so as to pass on to essential matters, or, from their very appearance of superfluity, indicate the presence of some secret symbolical meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2234
verses.text: For in the books we speak of, so far from there being a want or a scarcity of prophetical announcements, such announcements are numerous and distinct; and now that the fulfillment has actually taken place, the testimony thus borne to the divine authority of the books is irresistibly strong, so that it is mere madness to suppose that there can be any useless or unmeaning passages in books to which all classes of men and of minds do homage, and which themselves predict what we see thus actually coming to pass.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2235
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2236
verses.text: If, then, any one reading of the action of David, of which he repented when the Lord rebuked and threatened him, find in the narrative an encouragement to sin, is Scripture to be blamed for this? Is not the man's own guilt in proportion to the abuse which he makes for his own injury or destruction of what was written for his recovery and release? David is set forth as a great example of repentance, because men who fall into sin either proudly disregard the cure of repentance, or lose themselves in despair of obtaining salvation or of meriting pardon.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2237
verses.text: The example is for the benefit of the sick, not for the injury of those in health.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2238
verses.text: If madmen destroy themselves, or if evil-doers destroy others, with surgical instruments, it is not the fault of surgery.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2239
Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2240
verses.text: Even supposing that our fathers the patriarchs and prophets, of whose devout and religious habits so good a report is given in that Scripture which every one who knows it, and has not lost entirely the use of his reason, must admit to have been provided by God for the salvation of men, were as lustful and cruel as the Manich aeans falsely and fanatically allege, they might still be shown to be superior not only to those whom the Manich aeans call the Elect, but also to their god himself.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2241
verses.text: Is there in the licentious intercourse of man with woman anything so bad as the self-abasement of unclouded light by mixture with darkness? Here, is a man prompted by avarice and greed to pass off his wife as his sister and sell her to her lover; but worse still and more shocking, that one should disguise his own nature to gratify criminal passion, and submit gratuitously to pollution and degradation.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2242
verses.text: Why, even one who knowingly lies with his own daughters is not equally criminal with one who lets his members share in the defilement of all sensuality as gross as this, or grosser.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2243
verses.text: And is not the Manich aean god a partaker in the contamination of the most atrocious acts of uncleanness? Again, if it were true, as Faustus says, that Jacob went from one to another of his four wives, not desiring offspring, but resembling a he-goat in licentiousness, he would still not be sunk so low as your god, who must not only have shared in this degradation, from his being confined in the bodies of Jacob and his wives so as to be mixed up with all their movements, but also, in union with this very he-goat of Faustus' coarse comparison, must have endured all the pains of animal appetite, incurring fresh defilement at every step, as partaking in the passion of the male, the conception of the female, and the birth of the kid.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2244
verses.text: And, in the same way, supposing Judah to have been guilty not only of fornication, but of incest, a share in the heats and impurities of this incestuous passion would also belong to your god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2245
verses.text: David repented of his sin in loving the wife of another, and in ordering the death of her husband; but when will your god repent of giving up his members to the wanton passion of the male and female chiefs of the race of darkness, and of putting to death not the husband of his mistress, but his own children, whom he confines in the members of the very demons who were his own lovers? Even if David had not repented, nor been thus restored to righteousness, he would still have been better than your god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2246
verses.text: David may have been defiled by this one act, or to the extent to which one man is capable of such defilement; but your god suffers the pollution of his members in all such actions by whomsoever committed.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2247
verses.text: The prophet Hosea, too, is accused by Faustus: and, supposing him to have taken the harlot to wife because he had a criminal affection for her, if he is licentious and she a prostitute, their souls, according to your own assertion, are parts and members of your god and of his nature.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2248
verses.text: In plain language, the harlot herself must be your god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2249
verses.text: You cannot pretend that your god is not confined in the contaminated body, or that he is only present, while preserving entire the purity of his own nature; and you acknowledge that the members of your god are so defiled as to require a special purification.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2250
verses.text: This harlot, then, for whom you venture to find fault with the man of God, even if she had not been changed for the better by becoming a chaste wife, would still have been your god; at least you must admit her soul to have been a part, however small, of your god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2251
verses.text: But one single harlot is not so bad as your god, for he on account of his mixture with the race of darkness shares in every act of prostitution; and wherever such impurities are perpetrated, he goes through the corresponding experiences of abandonment, of release, and of confinement, and this from generation to generation, till this most corrupt part reaches its final state in the mass of darkness, like an irreclaimable harlot.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2252
verses.text: Such are the evils and such the shameful abominations which your god could not ward off from his members, and to which he was brought irresistibly by his merciless enemy; for only by the sacrifice of his own subjects, or rather his own parts, could he effect the destruction of his formidable assailant.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2253
verses.text: Surely, there was nothing so bad as this in killing an Egyptian so as to preserve uninjured a fellow-countryman.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2254
verses.text: Yet Faustus finds fault with this most absurdly, while with amazing infatuation he overlooks the case of his own god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2255
verses.text: Would it not have been better for him to have carried off the gold and silver vessels of the Egyptians, than to let his members be carried off by the race of darkness? And yet the worshippers of this unfortunate god find fault with the servant of our God for carrying on wars, in which he with his followers were always victorious, so that, under the leadership of Moses, the children of Israel carried captive their enemies, men and women, as your god would have done too, if he had been able.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2256
verses.text: You profess to accuse Moses of doing wrong, while in fact you envy his success.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2257
verses.text: There was no cruelty in punishing with the sword those who had sinned grievously against God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2258
verses.text: Indeed, Moses entreated pardon for this sin, even offering to bear himself in their stead the divine anger.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2259
verses.text: But even had he been cruel instead of compassionate, he would still have been better than your god.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2260
verses.text: For if any of his followers had been sent to break the force of the enemy and had been taken captive, he would never, if victorious, have condemned him when he had done no wrong, but acted in obedience to orders.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2261
verses.text: And yet this is what your god is to do with the part of himself which is to be fastened in the mass of darkness, because it obeyed orders, and advanced at the risk of its own life in defence of his kingdom against the body of the enemy.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2262
verses.text: But, says the Manich aean, this part, after mixture and combination with evil during the course of ages, has not been obedient.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2263
verses.text: But why? If the obedience was voluntary, the guilt is real, and the punishment just.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2264
verses.text: But from this it would follow that there is no nature opposed to sin; otherwise it would not sin voluntarily; and so the whole system of Manich aeism falls at once.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2265
verses.text: If, again, this part suffers from the power of this enemy against whom it was sent, and is subdued by a force it was unable to resist, the punishment is unjust, and flagrantly cruel.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2266
verses.text: The god who is defended on the plea of necessity is a fit object of worship to those who refuse to worship the one true God.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2267
verses.text: Still, it must be allowed that, however debasing the worship of this god may be, the worshippers are so far better than their deity, that they have an existence, while he is nothing more than a fabulous invention.

verses.name: Augustine: Reply to Faustus the Manichaean I 2:2268
verses.text: Proceed we now to the rest of Faustus' vagaries.
